headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Sales Fall At Ad Concern
abstract: World Business Briefing:

headline: Economy Slowed In 2nd Quarter, U.S. Report Says
abstract: The pace of economic growth slowed abruptly in the second quarter of the year as consumers forced to pay higher energy bills curbed their spending on just about everything else, the government reported yesterday.    The Commerce Department estimated that the nation's gross domestic product -- the broadest measure of economic activity -- expanded at an annual rate of 3 percent in the April-to-June quarter, sharply below the 4.5 percent growth achieved in the first quarter of the year and less than the expectations of Wall Street analysts.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: In-Flight Entertainment Fees
abstract: Ryanair plans to start charging about $9 for in-flight entertainment on five of its Boeing 737-800's based at Stansted Airport outside London in November; airline expects to make about 14 million euros ($17 million) per year from entertainment fees (S)

headline: EXELON RAISES EARNINGS TARGET FOR 2004
abstract: Exelon Corp, utility owner, raises its 2004 earnings target, citing cost-cutting and increased wholesale power prices (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Blair Warns Of Climate Threat
abstract: British Prime Minister Tony Blair, who is scheduled to assume leadership of Group of 8 industrialized countries next year, vows to make issue of global warming priority (S)

headline: EXPENSIVE ADVICE
abstract: Online auction for private lunch with billionaire investor Warren E Buffett raises $202,100 for Glide Foundation, San Francisco-based charity for homeless; winning bidder remains anonymous; can invite seven friends to dine with Buffett at Smith & Wollensky in Manhattan; restaurant donated $10,000 to foundation for right to be host for lunch (S)

headline: NASA Finally Gets Down To Business Side of Space
abstract: NASA exhibits for first time at Farnborough, Eng, International Air Show; associate administrator Craig E Steidle leads 50-member delegation to drum up global business partners to help NASA pursue its new missions to moon and Mars; Steidle says NASA wants to start dialogue with companies and industries; says NASA looks to industry for innovation and commercialization; calls on Japanese, Russian and European space agencies to join in; show is first stop on exhibit's worldwide tour (M)

headline: Senate Bill Aims at Makers of File-Sharing Software
abstract: Senate committee weighs Sen Orrin G Hatch bill aimed at makers of peer-to-peer Internet file-sharing software in bid to curb piracy of copyrighted materials; opponents say broad language will stifle innovation; fight has brought together some unusual alliances; months of haggling have yielded alternative drafts, but little in way of middle ground; bill, at its heart, is music and film industries' response to federal appeals court ruling in August that technology capable of legal uses cannot be held liable because most of its users deploy it to violate copyrights; file sharing graphs; photos (M)

headline: US AIRWAYS AND DISPATCHERS' UNION AGREE ON CONTRACT
abstract: US Airways Group reaches agreement with Transport Workers Union on cost-cutting contract for 151 flight dispatchers; pact provides savings of $4.5 million to company, including lower wages (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Chile: Record Copper Exports
abstract: Chile says exports of copper during second quarter rose to record on demand from expanding economies in US and China (S)

headline: CANTOR TO SPIN OFF PERSON-TO-PERSON BROKERAGE UNIT
abstract: Cantor Fitzgerald will split off its oringial business of person-to-person sales to focus on more profitable activities like institutional equity sales and trading; company will separate so-called voice brokerage business into partnership called BCG Partners (S)

headline: THREATS AND RESPONSES
abstract: Summary of terrorism-related stories on inside pages

headline: An Early Push on Fall Sales by Airlines
abstract: Aggressive and unusually early round of air fare sales for fall by low-cost carriers is threatening to wipe out any chance of profit for industry; JetBlue Airways and Southwest Airlines are have announced lower fares for autumn; period from Labor Day to Thanksgiving week is one of slowest of year for air travel, and industry is used to fare sales in that period, but they are rarely so sweeping, or announced so early, nor are they usually led by low-fare carriers rather than major carriers; chart (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Dying Surname
abstract: Seventy-three-year-old Briton Mike Pimbury, appearing on BBC, appeals for anyone with same surname to contact him; has no children and wants surname to live on (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Inflation Slows
abstract: Brazilian government reports 0.69 percent rise in consumer price index in August, bringing year-to-date inflation rate to 5.14 percent (S)

headline: Saudi Plan for Muslim Force in Iraq Gains in U.S.
abstract: Bush administration expresses interest in Saudi proposal to send all-Muslim security force to Iraq to help stabilize country and lend regional credibility to interim government in Baghdad; foreign policy experts voice skepticism that plan would result in substantial contributions of troops; five American allies have withdrawn their troops and some members of coalition, including Ukraine, are considering pulling out; terrorists in Iraq are increasingly using kidnapping and execution of foreigners as way to deter cooperation with Americans and interim government (M)

headline: Coming Soon: The Vanishing Work Force
abstract: Pittsburgh and southwestern Pennsylvania,, while seemingly flush with surplus workers, could face shortage of 125,000 workers, about tenth size of today's labor force, by 2012 because of declining and aging population; region's demographic issues seem precursor of problems across nation as fewer new workers will be available to replace aging baby boomers; shift is expected to continue intensifying, with people 55 and older making up 37 percent of population in 2030, up from 15 percent today; some companies are scrambling now to secure tomorrow's work force; others are lobbying for more immigration or outsourcing work abroad; experts say efforts are inadequate, given magnitude of coming demographic dislocation; say workers will probably be made to work longer; population graphs; photos (M)

headline: OWNER OF DALLAS MAVERICKS SELLS STAKE IN MAMMA.COM
abstract: Mark Cuban reports selling his 9.2 percent stake in Mamma.com Inc, Internet search service (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: A Forecast For Growth
abstract: Thailand's Prime Min Thaksin Shinawatra tells group of fund managers that his country's economy could grow 6 percent to 7 percent this year (S)

headline: On Iraq's Border, Sailors of the Desert Smuggle Subsidized Gasoline
abstract: Bahara, or sailors of desert, constantly crisscross Iraq's border with Jordan at Trebil; they specialize in form of petty smuggling that flourished under Saddam Hussein and continues briskly, making tidy profits by buying highly subsidized gasoline in Iraq and reselling it in Jordan at over 10 times cost; map (M)

headline: Univision Profit Up 63%
abstract: Uniivsion Communications Corp says second-quarter profit rose 63 percent because it sold more advertising; net income increased to $83.7 million, from $51.4 million year ago; revenue rose to $495.3 million, from $395.6 million (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago       Prime rate   4.25   4.25   4.25       Federal Funds   1.38   1.38   0.96       3-month Libor   1.60   1.61   1.11       3-month T-bills   1.22   1.28   0.83       6-month T-bills   1.63   1.64   0.92       10-yr. T-infl.   1.99   2.04   1.92       10-yr. T-note   4.56   4.58   3.66       30-yr. T-bond   5.29   5.29   4.69       Telephone bd.   6.60   6.60   5.74       Municipal bds.   5.18   5.19   4.76          (Sources by Bloomberg News; Telerate; The Bond Buyer; British Bankers' Assoc.)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Intercontinental Cuts Ties To 2 Travel Sites
abstract: InterContinental Hotels Group will no longer let Expedia.com and Hotels.com sell its rooms because online travel sites, owned by InterActiveCorp, do not meet its standards; Travelocity will now be InterContinental's main online travel agency; InterContinental pledged in April not to work with Web sites that do not show customers commissoins they charge and that fex bookings to hotels rather than automate their reservations (S)

headline: Omnicom Unit Resigns Schwab Account
abstract: GSD&M resigns creative and strategic account of Charles Schwab discount brokerage by deciding not to take part in review for assignment (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Car Sales Rise
abstract: Indian carmaker Maruti Udyog, majority owned by Suzuki Motor Corp of Japan, reports 9.8 percent increase in vehicle sales in June; domestic sales rose 24 percent, to 36,415 units, while exports fell 52 percent, to 3,159 units (S)

headline: China's Economy Offers Another Hint of Slowing
abstract: China's industrial output was 15.5 percent higher in July than year earlier; is fifth consecutive month of growth rate's inching lower, after hitting 23 percent in February; production rose fastest in those industries where China needs more output to relieve bottlenecks; with blackouts becoming national problem, Chinese power plants increased electricity output while coal mines and oil wells stepped up production; central bank warns inflation will continue to rise through third quarter, but predicts increases in consumer price index will weaken by end of year; vehicle output increased only 5.4 percent in July from year ago, while production of passenger cars in particular was only up by half a percent;

headline: Israeli Intelligence Faulted for Failure to Halt Hamas
abstract: Israeli intelligence came under careful criticism today for its failure to crack the cell that carried out two bombings.

headline: The Best Amenity Of a Hotel Stay
abstract: J Philip Zand letter on July 4 article on hotel ratings says he would gladly forgo any of qualities which contribute to ranking systems for assurance of not hearing conversations, noisy children or television broadcasts coming through walls of adjoining hotel room3

headline: Kicking Some Sand in the Face of Business
abstract: Reviews of some business books for summer reading; photo (M)0

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: 2 Policemen Dead In Ingushetia
abstract: New violence flares in Ingushetia as authorities continue to hunt for militants involved in raid that killed nearly 100 people last week; location of heaviest fighting suggests that some of those involved were local Ingush militants, and not Chechens as Russian officials first suggested (S)

headline: Mitsubishi Looks for Buyers and Its Niche
abstract: Executives at Mitsubishi Motors North America struggle to regain sales in US, where its market share has been halved in just a year; company has had to lay off 1,200 employees at factory in Normal, Ill, and cut its advertising; has suffered from a cover-up of defects in its cars and trucks for decades; Finbarr J O'Neill, chief executive, is using some of same strategies he used to lift sales at Hyundai in late 1990's; company is inviting consumers to re-enact tests shown in its advertising in which 2004 Galant midsize sedan outperforms Toyota Camry in high-speed crash avoidance and both Camry and Honda Accord in acceleration and breaking; photo; graph (M)

headline: CVS TO CLOSE 160 ECKERD STORES WITH LAGGING SALES
abstract: CVS Corp will close 160 Eckerd drugstores this year, about one-eighth of those acquired from J C Penney Co, to eliminate least profitable outlets; expects to complete converting 1,100 Eckerd stores to CVS sites by July (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Yukos Says It Will Cut Oil Shipments to China  The Russian oil giant Yukos said that it would immediately reduce some of its rail exports of crude oil to China. It appears to be the first time that Yukos's ability to transport oil has been affected by its tax dispute with the government, which has frozen most of its bank accounts.    An unnamed Yukos spokesman told Interfax, the government-controlled news agency: ''Yukos will resume its exports to China fully the moment it regains access to its accounts, frozen by the Justice Ministry. We hope that the Russian government correctly understands the great importance of Russian oil exports to the world market and will take measures to ensure uninterrupted supplies of oil to our Chinese partners.'' [Page C10.]

headline: Following the Leaders
abstract: Claude M Gruener letter on July 25 article on high costs of American automakers of meeting prospective standards to curb global warming; says it would have been nice if American companies had 'done the right thing' and led rather than followed trend of reducing emissions

headline: Marching Sideways Into the Second Half
abstract: Mutual fund performance in second quarter and and outlook for second half discussed; average general domestic stock fund eked out gain of just 0.7 percent, down from 3.3 percent in first quarter and 11.9 percent in 2003 fourth quarter; average bond fund lost 1.8 percent; photo (M)/

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Woolworths Bids For Liquor Group
abstract: Woolworths, Australia's leading supermarket chain, moves to increase liquor sales by bidding 969 million Australian dollars ($701.2 million) for Australian Leisure and Hospitality, country's largest listed pub and saloon group (S)

headline: After Months of Gains, U.S. Job Growth Slows Sharply in June
abstract: The Labor Department said only 112,000 jobs were created last month, far fewer than the 250,000 forecasters had expected.

headline: The New Miniature Computers (They Also Make Phone Calls)
abstract: Cellular telephone industry abandons quest for ever smaller phones in favor of bulkier handsets needed for large color screens and small versions of standard keyboards to send e-mail and instant messages; market for larger devices, previously limited to business travelers and technology enthusiasts, is expected to broaden as networks add digital audio and video entertainment and services to their offerings; photos (M)

headline: At Least 25 Dead After Violent Day in Baghdad
abstract: Suicide car bombings and a barrage of missile and mortar fire in several Baghdad neighborhoods left at least 25 Iraqis dead.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; After a Recall, Boston Scientific Tries to Assure Wary Investors
abstract: Boston Scientific says it is still leading market for drug-coated stents, despite its recall of some devices about 10 days ago; company tries to reassure investors that problem with device has been fixed, but some doctors say next few weeks will be critical to determining whether issue has been resolved; chief executive James R Tobin says company had blow-out quarter despite recall; photo (M)

headline: Ex-G.I., Charged in Kabul, Says He Was on U.S. Mission
abstract: Jonathan K Idema, former member of United States Special Forces, is charged in Kabul along with two other Americans with running their own vigilante war on terrorism; claims they were on secret mission approved by Pentagon at highest level, even as Afghan prosecutor claims men maintained under questioning that they had no connection with government; Idema claims to have e-mail messages and tape recordings to prove that he was in daily direct contact with Defense Sec Donald Rumsfeld's office; claims he had arrested and interrogated men while working directly with American and Afghan officials; American Embassy says Idema has no connection to any US government or military body; three men who say they were held prisoner by three Americans tell of being beaten and kicked and deprived of food; Americans charged with Idema are Edward Caraballo and Brent Bennett; photo (M)

headline: Fear of Betrayal
abstract: The Kurds suspect that Baghdad is trying to force them onto the sidelines, and are threatening to secede. They have apparently found an ally in Israel, of all countries.

headline: ENRON AGREES TO SELL GAS COMPRESSION UNIT TO PARAGON
abstract: Enron Corp sells its Enron Compression Services unit to Paragon ECS Holdings for $51.6 million; unit provides natural gas compression services to Florida Gas Transmission Co and to Transwestern Pipeline Co (S)

headline: Saber Seven
abstract: US bounty hunters are on trial in Kabul for the alleged torture of Afghan civilians. Did the Pentagon know that these weekend Rambos were on the hunt for terrorists?

headline: BOARD APPROVES NEWS CORPORATION'S MOVE TO U.S.
abstract: News Corp's board unanimously endorses company's plan to shift headquarters to US from Australia (S)

headline: Admitting Intelligence Flaws, Bush Stands by Need for War
abstract: Pres Bush, campaigning in Pennsylvania, acknowledges that prewar intelligence on Iraq was flawed, but defends his decision to go to war; reacts to Senate Intelligence Committee report criticizing intelligence agencies by asserting that Saddam Hussein had posed threat to US and other nations; photo (M)

headline: Peruvians Tire of Toledo, but Worry About Ousting Him
abstract: Pres Alejandro Toledo of Peru is embroiled in corruption scandal so debilitating that in recent survey, half of Peruvians polled believe he would not finish out remaining two years of his term; scandal involves accusations that he took $5 million bribe; his approval rating has been as low as 8 percent recently; his party lost its leadership of Congress, change that could give his adversaries more solid stage from which to remove him as president, as some in Congress have threatened; he has been plagued by series of personal scandals since taking office; major beneficiary of his troubles is Alan Garcia, runner-up in 2001 election, who now casts himself as remade reformer; during his presidency corruption reached new heights; photo (M)

headline: Attack targets hideouts in Falluja; 15 killed : French TV crews pull out (folo)
In Internet Calling, Skype Is Living Up to the Hype
abstract: James Fallows article on Skype,

headline: FORMER WORLDCOM OFFICERS SETTLE EMPLOYEE LAWSUIT
abstract: MCI, former WorldCom chief executive Bernard J Ebbers and 18 former WorldCom officers agree to pay about $51 million to settle suit by employees who lost billions of dollars when company collapsed; pact leaves Merrill Lynch Trust Co of America as only active defendant; WorldCom employees are seeking about $100 million from Merrill (S)

The Commerce Department estimated that the nation's gross domestic product -- the broadest measure of economic activity -- expanded at an annual rate of 3 percent in the April-to-June quarter, sharply below the 4.5 percent growth achieved in the first quarter of the year and less than the expectations of Wall Street analysts.

abstract: Senate committee weighs Sen Orrin G Hatch bill aimed at makers of peer-to-peer Internet file-sharing software in bid to curb piracy of copyrighted materials; opponents say broad language will stifle innovation; fight has brought together some unusual alliances; months of haggling have yielded alternative drafts, but little in way of middle ground; bill, at its heart, is music and film industries' response to federal appeals court ruling in August that technology capable of legal uses cannot be held liable because most of its users deploy it to violate copyrights; file sharing graphs; photos (M)

abstract: US Airways Group reaches agreement with Transport Workers Union on cost-cutting contract for 151 flight dispatchers; pact provides savings of $4.5 million to company, including lower wages (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Chile: Record Copper Exports
abstract: Chile says exports of copper during second quarter rose to record on demand from expanding economies in US and China (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: More Hospitals Took Children's Glands
abstract: Novo Nordisk, pharmaceutical company, reports that it received 2,500 pituitary glands from 32 hospitals around Ireland during 1980's that were removed from dead children without parental knowledge; parents' organization chairwoman Fionnuala O'Reilly comments (S)

headline: MediaTalk; Helping Parents Lock the TV Remote
abstract: Cox Communications is teaming up with John Walsh, children's advocate and host of America's Most Wanted, to teach parents how to protect their children from obscene and otherwise objectionable material on television (S)

headline: Figaro journalists vow independence
AFFILIATED MANAGERS TO BUY FREMONT INVESTMENT ASSETS
abstract: Affiliated Managers Group agrees to acquire $3 billion in assets from Fremont Investment Advisors Inc, firm under investigation for suspected improper trading of mutual funds (S)

headline: EU boom produces Brussels bloom
DREYER'S BUYS SILHOUETTE TO ADD LOW-FAT SNACKS
abstract: Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream Holdings Inc acquires Silhouette Brands Inc for about $70 million to add Skinny Cow low-fat and low-carbohydrate frozen snacks (S)

headline: 3 Americans Urge Dropping of Charges They Ran Afghan Jail
abstract: Lawyers for two of the defendants said today that they had asked the U.S. ambassador to request the Afghan authorities drop the charges.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Statue Vandal Caught
abstract: Police in Venice, Italy, say they caught vandal who destroyed arms of some of city's favorite statues; police say suspect is apparently deranged man; photo (S)

headline: Kia Narrows Search To Four Agencies
abstract: Kia Motors America in Irvine, Calif, part of the Hyundai Motor Co, narrows to four finalists a review for its creative ad account (S)

headline: Report Is Likely to Prompt Criminal Charges
abstract: Defense Dept report on abuses at Abu Ghraib prison is expected to give rise to criminal charges or disciplinary action against many of more than 50 people found responsible; report's most immediate impact will probably be in handful of pending cases against low-level military police personnel; lawyers for five who have not pleaded guilty say report's findings lend support to their central defense--that they were following orders from military intelligence officers and others (M)

headline: Brazil's Central Bank Raises Key Rates
abstract: Brazil's central bank raises its benchmark lending rate by quarter of percentage point to 16.25 percent, saying it hopes to rein in inflation without disrupting country's economic recovery (S)

headline: Closing Arguments Made In Suit Over Oracle's Bid
abstract: Lawyers present vastly different views of software market in closing arguments to Judge Vaughn R Walker in government's suit to block Oracle's proposed hostile takeover of PeopleSoft; Oracle characterizes market broadly, holding it competes with many companies despite widespread consolidation; Justice Department defines market narrowly, holding Oracle, PeopleSoft and SAP compete for largest customers (M)

headline: Contact With Campers
abstract: Sheila Feit letter notes that camps would not release videos of unhappy campers for parental viewing (July 29 article)

headline: In Estonia, e-commerce, e-banking, e-parking
Use Encryption to Protect Files
abstract: Basics column explores encryption techniques and software available to secure computer files; drawing (M)

headline: Bank of New York Reports Higher Quarterly Profits
abstract: Bank of New York Co says second-quarter profit rose 26 percent, to $371 million (S)

headline: Conan O'Brien to Replace Jay Leno in 2009
abstract: NBC announced today that Conan O'Brien will succeed Jay Leno as host of the "Tonight" show at the end of Mr. Leno's current five-year contract, in 2009.

headline: Kmart: Rich in Cash and Real Estate but Not in Sales
abstract: Constance Hays analysis of rise in Kmart stock price in view of fact that it is has been able to increase cash holdings to $2.6 billion while simultaneously losing ground on sales, which fell 15 percent in most recent quarter; photo (M)

headline: CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER STEPS DOWN AT KPMG
abstract: KPMG chief financial officer Richard Rosenthal resigns; deputy chairman Joseph Mauriello will become chief financial officer until successor is found (S)

headline: Turkey in EU? French wary
Out for V-I-C-T-O-R-Y, but Missing Tiles
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column on buying replacement pieces for board games on Internet; drawing (M)

headline: What Drives Consumer Confidence?
abstract: Outlook for consumer confidence and factors affecting it discussed; graph (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Peru: President Asks For An Audit
abstract: Peru's President Alejandro Toledo, who has been accused by former adviser Cesar Almeyda of taking $5 million bribe, calls for audit of his bank accounts and asks citizens to have faith in his leadership; presidential approval rating is at 8 percent; photo (S)

headline: Saks Seeking Riches in Yet Another Incarnation
abstract: Saks Fifth Avenue's new management plans to rip out much of $125 million renovation in its flagship store in Manhattan and spend $150 million more on even more striking remodeling of store; chief executive Fred Wilson says he intends to overhaul entire $2.6 billion chain, which includes 63 stores; is considering closing significant number of branches; adds changes are necessary to bring Saks 'back to its roots' as luxury emporium; photo (M)

headline: Unsure of Earnings, St. Paul Delays Report
abstract: St Paul Travelers Companies surprises investors by postponing its earnings announcement until Aug 9 while awaiting guidance from Securities and Exchange Commission on how to handle $1.6 billion write-off; one way of accounting for write-off would have resulted in profit of at least $775 million for second quarter; other would have resulted in loss of at least $275 million; photo (M)

headline: WELLS FARGO TO BUY FIRST COMMUNITY CAPITAL, A TEXAS BANK
abstract: Wells Fargo & Co pays $124 million in stock to buy First Community Capital Corp, banking company in Houston (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    Today  None    Tuesday  Housing Construction: August

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: U.N.'S Deadline Expires
abstract: United Nations Security Council resolution deadline for Sudan to disarm and prosecute government-backed militiamen expires; UN special envoy to Sudan Jan Pronk has left Khartoum and is scheduled to address council and report on progress by Sudan government; aid workers and African Union monitors hold there has been no improvement in Darfur Province (S)

headline: Lott Seeks Oversight Of Classified Data
abstract: Sen Trent Lott calls for independent commission to govern classified information; criticizes CIA's deletion of extensive sections of Senate Intelligence Committee's report on intelligence failures on Iraq; is working with Sen Ron Wyden on bill to establish commission (S)

headline: France Plans to Cut Phone Stake
abstract: French government accelerates its privatization effort, saying that it will sell as much as 12.1 percent of France Telecom, former state monopoly, and take its stake below symbolically important level of 50 percent; sale may raise as much as 5.75 billion euros ($7 billion) to help trim France's national debt; France will sell at least 236 million shares of France Telecom, or 9.6 percent, of company; state will retain 41 to 43.5 percent of company; Finance Min Nicolas Sarkozy comments; photo (M)

headline: Dutch Tell of a Spate of Threats From Islamists
abstract: Dutch officials who declared national security alert July 9 disclose arrests of at least five men suspected of planning terrorist attacks; says some had maps of targets such as nuclear power plant, Schiphol airport, Parliament, Defense Ministry and other public buildings; Dutch have had no attacks but Islamic militants are said to use country as convenient base and for recruitment (M)

headline: Bribery Inquiry Needs a Year, Its Chief Says
abstract: Paul A Volcker, who heads United Nations-appointed panel investigating charges of corruption in its oil-for-food program in Iraq, says he would need at least $30 million, staff of 60 and probably another year to determine whether UN officials took bribes or engaged in other corruption while administering program; vows that his would be 'definitive' inquiry into how program, United Nations' largest relief program,, was managed, or mismanaged (M)

headline: Life as Prologue to Fiction
abstract: Electronic Data Systems chairman and chief executive Michael H Jordan, in The Boss column, on some life experiences that led to him heading up Electronic Data Systems; photo (M)0

headline: Black & Decker Earnings Rise 61%
abstract: Black & Decker Corp, power tool maker, reports second-quarter net income surged 61 percent, to $121.8 million, from a year earlier; agrees to buy Pentair Inc's tools unit for $775 million (S)

headline: Relief Charities
abstract: List of organizations accepting donations to help Beslan, Russia, in aftermath of terrorist siege that left hundreds of people dead

headline: TECHTRONIC TO BUY 2 TOOL DIVISIONS FROM ATLAS COPCO
abstract: Techtronic Industries acquires Milwaukee Electric Tool Corp and Atlas Copco Electric Tools from Atlas Copco of Stockholm for $713 million (S)

headline: For a Hopeless Generation, A Rebel Militia Fills a Void
abstract: Muhammad Hussein, 19-year-old member of Moktada al-Sadr's Mahdi Army, was killed while firing on US and Iraqi forces in Sadr City; there is debate about effectiveness of fighters who make up Sadr's ragtag army; Hussein's story casts light on that question, as well as on new threat that he and other young, disaffected men like him pose to US presence and Iraq's interim government; photos (M)

headline: FAIRMONT HOTELS POSTS 28% DROP IN PROFIT
abstract: Fairmont Hotels and Resorts Inc says second-quarter earnings fell 28 percent from year ago; net income declined to $29 million from $40.1 million; revenue increased 21 percent, to $219.2 million from $181.9 million (S)

headline: Threat of Civil War Is Turning the Abkhaz Into Russians
abstract: Fear of renewed war between Georgia and break-away republic of Abkhazia is prompting Abkhaz people to apply for Russian citizenship under provision accepting citizens of former Soviet Union; Abkhazia expelled Georgian Army in 1992-93 civil war, but new Georgian Pres Mikhail Saakashvili has vowed to retake region; Abkaz Pres Vladislav Ardzinba is ill and not visibly in control of government; photos; map (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Pope Discusses Abuse Scandal With U.S. Bishops
abstract: Pope John Paul II meets with bishops from New England and urges leadership to reach out to clergy involved in widely publicized sex abuse scandal; Archbishop Sean P O'Malley of Boston attends meeting (S)

headline: Decorate a Couch With a Tourist
abstract: Casey Fenton and partners in CouchSurfing Project set up Web site, www.couchsurfing.com, which guides house guests to willing hosts around world; criteria described; drawing (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Youth Pleads Guilty In Blaster Worm Case
abstract: 19-year-old Minnesota resident Jeffrey Lee Parson, who was arrested last August for propagating version of Blaster computer worm, pleads guilty to charges of intentionally causing and trying to cause damage to protected computer; is scheduled to be sentenced Nov 12 (S)

headline: Globalist : In Ohio, small shifts that could hurt Bush
abstract: BOSTON  Zeba Khan, 23, missed her flight to the Democratic National Convention last week. Her father, a 62-year-old retired civil engineer, was detained for questioning at the airport in Toledo, Ohio. Perhaps his name, recognizably Muslim, was suspicious. Or the way he looked. Or something.

headline: Health Plans Cover Fewer While Costs Keep Rising
abstract: Experts say rising costs for health coverage and continuing fall-off in number of workers in employer-sponsored health plans are among reasons that greater number of people did not have health insurance last year; Census Bureau says increase in uninsured people last year was 1.4 million, to record 45 million; government officials say more than 10 million of those without insurance are young, 25 to 34 years old, increase of 576,000 from 2002; Sens Judd Gregg and Bill Frist and Len M Nichols, vice president of nonprofit Center for Studying Health System Change, comment; graph (M)

headline: Court Lets Settlement Stand In Microsoft Antitrust Case
abstract: Federal appeals court upholds antitrust settlement Microsoft reached with federal government in 2001; state of Massachusetts challenged settlement, seeking stronger sanctions against Microsoft; ruling removes legal cloud over company, freeing it up to use some of its more than $50 billion in cash to buy back shares or pay larger dividend (M)

headline: World Briefings
abstract: EUROPE.

headline: Banging the drum for German music
Chirac Takes a Practical Approach to U.S.-Franco Partnership
abstract: President Jacques Chirac praised the U.N. for restoring sovereignty to Iraq and portrayed France as a participant in the process.

headline: U.S. Attacks Rebel Base in Falluja; 20 Are Killed
abstract: U.S. warplanes made what the military called a precision strike on a meeting place of militants believed linked to Al Qaeda.

headline: A Young American Outsources Himself to India
abstract: Profile of Joshua Bornstein, 23-year-old American who quit his job at investment banking firm in Los Angeles to work for Infosys Technologies, one of India's software giants; notes that he is one of few Americans of his generation living in Bangalore; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Coup Case For Thatcher's Son
abstract: Legal representatives for Equatorial Guinea's government are reportedly seeking extradition of Mark Thatcher, former British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's son, from South Africa; hold he aided in unsuccessful plot to overthrown Equatorial Guinea's government; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Shipload Of Toxic Waste Sinks Off Coast
abstract: Turkey announces that Ulla, rusting cargo ship carrying 2,200 tons of toxic material from Spanish power plants, sank at Iskenderun (Turkey) port; Greenpeace contends that ship and cargo had been held in bay for considerable time as officials debated what to do with ship (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: Violence In South Ossetia
abstract: Flare-up of fighting in separatist South Ossetia (Georgia) kills three people; President Mikhail Saakashvili, who is dedicated to ending conflict in region, holds that outside influences are aggravating situation and government will exercise restraint (S)

headline: German state banks near deal
Method to Turn Off Bad Genes Is Set for Tests on Human Eyes
abstract: Medical researchers are harnessing naturally occurring phenomenon, RNA interference, to create treatments they hope will fight diseases by shutting down genetic process that prompts person's cells to produce disease-causing proteins; if medical trials are successful, they could potentially yield cornucopia of drugs designed to silence errant, disease-causing genes in body, or disarm invading virus by knocking out its genes; in first test, Dr Lawrence J Singerman is injecting RNAi, as it is known, into whites of eyes of half dozen elderly people who are at risk of blindness from age-related macular degeneration; while RNAi works well in laboratory, it may not work on humans; two other techniques once considered highly promising have not yielded any significant drugs despite years of effort; Singerman's experiment is sponsored by Acuity Pharmaceuticals, which received permission from Food and Drug Adm to conduct first human test of RNA interference; Sirna Therapeutics has appled to FDA for permission to begin trial of its own drug for macular degeneration; process described; diagrams (M)

headline: Hearing Confronts Insurers Who Market to Soldiers
abstract: Rep Richard H Baker, chairman of House subcommittee that is investigating sale of life insurance and mutual funds to young soldiers and other military members, unleashes scathing attack on financial companies active on military bases; challenges not only sales practices of their agents but also fundamental merits of their products; Specialist Brandon Conger testifies that he was misled into buying expensive insurance policy he did not want or understand; Baker's fiercest criticism falls on companies that package and sell high-commission products, including American Amicable Life Insurance Co and First Command Financial Services plan; photos (M)

headline: The Big Sale That May Never Be
abstract: DealBook column on whether Adelphia Communications' assets will be sold or whether Adelphia's chief executive William T Schleyer is going through motions of setting up auction to placate creditors; photos (M)

headline: Deal Preserves Hong Kong's Hub Status
abstract: Deal Preserves Hong Kong's Hub Sta8

headline: Budget Use of Pensions Sows Trouble in San Diego
abstract: San Diego is caught in financial bind, facing possibility of bankruptcy filing, largely because of $1.2 billion shortfall in its pension fund for municipal workers; report by Paul S Maco and Richard Carl Sauer calls city's practice of spending money from illusory pension fund earnings dangerous; practice is sanctioned by law in California and other places ans is commonplace among cities that offer pensions to their workers; at core of San Diego's problems is its use of pension fund earnings that exceeded projections to pay for variety of local projects, including expenses associated with playing host to 1996 Republican National Convention and paying health insurance premiums for retired teachers and firefighters; photo (M)

headline: Grand Pr Journal; Evangeline's People Gather and Weep for Ancestors' Fate
abstract: Tens of thousands of people from around world gather in Grand Pres, Nova Scotia, for two-week reunion to celebrate 400th anniversary of arrival in North America of their French ancestors, who settled colony of Acadie, and 250th anniversary next year of brutal deportation of 13,000 Acadians who would not pledge unconditional allegiance to British Crown; photos; map (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Rebuke To Iran
abstract: Canadian Foreign Affairs Minister Bill Graham recalls Canada's ambassador to Iran after government refuses Canadian observers right to attend trial of Iran intelligence agent accused of Canadian photojournalist Zahra Kazemi's murder while in police custody; Iranian officials says Kazemi died of brain hemorrhage after being beaten (S)

headline: Five U.S. Soldiers Are Killed in Iraq as Mortars Hit Base
abstract: Also, the abduction of a Filipino led the president of the Philippines to order citizens to stop traveling to Iraq in search of work.

headline: Mexican Cement Maker on Verge of a Deal
abstract: Cemex of Mexico, cement giant, nears deal to buy RMC Group of Britain for $4 billion; RMC, world's largest maker of ready-mix concrete, has been cutting costs and closing plants (S)

headline: A HealthSouth Trial Delay
abstract: Federal Judge Karen Bowdre postpones start of criminal trial of company's founder Richard M Scrushy from next week until Jan 5 (S)

headline: Captured Terrorists Hint At New Plan, Officials Say
abstract: Senior American intelligence officials say Al Qaeda members captured in recent weeks in Saudi Arabia, Pakistan and Afghanistan have provided important information about possible impending terrorist attack on scale of 9/11 attacks; say interrogations of Qaeda members have been major factor in raising American concerns; say Qaeda provided clues tracing planning for major attack back to group's central leadership, including Osama bin Laden, who is believed to be in Afghan-Pakistan border region; this is first time American officials have revealed source of information that has prompted them to issue warnings of future attacks (M)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Judy Barry was named vice president for marketing and business development at The Wall Street Journal, New York, published by Dow Jones & Company. She succeeds Jim Donoghue, now chief operating officer for financial information services at a sibling, Dow Jones Newswires. Ms. Barry had been a consultant and previously worked for publications including The Los Angeles Times and The Washington Post.

headline: Disney Says 2004 Earnings Are Closing In on Forecasts
abstract: Walt Disney Co says net income increased 20 percent, to $604 million, in its fiscal third quarter, compared to $502 million year earlier; revenue rose 17 percent, to $7.47 billion, from $6.37 billion; company says it is on track to meet analysts' expectations for year; chief executive Michael D Eisner and president Robert A Iger comment (M)

headline: Ex-Regulator Now at Riggs Is Called Focus of Inquiry
abstract: Justice Department is reportedly conducting ethics investigation of R Ashley Lee, executive vice president and chief risk officer at Riggs Bank, who was previously regulator at office of comptroller of currency with responsibility for monitoring money-laundering controls at Riggs; appears to focus largely on his involvement with account held at bank by Gen Augusto Pinochet, former Chilean dictator; Lee met with federal regulators several times after joining Riggs in 2002 to discuss compliance procedures, prompting some members of Senate investigations committee to say he may have violated federal ethics guidelines aimed at limiting conflicts of interest among former government employees; photo (M)

headline: VENTIV HEALTH AGREES TO PURCHASE SMITH HANLEY
abstract: Ventiv Health, which provides marketing and sales services to pharmaceutical companies, acquires Smith Hanley Corp for $50 million in cash and may pay more based upon profitability targets (S)

headline: To Our Readers
Realty Trust Plans a Shift in Its Market
abstract: United Dominion Realty Trust, one of nation's largest apartment owners, plans to announce $1.1 billion of acquisitions and disposals that will shift company's focus to Southern California; agrees to pay $897 million for 6,172 apartment units in four separate transactions; agrees to sell 3,515 apartments in Detroit, Louisville, Ky, and Phoenix for $174 million (M)

headline: When the Keyboard Won't Wait, an Instant Score
abstract: Pianist Mark Zeltser has created Web site that offers sheet music for more than 4,000 compositions for piano and violin; site plans to offer music for other instruments; photo (M)

headline: Moscow's Nuclear Past Is Breeding Perils Today
abstract: Radon, little known arm of Russian government charged with locating, retrieving and securing radiological waste, is working to undo consequences of an incautious time; under orders from Stalin, researchers working in totalitarian secrecy and with incomplete understanding of radiation's dangers built network of institutes and factories with little planning for dealing with discarded material; those sites left behind all manner of radiation-emitting waste; more than 1,200 orphaned sources have been retrieved in Moscow alone; much radioactive material was hastily dumped in forests that were outside city line; but as Moscow grew, it overtook its outskirts and sent down roots into illicit radioactive dumps; Radon began its work in 1961 after more than decade's worth of waste had been orphaned; work became more intensive after 1986 explosion at Chernobyl; Radon recovers and stores only low- and medium-level radioactive waste which are incapable of chain reaction leading to nuclear explosion but dangerous because of radiation emissions; health risks of these sources have not been conclusively establshed; photos; 1993 map showing sites contaminated by radioactive waste in Moscow (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: BP Expects Higher Profit
abstract: BP predicts higher second-quarter profit after raising production through TNK-BP, its joint venture in Russia with Tyumen Oil Co (S)

headline: Luxury Market Blooms Near Red Square; Designer Boutiques Rush In to Meet Demands of the Wealthy in Moscow
abstract: Moscow has become one of fastest growing luxury markets in world despite economic and political turmoil in Russia; Muscovites spend estimated $2 billion to $4 billion per year on luxury goods, surprisingly hefty amount, even when compared with $2 billion spent on high-end clothes and accessories in New York City; upscale retailers that have opened in Moscow include Burberry, Hermes, Christian Dior, Salvatore Ferragamo, Gucci, Bulgari, Ferrari and Rolls-Royce; photos (M)

headline: Target is putting its bull's-eyes on Times Square Tower.
abstract: Discount retailer Target is taking more than 23,000 square feet of ad space on nine signs on exterior of lower floors of skyscraper at 7 Times Square, also known as Times Square Tower; will pay $750,000 to $1 million in rent, in addition to production and maintenance expenses; photo (M)

headline: Eisner won't stay on as Disney's chairman
U.S. Economy Grew More Slowly Than Expected in 2nd Quarter
abstract: The economy grew at just 3 percent, as higher energy prices prompted consumers to slow their spending.

headline: Perelman Seeks Controlling Stake in Maker of Hummer
abstract: Ronald O Perelman is near deal to buy control of AM General, maker of Hummer sport utility vehicles and military Humvees, in complex deal worth more than $930 million; transaction will put Perelman in partnership with Ira L Rennert, who brought AM General out of bankruptcy for $133 million in 1992 and who will maintain stake in business after selling control to Perelman (M)

headline: Testimony On Asbestos Is Questioned
abstract: Johns Hopkins study raises significant questions over medical findings os some doctors acting as expert witnesses in asbestos liability lawsuits; independent panel of doctors reviewed 492 chest X-rays that had been submitted by plaintiffs' lawyers in asbestos lawsuits; doctors found that only small fraction indicated possible asbestos-related lung damage; finding is in stark contrast to conclusions of doctors who originally read X-rays after being retained by lawyers representing people who were claiming injury; those doctors found that 96 percent of X-rays showed possible damage; Dr Joseph N Gitlin, lead author of study, comments (M)

headline: Kenya Tells Citizens in Iraq To Go After 3 Are Abducted
abstract: Government of Kenya acknowledges that it is following in footsteps of Philippines, ordering all its citizens in Iraq to leave in effort to save lives of three Kenyan hostages threatened with execution by Iraqi insurgents; Secretary of State Colin L Powell says Kenya's response to threat will only encourage insurgents; says United States might work with other countries to establish 'code of conduct' for abductions in Iraq (M)

headline: Offer to Buy Into Yukos May Be Spurned
abstract: London consortium made up of Yukos shareholder Konstantin Kagalovsky, George Miller, businessman based in Kent, Eng, and small number of private investors offers to buy Yukos Oil's assets and pay company's taxes and debt, totaling $10 billion to $12 billion; Russian government gives strong indications of favoring ConocoPhillips as buyer for Russia's stake in Lukoil; Miller, in letter to Pres Vladimir V Putin, proposes buying portion of Yukos owned by Mikhail B Khodorkovsky, company's founder who has been in jail since October facing charges of fraud and embezzlement, and his partners in Group Menatep; consortium has received no answer to its proposal (M)

headline: Russian Oil Executive Enters Not Guilty Plea in Fraud Case
abstract: Mikhail B Khodorkovsky, Russia's richest man, pleads not guilty to charges of tax evasion, fraud and embezzlement; he asks court for one-day postponement of his opening statement; his arrest last Oct was one of most highly publicized cases in post-Soviet Russia; dual investigations of him and his oil company, Yukos, are widely seen as Kremlin-inspired campaign to part him from source of his wealth and punish him for his political ambitions (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Cognizant Posts 76% Earnings Rise
abstract: India-based Cognizant Technology Solutions Corp says second-quarter earnings surged 76 percent as sales soared; net income rose to $23.8 million from $13.5 million; revenue rose 59 percent, to $139 million, from $87.4 million (S)

headline: Some Storytellers Of 90's Innovation Plan Comebacks, However Modest
abstract: Magazines devoted to digital technology are back, even if far more modestly than in high-flying days of 1990's; will be using Web primarily, and magazines more sparingly, to reach both mass audience and advertisers who seek them; photos (M)

headline: The Next Shock: Not Oil, but Debt
abstract: Daniel Gross article warns America's heavy government, business and consumer reliance on debt makes economy vulnerable to interest rate rises; notes consumers and government have kept interest bill down by assuming greater interest-rate risk instead of locking in rates, making them more vulnerable to shocks; debt graph (M)

headline: Is That Dog Barking Up the Wrong Family Tree?
abstract: DNA testing is increasingly being used to verify bloodline claims in dogs; MMI Genomics, which started analzying tests for American Kennel Club in 1995, asserts that parental identification through DNA testing is 99.9 percent accurate; photo (M)

headline: 3 Palestinians Killed by Bomb That Explodes Prematurely
abstract: Three Palestinians are killed and more than dozen wounded in large explosion apparently set off by militants preparing bomb; blast occurs as Israeli army enters Rafah refugeecamp to find smuggling tunnels; photo from video in which Hamas warns that terrorists will continue rocket attacks against Sederot in Israel; separately, King Abdullah of Jordan criticizes Palestinian leadership for changing demands and calls for reforms (M)

headline: Medtronic Ordered to Pay Inventor
abstract: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services proposes broadening its Medicare coverage for implantable defibrillators, devices that electrically shock heart to restore normal heartbeat, to include patients suffering from mild to moderate heart failure; Medicare currently covers only patients who have survived sudden cardiac arrest; agency says change would raise total of potentially eligible patients by one-third, to about 500,000 (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Coup Suspects Admit Some Charges
abstract: Sixty-seven men who were arrested at Harare (Zimbabwe) airport last March and are suspected of involvement in failed coup attempt in Equatorial Guinea plead guilty to violating Zimbabwe's immigration and air-traffic laws, but stil face charges related to firearms possession (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Computer Associates Misses Forecast
abstract: Computer Associates International says revenue rose to $830 million to $850 million in quarter ended June 30, less than company's forecast of $865 million to $885 million; net income increased to 5 cents to 7 cents a share; company is trying to settle two-year inquiry by Justice Department and Securities and Exchange Commission into its accounting (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cablevision To Spin Off Unit In 4th Quarter
abstract: Cablevision Systems Corp delays spinoff of its Rainbow Media Enterprises division to fourth quarter as it awaits approval from Securities and Exchange Commission and own board (S)

headline: An Outsider's Grim Prognosis for Pension Agency
abstract: Independent study by Douglas J Elliott says Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp will go broke in 2020 if current conditions persist; agency is expected to run out of money by 2023 even if things improve; if agency goes broke, retirees who rely on it would stop getting their checks or taxpayers would have to bail agency out; photo (M)

headline: Want to Rent a Movie? Help Yourself
abstract: MoveibankUSA is entering already-crowded video rental market; movies can be rented through vending machines and reserved on company Web site; photo (M)

headline: Technology spawns basket of new fabrics
abstract: PARIS  In recent weeks a lot of Europe  both male and female, but especially male  has traded in fashion for nationalistic function in the guise of garish jerseys as they supported their native teams through the Euro 2004 soccer tournament.

headline: F.T.C. WITHDRAWS COMPLAINT AGAINST ARCH COAL DEAL
abstract: F.T.C. Withdraws Complaint Again

headline: Google Shares Just May Be Winners After All
abstract: Research analysts associated with five investment banks that managed Google's initial stock offering in August and forced it to lower offering price sharply release their first reports on company after required quiet period, valuing shares at more than 50 percent above offering price; stock price graph (M)

headline: North Korea Seen as Tying Nuclear Talks to U.S. Election
abstract: North Korea is waiting out the American presidential election in order to bargain with the winner over its nuclear weapons program, according to analysts here and a British diplomat who left Pyongyang today.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Industrial Output Rises
abstract: World Business Briefing

headline: Salaries Cut 10% at Delta in Bid to Remain Solvent
abstract: Delta Air Lines cuts pay of executives and other salaried workers by 10 percent and makes other changes aimed at avoiding bankruptcy; chief executive Gerald A Grinstein says he will not draw salary for rest of 2004; Delta's pilots approve plan meant to fend off potential staff shortages in wake of high number of early retirements among pilots; photo (M)

headline: CENDANT TO BUY RAMADA'S FOREIGN HOTELS AND NAME
abstract: Hotel franchiser Cendant acquires Ramada's overseas hotel business from Marriott International to gain full control of Ramada name (S)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: The American Advertising Federation, Washington, is expanding its Addy Awards program by creating a competition for college students. The Student Addy Awards, which will include a $1,000 prize for the top winner, will be presented along with the traditional Addy Awards during the federations annual conference.

headline: Google Says It's Set to End Stock Auction
abstract: Google might conclude bidding in its auction-style initial public offering late Aug 17, leaving it step away from becoming publicly traded company; formally asks Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to begin selling its shares after 4 pm; advisers investors on its Web sitge that stock's underwriters might accept auction bids as soom as 5 pm; request to SEC indicates company is moving ahead despite speculation that offering could be postponed (M)

headline: Flying on Two Small Wings and Your Choice of Prayer
abstract: Some business travelers discuss flying on small aircraft that was known in 1930's as 'puddle jumpers'; says puddle jumpers today are called general aviation and commuter aircraft and include turboprop planes that can seat 16 or more; photo (M)

headline: Europe Opens Another Inquiry Involving Microsoft
abstract: European Commission opens probe into planned acquisition of ContentGuard Holdings by Microsoft and Time Warner; ContentGuard specializes in software the protects digital material from counterfeiting; Microsoft uses ContentGuard technology under license inits development of rights management systems and services (M)

headline: A Deepening Debate on Soldiers and Their Insurers
abstract: Some life insurers and their agents charge that improper meddling by senior military officers is preventing young soldiers from getting supplemental insurance coverage before they head for Iraq and other dangerous assignments; cites five cases in which they say young soldiers dropped insurance on officer's advice and were later killed on duty; say thousands of other people in military are at risk of sharing same fate; insurers' complaints have led to investigation by Government Accountability Office; insurance industry says soldiers, not officers, should have final say on carrying additional insurance coverage; examination of cases cited by insurers shows that issue is not so simple and that insurance being sold to soldiers includes policies that provided little additional coverage at high prices; four of cases illustrate sales technique of selling military people expensive policy in tandem with low-cost policies; photo of Pvt Michael R Deuel, one of soldiers cited by insurers (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Illegal Airline Aid Estimated
abstract: European Commission says regional government in southern Belgium estimates it paid 4 million euros ($4.9 million) in illegal aid to Irish airline Ryanair; ordered regional government in February to recover illegal aid in move that it said was aimed at restoring fair competition in market; Ryanair received discounts for landing and service fees at Charleroi airport in southern Belgium (S)

headline: The Fears of the bin Laden Hunter
abstract: Under the seal of anonymity, an active US intelligence agent publishes a scathingly critical assessment of American anti-terrorism policy.

headline: Moscow Journal; As Russia Discovers Beer, Deputies Try to End the Binge
abstract: Demand for beer has surged in Russia, where per capita consumption has doubled by volume since 1998; many Russians consider beer little more than soft drink, but it is being blamed for youthful alcoholism, hooliganism and even political apathy; Russian lawmakers have approved bill that would restrict advertising and marketing of beer; photos (M)

headline: Competition Regulator Loses Spot on European Commission
abstract: Europe's c

headline: 70 Are Killed By Car Bomber In an Iraqi City
abstract: Suicide car bomber kills as many as 70 people in Baquba, Iraq; attack apparently aimed at new police recruits also kills scores of ordinary Iraqis; attack is deadliest since Iraqis took back formal sovereignty from American occupation on June 28; violence flares elsewhere around country; at least 35 insurgents and 7 Iraqi soldiers are killed in joint raid by Iraqi and foreign troops south of Baghdad; in Ramadi, insurgents attack several American bases, possibly hitting two United States aircraft and killing two American soldiers; two other American soldiers are also reported killed, one by another car bomb and other by roadside bomb; insurgents have beeen directing scores of attacks, kidnappings and assassinations against new interim government, which they view as illegitimate; scale of latest bombing may reflect insurgents' willingness to attack Iraqis with same ferocity as they have Americans, and may force Prime Min Ayad Allawi into stiffer and more concrete action against them; Al Jazeera television reports that militant group holding two Pakistani contractors claims it killed them; photos; map (M)

headline: For Frugal Drivers Who Want to Talk, Headsets at a Discount
abstract: FreeHeadset.org distributes discounted hands-free cellphone devices; photo (S)

headline: PEPSICO WINS BEVERAGE CONTRACT FROM QUIZNOS
abstract: PepsiCo Inc, which lost Subway Restaurants as major fountain customer last year to Coca-Cola, wins US beverage and snack business of Quiznos Corp; agreement will end sandwich chain's 23-year relationship with Coke (S)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Arab Appeal To U.N.
abstract: Arab states, concerned over Israel's construction of West Bank barrier in violation of International Court of Justice ruling, call for emergency United Nations General Assembly session (S)

headline: Fed Increases Interest Rates Quarter-Point
abstract: Federal Reserve raises federal funds rate target by 25 basis points, to 1.5 percent; strongly implies it will keep raising short-term interest rates modestly but regularly in months ahead; says economic growth has slowed, but that economy seems poised to resume stronger growth; stock prices rise on forecast; photo (M)

headline: S.E.C. SAYS BERKSHIRE MUST REVEAL A STOCKHOLDING
abstract: Berkshire Hathaway Inc is denied permission by Securities and Exchange Commission to conceal a stockholding; Berkshire files such requests to prevent copycat investing (S)

headline: Chrysler, With a Profit, Lifts Quarter For Daimler
abstract: Earnings at DaimlerChrysler soar more than fivefold in second quarter, to $675 million, lifted by continuing recovery of company's Chrysler unit as well as strong performances in its financial services and commercial vehicle divisions; revenue rises 9 percent, to $45.2 billion; Mercedes group, Daimler's crown jewel, reports decline in operating profits, and struggles of Mitsubishi Motors reduces Daimler's earnings by $600 million in quarter; Eckhard Cordes, head of commercial vehicles group, will take over Mercedes group in October; photo (M)

headline: Intelligence estimate from July is bleaker than Bush's tone : U.S. study has a dark forecast for Iraq
Copter-Borne Medics: Disciplined Ballet, Choreographed to Save G.I.'s
abstract: Army's 45th Medical Company is one of four airborne medical evacuation units supporting 130,000 American troops in Iraq; dog days of Aug end abruptly for unit after fighting renews in Najaf and in Sadr City; flying medevac missions is intensely hazardous undertaking in Iraq; unarmed Black Hawk air ambulances frequently come under ground fire; one mission described; photos (M)

headline: RENT-A-CENTER CUTS PROFIT FORECAST; SHARES FALL
abstract: Rent-A-Center Inc cuts its forecast for profit in third quarter, setting off 14 percent decline in its share price; also reduces its 2004 profit outlook (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Greece And Turkey Cancel Military Exercises On Cyprus
abstract: Both Greece and Turkey agree to cancel all military exercises on Cyprus in show of support for political resolution for divided island (S)

headline: Buckingham Palace's New Tourist Attraction: Batman
abstract: Member of group advocating greater rights for fathers in child custody cases, dressed as Batman, scampers up ladder to ledge near queen's balcony at Buckingham Palace, setting off security alert and tense standoff with police; Queen Elizabeth II and family members are said to be at Balmoral Castle on vacation; intruder Jason Hatch unfurls banner calling for fathers' rights, and waves at befuddled crowds of tourists below; finally removes Batman mask and agrees to come down after five and half hours; breach raises questions about state of security for royal family and Britain's other government institutions at time when British intelligence services are warning that London is prime target for Al Qaeda and affiliated groups; photo (M)

headline: 3 Weeks After Hurricane, Grenada's Life Is Still in Ruins
abstract: Hurricane Ivan was one of most powerful storms to hit Caribbean and United States in decades, and no island suffered more damage than Grenada; at least 39 people were killed and tops of most buildings were ripped off by winds; looting broke out after storm hit, and, to complicae security, warden of island's only prison let all inmates out during storm; photo of ruins of church totally destroyed by hurricane; map (M)

headline: In Climax to a Tumultuous 4-Day Debate, Iraq Chooses an Assembly
abstract: Political conference in Baghdad selects national assembly after four marathon days of back-room bargaining and strident debate; this puts Iraq on road to becoming constitutional democracy in jumbled process that never included formal vote; result is list of names to fill 100-seat assemly that will act as parliament, overseeing interim government of Prime Min Ayad Allawi until elections slated for Jan; body will represent broad cross section of Iraqi society; photo (M)

headline: Four Palestinians Reportedly Killed While Planting Bomb
abstract: Israeli soldiers shot four Palestinian militants who were spotted trying to plant a bomb alongside a border road between the central Gaza Strip and Israel.

headline: With Interest : Turning the tables on reform
World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Bank Stake Sold
abstract: Spain's Banco Santander Central Hispano sells about half of its stake in Royal Bank of Scotland, or 79 million shares, raising $1.49 billion (S)

headline: Italian Aid Workers and 2 Iraqis Kidnapped
abstract: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 7  Armed men seized two Italian aid workers and two Iraqis in their offices here today in the most brazen kidnapping in months.

headline: Sikh Group Finds Calling in Homeland Security
abstract: One of nation's fastest-growing security companies in wake of 9/11 terror attacks is Akal Security, wholly owned by Sikh Dharma, religious compound in New Mexico; Akal has 12,000 employees and $1 billion in contracts to protect vital and sensitive government sites, from military installations to federal courts to airports and water supply systems; Sikh Dharma members say they are following ancient Sikh tradition of warrior-saint; it is thought to be only security company owned by nonprofit religious organization; it has been generous campaign contributor to both Democratic and Republican candidates at federal level; sect official Mukta Kaur Khalsa has met with Pres Bush in White House and in New Mexico; photo; chart (M)

headline: France Condemns Anti-Semitic Attack
abstract: French politicians condemn anti-Semitic attack against young woman and her baby on commuter train near Paris, latest in string of such incidents in France; Pres Jacques Chirac says everything possible is being done to find six young men accused of cutting woman's clothing and drawing swastikas on her stomach, then overturning stroller carrying her baby (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Reserve Bank Signs Loan Pact
abstract: South Africa's central bank signs accord for $1 billion syndicated loan invovling 39 banks to refinance $1.5 billion loan maturing in July; says loan might help bolster nation's credit rating (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Antitrust Nominee Sells Shares
abstract: Neelie Kroes, set to become European Union's top antitrust regulator, says she has sold all her shares and put assets in trust, removing potential conflicts of interest; photo (S)

headline: NAVY CONTRACTS LIFT PROFIT AT NORTHROP GRUMMAN
abstract: Northrop Grumman Corp's second-quarter profit rises 44 percent, to $295 million; sales climb 11 percent, to $7.37 billion (S)

headline: Pressure Builds In Kremlin Vs. Oil Giant
abstract: Russian authorities appear to be winning their battle with Yukos founder Mikhail B Khodorkovsky; Khodorkovsky is in prison awaiting resumption of his trial July 12; faces 10 years in prison on criminal charges of fraud, embezzlement and tax evasion related to his creation of Yukos; Yukos receives its first notice from group of Western creditors that it is in danger of default; Yukos says default warning pushes it closer to insolvency; credit syndicate, led by Societe Generale, has sent notice of debt $1 billion; July 7 is deadline for payment of Yukos's $3.4 billion back tax bill, which company contends is illegal and part of wider political campaign to break Khodorkovsky; Khodorkovsky has denied all charges and has said only options are settlement with government or bankruptcy; Khodorkovsky could win larger point even if he were to lose his 44 percent share of Yukos, forcing government to concede that property rights in Russia exist only at whim of state and that direction of Russia's economy is moving toward government-controlled model rather than free-market model (M)

headline: Magazine Advertising Continues Recovery
abstract: Publishers Information Bureau reports magazine ad pages rose 3.1 percent in June from June 2003, continuing rebound that began in May after nearly year of declines (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Parmalat Debt Plan Approved
abstract: Italian government approves Parmalat's proposal to swap billions of euros of debt for shares as part of turnaround plan that would give most bondholders little more than 10 percent of their investment (S)
