abstract: Update of situation in Iraq (S)

headline: Staples Names Agency For Television Account
abstract: Staples names McCann-Erickson Worldwide as ad agency of record for its TV account, which had been handled by Martin/Williams; spending estimated at $60 million to $70 million (S)

headline: SALADS HELP MCDONALD'S INCREASE PROFITS 25%
abstract: McDonald's Corp says second-quarter profit rose 25 percent; net income rose to $590.7 million from $470.9 million year ago; sales climbed 10 percent to $4.73 billion (S)

headline: CAMPAIGN 2004: As debate nears, Bush keeps lead over Kerry
Citing Threats, Entrepreneur Wants to Quit Caller ID Venture
abstract: Jason Jepson, three days after starting Star38, decides to sell business; service enables customers, for fee, to alter phone number that appears on caller ID phone screen; says he has received hundreds of harassing e-mail and phone messages and death threat taped to his front door, apparently from people opposed to his publicizing commercial version of technology that until now has been mainly used by software programmers and computer hackers' underground; photo (M)

headline: AMERICAN SEAFOODS LOWERS PRICE ON SECURITY OFFERING
abstract: American Seafoods Corp cuts price of its initial public offering of new hybrid security by about 20 percent, as demand for new stock declines; plans to raise up to $430.3 million by selling 30.7 million income deposit securities at $13.50 to $14 each (S)

headline: Russia Moves to Sell Crown Jewel of Yukos
abstract: Observers say the sale would kick a key foundation out from under one of the country's largest oil companies.

headline: Top Honors Taken By Miami Agency
abstract: Crispin Porter & Bogusky takes top honors, winning best in show at Athena Awards competition sponsored by Newspaper Association of America (S)

headline: For Some Beta Testers, It's About Buzz, Not Bugs
abstract: Beta testing of new products has become marketing tool for companies and status symbol for testers, as evidenced by enthusiasm of people wanting to beta-test Gmail from Google; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Qualcomm Announces Stock Split
abstract: Qualcomm Inc declares two-for-one stock split and increases its quarterly dividend to 7 cents from 5 cents on post-split basis (S)

headline: TV Rating Companies To Form Joint Venture
abstract: Nielsen Media Research International, Haarlem, Netherlands, part of Nielsen Media Research division of VNU, and AGB Group, part of Kantar division of WPP Group, will form joint venture to offer ratings in 30 countries outside US; venture will be called AGB Nielsen Media Research; Alberto Colussi and Rolando Stalli are named to lead AGB Nielsen (S)

headline: ON ADVERTISING : Marketing's great leap in China
Loss widens 33% on cost overruns at Capgemini
Rightists Make Strong Strides in Eastern German State Elections
abstract: Far-right parties make their strongest showing in six years in German state elections, as voters react against Chancellor Gerhard Schroder's governing party after sharp cutbacks in welfare benefits; voters in eastern German states of Saxony and Brandenburg show strong support for parties that attribute much of country's ills to foreigners and that favor closing off borders (M)

headline: French Socialist links vote on EU constitution to loss of jobs
A New Way to DescribeComputer Muscle Power
abstract: Q. The way computer processor speed is listed has changed, but what does it all mean? How can I find out how fast the chip is supposed to be if the gigahertz speed is not listed?    A. The computer's processor, also known as a microprocessor or central processing unit, is the brain of the machine; it sends information to other parts of the system. The processor's clock speed -- the rate of the chip's internal clock, dictating how fast it can chew through its computing tasks -- has been one of the main ways to describe the computer's overall power.     But earlier this year Intel, the maker of Pentium and Celeron processors, announced that it was changing the way it labeled its processors for desktop and laptop computers. In an attempt to describe more elements of a processor than just the clock speed, Intel will factor in variables including the design of the processor (known as the architecture) and the size of the chip's temporary memory storage area (known as the cache).

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction: Aug 22 article on Bush administration's ties to Wall Street misstated former occupation of Treasury Sec John W Snow; he headed railroad company, not steel company

headline: Your Shot, He Said, Distantly
abstract: As online applications grow, phenomenon of pervasive connections--shared space where people can interact online--is widening and deepening; athletes often link to compete and share tips in various sports; photos (M)

headline: Martin Agency to Help AOL With Branding
abstract: America Online names Martin Agency to create fall campaign intended to help burnish AOL brand image among businesses and investors; spending has not been determined (S)

headline: State Dept. Official Arrested in Inquiry on Taiwan Contact
abstract: Career Foreign Service officer Donald W Keyser, who is suspected of improperly passing documents to Taiwanese intelligence agents, is arrested and charged with concealing trip to Taiwan; Keyser was until recently top advisor on China to Secretary of State Colin L Powell; he resigned abruptly several weeks ago when he found he was under investigation; he allegedly met with Taiwanese intelligence agent in Tapei, and failed to disclose meeting as required; in subsequent FBI surveillance operation, he was seen meeting with two Taiwanese agents in series of covert meetings around Washington, and handing Taiwanese what appeared to be government material; because United States does not have diplomatic relations with Taiwan, it is rare for diplomats to travel there, especially in any official capacity, without special permission (M)

headline: F.D.A. MAY SUSPEND WORK AT STAAR SURGICAL PLANT
abstract: Staar Surgical Co, which makes devices used in eye surgery, says Food and Drug Administration might suspend operations at its Monrovia, Calif, plant because of flaws in company's surgically implanted contact lens; says it has taken corrective actions aimed at resolving FDA's concerns; Staar stock plunges (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Grocer Trims Outlook
abstract: William Morrison Supermarkets warns of lower-than-expected profits, citing falling sales at recently acquired Safeway supermarkets; stock price graph (S)

headline: After Months Of Hoopla, Google Debut Fits the Norm
abstract: Price of Google shares rises 18 percent in first day of trading, to just above $100, which is about where it would have landed if this had been typical IPO rather than Dutch auction chosen by company's founders; closing price gives company market valuation of more than $27 billion; shares are bought, sold and flipped during day, disappointing founders' hope that unorthodox offering would attract bidders who would buy its stock as long-term investment; there now appears to have been little substance to idea that Google was bucking Wall Street's establishment by seriously undercutting fees investment bankers typically receive in taking companies public; company is paying its bankers fee of 2.8 percent of $1.67 billion raised in auction, which is said to be comparable to fees charged in other deals of this size; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Victims' Center Raided
abstract: Egypt's Health Ministry raids El Nadim Center for the Psychological Rehabilitation of Victims of Violence medical center; human rights workers say raid is part of crackdown on agencies documenting police abuse (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Strike At Copper Mine
abstract: About 4,000 workers strike at copper mine and refinery at La Caridad, seeking profit sharing, overtime pay, promotions and safety enhancements; mine owner Grupo Mexico expects authorities to declare strike illegal (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Bank Rules Tightened
abstract: Thailand's central bank tightens rules on how much cash commercial banks must set aside against delinquent loans (S)

headline: Speculators Place Bets on Oil, Roiling Fickle Energy Market
abstract: Oil prices reach another record high, and then fall by more than dollar per barrel, as turbulent markets react to new promises of greater production; crude oil for September delivery briefly trades as high as $44.34 per barrel, then plunges to $43.99 at close of floor trading in New York; contract settles at $42.83 per barrel at end of day; Energy Department releases figures showing gasoline inventories grew by 2.4 million barrels, to 210.1 million; Saudi Arabia says it will start pumping crude oil from new fields three months ahead of schedule and that it will delay closing of some wells; graph; photos (M)

headline: 2,000 Return Home After Israel Opens Border Crossing
abstract: Israel opens border crossing between Gaza Strip and Egypt that has been closed for nearly three weeks, allowing most of over 2,000 stranded Palestinians to return home; Israel closed Rafah crossing on July 18, saying it believed that Palestinians were planning to attack site; photo (M)

headline: WESTINGHOUSE AIR BRAKE INCOME RISES 62% IN QUARTER
abstract: We

headline: Gay Pair Seeks Canada's First Same-Sex Divorce
abstract: Two Toronto women who were among first same-sex couples to marry in Canada are now seeking what may be first Canadian same-sex divorce; couple had been together for nearly 10 years, but separated after five days of marriage; women are seeking to change Canada's divorce law, which still applies only to marriages between man and woman (M)

headline: Seiko Increases Forecast
abstract: Seiko Epson Corp raises by third its forecast for net profit for year ending March 31, 2005 (S)

headline: Private Company Finds No Evidence Its Interrogators Took Part in Prison Abuse
abstract: CACI International Inc, company that supplies civilian interrogators to American military in Iraq, says its own investigation and information supplied by Army has produced no 'credible or tangible evidence' so far that its employees were involved in abuse of prisoners at Abu Ghraib and elsewhere in Iraq; says it is cooperating with government investigations of abuses and is continuing to conduct its own probe; company recently announced that its contract to provide interrogation services in Iraq has been extended by Army for four months at value of $15.3 million, with optional extensions; lawyer for Steven Stefanowicz, CACI employee under scrutiny since report issued by Maj Gen Antonio M Taguba, says his client is 'heartened' by company's statement that it found 'no wrongdoing' by him (M)

headline: MELLON FINANCIAL PLANS GROWTH IN SOUTHWESTERN U.S.
abstract: Mellon Financial, which runs Dreyfus mutual funds, acquires Paragon Asset Management Co to expand its wealth management business in Las Vegas (S)

headline: Employee Suit Accuses Kodak of Race Discrimination
abstract: Group of past and current employees of Eastman Kodak sues company, accusing it of discriminating against black workers; employees contend that Kodak has for more than decade paid black employees less than their white counterparts, promoted them less often and retaliated against those who complained; suit also contends Kodak allowed harassment to continue in several divisions and gives numerous examples of racial epithets and slurs that it says continue to be directed at black employees; suit, which is seeking unspecified monetary damages, comes after breakdown of several months of settlement talks between Kodak and plaintiffs' lawyers; talks began in February, when Buffalo office of Equal Employment Opportunity Commission concluded four-and-a-half year probe with written determination that company was engaging in discrimatory practices (M)

headline: EU ready to approve Alitalia's rescue plan
Halliburton Settles S.E.C. Accusations
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission says Halliburton Co secretly changed its accounting practices when Vice Pres Dick Cheney was its chief executive; fines company $7.5 million and brings actions against former financial officials Robert Muchmore Jr and Gary V Morris; says accounting change enabled Halliburton to report annual earnings in 1998 that were 46 percent higher than they would have been had change not been made; also allowed company to report substantially higher profit in 1999; commission does not say Cheney acted improperly, and papers released by commission do not detail extent to which he was aware of change or of requirement to disclose it to investors; Cheney's lawyer Terrence O'Donnell says Cheney's conduct as chief executive officer of Halliburton was proper in all respects (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    TODAY  None    TOMORROW  Consumer Price Index -- July  Housing Construction -- July  Industrial Production -- July

headline: Violence Flares Again in 2 Separatist Regions of Georgia
abstract: Tensions flare anew in Georgia; new violence is reported in separatist South Ossetia one day after Pres Mikhail Saakashvili threatens to sink ships approaching other break-away region Abkhazia; threat includes ships ferrying Russian passengers; Russia warns that it would view such action as piracy; there are no immediate reports of casualties in latest flare-ups, but clashes, threats and counterthreats underscore growing tensions in and around Georgia as Saakashvili's new government continues its efforts to assert sovereignty over two regions; photo; map (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Tribute To The Head Of State
abstract: Pskov Newswire, local news agency in Pskov (Russia), which is near Estonian-Russian border, reports that citizens group has erected monument of President Vladimir V Putin; group, which opposes local governor, does not have permit to erect monument so official announcement has not been made (S)

headline: Pair of Car Bombs in Iraq Kill Dozens, Including Many Children
abstract: The car bombs tore through a street celebration at the opening of a new government-built sewer plant in Baghdad.

headline: I.M.F. Delays $728 Million for Argentina
abstract: International Monetary Fund delays $728 million loan payment to Argentina to assess government's progress in debt restructuring talks and in raising utility rates (S)

headline: Former Chief of Royal Ahold Facing Charges
abstract: Former Royal Ahold chief executive Cees van der Hoeven says he faces charges in connection with $1.2 billion accounting scandal at company (M)

headline: Militants' Blast Kills 2 Palestinians by Israel Checkpoint
abstract: Palestinian bomber detonates explosives 200 yards from busy checkpoint at northern edge of Jerusalem, killing two Palestinian passers-by and wounding 20 other people, including 6 Israeli border police officers; Israeli officials say they had hard intelligence about impending bombing and were on high alert; note explosion occurred when Israeli soldiers approached suspicious car; last attack inside Israel was on July 11 in Tel Aviv, when bomb killed Israeli soldier and wounded five others; photo; map (M)

headline: Indonesians Prepare to Vote on Monday
abstract: JAKARTA, Indonesia July 4  As Indonesians prepare to vote on Monday in the first direct presidential elections since the fall of the Suharto regime, the biggest question is whether the front-runner, a former general, can muster the more than 50 percent of the vote he will need to avoid a runoff.

headline: More Disarray In Yukos Case As the Judge Withdraws
abstract: Judge Olga Mikhailova, citing psychological pressure from intense news coverage, removes herself from hearing Yukos Oil suit challenging Russian government's claim that Yukos owes about $3.4 billion in back taxes for 2000; new Yukos chairman Viktor Gerashchenko reacts angrily to call by Yukos founder Mikhail B Khodorkovsky for his dismissal for failing to broker deal with government quickly; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Graph tracks crude oil prices since March 2003

headline: Shares Drop on Weak Employment Report
abstract: Stocks fall sharply, setting new lows for year, after surprisingly weak July jobs report heightens concerns about slowdown in economic growth; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index drops 16.73 points, or 1.6 percent, to 1,063.97; Nasdaq composite index declines 44.74 points, or 2.5 percent, to 1,776.89; Dow Jones industrial average declines 147.70 points, or 1.5 percent, to 9,815.33; price of US Treasury's 10-year note rises 1 13/32, to 104 7/32; yield plunges to 4.22 percent from 4.39 percent; US dollar drops 1.8 percent against euro, leaving one euro worth $1.2277, and 1.2 percent against Japanese yen, to 110.36; graph; charts; photo (M)

headline: Right-to-Roam Laws Let British Walk Over Class Lines
abstract: Thousands of ramblers gather in England's hills, fields, moors and downs to mark first mass opening of private land to public access in decades; opening of 375 square miles of private land offers quiet counterpoint to fraught relationship between town and country that underpins fox hunting legislation; two issues, hunting and walking, are not formally linked; but both evoke class distinctions that permeate British society; photo; map (M)

headline: F.D.A. FAULTS SANOFI-AVENTIS ON VACCINE TESTING
abstract: Food and Drug Administration says French drug maker Sanofi-Aventis failed to conduct required follow-up tests to ensure that vaccines produced at Lyon, France, plant were uncontaminated; also says Sanofi-Aventis did not follow up on defects in Thymoglobulin batches, Genzyme Corp's treatment to prevent kidney transplant rejection (S)

headline: ONLINE DIARY
abstract: Pamela LiCalzi O'Connell Online Diary column; Web site offers help for songwriters who want to create 'critic-friendly music'; allreaders.com helps users select novel based on setting; other book sites noted; National Weather Service Web site was designed for educators and emergency officials but has attracted users who just want to know more about weather; drawings (M)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: The Aegis Group, London, raised its forecasts for worldwide advertising spending in 2004 and 2005, citing growth in markets like Asia, Europe and the United States. Aegis now calls for a gain this year of 5.7 percent from 2003, compared with a forecast in March for a gain of 5.3 percent. For next year, Aegis predicts an increase of 5 percent from 2004, compared with a previous estimate of 4.4 percent.

headline: A Classic Pad Goes Digital, But Is It Shakable?
abstract: Ohio Art Company introduces new ETO, which is like old-fashioned Etch A Sketch for TV screen, but has upgraded features; photo (S)

headline: Coffee, Tea or Job? For Airline Workers, an Uncertain Future
abstract: Airline industry is split between carriers that created attractive jobs but can no longer afford them and airlines that are thriving in large part because they have avoided creating such jobs; struggling traditional airlines like United, Delta and US Airways have laid off tens of thousands of employees and told rest that they must absorb round after round of salary and benefit cuts to keep flying; at healthier low-fare carriers like Southwest and JetBlue, pay is much lower and benefits are skimpier, but good year can yield big bonus at end; some airline employees comment; graph; photos (M)

headline: In Promising Light in Chechnya, Moscow Shines It on One of Its Own
abstract: Moscow's proxy government in Chechnya signed an agreement on Friday with Russia's electricity monopoly for restoring power to the republic, where utility services have been rendered almost nonexistent by a decade of lawlessness and war.    On the surface it was a simple event, promising a modicum of recovery in a region in ruins. But the stage-managed show surrounding the signing was full of the choreographed power maneuverings tied to the republic's coming special presidential election.

headline: Worried Families in India Wield Power of Publicity
abstract: Indian government's frenzied efforts to show it is doing everything it can for Indian hostages in Iraq can be traced partly to vans belonging to four round-the-clock news channels that have been parked outside family home of one of hostages in Makrauna Kalan since July 21; Iraqi insurgents are quickly learning that it often does not take much to pressure democratic governments; photo; map (M)

headline: COCA-COLA CHIEF TO BE PAID LESS THAN PREDECESSOR
abstract: Coca-Cola Co sets salary and bonus of chief executive E Neville Isdell at $4.5 million, less than his predecessor's, amid sluggish sales; will pay Isdell base salary of $1.5 million and bonus of up to $3 million (S)

headline: Race Remains a Difficult Issue for Many Workers at Kodak
abstract: Interviews with Eastman Kodak employees, managers and outsiders paint picture of company that is setting strong antidiscrimination policies, and trying to enforce them, but with varying degrees of success; group of past and present Kodak employees on July 30 sued company, accusing it of systematically discriminating against African-American; suit was filed on behalf of 10 named plaintiffs as well as Employees Committed to Justice, group of about 200 others who meet monthly to compare notes about possible racism at Kodak; some African-American employees suggest that their litigious colleagues may be ascribing racist overtones to ordinary workplace disputes; many employees say Kodak act decisively when real racism occurs; photo (M)

headline: Judge gets tough on campaign funding
North Korea, Eyeing Election, Issues Stream of Insults at Bush
abstract: North Korea unleashes stream of insults at Pres Bush, calling him 'imbecile' and worse, that seem to rule out any serious progress on nuclear disarmament talks before American election this fall; tirade appears to have been set off by recent campaign speech in which Bush referred to Kim Jong Il as 'tyrant'; South Korean experts, often optimists with regard to North Korea's behavior, speculate that North is following standard negotiating tactic of ratcheting up its polemics before settling down for real talks; Sen John Kerry has indicated that, if elected president, he would pursue direct bilateral talks with North, something Bush refuses to do, and he sharply criticized Bush for promising to pull out one-third of American troops from South Korea without winning any reciprocal military concession from North (M)

headline: A Wi-Fi Thief Unmasked: Guess It's Time to Move On
abstract: Article on Wi-Fi service problems when more than one provider occupies an access area; drawing (M)

headline: RealNetworks Plans to Sell Digital Music at Half Price
abstract: RealNetworks plans to put its digital music offerings on sale at half price as part of aggressive strategy to force its way onto Apple Computer Inc's popular iPod digital music player; acknowledges that sale--which lowers price of songs on online RealPlayer Music Store to 49 cents and cost of most albums to $4.99, tentatively through Labor Day--would have impact on company's finances; RealNetworks' founder-chief executive Rob Glaser comments (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cuts In Ferry Service
abstract: Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Co, British ferry operator, will cut 1,200 jobs and shut routes to stem losses in cross-channel ferry business; cuts will result in one-time loss of 240 million pounds ($435 million) this year (S)

headline: Good Deals for Banks, Both Coming and Going
abstract: Andrew Ross Sorkin article on increase in staple financing, in which investment banks both advise seller and provide financing for buyer, earning advisory fee and interest payments on same merger deal; cites potential conflicts of interest; drawing (M)/

headline: Shift in Medicare Use Expected
abstract: New, sharply higher charges announced for Medicare beneficiaries last week may prompt more elderly people to join Medicare health maintenance organizations operated by private industry; 17.4 percent increase, to $78.20 per month in Medicare premiums that mainly pay for coverage by doctors, is largest one-step increase since start of program in 1965 (M)

headline: Portraits From North Main Street, the Heart of a Town
abstract: Profiles of owners of sm

headline: Taxes decline for top U.S. companies even as profits rise, study finds
Israel Expands Program to Attract Jews from North America
abstract: With immigration to Israel down in recent years, a charter flight delivered nearly 400 arrivals from the U.S. and Canada.

headline: Saudis Find Head of American Who Was Held by Militants
abstract: The head of Paul M. Johnson, Jr., was discovered in a freezer when Saudi forces conducted a raid on a house in Riyadh.

headline: Nortel Financial Statements to Be Delayed
abstract: Nortel Networks Corp, which is restating results back through 2001, says it will not have financial statements for 2003 and first half of 2004 ready until end of October, month later than planned (M)

headline: A Bit Battered, Google Still Sticks to Plan For Its Offering
abstract: Google says it will end registration period for its initial public offering by early Aug 13 and start bidding 'soon thereafter'; big institutional investors have scoffed at value of offering, in which Google has estimated company's worth at no less than $27 billion (M)

headline: Bush Sees Joint World Effort To Press Iran on Nuclear Issue
abstract: Pres Bush says United States will maintain pressure on Iran to abandon its nuclear weapons program, emphasizing that his administration is working with other countries and not confronting Iran on its own; he has come under searing criticism from Sen John Kerry for what Kerry calls Bush's go-it-alone approach to foreign policy; Kerry has also attacked Bush for allowing Iran to move forward with its nuclear ambitions while going to war with Iraq, where almost no evidence of nuclear weaopns program has been found; Bush has not directly answered Kerry's charges, but he repeatedly emphasizes how much US is cooperating with other nations to try to stop spread of nuclear weapons, particularly in Iran (M)

headline: Medco hopes ads not only tell clients what it does, but who it is.
abstract: Medco Health Solutions begins first big advertising campaign, with ads created not just to promote company brand but also to demystify what Medco, pharmacy benefit manager, does; campaign was developed by Gotham ad agency; photo (M)

headline: DataBank; Summertime, and the Stocks Are Wilting
abstract: In what has become a familiar summertime pattern, the stock market declined again last week, as worries about flagging demand in the technology sector, soaring oil prices and rising interest rates cooled ardor for stocks.    With losses of almost 15 percent for the week, Intel and Advanced Micro Devices were among the biggest decliners in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. The shares of the two companies fell after Intel, a technology bellwether, said that its inventories had swollen and that its profit margins were narrowing. Those comments led to widespread declines among tech shares for the week, although I.B.M. rose on Friday after reporting higher-than-expected profit for the second quarter.

headline: IN WESTERN IRAQ, FUNDAMENTALISTS HOLD U.S. AT BAY
abstract: In latest reversal for First Marine Expeditionary Force, Falluja and Ramadi and much of Anbar Province in western Iraq are now controlled by fundamentalist militias, with American troops confined mainly to heavily protected forts on desert's edge; Baath Party officials once loyal to Saddam Hussein who were willing to work with US have mostly resigned, defected to fundamentalists or been killed; insurgents have made videotapes of former officials denouncing themselves as traitors and then being beheaded; militants' principal power center is mosque in Falluja led by clerk Abdullah al-Janabi, who has instituted harsh rule in city; photos; map (L)

headline: Russia grasps at security with an iron hand
World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Interest Rate Unchanged
abstract: Bank of England leaves key interest unchanged at 4.75 percent (S)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: Defense Dept confirms deaths of two service members in Iraq (S)

headline: Talks Go On in Iraq; Aide Says Cleric Asks Fighters to Disarm
abstract: Moktada al-Sadr's ability to forge a more peaceful path may well depend on the outcome of the talks this week.

headline: Commercial television in Britain means just that: a channel devoted to nothing but commercials.
abstract: New British satellite television network called Advert Channel shows commercials 24 hours a day; one analysts says Britons, unlike Americans, take great pride in creativity of their commercials and actually enjoy watching them (M)

headline: Jury Finds Ex-Tyco Lawyer Not Guilty of All Charges
abstract: Mark A. Belnick was acquitted on Thursday of charges that he stole millions of dollars in the form of unauthorized bonuses and loans.

headline: Glum Day for Hong Kong Democrats
abstract: Tactical errors, plus peculiarities in voting process, prevent democracy advocates in Hong Kong from winning as many seats as expected in legislative elections; question now is how China will react to voting; election is being widely watched as test of Chinese government's tolerance for democracy; pro-Beijing candidates fare better than expected after mainland officials use voter incentives and intimidation; candidates from pro-democracy opposition capture roughly three-fifths of popular vote; in terms of seats, democracy opponents win 18 of 30 chosen by public, but only 6 of 30 chosen by industries and professions, which are allowed to send representatives to legislature; photo (M)

headline: EDITOR'S CHOICE: These sites are a snap
Names of the Dead
abstract: Defense Department confirms deaths of two service members in Iraq (S)

headline: THE WORKPLACE : Bully them to make them leave
World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Telecom Profit
abstract: China Mobile (Hong Kong), listed unit of China's biggest cellphone operator, posts a 7.8 percent increase in first-half profit, to 18.83 billion yuan, on 23 percent increase in its subscriber base; revenue rises to 86.42 billion yuan from 76.66 billion yuan (S)

headline: Unlikely alliance built on opposition to Iraq war now raises questions
abstract: Almost two years after Russia, Germany and France forged an unlikely alliance around their opposition to the war in Iraq, the countries' leaders are preparing for their second three-way summit meeting next week, even though the issue that drew them together no longer drives their agenda.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: HOMESERVICES OF AMERICA INC., Edina, Minn., the residential real estate brokerage owned by Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc., Omaha, bought Graham & Boles Properties to expand in North Carolina. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: CONTINENTAL AIR TO DEFER PENSION CONTRIBUTIONS THIS YEAR
abstract: Continental Airlines will skip contributions to employee pension plans this year; move, under law enacted in April, will help company keep $1.5 billion in unrestricted cash (S)

headline: British Cabinet Changes Set Stage for Elections
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair of Britain completes cabinet realignment in advance of possible elections next year; Gordon Brown, Blair's main rival within Labor Party, retains position of chancellor of the exchequer; this is interpreted as Pyrrhic victory for Blair, reinforcing his authority over Brown, who sought higher post, but possibly storing conflict for future; Alan Milburn is to take charge of general election planning (M)

headline: AT&T Cuts Jobs at Call Centers as It Struggles to Regroup
abstract: Labor union officials say AT&T informed them in recent weeks that it is in process of closing call centers in Hawaii, Puerto Rico and Charleston, W Va; at least 400 workers will be laid off from those three locations, and another 130 will be cut at customer service center in Fairhaven, Mass, which is being reduced in size; thousand contract workers were let go after Labor Day; industry analysts expect even more cuts, perhaps up to 10,000 jobs, in coming weeks so that workers can be removed from company's books by end of year; those cuts will come on top of plans to reduce work force by 8 percent, to about 57,000, this year; some industry analysts have embraced AT&T's decision to pull back from its traditional business, calling it necessary in face of fierce competition in consumer market against rivals like MCI, which emerged from bankruptcy in April; graph (M)

headline: Treasury Offerings Scheduled for This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week include today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.    At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 1.43 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 1.72 percent, and the four-week issue was 1.32 percent.

headline: Collapse at airport injures dozen others : 5 are killed as wall in Dubai falls
7 Arabs Killed in 5 Attacks, One by a West Bank Settler
abstract: Seven Palestinians are killed in scattered violence including Israeli airstrike in Gaza Strip and raid by soldiers into West Bank refugee camp; Palestinian gunmen in Gaza City abduct Riad Ali, Israeli Arab working for CNN; no group claims responsibility; it is not clear who is behind Ali's kidnapping, or why kidnappers singled him Ali; Gaza has grown increasingly lawless and has had rash of kidnappings in recent months; most abductions have been related to internal Palestinian fighting, and most victims have been released unharmed after several hours; in West Bank, Jewish settler is arrested by Israeli police after fatally shooting Palestinian taxi driver near Nablus; in Jerusalem, Israeli authorities announce arrest of five border policemen accused of abusing Palestinian men in incident this month (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Perrier Decision Postponed
abstract: Bottled-water unit of Nestle postpones until at least October any decision on whether to sell its Perrier brand; graph (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Casualties In Factional Warfare
abstract: Herat (Afghanistan) Governor Ismail Khan reports that at least 18 and possibly as many as 50 people have been killed during four days of factional fighting with rival militia commander (S)

headline: In Words of World Court, a Wall That Is 'Contrary to International Law'
abstract: Excerpts from nonbinding decision by International Court of Justice, which concluded that Israel's construction of barrier in West Bank is illegal (M)

headline: Europa : Looking more closely at the message of Sochi
C.I.A. Expands Its Inquiry Into Interrogation Tactics
abstract: A Central Intelligence Agency review that grew out of the furor over abuses at Abu Ghraib prison now includes scrutiny of the agency's interrogation and detention practices at military-run facilities and other sites across Iraq, government officials say.     The reassessment, which is more far-reaching than previously known, could have implications for the agency's conduct elsewhere, including interrogations of high-level Al Qaeda suspects like Khalid Shaikh Mohammed who are being held by the C.I.A. in secret facilities around the world.

headline: Yes, There's Life After Pets.com
abstract: yes, ther's life after

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: J.P. MORGAN CHASE, New York, said it planned to spend more than $60 million this year to add 16 branches in the New York area and replace automated teller machines, its first retail expansion since 1997.    BLAVOD EXTREME SPIRITS, London, the maker of black vodka, said Costco Wholesale Corp., Issaquah, Wash., agreed to stock Blavod Black Vodka at its northern California stores, starting Oct. 1.

headline: Nielsen Ratings System Reviewed in Congress
abstract: Nielsen Ratings System Reviewed in Congress.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Telecom Profit Rises
abstract: Dutch communications company Royal KPN says second-quarter profit more than doubled to 369 million euros ($453 million) despite stagnant revenues of 2.93 million euros; graph (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Merck to Post Results Of Clinical Trials Online  Merck & Company says it will post the results of its clinical trials on drugs on a Web site run by the National Institutes of Health. The move comes ahead of a House subcommittee hearing where, it is expected, drug companies will be excoriated for refusing to publish unfavorable drug trial results.    Merck said that it had already posted the outlines of 46 studies, or every trial for which it is currently recruiting patients, as well as some others. By the end of the month, the company will post 50 more trials that are already under way but where patients are no longer being recruited. GlaxoSmithKline also recently agreed to post data online. [C4.]

headline: Ontario Warns 4 Fund Managers
abstract: Ontario Securities Commission might take action against Canadian mutual fund management companies IGM Financial Inc, AIC Ltd, CI Fund Management Inc and AGF Management Ltd as part of nearly year-old probe of industry; any disciplinary action would center on market timing activity by funds (S)

headline: For Others From Tyco, Verdict Makes Case for Optimism
abstract: Analysis of acquittal of Tyco International's former general counsel Mark A Belnick on larceny charges; says decision may also be victory for former Tyco executives L Dennis Kozlowski and Mark H Swartz; says main charges against Belnick are similar to some of those against Kozlowski and Swartz, whose trial ended in mistrial in April (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Pilots Union of US Airways To Resume Wage Cut Talks  The pilots union of US Airways plans to resume talks immediately with the struggling airline, which is urging unions to grant $800 million in cuts to save it from another bankruptcy filing.     The union's leadership made the decision to return to the bargaining table at the end of a three-day meeting in Arlington, Va., the Air Line Pilots Association said. [Page C2.]

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Bank Executive Named
abstract: BOC Hong Kong names Raymond Lee chief financial officer, succeeding Law Man Wah, who will become general manager overseeing financial department (S)

headline: UNITED AIRLINES WILL RECALL 375 LAID-OFF FLIGHT ATTENDANTS
abstract: United Airlines is recalling 375 flight attendants to increase that work force about 2 percent as it adds more international flights and keeps its aircraft flying for more hours (S)

headline: Dispute Disrupts Daimler in Germany
abstract: Tens of thousands of autoworkers walk off job at Mercedes-Benz plants across Germany, intensifying already bitter dispute between DaimlerChrysler and its union; more than 20,000 workers strike plant in Sindelfingen, where company has been trying to eliminate hourly breaks in effort to cut labor costs; carmaker is seeking to reduce labor costs by 500 million euros ($617 million) a year; workers have offered cuts worth 180 million euros ($222 million); photo (M)

headline: Seeing Google With the Eyes of Forrest Gump
abstract: Article on prospects for Google's initial public offering; focuses other companies, including Apple Computer, whose share prices started out strong but later faltered; photos (M)

abstract: Advertising account changes noted (S)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: Defense Dept confirms deaths of five service members in Iraq (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Toyota Increasing Production In China
abstract: Toyota Motor and Chinese partner Guangzhou Automobile Group will spend 3.8 billion yuan ($460 million) to build factory in Guangzhou; plant is scheduled to produce 100,000 Camry sedans per year beginning in 2006; graph (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Xilinx 2nd-Quarter Sales To Fall Short
abstract: Technology Bri

headline: Condominiums for Businesses Fill a Niche in California
abstract: Commercial condominiums, obscure class of office buildings that are divided into small units that are sold to occupants, are gaining new prominence in California; Venture Commerce Corp, company in fore of developing projects, recently broke ground on its 11th such project; has competition from at least four other companies in San Francisco Bay Area, with other developers preparing to enter market; photo (M)

headline: Despite Terror Risk, Washington Is Unlikely to Press Reform of C.I.A. This Year
abstract: Pres Bush will not move quickly to initiate reform of intelligence system called for in scathing Senate Intelligence Committee report; is looking at series of proposals and awaiting release of second report; Congressional debate will not begin until Bush's views on issues are clear; Bush will try to avoid issue in run-up to election and is concerned that prolonged reorganization would disrupt Pentagon intelligence operations at critical time; photos (M)

headline: Will Big Four Audit Firms Survive in a World of Unlimited Liability?
abstract: Floyd Norris column suggests that Big Four accounting firms will be able to survive without federal protection against liability lawsuits from shareholders; says that good auditing is essential to functioning capital markets and that government auditing, only alternative to firms, is unworkable because of government pay scales, which are too low to draw top talent, and prospect of political pressure; says that firms appear to be engaged in real effort to prevent recurrence of past abuses and that that should offer some protection against devastating lawsuits and criminal prosecutions; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Peru: Tourists Held In Coca Protest Freed
abstract: Peruvian authorities announce release of 20 foreign tourists held in Spanish Church built on Incan Koricancha temple site in Cuzco; hostages were held by coca farmer protesting American-backed drug-eradication eforts; seven coca farmers have been arrested (S)

headline: Six Palestinians and Israeli Killed in Clashes
abstract: The Palestinian dead included four militants, but the ISraeli military also acknowledged the deaths of "two innocent Palestinians."

headline: Older Investors More Jittery As U.S. Markets Disappoint
abstract: Many older investors are concerned about their retirement funds because of disappointing US markets this year; with Standard & Poor's 500-stock index down 1.5 percent and Nasdaq composite index off 8.2 percent this year, investors who thought that 2004 would repeat last year's 26 percent rise in Standard & Poor's index are beginning to face fact their expectations will not be met; some investors comment; graph; photos (M)

headline: Mortgage Giant Agrees to Alter Business Ways
abstract: Fannie Mae agrees to major changes in its accounting and management practices in unusual deal reached with Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight; agreement comes after regulator's scathing report cited accounting irregularities and earnings manipulation that helped enrich company's senior executives and present apparently false portrait of Fannie Mae's financial well-being to public; Fannie Mae has agreed to add more than $5 billion in fresh funds to its capital reserve in next nine months and to have its board reassess company's structure, staffing and managerial practices and provide its regulator with regular updates on its progress in meeting terms of agreement; latter move indicates regulators have little confidence that Fannie Mae chief executive Franklin D Raines or other members of management and board have exercised effective oversight of company; company is still subject of Securities and Exchange Commission investigation that may extend to major Wall Street firms that have dealt with Fannie Mae; photo (M)

headline: Most unions agree to split Alitalia in 2
Through All Their Ordeals, Iraqis Bank on Free Food
abstract: Iraqi government has been giving entire populace survival rations since 1991, when country faced international sanctions, and program continues unchanged, even in cities like Falluja, where militants are in control and all other government services have been cut off; monthly supply is worth about $15 per person; even among those who are well-off, rations are regarded as entitlement and people are clamoring for list of items to be expanded; costs of program is about $3.8 billion, or one-fifth of annual national budget, and has fostered bureaucratic corruption, created culture of dependency and suppressed domestic industry; Western advisers and Iraq's own economists agree that subsidies will cripple economy, but know that consequences of cutting them off could be dire while political situation is so fragile and could result in open revolt; Western advisers promote switching to cash payments; photo; chart shows monthly ration (M)

headline: Worlds Apart On the Economy
abstract: Yvette Bozzini letter replies to Ben Stein's July 18 column criticizing Democrats for ignoring role of personal responsibility in Americans' economic problems

headline: A Former Italian Journalist Lets Her Politics Show
abstract: Profile of Lilli Gruber, former Italian TV anchor who was elected to European Parliament as independent candidate; Gruber says Italian broadcasting has fallen under thrall of Silvio Berlusconi, billionaire prime minister whose family owns three of seven commercial television channels; photo (M)

headline: How Much Break, RoboKaddy?
abstract: Article on PowaKaddy, motorized golf-bag carrier developed in 2002 by2

headline: Is Broadband Out of a Wall Socket the Next Big Thing?
abstract: Is Broadband Out of a Wall Sock

headline: OPEC Cancels a Meeting; Output Plan to Stay the Same
abstract: OPEC abruptly cancels scheduled meeting in Vienna to review production quotas and oil prices; will continue policy it adopted in June, 2 percent increase in quotas, effective in August; crude oil for August delivery closes at $40.77 a barrel in New York, down 20 cents; graph; chart (M)

headline: Seeking antitrust job, she vows never to return to board seats : EU's Kroes confronts conflicts of interest
Bank Takeover in Japan Steps Away From Tradition and Into Open
abstract: Sumitomo Mitsui Financial, led by Yoshifumi Nishikawa, makes $29 billion bid for UFJ Holdings; UFJ earlier reached agreement to be taken over by Mitsubishi Tokyo Financial Group; UFJ says it will examine offer from Sumitomo Mitsui, although there is no change to its plans to combine with Mitsubishi Tokyo; photo (Market Place column) (M)

headline: LOW-FARE EXECUTIVES, TOO
abstract: Southwest Airlines' board is not expected to give lavish gift to James F Parker, who retired unexpectedly from company last week (S)

headline: Greek Defense Minister Quits for Deadly Copter Crash
abstract: The resignation came a day after Africa's senior Greek Orthodox prelate and 16 others died in a helicopter crash in the northern Aegean.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Profit Off At VNU
abstract: World Busin

headline: HOLLYWOOD CASINO SHREVEPORT FORCED INTO CHAPTER 11
abstract: Hollywood Casino Shreveport, which operates riverboat casino on Red River in Louisiana, says creditors forced it to file for bankruptcy protection (S)

headline: Munch's 'Scream' Is Stolen From a Crowded Museum in Oslo
abstract: Armed robbers grab one of world's most famous paintings, The Scream by Edvard Munch, and another Munch painting in full view of museum goers at Munch Museum in Oslo, Norway; robbers then speed off in black station wagon; they had held guards at gunpoint and used wire cutter to clip framed paintings free of wall; their getaway car is later found in northern Oslo; art experts say that given fame of both The Scream and second painting, Madonna, it would be nearly impossible to sell them to collector; speculation is that thieves will demand ransom; 1994 theft of another version of The Scream recalled; photos (M)

headline: Lucasfilm Opens Digital Animation Studio in Singapore
abstract: Lucasfilm Ltd opens digital animation studio in Singapore to produce movies, television shows and video games (M)

headline: Letter from America : The gun culture counts in presidential politics
abstract: CHAMBERSBURG, Pennsylvania  In most of the world, the language of human rights and liberty is used to discuss universal issues, like the right to vote, to speak freely, to choose the place you live and work. But here, as in much of small-town U.S.A., there is a peculiar "right" that sits curiously close to the American heart:

headline: U.S. Seeks to Provide More Jobs and Speed Rebuilding in Iraq
abstract: State Dept is conducting major review of $18.4 billion program to rebuild Iraq, seeking ways to provide more jobs and visible results more quickly to Iraqis; Pentagon was initially put in charge of designing projects and doling out contracts, but it has increasingly shared authority with State Dept; only one-third of money has been designated for specific projects so far, and most of those ventures are still in planning stages (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Halliburton Considers Sale of Its KBR Subsidiary  Halliburton said that it was considering a sale of its KBR subsidiary, which provides military and oil field services. The unit has been plagued by disappointing losses, investigations into its activities in Nigeria and Iran, and sizable asbestos claims.    Making matters worse, KBR's work in Iraq has not been as profitable as other activities and has contributed to a public relations nightmare for its parent. All of this has happened while KBR is seeking to emerge from bankruptcy protection. [Page A1.]

headline: Legal Loophole Inflates Profits in Student Loans
abstract: Government Accountability Office report shows federal government is paying hundreds of millions of dollars in unnecessary subsidies to student loan companies even though Bush administration has authority to cut them off immediately; student loans companies for last two years have been taking advantage of loophole in federal law to receive big subsidies that Congress tried to retire more than decade ago; as lenders have stepped up practice, billing government for more than three times as much as they did three years ago, Education Department has maintained that there is little it can do to stop them soon; subsidies could cost government nearly $1 billion that many lawmakers should go directly to students (M)

headline: 7 Killed in Kabul as Bombing Rips a U.S. Contractor
abstract: Three Americans were among those killed when a powerful bomb exploded outside the compound of a U.S. contractor.

headline: Technology Briefing | Deals: 24/7 Real Media Acquires Decide Interactive
abstract: 24/7 Real Media acquires Decide Interactive for $26 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: Driver Is Fined for Nascar Ad Cover-Up
abstract: Nascar driver Jimmie Johnson, who is sponsored by PepsiCo Inc, is fined $10,000 for covering bottle of Coca-Cola Co's Powerade sports drink with sign after he won Pennsylvania 500; Johnson climbed from his car on victory lane while surrounded by media and placed sign for Lowe's Companies, his primary sponsor, in front of bottle of Powerade Nascar officials had placed on his car (S)

headline: Israeli Forces Kill 4 Palestinians in Clashes in Gaza
abstract: Israeli forces shoot and kill four young Palestinians during running clashes as military expands operations in northern Gaza Strip to try to prevent rocket attacks being mounted from area (S)

headline: Russian Official Urges That Yukos Be Given Some Slack
abstract: Russian Federal Energy Agency head Sergei Oganesyan comes to defense of Yukos, urging legal authorities to unfreeze company's bank accounts; says aim is to prevent stoppage of oil wells, since Yukos is 20 percent of output and other companies cannot pick up slack; Yukos produces about 1.7 million barrels of oil per day, or about 2 percent of world's supply; photo (M)

headline: Ex-Chief of Enron Pleads Not Guilty to 11 Felony Counts
abstract: Enron Corp's former chairman and chief executive Kenneth L Lay pleads not guilty to charges he engaged in conspiracy to deceive investors and employees about company's financial troubles just before it collapsed; is charged with 11 felonies, including conspiracy, making misleading statements, wire fraud, bank fraud and securities fraud; Securities and Exchange Commission also files civil complaint against him, seeking more than $90 million in fines and penalties; there are no allegations that Lay knew of fraudulent partnership dealings that hid extent of company's debt and contributed to its downfall; Lay's sales of stock in months leading up to Enron's bankruptcy filing in December 2001 have been primary focus of investigation, but no criminal charges contend that sales themselves were improper; SEC does accuse Lay of disposing of his stock at prices that did not reflect Enron's true, much lower value; Law is released on $500,000 unsecured bond; government reveals it has obtained written evidence showing that former chief accounting officer Richard Causey and former chief financial officer Andrew S Fastow entered into illegal agreement, initiated by them and known as Global Galactic, to manipulate company's reported earnings through bogus sales of company assets; chart on charges; photo (M)

headline: Skip the Oven, Just Bring On the Toast
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column compares prices and features of toasters and toaster ovens at various Internet sites; drawing (M)

headline: A Graceful Exit to Greener Pastures
abstract: Advice on how to preserve relationships built at current employer when resigning to take better job elsewhere; drawing (M)0

headline: Flight Delays, Down After 9/11, Grow Worse Again
abstract: US Bureau of Transportation Statistics says more than 400,000 flights have been delayed or canceled so far this year, more than one of every five that take off; delayed flights have increased 34 percent so far this year from same period in 2003, reversing two-and-a-half year trend of fewer delays set in motion as airlines cut back service and passenger traffic fell sharply; photo (M)

headline: This May Be News to Hussein, but He's Got a Defense Team, and It's Hoping for Bail
abstract: Saddam Hussein's legal defense fund is headquartered in Amman, Jordan; it is led by Muhammad Rashdan, former Baathist who says Hussein has been misunderstood; another member of team is Ali Nasrat al-Asaadi, Kurdish-American lawyer who defends Hussein's use of chemical weapons on Iraqi Kurds, calling it matter of self defense; lawyers are drafting first legal challenges to Hussein's prosecution; they concede their work will not be easy; they do not even know if Hussein wants to hire them; in addition, Iraqi lawyers' union is lobbying to bar foreign lawyers from appearing before special tribunal; photo (M)

headline: Freddie Mac Receives Notice That It May Face Action by S.E.C.
abstract: Freddie Mac, government-chartered mortgage company that restated earnings by $5 billion, says that it might be subject of civil lawsuit by SEC; SEC is investigating possible violations of regulation that covers fraud and deceptive practices as well as insider trading (S)

headline: In These Days of Insecurity, Stick to Itinerary Is the Rule
abstract: Global security and growing importance of internal online booking systems are majin topics at National Business Travel Association annual convention, Orlando, Fla; managed online booking on corporate intranet systen not only saves money, it can provide network where traveler, travel manager, security director and other company executives can maintain close contact for security reasons; drawing (M)

headline: Treasury Bills Set for This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.    At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was at 1.65 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 1.87 percent, and the four-week issue's rate was 1.60 percent.

headline: Pakistan Official Unhurt as 5 Die in Attack
abstract: A suicide bomber blew himself up next to the car of Pakistan's prime minister-designate, Shaukat Aziz, at a crowded political rally on Friday evening, killing the driver and four other people but leaving Mr. Aziz unhurt, according to the police and witnesses.     The attack, near this northwestern town in Punjab Province, also wounded 45 people, including seven police officials, the police said.

headline: The Wall of Water
abstract: Restrictions on US tourists, sanctions against European trading partners: The regime of aging revolutionary Fidel Castro faces pressure under an intensified US embargo.

headline: Stock Offerings This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:      American Campus Communities, 12.1 million shares. Citigroup, Deutsche Bank.    Archipelago Holdings, 11 million shares. Goldman Sachs, J.P. Morgan.

headline: Dmitri Dudko, 82, Foe of Stalin Who Recanted and Praised Him
abstract: Rev Dmitri Dudko, Russian Orthodox priest who spent years in prison for anti-Soviet activity but in his later years praised Stalin and grew close to nationalists who dreamed of restoring Soviet Union, dies at age 82 (M)

headline: Suddenly, a Bond Manager's Life Is Tougher
abstract: Start of Federal Reserve drive to raise interest rates to keep economy from overheating is making bond fund managers and financial advisers scurry to protect their portfolios because bond prices fall when yields rise; average taxable bond fund lost 1.8 percent in second quarter; return to higher rates comes at all-time peak for bond fund assets; graph of bond fund returns; photo (M)

headline: MDC Partners to Gain Majority Stake in Banjo
abstract: MDC Partners majority stake in Banjo, San Francisco entertainment marketing agency (M)

headline: 6 Are Charged With Murder After Paraguay Store Fire
abstract: Prosecutors in Paraguay file murder charges against owners and security guards at megastore in Asuncion where as many as 460 people were killed in fire; six people are charged with criminal homicide, including owner Juan Pio Paiva, son Victor Daniel and four guards; manager Fernando Humberto Casaccia is charged with refusing to help people escape burning building; photos; hundreds were injured at Ycua Bolanos store; victimes were trapped when guards apparently locked emergency exits after fire started to prevent looting; complex is one of three in capital that draw thousands of shoppers on weekends (M)

headline: Paris Faulted On Aid Given To Tlcom
abstract: European Commission, seeking to close loopholes in Europe's state aid rules, says France acted illegally in 2002 by extending unused credit line to France Telecom that enabled it to raise 9 billion euros on financial markets; orders company to repay to local government with interest tax breaks worth 800 million euros ($995 million) to 1.1 billion euros it got from 1994 to 2002; defining unused credit line as state aid sets key precedent; some competition lawyers say commission cannot order recovery of what amounts to psychological state aid; France is expected to appeal; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Seven More Managers Fired At Nortel Networks  Nortel Networks, the troubled Canadian telecommunications equipment maker, fired seven more financial managers as it continued to sort out an accounting scandal.

headline: Ex-Chief of Computer Associates Is Indicted on Fraud Charges
abstract: While Sanjay Kumar faces charges, Computer Associates agreed to cooperate with prosecutors, enabling the company to avoid a corporate indictment.

abstract: World Business Briefing: South Korea: Chinese Concern Wins Oil

Whimsy on a Child's Desk With Signature Mouse Ears
abstract: Disney Dream Desk PC is computer with screen shaped like familiar Mickey Mouse silhouette; photo (M)

headline: New York Group Seeks Controlling Stake in MCI
abstract: Leucadia National Corp. is seeking permission from regulators to buy a controlling stake in the troubled telecommunications company.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Packaging Unit Sold
abstract: Alcoa sells its Brazilian flexible-packaging business Itaipava to Dixie Toga; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: When Politicians Write Accounting Rules, Reality Can Be Forgotten
abstract: Floyd Norris comment on political wrangling regarding European and American proposals on accounting rules for derivatives; Repr Cliff Stearns' opposition to proposed American law noted; says eventual establishment of American accounting rules as de facto worldwide standard will be more likely; quesstions whether European really wants that; photo (M)

headline: Racial 'Handicaps' and a Great Sprint Forward
abstract: Liu Xiang is hailed in China as 'the Yellow Bullet' after returning from Athens Olympics with gold medal for 110-meter high hurdles; photo; admiring Chinese say Liu has ovecome 'congenital shortcomings,' proving that 'yellow men' can jump and sprint as well as black and white athletes (M)

headline: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- New Jersey; Realty Trust Plots a Route, Highway 24
abstract: Reckson Associates Realty Corp is buying office complexes along Route 24 corridor in New Jersey, including 1.25-million-square foot Giralda Farms office park in Madison; Todd Rechler, whose family founded company, comments on company's 'wealth-belt' strategy; photo (M)

headline: MORGAN STANLEY SETTLES BIAS SUIT WITH $54 MILLION
abstract: Morgan Stanley agrees to pay $54 million to settle sex discrimination case rather than stand trial on EEOC accusations that it denied equal pay and promotions to women in division of its investment bank; settlement would cover as many as 340 women, with at least 12 million going to Allison K Schieffelin, lead plaintiff; Morgan Stanley, which does not admit to any wrongdoing, agrees to spend $2 million on diversity programs overseen by outside monitor to improve chances that women will succeed there; must also provide antidiscrimination training for managers and employees in division that deals with stock trading for institutional clients; Shieffelin photo (M)

headline: Conseco Awards Options to Chief
abstract: conseco awar

headline: Cendant Is Close to Acquiring Orbitz for $1.1 Billion
abstract: Cendant Corp reportedly nears deal to buy Orbitz, online travel service controlled by alliance of airlines, for about $1.1 billion; Cendant chairman Henry R Silverman reportedly hopes to use Orbitz to lead customers to Cendant's brick-and-mortar travel businesses; photo (M)

headline: Russia Moves to Seize Yukos's Primary Oil Asset
abstract: Russia acts to seize and sell, possibly at hefty discount, Yuganskenftegaz, which produces some 60 percent of all Yukos oil, as payment for company's back tax bill; plan dismays investors, who fear possible renationalization; trial of Yukos founder Mikhail B Khodorkovsky on fraud, embezzlement and tax evasion charges continues; photo (M)

headline: She Tilts Against Power, but Don't Call Her Quixotic
abstract: Supinya Klangnarong, energetic campaigner for free press in Thailand, has been sued for libel for publicizing obvious profits that Shin media empire has made since its founder Thaksin Shinawatra became prime minister; photos; case highlighting media concentration is being fought against harsh backdrop of intimidation of environmental and human rights activists, several of whom have been killed or gone missing since Thaksin took over (M)

headline: Annan Urges Prompt Action on Sudan Draft
abstract: Secretary General Kofi Annan intervenes in Security Council debate to urge panel to act quickly on new resolution to curb violence in Darfur region of Sudan; says he is eager to set up commission to determine whether ethnic violence there has reached level of genocide (M)

headline: Pentagon Cautions on Intelligence Changes
abstract: Senior Pentagon officials caution against hasty move toward overhauling nation's intelligence agencies in response to 9/11 commission report; it calls for appointment of national intelligence director to oversee work of spy agencies within Defense Dept; some Democrats join with Rep Duncan Hunter, chairman of House Armed Services Committee, in expressing concern that there not be politically motivated 'rush to judgment' that would harm military; Congressional Republican leaders with eye on Nov elections have vowed to move within weeks on legislation to carry out many of commission recommendations; they have become central issue in presidential campaign; Sen John Kerry has endorsed all of recommendations, while Pres Bush has endorsed many of them; his plan for national intelligence director has far more limited budgetary and personnel powers than was envisioned by commission; photo (M))

headline: World Briefings
abstract: MIDDLE EAST.

headline: REPUBLICANS IN NEW YORK / Wrapping things up : Republicans, in a festive mood, celebrate early
Disney in Talks On Independence For a Weinstein
abstract: Walt Disney Co representatives and its subsidiary Miramax Films are expected to meet to discuss agreement that would allow Miramax's co-founder Harvey Weinstein to start production company, while his brother Bob remains at Disney to make movies; Disney would give Bob Weinstein budget of about $300 million to $350 million per year and small development and marketing staff to make four to six movies under Dimension Films, which Bob Weinstein already runs; Harvey Weinstein would become independent producer, securing financing for movies to be distributed by his brother; Disney could agree to license Miramax name back to Harvey Weinstein (M)

headline: Ford Delays Release of a Hybrid S.U.V.
abstract: Hybrid gasoline-electric version of Ford Motor Co's Escape sport utility vehicle will not reach showrooms until October, delaying release another month (S)

headline: 3 Palestinian Activists Face U.S. Charges
abstract: Three men have been charged with raising money for Hamas through a network of U.S. banks, Attorney General John Ashcroft said today.

headline: Security Tightened in Kabul After Bombing
abstract: Security is tightened across Kabul in wake of vehicle bomb that killed three Americans working for American contractor DynCorp Inc and at least four other people, injuring many others; DynCorp spokesman says two employees are missing, an Afghan and a Nepali; company is training Afghan police and providing guards for Pres Hamid Karzai; American Embassy advises its citizens to avoid military sites, government buildings and crowded places like bazaars, restaurants and Internet cafes; Taliban spokesman claims responsibility for bombing; photo (M)

headline: So the Jobs Report Is Dismal. The Fed Has No Place to Go but Up.
abstract: Federal Reserve seen likely to continue raising interest rates despite dismal jobs report; retail sales graph (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Uganda: 68 Percent In Poll Want Leader To  Retire
abstract: Monitor, Ugandan independent newspaper, publishes poll that shows two-thirds of Ugandans oppose constitutional changes that would allow President Yoweri Museveni to run again in 2006; current limit for president is two five-year terms (S)

headline: Powell vows the U.S. will 'finish work we started'
Dominican Republic on Edge of a Default
abstract: Dominican Republic is coming close to default on foreign debt as incoming administration of Leonel Fernandez positions itself to grapple with economic crisis; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: 32 Years For Bosnian Serb
abstract: Former Serbian political leader Radoslav Brdjanin is sentenced to 32 years in prison for his part in deportation of thousands of Muslims and Croats to prison camps as part of planned ethnic cleansing in Bosnia (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Debut Is Delayed
abstract: japan: debut is de

headline: Many See Musharraf Keeping Army Post to Cement Power
abstract: Senior Pakistani government officials appointed by Gen Pervez Musharraf urge him to break promise to resign as army chief and serve only as president by end of 2004; promise, made in December, 2003, was trade-off for support by hard-line religious parties and widely hailed as step toward democracy; latest pronouncements appear to prepare public for power-play; defenders point out that there is no widespread public disapproval of Musharraf, while inept and corrupt rule of former prime ministers has diminished public's faith in politicians; photo (M)

headline: People
abstract: Interpublic Group of Cos promotes Ellen Johnson to senior vice president and treasurer, succeeding Steven Burns; Doner promotes Shane Ankeney to executive vice president and executive media director, succeeding Fred Sattler, who is leaving to join PHD (S)

headline: IRAQ UPDATE
abstract: Recap of latest events in Iraq; map (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Biotechnology Profit Grows
abstract: Indin

headline: Agencies undergo shifts as advertisers try to spur consumer spending.
abstract: Second half of year is beginning for Madison Avenue advertising industry way first half ended--with flurry of account changes and assignments in competitive categories; shifts reflect in part growing if still wobbly confidence that additional advertising spending may well stimulate consumer spending; some account changes discussed; photo (M)

headline: Kosovo Report Criticizes Rights Progress by U.N. and Local Leaders
abstract: Ombudsperson branch of United Nations mission in Kosovo scores mission and local Albanian leaders who have led province for five years for failing to achieve even minimal level of protection of rights and freedoms, particularly for province's Serbian minority, annual human rights report; lays much of blame on international community's failure to resolve Kosovo's final status; focuses on inability of Serbs and other minorities to live, travel and work freely; Marek Antoni Norwicki, who wrote report, says many problems will not improve until status issue is resolved, interview (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Koizumi Tour Of Kuriles Protested
abstract: Russian Foreign Ministry holds that plans by Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi to cruise past disputed Kurile Islands could complicate relations between nations; islands were seized by Soviet Union at end of World War II (S)

headline: African Union to Send Troops in Bid to Curb Sudan Violence

headline: In Wake of Fire, Indian State Bans Thatched Roofs in Schools

headline: Industrial Pollution Destroys Fish Farms in Rural Region of China
abstract: Industrial pollution is destroying fish farms on Guo tributary of River Huai in China, where fishing families live on houseboats and raise fingerlings in netted fish farms; pollution killed fish stock worth about $550,000 in 2000, an enormous sum in rural China; losses were $265,000 in 2003; complaints to government have brought no action; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Economic Growth Rate Rises
abstract: Britain's real gross domestic product grew 3.4 percent in first quarter from year earlier quarter, fastest annual pace in three and half years (S)

headline: Government Wants to Bring Health Records Into Computer Age
abstract: Bush administration will offer long-term plan to modernize health care system with information technology, mainly by setting goals and working with private sector to establish product and technology standards so computer systems of doctors, hospitals, laboratories, pharmacists and insurers can efficiently communicate and share data; government will also use its buying power through Medicare and Medicaid programs to speed transition to electronic patient records; Health Sec Tommy G Thompson says government must encourage standards to cut risk of technology investments and then demand that medical industry invest in technology; administration and health care experts say modernizing health records could save both lives and about $140 billion a year; photos (M)

abstract: European Commission says it will probably approve France's plans to inject 517 million euros into ailing computer company Bull; aid would let Bull repay illegal 450 million euros loan it got from France in 2002 (M)

headline: Cable Companies Profit From Demand for High-Speed Internet

headline: Warmth Was Wanted; Instead, Putin's Chilly Responses Darken the Political Clouds
abstract: Many Russians fault Pres Vladimir V Putin's 'chilly response' to recent terrorist attacks; hold that Putin and those around him have failed to express sufficient grief over school attack in Beslan, recent crashes of airliners or attack of subways in Moscow; Putin aims to present himself as steely, decisive leader, but his perceived insensitivity could have profound consequences for his political authority and for country's future; photo (M)

headline: Bolivians Support Gas Plan And Give President a Lift
abstract: Bolivians cast ballots in referendum on how country's huge natural gas reserves should be developed; they are expected to approve all five questions on ballot, which would permit private energy companies to export large quantities of natural gas, while allowing Pres Carlos Mesa's government to increase royalties it receives and tighten restrictions on those companies to provide more benefits to country's 8.3 million people; result is seen as vote of confidence for Pres Mesa; political analysts expect criticism of referendum to linger because many Bolivians did not understand convoluted questions; photos; map (M)

headline: At Least 19 Killed, Scores Injured in Iraq Bombing
abstract: A suicide car bomb exploded today in the northern oil city of Kirkuk after the car plowed into a crowd of men seeking jobs with the Iraqi National Guard.

abstract: Russia's decisive support to the long-delayed climate change treaty should allow it to come into force worldwide.

headline: Right-Wing Israelis Protest Withdrawal Plan
abstract: The rally came just hours after Prime Minister Ariel Sharon told a Cabinet meeting that growing incitement by right-wing activists could lead to violence, or even civil war, in Israel.

headline: Ex-Occupation Aide Sees No Dent in 'Saddamists'
abstract: Former senior official of just-dissolved American-led occupation authority in Iraq says American military and CIA have been unable to destroy insurgency or to reduce number of 'hard-core Saddamists' seeking to destroy interim Iraqi government; says there is little insight into 'command and control' of insurgents, or into how relatively small rebel force is organized, and how can it be broken; says American officials have found it 'almost impossible' to penetrate network organized by terrorist Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, who is believed responsible for many of suicide bombings that have killed both American troops and Iraqis (M)

headline: People and Accounts of Note

Ms. Balik had been senior vice president and managing director for planning at Universal McCann, New York, part of the McCann Worldgroup division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

headline: Indonesian General Cleared Of Shooting Protesters in '84
abstract: Maj Gen Sriyanto Muntrasan, chief of Indonesia's powerful special forces, is acquitted of human rights violations stemming from incident in 1984, when 23 people were killed after he ordered his troops to open fire on 3,000 protesters; his case is one of number government has pursued involving abuse by military in three-decade rule of former Pres Suharto; he is latest of several senior officers to be acquitted; human rights organizations say prosecution of military officials from Suharto era has generally been weak (M)

headline: Killings Drive Doctor Group To Leave Afghanistan

headline: Despite Appeals, Chaos Still Stalks the Sudanese

headline: Spying Becomes an Issue In Brazilian Phone Dispute

headline: Iraqis Joyful, or Stung, to See Ex-Ruler in Dock
abstract: Iraqis in Baghdad sit spellbound, watching televised image of Saddam Hussein in the dock; some celebrate what they hope would be his impending punishment, even his death, while others say they feel humiliated that his arraignment in courtroom had been brought about by Americans; some are uncomfortable watching their former president being treated like common criminal; conversations with Iraqis across city reveal how powerful he remains in his ability to frighten, inspire and even divide this society over his legacy; while his court appearance sparked many strong opinions, one of most common sentiments voiced is denial, kind of forced indifference toward him; some Iraqis comment; photos (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Google Is Set to Trade After Selling Shares at $85  Google, conceding that demand for its long-awaited public stock offering had fallen far short of the company's hopes, reduced the number of shares and drastically reduced the target price range.       The final price was $85, far off the target range of $108 to $135 a share that the company had projected last month. The company's shares are expected to begin trading today on the Nasdaq market. [Page A1.]

headline: An Incident That Has Kept Merrill's Women on Edge
abstract: Tension between Merrill Lynch and employees charging sex discrimination has increased as word spreads through firm that broker said she was raped by company executive last year; female brokerage trainee complained to Plainsboro, NJ, police that Emmett M Wright attacked her in guest room in firm's conference center in Mar 2003; Wright told police sex was consensual; he was charged with sexual assault, but woman later decline to cooperate and case was drop; she also withdrew her complaint to Equal Employment Opportunity Commission; she says trial would have been too stressful, phone interview; Wright was suspended and then resigned; firm kept woman on payroll until she resigned and paid for counseling (M)

headline: A Nation of Airport Haves and Have-Nots

headline: 7 More Managers Fired Over Nortel Accounting
