headline: Has the Time Come for Touchscreen Voting?
abstract: I've been putting together a segment for "CBS Sunday Morning," to air in the next few weeks about touchscreen voting machines, which 50 million Americans will use in November's election. The main characters include Avi Rubin (the Johns Hopkins professor who analyzed the software in Diebold machines and found it disturbingly insecure); Rush Holt (the Congressman who's proposed a bill that requires a printed paper trail); Kevin Shelley (the California Secretary of State who banned or decertified e-voting machines statewide); and representatives of Diebold and Sequoia (the number 1 and 2 voting-machine makers).

headline: Quiet, Please! Suddenly, the S.E.C. Is Listening
abstract: THERE was a time not so long ago when a company poised to go public would invite a reporter inside to memorialize the moments leading up to the blessed event. Photographs of founders toasting their stock market debut with plastic cups of bubbly were a staple of magazine articles. And so often did chief executives of newly minted public companies show up on CNBC on their big day that the appearances seemed a rite of passage, not unlike a victory lap.     But no more. Like so much in the post-Enron world, the quiet period -- which begins when a company files paperwork to go public and ends no sooner than 25 days after its stock starts trading -- has been redefined. Where once lawyers offered a nuanced interpretation of what the Securities and Exchange Commission permitted during the quiet period, clients in recent months are hearing a far simpler message: Place a mute in your mouth and just shrug whenever a reporter comes knocking.

headline: Indonesia Detains 6 From U.S. Mining Business Over Pollution
abstract: Newmont Mining Corp, world's biggest gold producer, says Indonesian police detained six of its officials after questioning them about accusations of pollution from company mine in northern Indonesia; says among those detained were company's American president in Indonesia, Richard Ness; he was released after three hours; no charges have been filed; questioning and detention follow long-simmering dispute between company and billagers at Buyat Bay Beach, who say they suffer illnesses from pollution caused by company; photo (M)

headline: Haven Offered To 2 Militias In Colombia, If They Disarm

headline: Opposition makes gains in Senate : Support for Chirac erodes in elections
HUSSEIN, IN JAIL, REPORTEDLY SAID LITTLE OF VALUE
abstract: Saddam Hussein revealed little of what his interrogators most wanted to know--about his weapons programs and insurgency in postwar Iraq--during his seven months held captive by American forces; senior officials say Hussein would occasionally provide startling comments, such as his claim that he invaded Kuwait in 1990 to keep his army occupied; say he implied that he was surprised when United States began its invasion in Mar 2003; say he appeared to think that ambiguity over whether his government possessed illegal weaopns would keep his neighbors at bay, while US would be hung up in interminable debate at UN; say he was circumspect about his whereabouts while in hiding; say he was interrogated principally by one intelligence officer in Arabic, and that no physically coercive methods were used although psychological tricks were employed; say he behaved as if he were still Iraq's ruler (M)

abstract: NEW YORK  Animal rights activists have a sense of zeal that makes them compare themselves to abolitionists, suffragists and civil rights marchers.

headline: BBC Is Exploring Options for Its Commercial Unit
abstract: British Broadcasting Corp is in touch with American media companies Time Warner and Walt Disney, as well as other companies including Germany's Bertelsman, to discuss options for its BBC Worldwide commercial subsidiary; Financial Times says BBC has asked companies to discuss 'possible bids' for BBC Worldwide; unit could be worth up to 2 billion pounds, or about $3.6 billion; review of unit is part of wider set of consultations about corporation's future announced in June by BBC chairman Michael Grade; photo (M)

headline: Doctor's Homes Are Searched In the Anthrax Investigation
abstract: Agents from Federal Bureau of Investigation and United States Postal Service investigating deadly 2001 anthrax attacks search two homes of Dr Kenneth M Berry, self-described bioterrorism expert; carry away bags of material from home in Wellsville, NY, and cottage in Ocean Beach, NJ; also search apartment in Wellsville where he lived in 2001; Berry is founder and chief executive of Preempt, organization that advocates specialized training for medical professionals to respond to chemical and biological attack; several hours after search of his homes, Berry is arrested in Point Pleasant Beach, NJ, on domestic assault charges; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: S.&P. and Nasdaq Slide To New Lows for the Year  Stocks fell sharply, sending the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the Nasdaq composite index to new lows for the year. All three of the market's main gauges fell 1.6 percent or more as the high price of oil and new data on retail sales raised doubts about the outlook for economic growth and corporate earnings.    The S.&P. 500 dropped 17.93 points, to 1,080.70, falling below the low it hit July 26. It is down 2.8 percent for the year. The Nasdaq fell 33.43 points, to 1,821.63 breaking through the 2004 low it also reached on July 26. It is down 9.1 percent for the year. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 163.48 points, to 9,963.03. It is down 4.7 percent for the year. [C5.]

headline: Afghan Leader Tries to Persuade Main Rival to Quit Election Race
abstract: Afghan Pres Hamid Karzai hopes to persuade Yunus Qanooni, his main rival in presidential race, to drop out and join Karzai campaign; Qanooni announces his intention to remain in race and says he will present his own political program in few days; it is clear that he may be reconsidering his options; he declared his candidacy just six weeks ago, and two of his main supporters favor rejoining Karzai to ensure power-sharing deal for their mainly ethnic Tajik following in future administrations; Qanooni's rank-and-file supporters from provinces mistrust Karzai and his failure to deliver on his promises; Qanooni has served as both interior minister and education minister in Karzai's interim administration; photo (M)

headline: Sing With a Soundtrack; Watch the Movie, Too
abstract: Portable media player from iRiver plays music, video and displays photos; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: 16 Hurt In Mosque Bombings
abstract: Police official K F Naik reports that 16 people were injured when makeshift bombs were tossed into widows of two mosques in Maharashtra State (India); holds bombing is related to Assembly elections, which are planned for October (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Neo-Nazi Rally Allowed
abstract: Bavarian appeals court rules that thousands of neo-Nazis are entitled to hold march near tomb of Hitler's deputy Rudolf Hess in Wunsiedel despite town banning march; Hess, who committed suicide while serving life sentence in Spandau Prison, is seen as martyr by many neo-Nazis (S)

headline: Former General Wins Most Votes in Indonesia Election
abstract: Former Gen Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono wins largest number of votes in Indonesia's first direct presidential election; fails to win majority, however, and will face runoff election in Sept against second-place candidate; Pres Megawati Sukarnoputri and former Gen Wiranto are in tight race for second place; possibility of head-to-head battle between two former generals is considered one of worst possibilities by Indonesian political reformers; both men served during three-decade iron rule of Gen Suharto; photo (M)

headline: Study of Painkiller Suggests Heart Risk
abstract: Food and Drug Administration study finds Merck & Co's Vioxx pain-killer increases chance of heart attack and death from cardiac arrest more than Pfizer Inc's Celebrex; Merck disagrees with results of study (S)

headline: How to Spell 'Charlatan'
abstract: To the Editor:     Re ''Turning the Tables on E-Mail Swindlers'' (June 17), on people who strike back at perpetrators of online fraud: One characteristic unmentioned by the article is the lack of proper English grammar, sentence structure and punctuation in the e-mail come-ons.

headline: A Digital World With Analog As Its Workhorse
abstract: Digital revolution is driving strong demand for advances in analog electronics, arcane realm in which tens of thousands of products translate reality into 1's and 0's for computers and retranslate digital results into forms humans can perceive; Texas Instruments Inc has emerged as global leader in analog chip market, making both digital signal processors and number of analog devices surrounding signal processors; graph and table of analog-based revenues; photos (M)

headline: Agfa-Gevaert, Photo Pioneer, To Sell Film and Lab Business
abstract: Agfa-Gevaert is selling its consumer film and photo labs business to unit's managers for 175.5 million euros; will focus on its more profitable medical imaging and graphics businesses; move comes as sales of traditional rolls of film have declined with spread of digital cameras (M)

headline: MediaTalk; A Flirtation in Ethics Leaves Some Matters Utterly Unmentioned
abstract: Vanity Fair magazine discloses one conflict of interest in its New Establishment roundup, noting that son of magazine's editor was intern at agency selected for its power list; other undisclosed conflicts noted; magazine holds other conflicts, including $100,000 payment to editor Graydon Carter by movie studio, have already been widely reported; photo (M)

headline: Delta Fails to Gain Bondholders' Support for Debt Reduction Plan
abstract: Delta Air Lines, seeking to avoid Chapter 11 bankruptcy, is unable to persuade enough bondholders to change terms of their securities so that it could buy back debt at discount; company, which is about $20 billion in debt, says it is continuing to seek solutions that will allow for successful out-of-court restructuring (M)

headline: From a High-Tech System, Low-Fi Music
abstract: Randall Stross column warns downloads sold by Apple's iTunes Music Store are distributed using extreme form of compression to save file space that results in loss of fidelity; company has yet to switch to distributing music that is compressed only temporarily, process called lossless data compression; photo (M)

headline: MediaTalk; News Corp. Donors Show Bipartisan Spirit In Presidential Politics
abstract: News Corp president and chief operating officer Peter Chernin and executive vice president Gary L Ginsberg have made contributions to John Kerry, presumptive Democratic presidential nominee; company employees and their families have given almost $350,000 in campaign contributions as of June 1, 60 percent of which went to Democrats; at least four executives of company's Fox Network have contributed to Kerry's campaign; Fox cable channel has developed reputation, which it denies, as right-leaning news organization; photo (M)

headline: World Briefings
abstract: EUROPE.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Proxim Settles Suit With Symbol Technologies
abstract: Technology Brief

headline: CREDIT SUISSE CHAIRMAN LEAVES FOR CITIGROUP
abstract: Stephen R Volk resigns as chairman of Credit Suisse First Boston to become vice chairman of Citigroup (S)

headline: Russia Freezes Yukos Funds; 5 Days Given To Pay Taxes
abstract: $3.4 billion dispute between Russian government and Yukos Oil Co reaches decisive point, when court bailiffs take extraordinary step of freezing company's bank accounts and demanding payment in full within five days; Yukos officials say action threatens to shut company; offer to sell major block of stock to pay tax claim that Yukos holds in Sibneft, competitor that has tried and failed to merge with last year; government sharply raises ante in dispute hours before freezing company's account, indicating it might double its demand for back taxes from Yukos by adding charges for 2001 to case; original $3.4 billion claim relates to 2000 tax year; photo (M)

headline: Products Slide Into More TV Shows, With Help From New Middlemen
abstract: Television networks have worked hard in last two years to strike their own product placement deals; CBS plans to broadcast product-theme nights, with single brand featured on consecutive shows; entire episodes of NBC's The Apprentice will revolve around one brand; Campbell's Soup has been written into American Dreams, with NBC and soup maker sponsoring real-life essay contest mirroring one in show's plot; new emphasis on product placement in television has brought new players into business-brand wranglers who work with programmers and advertisers; Madison Road Entertainment, which calls itself independent, advertiser-driven television studio, is one of newest players; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Blair Brings Back An Ally
abstract: British Prime Minister Tony Blair appoints former Health Minister Alan Milburn, who is political ally, as chancellor of Duchy of Lancaster; position wields considerable influence over next year's election campaign; former union labor leader Alan Johnson is appointed minister of pensions (S)

headline: EU is seeking to weaken automakers' hold on the parts market
In reply, the president vows to honor dead by 'completing mission' : Kerry faults Bush over cost of Iraq war
A Crucial Vote for Venezuela and a Company
abstract: Smartmatic's voting machines will be used for first time in hotly contested Aug 15 referendum on rule of Venezuelan Pres Hugo Chavez; company chief executive Antonio Mugica says proving product works under hostile conditions will enable company to sell it around world, interview; any operational glitches leading to charges of fraud or vote manipulation would scar company's reputation; photos (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Microsoft to Distribute $32 Billion in a Dividend  Microsoft announced plans to pay shareholders a special dividend of $3 a share, a gift worth $32 billion. Although other companies have paid special dividends, the size of Microsoft's payout is believed to be the largest.

headline: Kerry Says Bush Has Not Acted Quickly Enough on Terrorism Defenses
abstract: John Kerry accuses Pres Bush of dragging his feet in bolstering nation's defenses against terrorism, campaign rally in Grand Rapids, Mich; says he should call special session of Congress to adopt recommendations of 9/11 panel; says Bush has encouraged recruitment of terrorists by alienating moderates in Muslim world, prompting Bush to say Kerry has 'fundamental misunderstanding of the war on terror'; Kerry's foreign policy adviser James P Rubin says Bush has flip-flopped on national intelligence director's post, using term that Bush-Cheney campaign has tried to affix to Kerry; photo (M)

headline: Greece Admits Faking Data to Join Europe
abstract: Greece confesses to having repeatedly misrepresented significant economic data before it joined European currency union, prompting suggestion that it might not have qualified had true figures been known; Finance Min George Alogoskoufis blames his socialist predecessors for what he calls creative accounting; says revised asessments of figures in question raised Greece's 2000 budget deficit to 4.1 percent of gross domestic product, compared with 2.0 percent previous government had said (M)

headline: Oil Prices Set Record Again As Supply Falls
abstract: Oil prices climb above $47 a barrel, setting yet another record, after figures show supplies in United States are down for third consecutive week and a report from OPEC highlights threat of high oil prices for world economies; crude oil for September delivery settles at $47.27 a barrel in New York; futures prices are up about $10 a barrel since end of June; graph shows slump in crude-oil inventory (M)

headline: War and Peace, and Politics
abstract: News analysis on dealing with terrorist alerts in heat of tight presidential campaign; points out that while Sec Tom Ridge dismisses link between latest warning and campaign, he also credited Pres Bush's 'leadership in the war against terror' with gathering information; rival John Kerry may not share that view, but biggest thing Democrats may have to fear this campaign is power of fear itself, as polls show that Bush's handling of terrorism remains his only clear advantage over Kerry in razor-close race; Bush would not be politically canny not to remind public of his strong suit, which is why his convention is in New York, why he has new ads with images of firefighters and the flag, and why he discusses terrorism with gravitas of White House Rose Garden setting; Bush at same time must take pains not to let political tail wag terrorism dog: use of old intelligence leaves even some in law enforcement wondering why Ridge raised alarm just now (M)

headline: Bursting With Functions, A Slimmer Braille Organizer
abstract: BrailleNote PK from Pulse Data is multi-function device for the blind that communicates with phone line, Bluetooth and WiFi wireless technology; photo (S)

headline: Negotiator warns of troubles in Caucasus
Homeowners Come Up Short On Insurance
abstract: Millions of American homeowners unknowingly have woeful shortfall in insurance coverage; experts cite shift in way property insurance has been sold in recent years; say that in move to cut costs from claims, insurance companies began in late 1990's to phase out coverage that guarantees replacement of destroyed homes, regardless of expense to insurers, and to substitute similar-sounding policy with crucial difference: it pays only amount stated on policy plus, typically, additional 20 percent to 25 percent; old policy was called guaranteed replacement policy; new one, which most Americans now have, is called extended replacement policy; California Insurance Commissioner John Garamendi says insurance companies and agents, under pressure to make sales, often aim low in valuing houses in effort to keep premiums down; dozens of owners of homes in Southern California that were destroyed say, in interviews, that they had been led to believe they bought enough coverage to rebuild their homes and are stunned to find out they were wrong; photo (M)

headline: Ownership Of Gazprom Questioned; Shares Fall
abstract: Yuri Savelyev, Russian lawmaker and member of radical Rodina Party, demands investigation into whether foreigners illegally bought Gazprom shares that only Russians may own, sending stock down 13 percent (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Bio-Rad Laboratories buys closely held MJ GeneWorks Inc for about $32 million (S)

headline: Putin Tells the Russians: 'We Shall Be Stronger'
abstract: Transcript of Russian Pres Vladimir V Putin's televised remarks at Kremlin on September 4 in wake of recent terrorist attacks on school in Beslan and on passenger airliners; Putin says attacks are aimed at all Russians; links attacks to international terrorism; promises specific steps to prevent future attacks (M)

headline: With market stability, Japanese return to stocks
QUARTERLY INCOME UP 55% AT OCCIDENTAL PETROLEUM
abstract: Occidental Petroleum Corp reports second-quarter net income rose 55 percent, to $581 million, from a year ago; says president Dale Laurance will retire Dec 31; chief executive Ray Irani will assume his duties (S)

headline: Shake-Up at Saatchi in New York
abstract: Saatchi & Saatchi division of Publicis Groupe is shaking up its flagship New York office, installing new leadership from without and within on both administrative and creative sides; co-chief executives Mike Burns and Scott Gilbert are being succeeded by single chief executive Mary Baglivo; Burns will remain at agency and Gilbert will retire; chief creative officer Tod Seisser is leaving; Tony Granger from London office will take up creative duties in New York; Fran Kelly will assume Baglivo's duties; chief executive Kevin Roberts comments; photos (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CASH AMERICA INTERNATIONAL INC., Fort Worth, the pawnshop operator, said it had agreed to buy SuperPawn, Las Vegas, for about $125 million. The transaction is expected to be completed in the next 90 days.

headline: United to Offer a Premium Service on Some Transcontinental Flights
abstract: Bankrupt United Airlines is ready to start up fancy new transcontinental service to lure high-paying premium business fliers who will pay top dollar for flatbed seats and other frills; drawing (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Internet Telecom
abstract: Britain's BT Group begins offering phone calls, e-mail and Yahoo Inc instant messaging free over Internet; access charges start at $37 a month (S)

headline: Treasury Offerings Set for the Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.    According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 1.50 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 1.73 percent, and the four-week issue was 1.33 percent.

headline: Browned to Perfection
abstract: Joan Bjorklund letter contends old toasters and other household appliances were much better in years gone by than they are today (July 22 article)

headline: And Now, a Message From Our Sponsor
abstract: PricewaterhouseCoopers study for Interactive Advertising Bureau finds online advertising revenue totaled $2.37 billion in second quarter, up 43 percent from 2003 period; search ads, which appear with results of online search, accounted for about 40 percent of all ad spending; online advertising graph by industry (S)

headline: It's BlackBerry Season, but Maybe Not for Long
abstract: Future of Research in Motion's hand-held Blackberry device is dim; BlackBerry faces formidable competition; well-financed Silicon Valley start-up, Good Technology, has developed software that is superior to Blackberry's; it is first to continuously and wirelessly synchronize every module of Outlook, needing no cradle to connect gadget to computer; Good has written its software to run on array of phones and hand-held devices--whatever runs Palm or Microsoft software; drawing (M)a

headline: Trans-Atlantic Fare Cut
abstract: Aer Lingus sharply cuts trans-Atlantic fares in both business and economy classes; simplifies fare structure, eliminating need for round-trip purchases and Saturday night stayovers to get best fare; International Air Transport Association reports international passenger traffic rose 18.7 percent in 2004 first eight months from same 2003 period; predicts airline industry will lose between $3 billion and $4 billion across world this year; Transportation Security Administration sets new screening procedures that will expand use of manual patdowns of passengers and give screeners more latitude in deciding when to refer passenger to more invasive secondary-screening process (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Glaxo Drops Patent Fight
abstract: GlaxoSmithKline, European drug maker, gives up fight to protect patent for its top diabetes medication in China, Avandia (S)

headline: People
abstract: Cory Shields was named executive vice president and chief communications officer at J Walter Thompson, New York (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Morgan Stanley Settles Bias Case for $54 Million  Morgan Stanley agreed to pay $54 million to settle a sex discrimination case rather than stand trial on the federal government's accusation that it denied equal pay and promotions to women in a division of its investment bank.    The settlement, which could cover as many as 340 women, is the second largest the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has reached with a company it sued and is the first with a major securities firm. [Page A1.]

headline: The name game:Can anyone famous be a designer?
U.S. Cuts Off Financing Of U.N. Unit For 3rd Year
abstract: State Department says Bush administration will withhold $34 million from UN Population Fund for third year in row because agency cooperates with activities in China that promote abortion; supporters of agency say it does not condone abortion and advocates voluntary family planning; debate has election-year overtones; Bush campaign releases new political advertisement criticizing Sen John Kerry for voting against parental notification for teenage abortions (M)

headline: Rival TV Boxing Shows Square Off in California Court
abstract: Dispute between creators of rival boxing reality shows grows nastier when DreamWorks SKG and Mark Burnett Productions, producers of The Contender on NBC, seek temporary restraining order that would prevent Fox Broadcasting from airing its version The Next Great Champ, produced by Endemol and Golden Boy Enterprises; The Contender producers, relying on report written by California State Athletic Commission chairman Sanford L Michelman that accuses Fox show of numerous violations of state boxing regulations, asks Judge Linda Lefkowitz to prevent Next Great Champ from using film of any match that was not legally promoted; such decision would effectively block any broadcast of Fox show (M)

headline: Strong Showing by USA Today Helps Gannett Profit Rise 9.3%
abstract: Gannett Co says second-quarter profit rose 9.3 percent, fueled partly by help-wanted ads and biggest rise in advertising at USA Today since first quarter of 2000; net income was $354.4 million, up from $324.3 million; sales rose 9.9 percent, to $1.87 billion (M)

headline: Lifetime Magazine Closing
abstract: Hearst Corp and Walt Disney Co will cease to publish Lifetime magazine in October amid disappointing results since publication's introduction in April 2003 (S)

headline: As Gaza Grows Unruly, Palestinian Premier Offers to Resign
abstract: Palestinian Prime Min Ahmed Qurei submits resignation, citing government's inability to enforce security; suggests entire cabinet may be replaced; resignation comes in response to three kidnappings by militants in one day that illustrate lawlessness in Gaza Strip; Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat rejects resignation; it is still unclear whether Qurei is determined to resign or move is largely attempt to convey gravity of situation to Arafat (M)

headline: G.O.P. Senators Voice Rising Concerns on Iraq
abstract: The comments came as the interim Iraqi prime minister, Ayad Allawi, was telling a television interviewer that "we are winning."

headline: Kerry team contact was Seoul spy
Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Insight To Buy Out Comcast Stake In Phone Venture
abstract: Insight Communications Co will buy full ownership of telephone operations of its Insight Midwest joint venture with Comcast Corp (S)

headline: AMERICAN STANDARD REPORTS 19% RISE IN PROFIT
abstract: American Standard Cos reports second-quarter net income of $159.7 million, up 19 percent from year earlier (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Fantasy Leagues Attract Money From Advertisers  Fantasy sports leagues like those offered on Sportsline.com were among the first services to prove that consumers were willing to pay for online content. But now, free or low-cost services from AOL, NFL.com and even Best Buy are attracting advertising dollars and, potentially, driving down the price of content for everyone.     Over the next four weeks of N.F.L. pre-season games, the league will run television commercials featuring N.F.L. stars like Michael Strahan, above left, of the New York Giants, playing for fantasy football teams and answering to their fantasy league managers. Bob Tedeshi: E-Commerce Report. [Page C7.]

headline: Companies With Cash Hoards Don't Necessarily Pay It Out
abstract: Microsoft Corp's decision to pay one-time dividend of $32 billion does not necessarily mean that other big companies with lots of cash on hand are going to increase or begin paying dividends; some of these companies have much less cash to distribute than it appears, and others with a lot of cash are already paying fairly high dividends and are unlikely to increase them any time soon; still, there is plent of room for other companies to raise dividends, and they are coming under pressure to do so (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Court Backs Vanunu Travel Ban
abstract: Israel's High Court of Justice upholds restrictions that limit Mordechai Vanunu's movements inside country and prevent him from leaving country for one year; he was imprisoned for discussing his work on nuclear reactor in 1986 interview (S)

headline: Tests to Begin on New Drugs to Protect Women From Contracting H.I.V.
abstract: International Partnership for Microbicides chief executive Dr Zeda F Rosenberg is set to tell International Aids Conference, Bangkok, that classes of drugs used to treat patients with HIV are being tested for first time as microbicides to protect women from becoming infected during sex; says microbicides, while never as effective as condoms, could save millions of lives, interview; microbicide would also protect infected woman's sex partner from infection (M)

headline: THE WORKPLACE : Postal jobs:Are losses permanent?
KRISPY KREME SUES ENTENMANN'S OVER TRADEMARK
abstract: Krispy Kreme Doughnuts Inc asserts it is only company that can call its products 'Original Glazed' and is suing rival baker, Entenmann's unit of George Weston Ltd, over phrase (S)

headline: 4 Executives At Ahold Unit Are Indicted
abstract: Four executives at US Foodservice, American food distribution company that is unit of Dutch supermarket conglomerate Royal Ahold, are indicted on charges of inflating company's earnings by more than $800 million; SEC files separate civil complaint against executive, accusing them of overstating income by smaller amount, $700 million, and pressing many suppliers to help conceal fraud; two of executives, Timothy J Lee and William F Carter, enter guilty pleas; Michael Resnick and Mark Kaiser are expected to surrender, and Kaiser's lawyer says he will plead not guilty; Lee and Peter O Marion, former supplier to US Foodservice, are charged with insider trading in late 1999 and early 2000 related to Royal Ahold's acquisition of US Foodservice (M)

headline: Conan O'Brien to Succeed Jay Leno in 2009, NBC Announces
abstract: Conan O'Brien will succeed Jay Leno as host of the "Tonight" show at the end of Mr. Leno's current five-year contract.

headline: JUDGE DENIES UNIVISION SUIT TO STOP NEW NIELSEN RATINGS
abstract: Nielsen Media Research may proceed with its plans to introduce new local television ratings system in Los Angeles next week after California Superior Court Judge J Stephen Czuleger denies Univision Television Group's bid for delay (S)

headline: TALKS FALL APART FOR SHIITE REBELS AND IRAQ LEADERS
abstract: Truce talks between Iraq's interim government and Moktada al-Sadr's rebels collapse, prompting American commanders to prepare new battle plans for breaking Sadr's grip on holy city of Najaf and Imam Ali mosque; American marines and soldiers line up in tanks and armored vehicles at their base in Najaf, but offensive is called off for second time in recent days; American commanders in Najaf say Dr Ayad Allawi has decided to turn to Iraqi forces, not American, to take lead against Sadr at such a sensitive location; photo (M)

headline: His Patience Fading, Powell Is Demanding Sudan Improvements
abstract: Secretary of State Colin L Powell demands that Sudan's leaders make 'dramatic improvements...right now' in Darfur region, where armed militias have routed more than million Sudanese from their homes; warns that United Nations Security Council would act against government--and Janjaweed militias it controls--if it fails to halt violence (M)

headline: Estonia's joining EU opens a tap for Finns : Boozing over the Baltic
abstract: Despite its name, this cruise ship is not your typical Love Boat. Hundreds of passengers, almost all of them Finns, have come aboard for a specific reason: cheap booze.

headline: 2 Bombings Seen as Part Of New Drive By Taliban
abstract: Two bombs explode in Jalalabad in eastern Afghanistan, killing one man and wounding 27 people; attacks come four days after bomb rips apart minibus carrying 15 women election workers, killing 2 and wounding 13; growing campaign by suspected Taliban aims to disrupt government preparations for national elections in Sept (M)

headline: Chrysler Aloof, So Far, From Latest Incentive War
abstract: Chrysler is holding back as General Motors and Ford increase incentives to combat slipping market share and rising inventories; is not drastically increasing its rebates as it enjoys surging sales of new Chrysler 300 model and strong advance orders for its Dodge Magnum station wagon; disappointing June sales touched off new round of incentives from GM and Ford; photo (M)

headline: Gunmen Wound Top Palestinian Intelligence Aide in Gaza
abstract: The shooting was the latest sign of the unrest in Gaza as Palestinian groups struggle for control of the Gaza Strip.

headline: U.S. Forces Take Action in Areas Dominated by Iraqi Insurgents
abstract: U.S. troops appeared to make a small but significant step in their effort to regain control of the contested Sunni Triangle.

headline: A Speedy Robotic Cleaner Tailors Its Task to Your Pool
abstract: Aquabot Bravo from Aqua Products is robotic swimming pool cleaner that learns shape of pool and calculates most efficient cleaning pattern; photo (S)

headline: Letter from Europe : As Iraq deteriorates, alliance loses its focus
World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Ad Agency Sells Shares
abstract: British advertising agency M&C Saatchi sells shares in initial public offering that values company at 67.8 million pounds ($128 million) (S)

headline: In China, Farmers' Labor Bears Too Much Fruit
abstract: Production of litchi, long a symbol of China, has soared there, causing retail prices to crash; plight of litchi industry shows both promise and pitfalls of China's remarkable economic growth and its shift to awkward but dynamic mix of capitalism and state socialism; growing litchi trees has been form of long-term investment for Guangdong Province peasants for centuries; their climbing incomes in last two decades prompted many of them to plant more litchi trees, disregarding warnings from academic experts that surplus would result; Chinese government has banned planting of any more litchi trees, and banks have stopped lending to litchi farms, but current glut is likely to last long time; growers are trying to open up new markets for their crops; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Machinery Orders Fall
abstract: Orders for Japanese machinery fell seasonally adjusted 11.3 percent in July from month earlier; graph (S)

headline: Tamil Suicide Bomber Kills 4 Policemen in Capital of Sri Lanka
abstract: Suicide bomber in Sri Lanka kills herself and four policemen in what appears to be failed attempt to assassinate local politician; this is first such attack since Sri Lanka government and Tamil rebels signed cease-fire two years ago; intended victim, Douglas Devananda, is government minister and leading ethnic Tamil politician who has been strident critic of rebel Tamil Tigers; United States continues to list Tigers as terrorist organization (M)

headline: Hyping history:18th century cool
Online Stores Branch Out
abstract: Many e-commerce sites are expanding into new products; CarsDirect.com, online auto marketplace, will announce creation of Autos.com, research and ratings service for auto shoppers; will also announce creation of LoanStore.com, which offers, among other services, mortgages and home equity lines of credit; chief executive Robert N Brisco comments; photo (M)

headline: With Oil Near $50 a Barrel, Gas Prices Start to Inch Up
abstract: Gasoline prices head up again as price of crude oil flirts with $50 a barrel, ending unusual period this summer when gas prices fell as oil prices rose; gas prices jumped 5.1 cents in last week, to US average of $1.917 per gallon, still below record average of $2.06 in May but 33 cents higher than year ago; graph; analysts explain odd divergence in terms of supply and demand, dismissing suspicions that oil companies could be trying to influence presidential election (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: The Gretchen Morgenson column last Sunday about second-quarter performance of technology companies referred imprecisely to reports of softer sales at the CDW Corporation, a computer reseller. Monthly sales reports from the company have shown a decline in sales growth; the company did not warn of a decline.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Slovenia And Croatia: Calls For Calm
abstract: Slovenian Prime Minister Anton Rop withdraws threat to block Croatia's bid to join European Union over continuing border dispute; union foreign policy chief Javier Solana urges both nations to resolve conflict (S)

headline: Profit at Talbots Up 4.8% for 2nd Quarter
abstract: Talbots, clothing retailer, says second-quarter profit rose 4.8 percent as sales increased and company benefited from resolution of income tax issue; profit in quarter ended July 31 rose to $19.4 million from $18. 5 million in year-earlier period (S)

headline: U.S. Signals End to Legal Fight Over an 'Enemy Combatant'
abstract: Bush administration officials acknowledge that Justice Dept announcement that it may soon free Yaser Esam Hamdi, American citizen captured in Afghanistan and held as enemy combatant for three years, signals end to one of longest and most important legal struggles to result from Bush administration's war on terrorism; Hamdi was denied access to defense lawyer for most of his confinement, situation that led Supreme Court to sharply rebuke administration; photo (M)

headline: Ouch! Insiders Feel an Unexpected Pinch
abstract: Floyd Norris comment on Google offering notes that investors' hesitance about offering cost insiders millions of dollars; notes Google's top executives wound up taking out only a third as much as they had hoped when company priced its offering; venture capitalists, who had nurtured Google and had expected to take out more money than anyone else, wound up not selling any shares at all; Google prices its offering at $85 a share, far below $108 to $135 it had been expecting and at bottom of new range it sets; in process, it also has to scale back number of shares being sold by selling stockholders; table shows shares held by Google's top executives, and venture capital firms (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Higher Profit For Clothier
abstract: German clothing retailer Hugo Boss says its profit rose 5 percent to 39 million euros ($47 million) in first half on 9 percent increase in sales (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: GMH COMMUNITIES, Newtown Square, Pa., a closely held owner of student and military-family housing, bought 15 student housing complexes in 13 states for $249 million.

headline: Victory for InterActiveCorp In Tax Dispute With Vivendi
abstract: Delware's Vice Chancellor Stephen P Lamb rules in favor of InterActiveCorp, run by Barry Diller, in tax-related dispute with partner Vivendi Universal; InterActiveCorp has estimated that Vivendi is obligated to pay it $600 million in tax payments (M)

headline: 3 Palestinian Activists Face U.S. Charges
abstract: Three men have been charged with raising money for Hamas through a network of U.S. banks, Attorney General John Ashcroft said today.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Premier's Ex-Aide Guilty Of Soliciting Minor
abstract: Dominique Ambiel, French Prime Minister Jean-Pierre Raffarin's former communications adviser, is found guilty of soliciting sex from under-age Romanian prostitute; had resigned from government post (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Bank Restrictions Eased
abstract: Overseas banks in China will be allowed to open more than one branch each year starting Sept 1 as country's banking regulator eases rules to meet China's commitments to World Trade Organization (S)

headline: The Gambler, Breaking Even
abstract: th

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican City: Icon To Be Returned To Russia
abstract: Mother of God of Kazan, Russian icon, is returned to Russian Orthodox church by Pope John Paul II; pontif hopes return will be seen as gesture of unity and improve relations between Orthodox and Catholic faiths; icon was taken from Russia sometine after Bolshevik Revolution and was later given to Pope; dispute between churches has kept John Paul II from visiting Russia (S)

headline: Notes Shed Some Light On Loan Panel Decisions To Deny Aid to United
abstract: Minutes of June meetings of Air Transportation Stabilization Board show panel's members felt United Airlines' bid for $1.6 billion in assistance was based on aulty business plan and they believed that helping airline could hurt rest of industry; board said company could find financing elsewhere and that it had not proved that loan was needed to maintain viable air transportation system; photo (M)

headline: Car Bomb Kills 3 Iraqis as New Round of Violence Breaks Out
abstract: Two U.S. soldiers were killed by another bomb and the deaths of two U.S. marines were reported by the military today.

headline: Lourdes Journal; Where Both Faith and Commerce Join Hands in Prayer
abstract: Several hundred thousand Roman Catholic pilgrims, many of them sick or injured, gather at Lourdes, France, at Sunday Mass with Pope John Paul II; this is pope's second visit to Lourdes; pilgrims generate largest amount of money for town; Mayor Jean-Pierre Artiganave says city needs to improve services to needy pilgrims, because that would allow Lourdes to corner its share of booming pilgrim market; photo (M)

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills 9 at Moscow Subway Station
abstract: Woman blows herself up outside Moscow subway station, killing at least nine people and wounding more than 50 others; photo; Mayor Yuri M Luzhkov says target may have been subway itself because witnesses say woman turned away when she saw police checking bags; Chechen 'black widows,' said to be avenging relatives' deaths, are suspected in latest attack and bombing twin air disasters week ago (M)

headline: Alitalia Tells Unions of Plan to Lay Off 5,000 Workers
abstract: Alitalia tells unions it plans to lay off about 5,000 of its 21,000 employees in move to avoid filing for bankruptcy protection; chief executive Giancarlo Cimoli says airline will further pare its payroll by not renewing contracts of another 1,000 seasonal workers; job cuts are part of general restructuring presented to union leaders that includes plan to split Alitalia's flight operations and ground services into separate units; some unions say they will accept plan while others promise strikes; photo (M)

headline: To the Patio and Beyond: Speakers Without Wires
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column on wireless stereo speaker systems; chart compares features of entries by Sony, RCA, Advent and Acoustic Research; photos; drawing (M)

headline: INVESTCORP SELLS WINDOW UNIT TO CAXTON-ISEMAN
abstract: Investcorp Bank EC, Bahrain-based buyout firm, sells MW Manufacturers Inc, maker of windows and patio doors, to New York-based Caxton-Iseman Capital Inc for $320 million (S)

headline: Exactly What Does a Doctor Sound Like?
abstract: Dr Julia Hunter, in Frequent Flier column, discusses some of air travel experiences; photo (M)

headline: The End User: Europe's picks for home flicks
Military Tribunal Begins for Terror Suspects at Guantnamo
abstract: A Yemeni man is accused of conspiring to commit acts of terrorism for which he could be sentenced to life in prison.

headline: A Coach's Rise, Plotted at the Keyboard
abstract: Baltimore Ravens head coach Brian Billick attributes his embrace of computers and other technology to his team's winning ways; predicts that time will come when players use virtual reality environments to supplement standard practice field; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cadbury Profit Falls 10%
abstract: Cadbury Schweppes says pretax profits fell 10 percent in the first half of 2004, to 285 million pounds ($491 million) (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Machete Attack At Security Agency
abstract: British police arrest man who attacks government building housing domestic division of MI5 with machete and knife; two security guards are injured before man is subdued with stun gun (S)

headline: Lights Out in the Dominican Republic
abstract: Blackouts are plaguing Dominican Republic, nation of 8.8 million that is festering while government and foreign-owned electricity companies feud; its economy, which until recently was Caribbean's most robust, has been thrown into upheaval in last year after banking crisis depleted resources needed to keep nation's lights on; Pres Hipolito Mejia, who lost re-election bid in May, has shown little inclination to confront issue, attributing much of blame for power failures to Leonel Fernandez, who returns to presidency on Aug 16 after four-year hiatus; much of nation's generating system is owned by foreign investors, who bought their stakes during Fernandez's previous term in late 1990's; Meija administration has been engaged in dispute with American companies, including AES Corp, Enron and Goldman Sachs, that control much of nation's electricity industry; Meija has repeatedly called for their executives to be deported; companies claim they are owed at least $300 million, much of it from government itself; photos (M)

headline: Economic Scene; Islamic economic principles may sound like just what the Middle East needs. In practice, things are more complicated.
abstract: Virginia Postrel Economic Scene column on Prof Timur Kuran's book Islam and Mammon: The Economic Predicaments of Islamism; photo (M)

headline: In School's Ruins, a Town Confronts the Unthinkable
abstract: Beslan, Russia, residents are drawn to view school where hundreds of hostages died after Army leaves building; two bombs that exploded amid children and final battle that rolled through halls and classrooms have left trails of destruction and carnage; photos (M)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Bennett Kuhn Varner, Atlanta, hired four employees. Edward J. Raldiris was named senior art director; he had been freelancing and previously worked as senior art director at Brann Worldwide, Wilton, Conn., now Euro RSCG 4D-Wilton, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide division of Havas. Linda Stevens was named senior account executive; she had been a business strategist at Worldspan, Atlanta. Brooke Romanowski was named assistant account executive; she had been account coordinator at Infinitee Communications, Atlanta. And Rochelle Turner was named assistant media planner; she had been agency partnership coordinator at Amrex, Alpharetta, Ga.

headline: A Bakery Cafe Chain Sets Sights on the New York Area
abstract: Panera Bread Co, which has about 640 bakery cafes in 35 states, hopes to open additional 100 to 120 cafes in New York City metropolitan area, many within 50 miles of Manhattan; Panera hopes to enter all five New York City boroughs; photo (M)

headline: Stocks Fall Sharply on Weak Job Figures
abstract: Stocks fell sharply to new 2004 lows today after a surprisingly weak July jobs report heightened concerns about a slowdown in economic growth. The dollar dropped and bond prices shot sharply higher. Oil prices slipped.

headline: One Fighter, 11 Nations and Building Problems
abstract: Dummy version of Joint Strike Fighter, next-generation fighter jet, is presented at international air show at Farnborough, England; plane, also called F-35, is collaboration of contractors in US, led by Lockheed Martin, and 10 other countries and was intended as model of how weapons systems might be made; project, which is expected to cost $200 billion, has run into range of problems, some with plane itself, which is 2,000 pound overweight in one version, and others involving global politics, with some foreign governments petitioning Pentagon for larger share of work; photos (L)

headline: East Germany Swallows Billions, and Still Stagnates
abstract: Hulking concrete housing project of Gorbitz in Dresden is symbol of stagnation and dwindling population in eastern Germany, despite national government's expenditure of $1.5 trillion since reunification in 1990; photo; many Germans now see grand project as failed effort that could drag down rest of country in years to come; experts say needs are not for more renovated housing projects that only remind people of Communist past but for investments and jobs to lure back those who migrated to west (M)

headline: Everything but the Potted Plant; An Ambitious Package To Raise Productivity (And Microsoft's Profit)
abstract: Microsoft is moving to transform Microsoft Office from bundle of personal computer programs into family of software that can put Microsoft's technology deeper into operation of corporate data centers; standard Office programs like Word, Excel and PowerPoint have helped enhance productivity by allowing workers to easily create and modify digital documents; new tools, including SharePoint, LiveMeeting, OneNote and InfoPath, are designed to increase that productivity by facilitating collaboration, communication, planning and document handling; company sees existing base of Office users as its biggest growth opportunity and as best way to fend off challenge from open-source software and other competitors; photos (M)

headline: 2 Aid Workers Are Freed After 3 Weeks in Captivity
abstract: Simona Pari and Simona Torretta, 29-year-old Italian aid workers, are released in Iraq, 21 days after they were kidnapped in audaciuos daylight raid on their office in central Baghdad; release announced by Prime Min Silvio Berlusconi ends national ordeal in Italy, where crowds held street vigils to plead for lives of hostages; intense guerrilla war continues as insurgents ambush British convoy in Basra, killing two soldiers; US warplanes hit terrorist targets in Falluja; insurgents in Sadr City fire mortars at district council headquarters guarded by US troops; photos; four of six kidnapped Egyptian workers reported freed (M)

headline: Is Knighthood Ready for the Ax? How Unchivalrous!
abstract: House of Commons committee's recommendation for drastic trimming of aristocratic honors list draws protests about overturning centuries-old royal tradition in name of modernity, egality and political correctness; photos; committee would trim honors from 16 to 4, replace words like 'empire' and abolish knighthoods and title of dame (M)

headline: Showdown Begins in Movie-Rental Business; Blockbuster Tries a Remake
abstract: Blockbuster, video-rental chain that will be spun off by Viacom in October, is remaking itself, offering online subscription service priced below that of Nexflix and with an in-store pickup option, introducing in-store video game subscriptions and expanding programs that let customers trade both videos and video games; Wall Street has yet to be impressed, and figures from most recent quarter reflect pressures from Netflix, booming sales of DVD's at mass merchants and advent of video-on-demand from cable operators; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Profit For Philips
abstract: Health care and technology company Royal Philips Electronics beats analysts' expectations with second-quarter profit of 616 million euros ($765 million) on 11 percent increase in sales; photo (S)

headline: After a Moment in the Sun, Bear Funds Go Back to Sleep
abstract: Bear mutual funds, which seek to profit from stock or bond declines, made brief comeback this spring, but ended second quarter as one of industry's weakest groups; are typically marketed as way for investors to hedge their portfolios, or for speculators to pursue short-term gains; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago       Prime rate   4.50   4.50   4.00       Federal Funds   1.56   1.55   1.00       3-month Libor   1.80   1.80   1.15       3-month T-bills   1.58   1.59   0.94       6-month T-bills   1.78   1.79   1.02       10-yr. T-infl.   1.75   1.76   2.33       10-yr. T-note   4.12   4.11   4.51       30-yr. T-bond   4.93   4.93   5.31       Telephone bd.   6.21   6.25   6.38       Municipal bds.   4.94   4.94   5.20          (Sources by Bloomberg News; Telerate; The Bond Buyer; British Bankers' Assoc.)

headline: Racetrack Deal Dropped
abstract: MI Developments Inc, Canadian real estate company controlled by Frank Stronach, drops $285 million bid to buy rest of racetrack operator Magna Entertainment Corp; MI faced opposition from shareholdes including Greenlight Capital because companies' businesses are too different (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: United Technologies Corp. said its Sikorsky helicopter unit, Hartford, Conn., agreed to buy Schweizer Aircraft Corp., Elmira, N.Y., to benefit from the U.S. military's increasing demand for unmanned spy planes. Terms were not disclosed.    PDI Inc., Upper Saddle River, N.J., which markets medicines for drug makers, agreed to buy closely held Pharmakon, Schaumburg, Ill., for at least $30 million in cash as it seeks to expand its biotechnology business.

headline: 3 Former Invesco Fund Executives Settle U.S. Case
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission says former Invesco Funds Group executives Timothy J Miller, Thomas A Kolbe and Michael D Legoski are barred from mutual fund industry and agree to pay combined $340,000 in fines to resolve accusations that they helped favored clients make about $58 billion in improper trades; settle without admitting or denying accusations; SEC and New York State Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer sued Invesco (M)

headline: Wily Milosevic keeps Hague judges guessing
Destination Wi-Fi, By Rail, Bus or Boat
abstract: Public transportation departments begin offering wireless Internet access; providing access in moving vehicle is complex; trials, which are being underwritten by grants and sponsors, are under way in several countries to determine technical feasibility of offering mobile Internet access and whether commuters will pay for privilege; photo (M)

headline: Iran Rejects U.N. Call to Freeze Nuclear Enrichment
abstract: Iran also warned that it would drop out of the nonproliferation treaty if its case is sent to the Security Council.

headline: Russian Court Refreezes Shares of Yukos Unit
abstract: Moscow Arbitration Court reverses short-lived victory it gave Yukos on Aug 6, when it overturned baliffs' seizure of Yuganskneftegas, unit that accounts for 60 percent of company's output; unit's shares are seized again after Justice Ministry wins appeal, citing Yukos's 'lack of cash' and its inability to pay $3.4 billion back tax bill for 2000; photo (M)

headline: Giving the Battery, That Stalwart, a Fuel-Cell Challenge
abstract: How It Works column on replacing batteries with methanol based fuel cells to power small electronic devices; drawings show how fuel cells convert chemical energy into electricity; (M)

headline: OECD offering a brighter global outlook
Female Bomber Kills 9 in Moscow, Officials Say
abstract: The bombing came exactly a week after terrorist bombs destroyed two passenger airliners over Russia.

headline: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE
abstract: Developers in California have discovered a growing demand for small commercial condominiums. [C7.]    Colleges and other schools are looking for Manhattan office space. [C9.]    The Supreme Court will hear the appeal of property owners in New London, Conn., who challenged that city's right to exercise its power of eminent domain to take the parcels and turn the land over to a private developer. [A16.]

headline: Kerry, in Midwest Tour, Laments Lost Jobs
abstract: Sen John Kerry begins Midwest presidential campaign tour by bus with patriotic paean to heartland and scathing indictment of Bush administration for being too willing to settle for modest job growth; holds June job growth numbers are not good enough, rally, Cloquet, Minn; notes private-sector jobs are still down 1.8 million since Pres Bush took office; seeks to reach out to small-town and rural America; photos (M)

headline: Israeli Web Site on Nuclear Programs Offers Little That Is New
abstract: Israel's Atomic Energy Commission posts Web site about country's nuclear program, which has always been highly secretive; site is limited to basic information and several long-distance photos; introduction of site comes just two days before visit by Mohamed ElBaradei, director of International Atomic Energy Agency who is calling for talks on nuclear free Middle East (M)

headline: U.S. to sell 'bunker busters' to Israel
Libel Lawsuit for Illustration Is Ground Rarely Walked
abstract: Former Hollinger International chief executive Conrad M Black includes illustrator Barry Blitt in libel suit against Toronto Life and others over article and drawing he claims imply that his conversion to Catholicism was sham and that he is irredeemably evil; his attorney defends suit against illustrator; suit is brought under Canadian law, which unlike United States law, does not automatically make public figures fair game; photo (M)

headline: Microsoft Shares Are Down 3.3%
abstract: Share of Microsoft Corp fall 3.3 percent after drop in investment income caused fourth-quarter profit to miss analysts' forecasts; profit for quarter ended June 30 rose 81 percent, to $2.69 billion compared with earnings of $1.48 billion year ago; sales rose 15 percent, to $9.29 billion (S)o

headline: Singapore Looks to Its New Leader to Restore Old Economic Glow
abstract: Government of Singapore releases upbeat economic forecast on eve of swearing-in of new leader Lee Hsien Loong after long rule of his father Lee Kuan Yew; reality is that Singapore's economy is suffering as regional giants like China and India suck away manufacturing jobs; younger Lee promises that new freedoms introduced in past year would lead to greater change, but he is firm about how much real discussion would be tolerated (M)

headline: SALLIE MAE BUYS MAJORITY STAKE IN ARROW FINANCIAL
abstract: SLM Corp, student-loan company known as Sallie Mae, buys majority stake in Arrow Financial Services; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Big Cable Companies See Next Challenge Around the Corner
abstract: Cable companies, which have been weighed down for years by heavy investments and sagging subscriber growth, are starting to turn corner; are meeting formidable foes in emboldened phone companies; Comcast says it earned $262 million in second quarter, after losing $22 million in same period year ago; revenues rose 10.2 percent, to $5.1 billion, compared with last year; sales at Time Warner increased 10 percent, to $2.1 billion; photo (Market Place column) (M)

headline: REPUBLICANS IN NEW YORK / From moderates to conservatives : Convention delegates just love New Yorkers, especially the police
Who'll Trade Two for a Freddy Adu?
abstract: Upper Deck executives comment on launch of new line of Major League Soccer trading cards; are limiting production of soccer set to increase long-term value; have also included prizes to bolster interest; photo (M)

headline: Health Experts Worry Over Return of Bird Flu in Asia
abstract: World Health Orgn officials voice concern that deadly strain of avian influenza has become nearly impossible to wipe out in Asian birds and poses continuing threat of starting global pandemic in people; chickens that have died of deadly strain have been found in China, Thailand and Vietnam in past week; those countries are killing thousands of birds in hope of preventing virus from evolving into form that passes easily among humans; new outbreak among chickens confirms that disease was not stamped out early this year, when those three countries and seven others reported cases in poultry and killed more than 100 million chickens in response; photo (M)

headline: About Those Fearsome Black Holes? Never Mind
abstract: Dr Stephen W Hawking says he was wrong in controversial assertion he made 30 years ago that information swallowed by black hole could never be retrieved from it; fearsome gravitational abysses can swallow matter, energy, even light; Hawking says that on basis of new calculation, he concludes that physics is safe and information can escape from black hole; esoteric sounding debate is of great consequence to science; had Hawking been right, it would have violated basic tenet of modern physics: that it is always possible to reverse time; Hawking makes announcement at 17th International Conference of General Relativity and Gravitation in Dublin; his new calculation is received by other physicists with reserve; they note that long line of work by various theorists in recent years suggested that information could escape from black holes; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Global Crossing To Restate 2003 Results
abstract: Global Crossing, which left bankruptcy in December, will restate its 2003 results, reversing earlier decision that accounting mistakes could be fixed by taking charge; restatement will increase company's 2003 net loss before gains from Jan 1 to Dec 9 to $295 million from $230 million; will increase rest of year to $11 million from $9 million (S)

headline: Richard Ney, Financial Adviser, Popular Author and Actor, 87
abstract: Richard Ney, who had career as actor before changing course to become investment adviser and best-selling author on finance, dies at age 87; photo (M)

headline: So That's What He's Looking For
Now Newshounds Have More to Watch
abstract: ABC is offering gavel-to-gavel coverage of Democratic and Republican conventions and 24-hour news programming until election on digital sub-channels; to see those channels, viewers must have digital TV with decoding equipment and receive digital signals; photo (M)

headline: IRAQ UPDATE
abstract: Guerrillas launch motor attack near hotel in central Baghdad, killing child and wounding three people; US military postpones preliminary hearing to consider whether Pfc Lynndie England should be court-martialed in Abu Ghraib prison scandal; map (S)

headline: 7-ELEVEN BUYS A.T.M. NETWORK FROM AMERICAN EXPRESS
abstract: 7-Eleven Inc acquires automated teller machine network in its stores from American Express Co for about $44 million (S)

headline: Palestinian Carries a Tune And the Hope of His People
abstract: Palestinian Ammar Hassan will compete with Libyan Ayman al-Atar in Lebanon for title of Arab world's finest singer; Palestinian mobile phone company Jawwal is offering 20 percent discount so people can call in votes; according to rumors, Libyan Col Muammar el-Qaddafi is offering free calls to back his singer; Hamas is critical of whole affair as un-Islamic, but Palestinian public is enthusiastic about competition; contest, begun in February, had thousands of contestants; photo (M)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: The Aguila Trading Corporation, Miami and New York, chose CSA Marketing, Miami, to create campaigns introducing Cerveza Aguila, a Colombian beer, to the United States. The agency will begin with campaigns aimed at Hispanics in Florida and Northeastern states, then branch out to the general market. Billings were not disclosed.

headline: IRAQ UPDATE
abstract: Latest events in Iraq noted (S)

headline: CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER IS APPOINTED AT NCR
abstract: NCR Corp names Peter Bocian chief financial officer (S)

headline: I.B.M. to Share Technology and Designs for New Computer
abstract: IBM plans to announce it will share designs and technology for fast-growing line of computers known as blade servers; move is effort to enlarge IBM's lead in emerging market by making it easier for other hardwarae and software companies to build products for company's machines; announcement reflects IBM's recent strategy of trying to gain competitive advantage by sharing some of its intellectual property with industry partners and by embracing open technology standards (M)

headline: Ryanair Reports Slight Recovery in Quarter
abstract: Ireland's Ryanair says after-tax profit rose 30 percent in first quarter, to 52.6 million euros ($63.4 million) including exceptional items, as number of passengers rose 28 percent from year earlier, to 6.6 million; chief executive Michael O'Leary comments; photo (M)

headline: China Construction Bank defers share listing
Merrill Earnings Rise 10% But Are Short of Estimates
abstract: Merrill Lynch reports weaker-than-expected second-quarter earnings; earings rose 10 percent, to 1.08 billion compared with $977 million year earlier; net revenue was little changed at $5.3 billion (M)

headline: Maker of Paxil to Release All Trial Results
abstract: The New York State attorney general predicted other companies would soon follow GlaxoSmithKline's lead by posting the results of their own studies online.

headline: FREED EGYPTIAN THINKS REMORSE TURNED CAPTORS
abstract: Muhammad Mamdouh Qutb, Egyptian diplomat held hostage in Iraq, believes captors' remorse led to his release after four days; says they roughed him up and threatened to kill him but also came to realize that he is religious Muslim who prays five times daily and is known for teaching Koran to children at local mosque; believes captors were all Iraqis trying to discourage Egypt from helping new Iraqi administration; photo; hostage-taking has emerged as popular, powerful, often deadly tactic, yielding instant publicity and formidable political setback for US-backed government; dozen foreigners have been seized in last week (M)

headline: Arafat Struggles to Pacify Gaza; Israeli Judge Is Killed
abstract: Yasir Arafat is facing perhaps strongest internal challenge to his authority since establishing Palestinian government decade ago; Palestinian Prime Min Ahmed Qurei says he has not received written response from Arafat to his letter of resignation; says he is quitting to protest lawlessness in Gaza and disarray among security forces, which are controlled by Arafat; collapse of Palestinian government would be another blow to Arafat; it is not clear if he would agree to cede some of his broad powers or introduce popular political reforms; in suburb of Tel Aviv, gunman shoots and kills Israeli Judge Adi Azar at close range, fleeing on motorcycle; Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades, linked to Arafat's Fatah movement, claims responsibility but Israeli official says he is 'quite sure' Palestinians were not involved; photos; map (M)

headline: ABB Units Fined $10.5 Million for Bribes
abstract: ABB Vetco Gray Inc and ABB Vetco Gray UK Ltd, units of ABB Ltd, are fined $10.5 million after pleading guilty to bribing Nigerian officials to win contracts for oil exploration (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Bomb Injures American Soldiers
abstract: Remote control car bomb outside Kandahar (Afghanistan) explodes, injuring several American soldiers (S)

headline: Many Delta Pilots Plan to Retire Next Month
abstract: Many Delta Pilots Plan to Retire

headline: Schlepping to Moguldom
abstract: Interview with Haim Saban, who became billionaire by turning Power Rangers cartoon into global franchise and selling it to Walt Disney Co and has since emerged as perhaps most politically connected mogul in Hollywood, using his money in Washington and increasingly around world to try to help Israel; is one of largest individual donors to Democratic Party and its candidates; weighs buying media properties around world as he looks to expand his empire and political reach; has bought largest German television broadcaster, ProSiebenSat1 Media, and turned it around, cutting costs and sending it American hits; photos (M)

headline: Delta Wants $1 Billion in Wage and Benefit Cuts From Pilots
abstract: Delta Air Lines asks its pilots union for wage and benefit concessions worth $1.02 billion each year, including 35 percent pay cut, and says it wants to replace pension plan for more affordable version; $1 billion request is greater than proposal made by Air Line Pilots Association to Delta last week and also tops Delta's original proposal for cuts worth $800 million, made to pilots in January; union says it can make concessions of as much as $705 million each year, equivalent to 23 percent wage and benefit cut, as well as work rule changes; union is seeking stake in company as well as board representation (M)

headline: 3 Directors at Cox to Study Bid By Parent to Take Unit Private
abstract: Cox Communications, nation's third-largest cable television operator, forms committee to consider $7.9 billion bid by its parent, Cox Enterprises, to take company private (S)

headline: She aims to avoid conflicts of interest : EU's Kroes to cut links with business world
Politicus : The French beacon dimmed by racism
abstract: PARIS  Tomorrow is Bastille Day, and if France still represents some kind of universal message, it is having a miserable time matching the dim wattage of its current beacon with that of its luminescent past.

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: Defense Department confirms deaths of marine and two soldiers in Iraq

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: DreamWorks to Sell Stock In Its Animation Business  DreamWorks SKG announced that it planned to sell as much as $650 million in stock in its animation unit and planned to use the proceeds to expand its film production schedule and improve its competitive position.    The share sale, expected to be the biggest initial offering in the entertainment business since MGM went public seven years ago, should allow the DreamWorks founders, Steven Spielberg, David Geffen and Jeffrey Katzenberg, above, and the original backers of DreamWorks to recoup some of their $1.1 billion investment. According to the filing, Mr. Katzenberg will be named chief executive of DreamWorks Animation. [Page C6.]

headline: Write-downs bring wider loss at BAE
Telecom Italia Wins Ruling on Move in Brazil
abstract: Brazil's antitrust agency rules Telecom Italia can regain controlling stake in Brasil Telecom Participacoes, country's third-largest fixed-line telephone company, but imposes some restrictions on scope of Italian group's voting power on board; ruling reverses decision in March that blocked Telecom Italia's return to Brazilian carrier's board on competitive grounds; photo (M)

headline: DYNEGY RESTATES RESULTS RELATED TO ILLINOIS POWER SALE
abstract: Dynegy will restate results for 2003 and first two quarters of 2004 (S)

headline: Racial Tensions Puncture Corsica's Picturesque Setting
abstract: Anti-Arab violence has unsettled French island of Corsica for past year; violence there is magnified version of racist disquiet through rest of France and many other places in Europe as generation born to Arab immigrants comes of age and tries to take its place in societies that were once mostly homogeneous; many fear it is harbinger of conflicts to come as immigration, particularly Arab immigration, reshapes Europe's aging populations; conflict is greatest in tradition-bound areas like Corsica and Alsace, where distinctive local customs are under pressure; photos of bombed Muslim prayer center and racist grafitti on wall in Corsica; map (M)

headline: Airlines That Are in It for the Long Haul
abstract: Nonstop flights are increasingly important to business travelers; travel to and from Asia is booming, and it is expected to continue expanding indefinitely, especially as China emerges as major business destination, meaning more business travelers will be facing longer flights; major airlines are gearing up to get business; Singapore Airlines' new nonstop service from Singapore to Newark discussed; drawing (M)

headline: InVision Inquiry Could Threaten G.E. Deal
abstract: InVision Technologies Inc, which is being acquired by General Electric, could face Justice Department and Securities and Exchange Commission probes after internal inquiry shows possible improper payments by distributors tied to sales outside US; either company can call off $900 million purchase if it is not completed by Oct 31 (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: IPod and Macintosh Sales Help Triple Apple's Profit  Apple Computer said that its fiscal third-quarter profit tripled, led by surging demand for the iPod portable music player and higher sales of its Macintosh computers.    ''It was an outstanding quarter -- our highest third-quarter revenue in eight years,'' said Steven P. Jobs, Apple's chief executive. ''Our Mac sales were up 19 percent, and we're thrilled with that.'' [Page C4.]

headline: Mortgage Rates Decline
abstract: Freddie Mac says average rate on benchmark 30-year mortgage fell to two-month low of 6.01 percent for week (S)

headline: KPMG Developed New Version of Tax Shelter I.R.S. Had Disallowed
abstract: Newly disclosed internal e-mail messages show KPMG, accounting firm under scrutiny for promoting tax shelters found to be abusive, discussed selling new shelter highly similar to banned version more than two years after Internal Revenue Service outlawed original one and any variations; new documents offer glimpse into KPMG's tax shelter activities, but do not show whether KPMG ever sold new version of older shelter, which was called OPIS, or Offshore Portfolio Investment Strategy (M)

headline: Alternate Juror Joins Tyco Panel
abstract: Jury deliberating grand larceny charges against Tyco International's former general counsel Mark A Belnick begins anew after judge dismisses juror and puts alternate on panel (S)

headline: Black Suggests Trust to Control Hollinger Stock
abstract: Embattled Hollinger Inc chief executive Conrad M Black offers to create trust that would control Hollinger shares owned by him or his holding company, Ravelston Corp; hopes move will enable company to recover its right to act as Hollinger International's controlling shareholder; offer comes after Catalyst Fund General Partners Inc, which holds Hollinger Inc bonds, files lawsuit charging Hollinger Inc paid $1.1 million to Ravelston June 30 without consent of its board (M)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: VH1 cable network signs two-year partnership agreement with Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria to raise awareness about HIV and AIDS; VHI and fund will collaborate on commercials (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Currencies: D

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Missile Test
abstract: Iranian Defense Minister Ali Shamkhani announces completion of field test of Shahab-3, new medium-range ballistic missile (S)

headline: People
abstract: John Zeigler, executive vice president at Melbourne office of DDB Worldwide, is named president and chief executive at DDB Asia/Pacific (S)

headline: Washing That Hair Right Off the Man
abstract: Nair for Men, which retails for about $7, is country's best-selling men's depilatory; sales were $2.9 million in 52-week period ending April 18; manufacturer Church & Dwight says it is creating new products that will act more quickly; photo (M)

headline: Another Upward Shift In a Spending Forecast
abstract: ZenithOptimedia raises its forecast for 2004 global advertising spending to gain of 5.7 percent, to $359.5 billion; raises forecast for American ad spending growth to 5.7 percent (S)

headline: Earnings Decline 35% at Barnes & Noble
abstract: Barnes & Noble's second-quarter earnings decline 35 percent, to $8.9 million; sales rise 13 percent, to $1.45 billion (S)

headline: EU looking into Greek debt figures
Elfrieda Dyck, 87, Mennonite Who Helped Thousands Resettle, Dies
abstract: Elfrieda Dyck, Canadian nurse who helped thousands of Mennonite refugees from eastern Europe find new homes in South America, dies at age 87; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: More Illegal Migrants
abstract: Italian Coast Guard deposits boatload of 26 Somali migrants in Lampedusa (Sicily), which is already overcrowded with hundreds of Africans requesting asylum (S)

headline: Laissez-Faire My Gas Guzzler, Already
abstract: Consumers may be buying fewer Hummers while sales of hybrid vehicles are climbing, but for most part, Americans are not altering their fuel-consumption habits as they pay some of highest prices ever for gasoline; some consumers comment; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Retailer Selling Assets
abstract: KarstadtQuelle, European department store operator, will raise 1.6 billion euros ($1.97 billion) by setting shares and assets, including almost half of its department stores; will cut jobs and pay no dividend over two years; names Harald Pinger as chief financial officer to help with overhaul; photo (S)

headline: Bayer to Settle 2,771 Suits
abstract: By Bloomberg News.

headline: Correction
In Competitive Move, I.B.M. Puts Code in Public Domain
abstract: IBM will contribute more than half million lines of its software code, valued at $85 million, to Apache Software Foundation, open source software group; hopes contribution will help make it easier and more appealing for software developers to write applications in Java programming language (M)

headline: Correction
Wall Street Is Ogling the Real Google Payoff
abstract: Andrew Ross Sorkin column h

headline: Young Workers Are Changing India's Politics and Society
abstract: 54 percent of India's one billion plus people are under age of 25; as those people age, seek jobs and raise families, their demands, dreams and frustrations will dominate India; young people express clear split over how India can achieve greatness; highly educated Indians express little faith in government and hail private sector work; poorer, less educated Indians generally trust government and believe state should lead sweeping campaign to end poverty; engineer Rohit Pandey, university students Muhammad Imtiaz and Anamika Chakraborty and train sweeper Munna Kumara quoted; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Karzai To Face 17
abstract: Afghanistan's election commission approves 18 candidates for October 9 presidential election including transitional President Hamid Karzai and his major rivals Tajik leader Muhammad Yunus Qanooni and Uzbek general Abdul Rashid Dostum (S)

headline: BREUNERS HOME FURNISHINGS FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY
abstract: Breuners Home Furnishings, owner of Huffman Koos and Good's Furniture stores, seeks bankruptcy protection to liquidate its assets after it is unable to find buyer or financing (S)

headline: With the Wave of a Wand, a Copied Page
abstract: How It Works column on DocuPen from Planon System Solutions; device is hand-held scanner with self-contained power source that stores up to 100 pages of text and graphics; illustrations (M)

headline: An Oil Shock That Could Be an Economic Stimulus in Disguise
abstract: Economic impact of current surge in oil prices is likely to be much less intense than in past, when oil shocks drove United States into recession; economy is much more energy-efficient than in past and inflation remains under control; rising energy prices are slowing rise of interest rates, providing unexpected economic stimulus; photo (M)

headline: De la Renta To Offer Line With Prices Below $100
