abstract: Oscar de la Renta, one of world's best-known couturiers, will introduce moderately priced line of women's clothes--with rhinestone-buttoned silk tops, embroidered sweaters and broacade jackets--designed for midlevel stores like Macy's West, Belk and Dillard's; his day suits sell for more than $3,000, but pieces in this newest line will sell for less than $100; photo (M)

headline: 3 Technology Giants Surge in Quarter
abstract: Motorola reports net loss of $203 million for quarter ended July 3; earned 21 cents a share, absent one-time adjustments, beating analysts estimates; EMC, data storage leader, reports second-quarter net income jumped to $192.8 million from $81.7 million in 2003 period; Sun Microsystems reports net income of $795 million for fiscal fourth quarter ended June 30 (M)

headline: Carmakers Face Huge Retiree Health Care Costs
abstract: General Motors, nation's largest private purchaser of health services and drugs, faces staggering health care costs of 1.1 million Americans, including under 200,000 active workers and hundreds of thousands of dependents and retirees like Ernest Pusey, who, at 109, is older than company and one of 240 retirees over age 100; photo; graph; company faces not only soaring costs but competition from Japanese and German rivals that have virtually no US retirees yet and have nationalized health systems at home; economist Uwe Reinhardt notes serious long-term disadvantage of saddling American businesses with obligation that competitors do not have (M)

headline: A Cellphone User's Lament
abstract: Josh Tane letter on June 20 article notes taking two-year cellphone contract to save on phone backfired when his phone broke after one-year warranty expired, while his insurance proved worthless because of its high deductible

headline: Venerable Yacht Builder Tries to Regain Sea Legs
abstract: Boat builder Palmer Johnson of Sturgeon Bay, Wis, is out of bankruptcy and its executives plan return company to its former glory by introducing sleek new motor yacht design and concentrating on building boats; president Mike Kelsey Jr comments on company's plans; photo (M)

headline: New chief faces debt, unions and market : French utility's next era
COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PIPER JAFFRAY COS., Minneapolis, the investment services firm, said that it would buy Vie Securities, New York, a provider of electronic trading services, for $15 million.    ALBERTSON'S INC., Boise, Idaho, the supermarket chain, said that it had purchased the closely held Bristol Farms, Carson, Calif., the owner of gourmet and specialty food stores. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Delta Aims to Cut Jobs 12%, Drop a Hub and Reduce Pay
abstract: Delta Air Lines will cut 12 percent of its work force over next 18 months and says bankruptcy filing will be 'real possibility' as soon as end of month unless it can get its problems under control; chief executive Gerald A Grinstein tells employees that airline plans to eliminate 6,000 to 7,000 jobs by 2006, partly through buyouts and attrition; airline, which has been battling with its pilots' union over $1 billion in proposed wage and benefit concessions, unveils sweeping revamping plan; says all employees face significant wage cuts; plans to eliminate as many as four types of aircraft and will dismantle its hub in Dallas while adding flights from cities on East Coast to Florida; will spare its low-fare operation Song, whose demise has been widely rumored; will add dozen planes to Song's fleet; graph; photos (M)

headline: A Duet That Straddles the Political Divide
abstract: Gregg and Evan Spiridellis of Web-based JibJab Media create two-minute animated film ridiculing Pres Bush and Sen John Kerry, keeping it light and avoiding partisan nastiness that is typical of much of political discourse on Web; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Unemployment Rate Rises
abstract: Seasonally adjusted unemployment rate in Australia rose in July to 5.7 percent from 5.6 percent in June (S)0

headline: 2 Top Palestinians Settle Dispute With a Kiss
abstract: Yasir Arafat and his prime minister pledged to pursue limited reforms that have been attempted previously without success.

headline: All Thumbs, Without the Stigma
abstract: Cellphone text messaging has re-established reliance on thumb as power digit in hierarchy of hand; those most facile are teens and young adults; photos (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.25   4.25   4.25       Federal Funds   1.44   1.35   0.99       3-month Libor   1.68   1.67   1.13       3-month T-bills   1.50   1.47   0.93       6-month T-bills   1.75   1.66   1.02       10-yr. T-infl.   1.88   1.85   2.24       10-yr. T-note   4.29   4.26   4.43       30-yr. T-bond   5.07   5.06   5.35       Telephone bd.   6.34   6.51   6.33       Municipal bds.   4.97   4.95   5.20          (Sources by Bloomberg News; Telerate; The Bond Buyer; British Bankers' Assoc.)

headline: In Contest to Show First Scenes of Hussein in Courtroom, ABC and CNN Come Out Winners
abstract: ABC and CNN manage to place only Western journalists, aside from news pool reporter, inside Baghdad courtroom as Saddam Hussein listened to charges he will face when he goes to trial; every news organization interrupts its other programming to air scene live except NBC, which continues regular programming; NBC News spokeswoman later says this was 'bad call' (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Today.

headline: Powell Holds Unusual Meeting With Egyptian Leaders and Activists
abstract: They discussed American support for political reform in the region, support often viewed here with broad skepticism.

headline: Greek Orthodox Patriarch Dies With 12 Others in Copter Crash
abstract: Greek Orthodox Patriarch Petros VII of Alexandria dies along with dozen church officials in helicopter crash just minutes from landing at Mt Athos in northern Greece; bodies of patriarch and six others are recovered; cause of crash is unknown; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Gaza Evacuation Plan Sped Up
abstract: Israel's Prime Minister Ariel Sharon announces plans to speed up dismantling of Gaza settlements; government discussions with World Bank reveal that all but one settlement, which will become hospital, are to be demolished (S)

headline: Political Papers Become Dailies To Blanket The Conventions
abstract: Delegates to Democratic National Convention in Boston are receiving complimentary daily editions of four political publications based in Washington, DC: National Journal, Congressional Quarterly, Roll Call and The Hill, whose staffs have temporarily moved to Boston and will move again in August to New York for Republican convention; their traveling newspaper war is in large part extension of their escalating rivalry in Washington; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Government To Sell Phone Stake
abstract: World Business Briefing: Italy: Government To5

headline: DEAN FOODS PLANS TO STOP MAKING WEIGHT-LOSS DRINKS
abstract: Dean Foods Co, citing poor sales, will stop making weight-loss shakes and drinks; reportedly will close its nutritional-drinks plant in Michigan in fourth quarter (S)

headline: Can Little-Known Heroes Be Hollywood Hits?
abstract: Eighteen Hollywood films are previewed at Comic-Con International, nation's largest comic convention, which has become vital promotional tool in marketing campaigns of films based on comic books, graphic novels and original science-fiction and horror fare; such exposure and the buzz it is intended to generate have grown in importance because many of most well-known comic book characters have been exploited and Hollywood is tapping lesser-known stories; photo; graph of domestic box-office grosses of films basede on comic book characters (M)

headline: Philippine Leader Promises to Create More Jobs
abstract: Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo is sworn in as 14th president of Philippines; she promises to create 10 million jobs in next six years, balance budget, improve tax collection, provide cheap medicine for poor and unite nation, which has had divisive political climate since ouster of Ferdinand E Marcos almost 20 years ago; photo (M)

headline: Detroit Profits Most From Loans, Not Cars
abstract: Stock market reacts cautiously to improved earnings reports from Ford Motor Co and General Motors Corp because companies are making money largely as banks lending money and their competitors like Toyota Motor Corp are far more profitable in industry's core business of manufacturing cars and trucks; GM reports second-quarter earnings totaled $1.3 billion, up 49 percent from period year earlier; Ford reports $1.17 billion in net income in second quarter; auto sales in Asia remains especially lucrative for GM, which has capitalized more successfully on surging Chinese market than Ford has; photo; map; chart (M)

headline: Singapore's New Prime Minister Goes With the Tried and True
abstract: Lee Hsien, set to become Singapore's prime minister, announces cabinet that includes his father, Lee Kwan Yew, in new post of 'minister mentor' and predecessor, Goh Chok Tong, as senior minister; Lee signals with cabinet of familar faces that he plans no significant changes that might rock nation; will remain finance minister (M)

headline: U.S. Clears Stent Sales by Guidant
abstract: Guidant receives Food and Drug Administration approval to sell stents that are inserted into main neck artery to reduce risk of strokes, making company first manufacturer cleared to sell that version of device in US (M)

headline: Adultery as a Criminal Offense May Still Have a Life in Turkey
abstract: Conservative lawmakers in Turkey insist on reviving proposal to criminalize adultery, even as Parliament nears completion of reform package to bring Turkey's laws in line with European Union human rights standards; Prime Min Recep Tayyip Erdogan is said to be backing demands of religious hard-liners for adultery law, despite moderates' protests about damaging Turkey's hopes of starting membership talks with European Union (M)

headline: TELEFLEX SAYS EARNINGS WILL MISS EXPECTATIONS
abstract: Teleflex Inc shares fall 9 percent after company says second-quarter earnings will miss Wall Street's expectations because of higher costs (S)

headline: S.E.C. Orders Mutual Funds To Cease Incentive Pay
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission orders mutual funds to stop paying higher commissions to brokers who promote companies' funds; also requires portfolio managers to reveal investments in funds they supervise; SEC, in wake of trading and sales abuses that reglators say harmed returns of long-term investors, has passed 10 rules in its overhaul of fund regulation; photo (M)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Advertising Information Services, New York, was renamed Media Information Services.

headline: Natural Gas Seems Headed the Way of Oil: More Demand, Less Supply, Higher Cost
abstract: American demand for natural gas is growing far faster than supply from domestic sources or from friendly neighbors like Canada, and it is probable that within a decade, US will become significant importer of gas from politically troublesome regions like North Africa, Middle East, former Soviet Union and Caribbean, transported in liquefied form by giant tanker ships; prospect raises possibility that natural gas will become another vulnerable front in American diplomacy and energy security, posing same quandaries and threats that crude oil does now; US now imports only 16 percent of its natural gas, nearly all of that coming by pipeline from Canada and only 2 percent brought in on LNG tankers; complexity and expense of bringing LNG to market prompts industry experts to warn that as demand for gas grows -- chiefly from electric-generating plants -- supply may not be there to meet it and price will rise; photos; graph (L)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction: Marakon Associates consultant interviewed in Aug 1 article on return to corporate growth is Mike Baxter, not Brewster

headline: Pyongyang stalls on next round of talks on suspected arsenal : Envoys view North Korean blast site
Stop Me If You've Seen This One Before
abstract: TiVo, which changed way people watch television with its 1999 introduction of digital video recorder, now faces onslaught of competition from cable system and satellite operators, which are quickly eroding its once-dominant market share; plans quirky advertising drive to promote major strategic and marketing changes aimed at broadening subscriber base; stock price graph; drawing; photos (M)

headline: Bombs Miss 2 Ministers but Kill 5
abstract: Two ministers of the interim Iraqi government were the targets of bombings that killed at least five bodyguards and wounded several bystanders.

headline: UN rights chief praises South Korea
World Business Briefing | Australia: Real Estate Trust Acquired
abstract: Australian real estate trust Ma

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Yahoo Japan Profit Soars
abstract: Yahoo Japan Corp, country's biggest Internet auction operator, says its fiscal first-quarter profit surged 83 percent, to 8.31 billion yen ($76.5 million), on gains from advertising and online sales (S)

headline: Mexico Economy Aided by Exports
abstract: Mexico's economy grew 3.9 percent in second quarter over year ago period; government expects economy to expand 4 percent this year; exports rose 21.5 percent in June over year ago (S)

headline: U.S. to Give Border Patrol Agents The Power to Deport Illegal Aliens
abstract: Homeland Security Department, citing terrorism concerns, plans to give border patrol agents sweeping new powers to deport illegal aliens seized within 100 miles of Mexico and Canada without giving them chance to appear before immigration judge; officials say deportation process in immigration courts is sluggish and cumbersome, with illegal immigrants often waiting over year before being deported; say immigrants who have spent up to 14 days in United States will typically be deported within eight days of apprehension; say most Mexicans and Canadians will still have their cases heard in immigration court, as will those from other nations who show credible fear of persecution; agents will focus on immigrants from nations other than Mexico and Canada (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Trade Surplus Widens
abstract: Brazil posts trade surplus of $3.43 billion in August, up from surplus of $2.67 billion year earlier; accumulated trade surplus for year is $21.95 billion, compared with $15.13 billion in first eight months of 2003; exports and imports totaled $9.1 billion and $5.6 billion, respectively (S)

headline: In Chaos, Palestinians Struggle for a Way Out
abstract: A People Adrift, first of two articles on Palestinians of West Bank and Gaza Strip after four years of Arab-Israeli conflict; contest is under way between warlords and democrats, between Islamists and secular leaders, between those who would destroy Israel and those who would live beside it; Israel's barrier against West Bank Palestinians is sign that after 37 years of occupying West Bank and Gaza, it seeks to cut itself off from Palestinians, to give up Gaza, to hold onto as much of West Bank as it can, and to retain Jewish majority in democratic state; for Palestinians there is no such clarity; they have made no national decisions, and mechanisms for making and enforcing any are breaking down; in Jenin, city of 45,000, many residents rely on themselves rather than Palestinian Authority; Mayor Waleed A Mwais blames Israel, saying it destroyed all forms of authority and now everyone has their own weapon; criticism of aging Palestinian leadership, even of Yasir Arafat, has reached new pitch; reform-minded leaders struggle to find way to start over; 3,200 Palestinians and 1,000 Israelis have died violently in conflict that has become way of life; photos; map (L)

headline: Can Galloping Britain Catch Gloomy Germany?
abstract: While Germany is still the strongest economy in the European Union, it also boasts an unemployment rate double the U.K.'s rate.

headline: Treasury Bills Set For This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.    At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 1.43 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 1.66 percent, and the rate on the four-week issue was 1.35 percent.

headline: AOL Expands Shopping Features
abstract: America Online to offer new shopping Web site, In-Store, that will include elements of both traditional online shopping mall and comparison shopping engine as part of its revamped shopping section; site will let consumers research products side by side before buying; consumers have yet to fully embrace comparison shopping; graph of comparison sites (M)

headline: Hague War Crimes Tribunal Frees a Convicted General
abstract: Appeals court of war crimes tribunal in The Hague throws out conviction on major charges of Tihomir Blaskic, former Bosnian Croat general, and reduces his sentence to 9 years from 45 years; he will become most senior offical to be released, after spending more than eight years in tribunal cell; new ruling throws out indictment charging him with crimes against humanity and war crimes against Muslims in Bosnia in 1993; appeals panel claims lower court misinterpreted law, made factual errors, obtained insufficient evidence and meted out unfair punishment; several British and Balkan military officers testified in favor of Blaskic; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Growth Pace for 2nd Quarter Is Revised Downward, to 2.8%
abstract: Commerce Department revises downward to 2.8 percent from 3 percent second quarter gross domestic product annual growth rate; University of Michigan reports its consumer confidence index fell in Aug to 95.9 from 96.7 in July (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Inflation Rises
abstract: Brazil's inflation rate rose 0.91 percent in July after rising 0.71 percent in June; accumulated inflation reached 4.42 percent in first seven months of year, while index has risen 6.81 percent in 12 months through July (S)

headline: IAMGOLD SHAREHOLDERS REJECT WHEATON RIVER MERGER
abstract: Shareholders of Imagold Corp reject proposed acquisition of Wheaton River Minerals for 2.3 billion Canadian dollars ($1.7 billion); move bolsters prospects for hostile bid for Iamgold by Golden Star Resources Ltd (S)

headline: WET SEAL HIRES ADVISER TO HELP EXPLORE ALTERNATIVES
abstract: Wet Seal Inc, struggling retailer of teenage apparel, hires Rothschild Inc as financial adviser to help it explore strategic alternatives (S)

headline: On eastern Germany, president breaks an old taboo
Pier 1 Lowers Outlook
abstract: Pier 1 Imports lowers second-quarter profit forecast (S)

headline: IRAQI INSURGENTS REPORT GRABBING 6 MORE HOSTAGES
abstract: Iraqi insurgent group calling itself Holders of the Black Banners says it has kidnapped six more foreign hostages; threatens to behead one every 72 hours unless their employer shuts down operations in Iraq; kidnappings come day after Filipino truck driver is released when his government complies with insurgents' demand and withdraws its soldiers from Iraq over objections of American and Iraqi officials; new victims are all truck drivers working for Kuwaiti company; they come from India, Kenya and Egypt, countries that do not have soldiers in Iraq, although Iraqi Prime Min Iyad Allawi recently asked India and Egypt to contribute forces; insurgents' target seems to be reconstruction effort; violence surges around Iraq; American troops battle insurgents in Samarra, killing what military official says were six attackers, and in Ramadi, five people are reportedly killed in clashes with US soldiers; in Baghdad, rocket hits hospital, killing four patients, and car explodes on street, killing another four people; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: S.E.C. Investigating Gtech
abstract: SEC opens investigation into Gtech Holdings Corp's operations in Brazil; Brazilian government is also suing company over its contract with Caixa Economica Federal, state-owned bank that runs Brazil's lottery (S)

headline: When Beauty and Value Are in the Beholder's Eyes
abstract: Investing column on index devised by New York University professors Michael A Moses and Jianping Mei that tracks value of art sold, mainly by Sotheby's and Christie's auction houses; by their calculations, value of art has kept pace with Standard & Poor's 500-stock index over last 50 years; other people with knowledge of financial matters and collectibles are far less convinced of their investment potential; photo; graph (M)

headline: Spanish Seek Oil Off Cuba; Potential Shift In Gulf Output
abstract: Spain's Repsol YPF hired Norwegian oil drilling platform Eirik Raude in June at cost around $200,000 per day to search for oil in Cuban waters, in narrow sector of Gulf of Mexico off northwestern coast; venture was established with Cubapetroleo, government-owned oil company; significant find by Repsol would be boon for Cuba, which imports most of its fuel, mainly from Venezuela, and often struggles to find hard currency to pay bills; could shake up dynamics of oil production in Gulf of Mexico, dominated for decades by US and Mexico; big oil discovery could change political debate in US over decades-old sanctions against Cuba, which prohibit most commerce with country; last thing that American energy companies want is to be trapped on sidelines by sanctions while European, Canadian and Latin American rivals are free to develop new oil resources on doorstep of US; Halliburton has said it wants economic sanctions against Cuba lifted; map; photo (M)

headline: Study Finds U.S. Companies Shifting Profits Overseas
abstract: Martin A Sullivan study for journal Tax Notes finds American multinational corporations increased profits taken in 18 nations with no taxes or low rates to $149 billion in 2002, up 68 percent from $88 billion in 1999; holds their subsidiaries now generate profits mainly in tax havens rather than in nations where they conduct most of their business; Commerce Department data not cited in study show American companies took 17 cents of each dollar of worldwide profits in tax havens in 2002, up from 10 cents in 1999; Sullivan notes use of tax havens to cut tax rates makes investing offshore more lucrative than investing in United States, interview (M)

headline: Catching Up to the Cost of Global Warming
abstract: World Resources Institute and Sustainable Asset Management predict that General Motors and Ford Motor stand to lose more than any other automakers in complying with regulations that countries around the world will adopt over next decade to curb global-warming emissions; some of their foreign competitors, particularly Toyota, may actually be helped by tougher regulations because they have already invested much more in fuel-efficiency technologies; photo; graph (M)

headline: California Looks Anew at a Truck-Stopping Device
abstract: Growing concerns about truck bombs prompt California authorities to look again at three-year-old invention designed to disable big rigs hijacked by terrorists; critics have dismissed it as flawed and waste of money; strong opposition from California trucking and oil industries killed state legislation that would have mandated devices on vehicles carrying flammable or combustible liquids; now, after latest terror alert, California High Patrol Comr Dwight Helmick says he will make appeal for device directly to federal authorities; photo (M)

headline: Bittersweet Taste of Change
abstract: Sergio Zyman, who managed ill-fated 1985 introduction of New Coke, remains relentless proselytizer of repositioning images of products and services as head of own consulting firm; retired from Coca-Cola Co for second time in 1998; photo (M)

headline: Critics Say Bush's Intelligence Chief Would Be Toothless
abstract: Members of Sept 11 commission join with Congressional Democrats in saying that Pres Bush's proposal for national intelligence director would not grant nearly enough power to position to end turf battles and duplications; Bush would not give director control over $40-billion annual intelligence proposal or veto over appointees to head agencies; Bob Kerry and John Lehman testify on commission recommendations; photo (M)

headline: Delta to Cut Up to 7,000 Jobs in Restructuring Bid
abstract: Delta will cut up to 10 percent of its work force over the next 18 months as part of a restructuring plan that the airline said would save $5 billion a year in costs by 2006.

headline: Foreign Buyers Step Up Treasuries Purchases
abstract: International investors stepped up purchases of US securities in June for first time in five months amid faster economic growth in America compared with Europe and Japan; Treasury Department says net purchases rose to $71.8 million in June from revised $65.2 billion in May; foreigners bought $40.5 billion of Treasuries as yield on benchmark 10-year note neared its highest in two years (M)

headline: Sure, I'll Chip In For College Tuition. But It Costs What?
abstract: Opinion Research Corp study for Fidelity Investments finds 95 percent of teenagers say they should pay part of cost of college, but 64 percent have little idea of cost; graph of findings (M)

headline: Panel Says Conrad Black Ran a 'Corporate Kleptocracy'
abstract: Conrad Black and other controlling shareholders of Hollinger used $400 million for personal perks, a new report says.

headline: U.S. Diplomat Starts New Job By Deferring To the Iraqis
abstract: US Ambassador to Iraq John D Negroponte, speaking for first time in Baghdad, draws distinction between new American diplomatic presence in Iraq and former Coalition Provisional Authority; emphasizes that his role will be to assist new Iraqi government; Negroponte's goals include training Iraqi soldiers to assume security responsibilities, helping government hold elections in January 2005 and pushing ahead on reconstruction projects that have been hindered by sabotage (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Hotel Concern Ousts Chief
abstract: InterContinental Hotels Group ousts chief executive Richard North (S)

headline: Overseer Says Fannie Mae May Be Due for Shake-Up
abstract: Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight raises possibility of management shake-up at Fannie Mae to clean up its culture and finances after harshly criticizing mortgage giant for improper accounting practices in report; submits list of corrective steps to Fannie Mae board, arguing that problems discovered thus far are grave enough that 'immediate action is warranted'; criticism of Fannie Mae's management appears to be sharp rebuke to its chief executive Franklin D Raines, even though he is seldom mentioned in regulators' report; graph; photo (M)

headline: MEMO PAD
abstract: Forecast International reports that business jet output rose 14 percent in first quarter from same 2003 period; predicts total of 10,800 business jets will be manufactured over next decade; Bombardier Inc says it flew new Global 5000 business jet model from San Francisco to London for display at Farnborough Air Show; Skytrax survey rating airline cabin staffs finds international travelers gave top rating to Malaysia Airlines; JetBlue Airways got top rating in North America; photo (M)

headline: World Briefings
abstract: ASIA.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: TM Advertising, Irving, Tex, opens division to create unconventional campaigns that rely on design, street marketing, music, art and film (S)

headline: Israel Approves Plan to Compensate Settlers
abstract: Israel will pay roughly $200,000 to $300,000 to each Jewish family that leaves the Gaza Strip under a withdrawal proposal.

headline: A South African City Loses Luster After the Gold Rush
abstract: Welkom, South Africa, once thriving gold-mining city, has deteriorated because South Africa's gold industry is in decline; most white miners have fled, while black miners have clustered in mushrooming shantytowns around central city or move into abandoned row houses; Welkom once produced 35 percent of South Africa's gold, and mining magnate Ernest Oppenheimer built world-class racecar track, gardens, parks, Olympic-length pools and broad avenues for white miners, while black miners languished in single-sex hostel; map; photo (M)

headline: A First Experience of War In a House for the Dead
abstract: US marines who have trained for years but not previously experienced battle find themselves in harrowing fight with rebel cleric Moktada al-Sadr's militia in sprawling cemetery on outskirts of Najaf; push through to inner ring of old city after two days of intense fighting at close quarters; many marines are eager to finish off militia, but others would be satisfied with peaceful solution, acknowledging that risk of damage to shrine of Imam Ali prevents them from bringing in their heaviest weapons (M)

headline: Cox Is Said To Consider Move to Take Cable Private
abstract: Cox Enterprises plans $8 billion offer to buy out public minority shareholders of its cable business and make Cox Communications wholly owned subsidiary; believes shares are undervalued in face of investor concerns about increased competition from satellite providers, other issues (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sun Cuts Prices On Some Computers
abstract: Sun Microsystems cuts prices on some computer models as much as 35 percent to reclaim market share from its rivals IBM and Dell; discounts on servers and workstations run through Nov 30 and apply to computers using Linux or Microsoft Windows operating systems and running on semiconductors from either Sun or Advanced Micro Devices (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Strike Looms At Bellsouth
abstract: Communications Workers of America members who work for BellSouth decide to allow their leaders to call strike, if needed, when their contract expires on Aug 7 (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: New Look At Sectarian Violence
abstract: India's new Railway Minister Laloo Prasad Yadav launches investigation into February 2002 Gujarat train fire that sparked sectarian rioting that killed more than 1,000 people (S)

headline: New Swell of Insurgent Violence Rolls into Baghdad
abstract: A botched rocket attack on two hotels used by foreigners paralyzed the city center.

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Aug 22 article about Merrill Lynch brokers who are accusing firm of sex discrimination, which included outdated name for building in Midtown Manhattan that houses their office; it is Citigroup Center, no longer Citicorp (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: An Early Retirement Plan
abstract: About 1,000 Communications, Energy and Paperworkers Union members at Bell Canada, Canada's leading phone company, accept early retirement packages as part of cost-cutting plan (S)

headline: I.B.M. Employees Get $320Million in Pension Suit
abstract: IBM agrees to pay $320 million to current and former employees to settle in part class-action lawsuit over its pension plan; case may affect millions of workers at many companies and nonprofit organizations; under settlement, IBM's liability in case will be limited to additional $1.4 billion if courts uphold ruling that new pension plan discriminates against its older workers and is illegal; agreement comes as Federal District Court Judge G Patrick Murphy was preparing to rule on how much IBM should pay to 130,000 current and former employees; he ruled year ago that company discriminated against its older workers in 1990's when it changed its traditional pension plan twice, leaving them with so-called cash-balance plan, which combines some features of traditional pensions with other features of 401(k) plans; at heart of case is whether cash-balance pension plans by definition discriminate against older workers; since 1995, fifth of large companies have converted to cash-balance plans, which allow employees to accrue benefits at fixed rate over their careers and permits companies to shrink long-term pension debt and reap accounting gains while still providing benefits to employees (M)

headline: EU urged to rethink its approach to security
Class-Action Status Is Upheld for Doctors Suing Insurers
abstract: US Appeals Court upholds class-action status for lawsuit brought on behalf of at least 600,000 doctors contending that health insurers WellPoint Health Networks, UnitedHealth Group, Prudential Insurance, PacifiCare Health Systems, Health Net and Humana regularly reduced payments for medical services; rules defendants must stand trial on charges of violating federal Racketeering Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (M)

headline: Early Steps, Maybe, Toward a Democracy in Iraq
abstract: Experiment in democracy in Iraq is at once inspiring and troubled, full of potential but not at all assured of success; caucuses are convening around country to select 1,000 delegates, who will hold national conference in Baghdad in next week with goal of voting--openly and freely--on 100-seat transitional council that will oversee government of interim Prime Minister Iyad Allawi until national elections are held in Jan; conference is also meant to function as opportunity for national dialogue, in which for first time since fall of Saddam Hussein, Iraqis from all religions, regions and political and ethnic groups begin to discuss way forward; because of widespread violence and fragmentation, United Nations is urging Iraq to postpone conference at least briefly; fear is that thousand or more fledgling politicians would make tempting terror target; major issue is that many groups considered crucial to any broad national dialogue are refusing to take part, largely because they view process as controlled by United States; photo; chart (M)

headline: Blair Defends War in Iraq In Parliament
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair forcefully defends decision to join US in Iraq war, telling spirited session of Parliament that intelligence assessments at time left 'little doubt' that Saddam Hussein was trying to develop prohibited weapons; also says Hussein would never have fully cooperated with arms inspectors without UN resolution authorizing force, which France opposed (M)

headline: MELLON FINANCIAL REPORTS RISE IN SECOND-QUARTER PROFIT
abstract: Mellon Financial Corp, which runs Dreyfus mutual funds, reports second-quarter net income rose to $176 million from $175 million in 2003 period (S)

headline: 'Fired' Topped by 'Hired' At the Trademark Office
abstract: Patent and Trademark Office turns down bid by Donald J Trump to register 'You're Fired,' tag expression from The Apprentice television show, for games and other playthings, saying it could be mistaken for 'You're Hired!,' educational board game from Franklin Learning System Inc that gives middle-school students taste of job hunt; photo (M)

headline: It's Available in Sleek, but It's Going to Cost You
abstract: Some companies are remaking humdrum housewares and telephones for those with elite taste; stylish gadgets come complete with array of bells and whistles, and prices to match; photos (M)

headline: COST OF BENEFITS CITED AS FACTOR IN SLUMP IN JOBS
abstract: Rise in cost of employee health insurance seen as major factor in employment slump, despite nearly three years of uninterrupted economic growth; health insurance now costs nation's employers annual average of $3,000 per worker; health premiums are sapping corporate balance sheets even more than rising cost of energy; there are million fewer jobs in United States now, after 11 straight quarters of economic growth, than there were at beginning of 2001, just before recession; spurt in job growth between Mar and May raised hopes, but job growth slowed sharply again in June and came to virtual standstill in July, when businesses added mere 32,000 jobs; also in Aug, and for first time this year, more businesses let workers go than hired new ones; rising cost of health insurance premiums, and of health care, is being driven by expensive new drugs, medical advances that require costly new machines for diagnostic tests and reaction to past restrictions in managed care health plans that sought to rein in costs; in presidential campaigns, both President George W Bush and Democratic party candidate John Kerry have proposed measures for tackling high cost of health insurance; their positions detailed; photos (M)

headline: Putin Moves to Strengthen Antiterror Forces in South
abstract: Kremlin imposes tighter security measures in region where hundreds were killed in school hostage-taking, first public step in program of heightened security announced earlier by Pres Vladimir V Putin; Putin is shown on television meeting with Interior Min Rashid Nuralyev, who says groups stationed around Chechnya would be commanded by senior officers from Interior Ministry and other ministries' forces; several local human rights groups issue statement calling for broader approach that would address root causes of separatist conflict in Chechnya; mood of uncertainty and anguish continues to grip country following latest terrorist attack that killed hundreds of schoolchildren, among others; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Trade Deficit
abstract: Philippines posts trade deficit of $142 million in June, reversing last year's surplus, as value of imports of oil and other petroleum products more than doubles (S)

headline: Yukos Warns of Export Halt, Driving Oil Futures to Record
abstract: Russia's largest oil producer Yukos warns tghat it might be forced to stop exporting, as dispute between company and government intensifies; remote prospect of losing more than 1.6 million barrels each day that Yukos produces is enough to rattle traders at time when demand is high and OPEC is pumping near its capacity; price of crude oil for September delivery settles at $42.90 per barrel, up 2.5 percent, after reaching record $43.05 per barrel; crude oil is up 32 percent so far this year, and has quadrupled since deep slump of late 1998; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Libya: Relief Agreement
abstract: John Powell, World Food Program deputy executive director, announces that agency has signed deal with Libyan government to allow passage of aid trucks through Sahara to reach Sudanese refugees in Chad and Darfur (Sudan) region (S)

headline: Forget parity, East Germans told
Technology Briefing | Deals: LG.Philips Raises $1 Billion In Public Offering
abstract: LGPhilips LCD Co, maker of liquid-crystal displays, raises $1 billion in initial public offering to finance new flat-screen plants (S)

headline: Remove Wall, Israel Is Told By the U.N.
abstract: UN General Assembly approves symbolic resolution demanding Israel obey World Court ruling to dismantle security fence on West Bank and pay compensation to Palestinians affected; vote is 150-6, US voting against 'unbalanced' measure; supporters include entire European Union; Israeli Amb Dan Gillerman points out that barrier was made necessary by Palestinian terrorism; photos (M)

headline: Bidding War May Shuffle List of Japan's Biggest Banks
abstract: Analysts say surprise announcement that second bank, Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group, is interested in merging with UFJ Holdings could touch off first major takeover battle for Japanese bank and offers clearest sign yet that industry has entered more competitive era; UFJ has announced plans for tie-up with Mitsubishi Tokyo Financial Group; either combination would create bank that would be world's largest and could establish dominant position in Japanese banking; Sumitomo Mitsui's announcement raises possibility of hostile takeover battle for a Japanese bank; chart; photos (M)

headline: COLONIAL BANCGROUP TO ACQUIRE FLORIDA BANK
abstract: Colonial BancGroup will buy Union Bank of Florida for $174.8 million in cash and $58.3 million in stock (S)

headline: Sony Set to Exert Influence on Discs
abstract: Purchase of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer by group led by Sony Corp will not only give company enormous film library but also considerable power in its fight to set format for next generation of digital video discs; transition to new discs, which are not expected to be widely available until next year at earliest, could generate billions of dollars in royalties to developers of technology that runs them; Sony, as part of Blu-ray Disc Association, consortium of major electronics makers, is at forefront of efforts to develop new technological standard; rival HD DVD group, led by Toshiba and NEC, is championing its own format (M)

headline: City of Fishermen in Pakistan Becomes Strategic Port
abstract: Gwadar, Pakistan, city of mostly poor fishermen, is set to emerge as strategic deepwater port, transformation spurred by interest of newly independent landlocked Central Asian republics in warm-water port and China's active role; China is paying $198 million of port's estimated costs through loans and grants; Pakistan is spending $50 million; development has also brought complications, helping fuel unrest in Baluchistan province; port will help southwestern Pakistan

headline: Man Arrested in Chicago in Connection With Truck-Bomb Plot
abstract: Law enforcement officials arrest Gale W Nettles, man they say was plotting to blow up Everett M Dirksen Federal Building in Chicago with truck bomb containing ammonium nitrate fertilizer, same material used in Oklahoma City bombing; US Atty Patrick J Fitzgerald says Nettles acted alone and has no connection to international terrorism; says he was embittered at federal courts after being convicted of counterfeiting, and he told fellow inmate of his plot to bomb building; says inmate alerted law enforcement officials, who put Nettles under intense surveillance after he was released from jail (M)

headline: 2 More Hostages Seized, but Progress Reported in Talks for Release of 7 Others
abstract: Abu Musab al-Zarqawi's terrorist group kidnaps two Turkish truck drivers and threatens to behead them if their employer continues to deliver goods to United States troops in Iraq; Turkish government confirmes release of another kidnapped Turk; Sheikh Hisham al-Dulaymi from Ramadi mediates in effort to free seven other drivers held by insurgents; photo (M)

headline: Libbey Closing a Factory
abstract: Glassware maker Libbey Inc is eliminating 140 jobs, or about 3.7 percent of its work force, as it closes plant in City of Industry, Calif (S)

headline: British Regulators Set Deadline for Bid on Retailer
abstract: British regulators give Philip Green until Aug 6 to make formal offer for Marks & Spencer retail chain; Green has approached retailer with informal bids twice since May and has been turned down both times by its board; regulators say Green cannot make bid for six months if he walks away; photo (M)

headline: Adding an Asterisk To the Jobs Scorecard
abstract: Jack McGann letter on Aug 1 article holds jobs picture is much worse than when Pres Bush took office

headline: MACE SECURITY INTERNATIONAL IS BEING REVIEWED BY S.E.C.
abstract: Mace Security International says Securities and Exchange Commission inquires about company's dealings with investor Price Legacy Corp; wants information and documents relating to Price Legacy's sale of 1.88 million Mace shares; also wants information on Price Legacy's payment of $8.95 million to Mace in exchange for comapny's removal of sales restriction from 1.75 million of shares that were sold (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Lexmark Earnings Rise 34%
abstract: Lexmark International Inc, computer printer maker, reports second-quarter net income of $136.6 million, up 34 percent from 2003 period; shares fall after company warns of lower-than-expected third-quarter profit (S)

headline: Free-Spending Chvez Could Swing Vote His Way
abstract: Venezuelans, in extraordinary recall referendum, will vote on Aug 15 on whether to dismiss Pres Hugo Chavez, who has alienated Bush administration with his anti-US bombast and polarized nation with promises to use oil wealth for social revolution; photos (M)

headline: Kremlin's Choice Wins in Chechnya Election
abstract: Maj. Gen. Alu Alkhanov had been assured of his victory in the presidential election since he declared his candidacy in June.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Crackdown On Money Laundering
abstract: Brazilian police, as part of nationwide crackdown on money laundering and black-market currency, arrest infamous currency dealer Antonio de Oliveira Claramunt in Sao Paulo; Claramunt is accused of sending $500 million abroad from 1996 to 2002 (S)

headline: Iraqi Insurgents Add an Egyptian Diplomat to Spate of Recent Kidnapping Victims
abstract: Iraqi insurgents kidnap Muhammad Mamdouh Qutb, third-ranking official at Egyptian Embassy in Baghdad, in continuing spate of abductions aimed at US allies and nations that might assist interim Iraqi government; rebel Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr rejects beheading of hostages as tactic of resistance; map (M)

headline: Expected Dates for the Release of Major Economic Indicators This Week
abstract: Today.

headline: A Warehouse Giant Picks Up Space in Greater New York
abstract: AMB Property Corp, industrial real estate owner, increases its New York-area presence, acquiring 1.5 million square feet of distribution space at Kennedy Airport and in Fairfield, NJ; Fairfield is hub for distribution companies that mostly serve New York area; map; photo (M)

headline: How to Run a B&B (but Still See the World)
abstract: Article on various groups that offer workshops on basics of innsitting; says though terms 'inn' and 'bed-and-breakfasts' are often used interchangeably, technical difference is that inn may serve lunch and dinner as well as breakfast; chart; photos (M)

headline: In a Fight Over King Crab, Russians Show Their Claws
abstract: Kamchatka, rugged, remote peninsula famous for its red king crab, is deprived of its mainstay by decision of federal government in faraway Moscow, which allotted this year's quotas for catching king crab in coastal waters, rather than auctioning quotas off as in past; as result, Kamchatka's biggest fishery companies received none; decision can be attributed to convoluted government bureaucracy, vagaries of Russia's feral form of capitalism, and corruption; adding to problem is that catch is shrinking; photo; map (M)

headline: U.N. Agency to Urge Vaccinations to Halt Avian Flu
abstract: United Nations Food and Agricultural Orgn will issue new guidelines urging wider use of vaccine for birds to help stop continuing spread of avian influenza virus that is deadly to birds and threat to human health; new findings show virus has become permanent fixture in many Asian countries, and cannot be wiped out by culling, quarantines and other standard measures alone; there has been resurgence of avian influenza this month in China, Thailand and Vietnam, and it continues to spread in Indonesia; influenza experts fear scenario in which individual becomes infected with both avian virus and human influenza virus; under such circumstances, viruses could swap genes to create new virus to cause global epidemic that would be difficult to control; human toll so far has been small but significant; photo (M)

headline: Brazil Pressing for Favorable Treatment on Nuclear Fuel
abstract: Brazil hopes to begin operating uranium enrichment plant this year, arguing that it deserves 'dignified and differentiated' treatment, recognizing that it is not a rogue state and its nuclear program is peaceful; International Atomic Energy Agency is seeking agreement on unimpeded access to enrichment factory in Recende, but Brazil is balking at granting access to technological aspects; Brazilian plan poses challenge for Western nations seeking to rein in Iranian nuclear program; Brazil, which has fifth-largest known reserves of uranium, ultimately hopes export enriched uranium, but some independent specialists consider those ambitions unrealistic and note glut of uranium on market (M)

headline: TBWA London Wins Top Commercial Award
abstract: London office of TBWA Worldwide, part of Omnicom Group, takes top honors in commercials category at annual International Advertising Festival, Cannes, France; other winners noted (S)

headline: A Scanner Plays Catch-Up, Exposing Details in Shadows
abstract: As digital technology advances and gadget prices retreat, features and performance that were once solely the province of professionals become available to average consumers. It has happened with digital cameras, and now it is happening with scanners.    The Epson Perfection 4180 Photo is a case in point. The 4180 has a maximum optical resolution of 4,800 dots per inch, which is two to four times the resolution of most comparably priced scanners. It also has an exceptional dynamic range, meaning it should be able to extract detail from shadows and highlights more effectively than most household scanners. The 4180's film and slide adapter accepts medium format as well as 35-millimeter slides and negatives.

headline: Fine-Tuning a Browser For a Mac With OS 9
abstract: Q. I have an iMac with Mac OS 9 as the operating system. America Online version 5.0 is the only AOL program that is compatible with my computer, but it will not allow me to browse Web sites. Can you recommend another Internet service?    A. Shortly after the introduction of its Mac OS X operating system, Apple Computer ceased development of earlier versions of its system software, including Mac OS 9. Many software companies stopped making new versions of their programs for the older Mac system, choosing instead to concentrate on Mac OS X.

headline: Symbolic gesture to giant economy : Beijing invited to G-7 talks
AIDS fund uses sharp message : Gold campaign cuts glitz (folo)
Iraqi Foreign Minister, Restoring Ties With World, Urges 'Mutual Respect'
abstract: Iraqi Foreign Min Hoshyar Zebari says interim government is preparing to appoint 43 ambassadors abroad as it reopens diplomatic ties with other nations; says countries in region should show 'mutual respect' by not getting involved in Iraq's internal affairs and by clamping down on any cross-border flow of foreign fighters or aid to insurgency; says all of Iraq's neighbors are interfering in 'many ways'; photo (M)

headline: Target Gives New Look to the Bronx
abstract: A Major Retail Presence J

headline: Financial Controls in Iraq Are Criticized by Overseers
abstract: International Advisory and Monitoring Board on Iraq says ministries of Iraqi government who are now able to spend billions in oil revenues lack proper auditing and financial controls, opening door to widespread corruption; board also criticizes American occupation authorities for lax accounting of their own as they spent nearly $20 billion in Iraqi funds through late June, when sovereignty was transferred to interim government; overseers say they have seen no evidence of fraud by American authorities, but they complain that Pentagon has not provided details about noncompetitive contract awarded to Halliburton Co last year, which provided $1.4 billion in Iraqi funds for importing fuels (M)

headline: 2 Suspects in Murder of Journalist Are Arrested
abstract: Officials provided few details about the men or their motive, and Russia's chief prosecutor later suggested the arrests were disclosed prematurely.

headline: Senator Steps In as the Referee in Washington's Turf Battles Over Counterterrorism
abstract: Article on Sen Susan Collins, Maine Republican who may have toughest assignment in Washington: drafting legislation to overhaul way nation combats terrorism; she is chairing hearings that are exposing conflicts among White House, intelligence agencies and members of 9/11 commission; has long history of taking on Washington bureaucracy and has bucked Pres Bush on several issues; some Republicans fear her close working relationship with Democratic Sen Joeseph I Lieberman could lead her to side with Democrats on crucial details of legislation; Democrats say her independence goes only so far; for her part, she maintains that she will challenge president if she sees fit; photo (M)

headline: Nokia puts new tools in phones
U.S. Asks That Court Halt United's Plan for Pensions
abstract: Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp says total shortfall in United Airlines' pension plans has grown more than previously disclosed, to $8.3 billion, and it asks judge overseeing United's bankruptcy proceedings to stake recent loan agreement that requires airline to suspend its contributions to plans; government says loan agreement is invalid because airline cannot fulfill it without violating federal pension law (M)

headline: C.I.A. Deleted Large Sections, Officials Say
abstract: Congressional officials say estimated 20 percent of Senate committee's report on faulty Iraq intelligence was deleted at request of CIA; say most of deleted sections relate to national security; deletions have renewed debate about whether CIA officials were trying to suppress certain information to avoid embarrassment; National Security Archive executive director Tom Blanton says public report deleted committee's reasoning for three key conclusions: that CIA misled Sec of State Colin L Powell, that it withheld reservations about its information from Oct 2002 white paper that was instrumental in making case for war against Iraq and that it misled Sen Carl Levin (M)

headline: Gamers Who Like Mobility Have a New Benchmark
abstract: Dell's Inspiron XPS laptop is geared toward gaming with its advanced graphics system from ATI; photo (S)

headline: 'We Were Supposed to Humiliate Them'
abstract: Interview with US Staff Sergeant Ivan Frederick on torture at Baghdad's Abu Ghraib prison.

headline: FRUIT OF THE LOOM TO CLOSE FACTORIES IN IRELAND
abstract: Fruit of the Loom will lay off 630 employees and shut its remaining two factories in Ireland over next five years to move its spinning, knitting and dyeing operations to Morocco, where it employs 1,700 people and has cheaper labor costs (S)

headline: Retailers feel a worldwide chill
British Airways to Examine Labor Shortage
abstract: British Airways will conduct internal investigation into labor shortage that caused it to cancel more than 100 flights in one week at its London Heathrow airport hub, stranding thousands of passengers; has cut 13,000 jobs and reduced costs by $1.6 billion over three years to counter competition from low-cost carriers and decline in air travel after terrorist attacks in 2001 (S)

headline: When the Koran Speaks, Will Canadian Law Bend?
abstract: Canadian Society of Muslims is testing boundaries of Canada's professed multiculturalism by seeking to apply Shariah legal code to settle disputes over property, inheritance, marriage and divorce; cites 1991 Ontario law giving religious authorities power to arbitrate civil matters as long as participants volunteer and are free to appeal in Canadian courts; Islamic scholar Syed Mumtaz Ali explains; photo; critics say women, often kept isolated even in Canada, would be deprived of rights (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Schering-Plough Is Said To Settle Medicaid Charges  The drug giant Schering-Plough has agreed to pay $350 million in fines and plead guilty to criminal charges that it cheated the federal Medicaid program, according to people involved in the case.    The settlement, expected to be announced next week with federal prosecutors in Philadelphia, stems from a six-year investigation prompted by three whistle-blowers who accused Schering-Plough of selling its products to private health care providers for far less than it sold them to Medicaid. [Page A1.]

headline: In Sudan, Hunter and Hunted Alike Invoke the Prophet
abstract: Darfur crisis in Sudan is ethnic and political conflict between Arab and black African Muslims; Darfur troubles may have originated in power struggle among top Muslim leaders in Khartoum; Islamic hard-liner Hassan al-Turabi was stripped of official positions and arrested by rival Pres Omar Hassan al-Bashir, but rebuilt power base by appealing to black Muslims of Darfur; clerics urge people to unite against foreign intervention; photo; maps (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil futures fall; crude oil for Aug delivery falls 35 cents to $38.39 a barrel; graphs; table (S)0

headline: The Collections / New York : Lauren's take on Hollywood
U.S. Lays Out Case in British Court to Extradite Cleric
abstract: Lawyers acting on behalf of US government in London seek extradition of Abu Hamza al-Masri, Egyptian-born Muslim cleric accused of supporting Al Qaeda; Masri was arrested in London in May; faces charges of hostage-taking and conspiracy in connection with attack in Yemen in 1998 on 16 tourists (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: Wider African Role In Darfur Rejected
abstract: African Union-led peace talks in Nigeria that are directed at ending Darfur (Sudan) conflict cannot find immediate solution to disarming government-backed militias; Sudan's Agriculture Minister Mazjoub al-Khalifa, who is government's chief negotiator, rejects union Chairman Olusegun Obasanjo's offer to send troops to region (S)

headline: The Power of Youth
abstract: Young Iranians look to excessive drug use and parties to escape their stifling lives. Following the conservatives' victory in parliament, many have turned away from politics. Religious hard-liners want to see a return to the Islamic model state.

headline: ALCOA CUTS PRODUCTION AFTER STRIKE AT CANADA FACTORY
abstract: al

headline: CONSOL ENERGY EXPECTS LOSS IN THIRD QUARTER
abstract: Coal producer Consol Energy Inc will have net loss of 30 to 40 cents per share in third quarter because of lower production and higher costs; equipment problems at mines and labor shortages in eastern Kentucky contributed to production drop (S)

headline: Social Democrats avoid big losses but conservatives slip : Local vote seen giving Schrder's party hope
S.E.C. Approves Google I.P.O.; Company Cuts Share Price
abstract: Google closed the auction after receiving approval from the Securities and Exchange Commission and set the share price at $85.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Yahoo To Start New Business Directory
abstract: Yahoo will start test of new service to help users find stores and other resources in specific neighborhood; new service is meant to replace Yahoo's existing online Yellow Pages listings with broader directory that combines information from traditional Yellow Pages directories with results of searches of Web and other databases (S)

headline: Ecological protest turns 'waste' into a fashion statement
An Investor's 'Gong Show' for Billion-Dollar Dreamers
abstract: Draper Fisher Jurvetson venture capital firm holds contest in which entrepreneurs pitch their ideas for billion dollar businesses to Timothy C Draper via Internet; Draper and his partners have reputation for investing in barely formed start-ups most rivals would not consider; photos; drawing (M)

headline: Terror Arrests in South Africa Raise Questions About Islamic Extremism
abstract: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 8  A string of international arrests of South African citizens, followed by sensational reports in the last week of terror plots against tourism and financial sites, is raising new questions about the depth of Islamic extremism in a country known for its racial and religious tolerance.

headline: Arafat Struggles to Resolve Leadership Crisis
abstract: Yasir Arafat is facing perhaps the strongest internal challenge since establishing the Palestinian government a decade ago.

headline: US Air Locked In Down-to-Wire Contract Talks With Its Pilots
abstract: US Airways is locked in tumultuous bargaining on wage and benefit cuts with its pilots' union, whose backing is critical if airline is to avoid another bankruptcy filing; airline is asking major labor unions for contract concessions worth $800 million; Air Line Pilots Association appears to be softening its resistance to US Airways' demands; photo (M)

headline: Rash of Kidnappings in Gaza Challenges the Authority of the Palestinian Government
abstract: Palestinian militants in Gaza Strip stage three kidnappings, seizing four French aid workers and two Palestinian security officials; release French captives and Ghazi al-Jabali, chief of Palestinian police in Gaza; are still holding other official; rash of abductions reflect rampant lawlessness and internal Palestinian feuding in Gaza and is seen as challenge to Yasir Arafat's authority; photo (M)

headline: As With Other Chip Makers, Sales Begin to Stall at Philips
abstract: Royal Philips Electronics becomes latest semiconductor company to say its chip sales have begun to stall, at least temporarily; says third-quarter sales in dollars will not exceed this year's second-quarter result of 1.4 billion euros ($1.72 billion); forecasts 27 percent increase in third-quarter sales measured year to year; chief executive Scott McGregor comments; photo (M)

headline: Ruling May Return Assets to Ex-Chief at Freddie Mac
abstract: Federal Judge Richard J Leon rules Freddie Mac's former chief executive Leland C Brendsel may recover more than $50 million in compensation that Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight froze during probe into $5 billion profit restatement; says argument that regulator had power to freeze Brendsel's assets was overreaching; Brendsel may recover more than $50 million as result of court decision; photo (M)

headline: For Eisner, a Sharp Turn on a Trip Through Disney
abstract: Investors, reacting to Michael Eisner's announcement that he will step down as chief executive when his contract expires on September 30, 2006, push Walt Disney stock 30 cents higher, to $23.16; reaction, on surface, is odd, given that those who bought Disney shares on day in 1984 when Eisner took reins, and reinvested dividends along way, would have gained 1,869 percent profit, compared with 1,009 percent for Standard & Poor's 500 index; most of gains came in first decade, bef ore president Frank Wells's death in plane crash in 1994, and investors have tended since then to blame Eisner alone for company's failures and not credit him with successes; graph; photo (M)

headline: More BlackBerry-equipped handsets and a sleeker smart phone : Nokia woos the business market
Israeli Military Pulls Back From Gaza After 5-Week Operation
abstract: The operation was intended to stop Palestinian rocket fire, but within hours of the retreat, Palestinians unleashed a new round of salvos.

headline: OAKLEY TRIMS ITS EARNINGS FORECAST FOR THE YEAR
abstract: Sunglass maker Oakley cuts its earnings forecast for 2004 and says its second-quarter sales will be less than analysts expected (S)

headline: Justice Is Blind, but a Court Surveillance System Sees All
abstract: New York State is implementing integrated video surveillance system for all court buildings; images are sent over court system's private high-speed network, not public Internet, to assure security from hackers; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Payless Shoesource Inc will exit its 181 Parade shoe stores by January (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Citigroup To Sell Nikko Stake
abstract: Citigroup Inc to sell 117.4 million shares in Japane

headline: Investigators Seek Causes of Near-Simultaneous Jet Crashes in Russia That Killed 89
abstract: Russian investigators scramble to discover what caused two passenger jets to crash almost simultaneously shortly after taking off from Moscow, killing at least 89 people; it has raised fears that terrorists might have infiltrated Domodedovo International Airport, Russia's most modern airport, in highly coordinated act; authorities are examining wide range of possible causes, and not ruling out case of awful coincidence; Russian news media notes that precedent for multiple passenger jets leaving airfield and crashing short while later is 9/11 terrorist attack in United States; fears of foul play are driven not only by improbable circumstances of crashes but also by reports that crew of second airline had activated emergency signal indicating that plane had been hijacked just before it disappeared from radar screens; airport security has been increased throughout Russia; photo; map (M)

headline: Army Report Criticizes Training and Practices at Detention Centers
abstract: Broad new Army report concludes that serious problems in training, organization and policy regarding military detention operations in Iraq and Afghanistan contributed to abuses at Abu Ghraib prison; inquiry by Lt Gen Paul T Mikolashek criticizes Army policy on detainee operations as cold-war relic; says 30 major findings paint sobering picture of conditions, policies and practices that left Army ill prepared to hold and question thousands of Iraqi detainees at Abu Ghraib; earlier drafts found no systemic abuse of American-run prisons in Iraq or Afghanistan; report is not expected to assign blame to senior American officers in Iraq; that task will be left to one or more of half-dozen other inquiries under way (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Drug Maker's Profit Rises
abstract: World Business Briefing: France: Drug Mar

headline: In Private World Of Hedge Funds, A Famous Name
abstract: Carl C Icahn wants to start $3 billion hedge fund, joining oher prominent financier who have looked to assemble hedge funds in last few months; photo (M)

headline: PFIZER TO PAY $430 MILLION FOR CLAIMS AGAINST UNIT
abstract: Pfizer agrees to pay $430 million to resolve claims against subsidiary, Quigley Corp, which sold products containing asbestos in 1970's; Quigley files for bankruptcy protection (S)

headline: Globalist : Why the 'good times' feel so good to us now
Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Telstra To Buy Half Of Wireless Network
abstract: Australia's Telstra Corp acquires half of Australia's only high-speed wireless network from Hutchison 3G Australia, owned by billionaire Li Ka-shing, for 450 million Australian dollars ($317 million) (S)

headline: France Wants Sharon to Explain His Call for Jews to Flee
abstract: Israeli Prime Min Ariel Sharon's appeal to Jews of France to emigrate immediately to Israel to escape anti-Semitism at home meets with angry reaction from French officials, lawmakers, commentators and Jewish leaders; office of Pres Jacques Chirac issues statement saying Sharon will not be welcome in France until he explains himself; France, secular republic, does not count its citizens according to religion or ethnicity and some prominent French Jews even resent being identified as Jews, saying they are citizens of France first; France's Interior Ministry reports 135 anti-Semitic acts in first half of 2004 compared with 127 acts for all of 2003; in Israel, government spokesman seeks to play down Sharon's remarks, claiming he was misunderstood (M)

headline: More Speed, More Stuff
abstract: Diffusion Group survey finds that Internet broadband uses rank ahead of dial-up users when it comes to ownershp of several kinds of high-tech devices, including DVD players, hand-held computers and digital cameras; graph; photo (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Corr

headline: PARMALAT GETS NEW DEADLINE TO EMERGE FROM BANKRUPTCY
abstract: The General Electric Capital Corporation and Citigroup Inc. gave the United States unit of Parmalat Finanziaria, Italy's biggest food company, two more weeks to file a plan to leave bankruptcy and avoid default. The unit, Parmalat USA Corporation, has until Sept. 30 to file the plan and until Dec. 31 to win court confirmation, the company said in papers filed with the United States Bankruptcy Court in New York. The filing deadline had been yesterday. ''The company is trying hard to meet the new deadline, but can't guarantee it will,'' said Stephen B. Selbst, Parmalat USA's bankruptcy lawyer. ''We informed the court we may need additional extensions, but we're working hard to try and meet this deadline.'' Parmalat is using funds from G.E. and Citigroup to pay employees and vendors.

headline: Olympians May Need Gold for Cellphone Bill
abstract: International Telecommunications Users Group reports that mobile phone companies reaped unjustifiably high profits from roaming charges at Athens Olympic Games, not because roaming charges, which are fees added when cellphone user is outside his or her phone network and another carrier handles call, were raised for Games, but because everyday roaming rates are too high; says roaming charges are going up, rather than down, even though mobile operators have formed alliances promising to bring them down; photo; graph (M)

headline: Xerox Profit Doubles; Forecast Is Raised
abstract: Xerox Corp says second-quarter profit more than doubled on lower costs and higher sales of wider-margin products; net income rose to $208 million from $86 million year earlier; revenue fell 1.7 percent, to $3.85 billion; equipment sales rose 3.7 percent, to $1.76 billion; company raises its 2004 forecast (S)

headline: Turning Confidence Into Business Success
abstract: Paul B Brown reviews sampling of management books by business and sports figures; photos (M)

headline: Founder of Adelphia Is Found Guilty of Conspiracy
abstract: John Rigas and his son were found guilty today of conspiracy in connection with the collapse of the cable television company.

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Lindows And Microsoft Settle Suit
abstract: Computer software giant Microsoft agrees to pay Lindows Inc $20 million to settle dispute over Lindows name, which Microsoft says is too similar to its Windows trademark; will gain rights to Lindows.com and other Internet domain names; Lindows will change its name to Linspire (S)

headline: COEUR D'ALENE SHAREHOLDERS ADVISED TO BUY WHEATON
abstract: Coeur d'Alene Mines Corp says Institutional Shareholder Services recommends that Coeur's shareholders vote to buy Wheaton River Minerals (S)

headline: Claritin Is Awarded To Euro RSCG
abstract: Schering-Plough expands its relationship with Euro RSCG Worldwide by awarding agency account of its Claritin allergy drug (S)

headline: Pope, Visiting Lourdes Shrine, Urges Compassion for the Sick
abstract: Pope John Paul II visits shrine at Lourdes in France; is ill with Parkinson's Disease, but he comes to Lourdes to urge compassion for sick, not seek cure for himself; greets thousands of pilgrims, many of whom use wheelchairs and canes; meets with French Pres Jacques Chirac and urges Europe not to turn back on Christian heritage; Chirac has opposed any mention of Christianity in European Union constitution and strongly supports secularism; photo (M)

headline: Ousted Shell Chairman Assails Regulators
abstract: Sir Philip Watts, in his first public statement since he was ousted as chairman of Royal Dutch/Shell Group, says British financial regulators violated his rights in their probe of company's restatement of its oil and natural gas reserves; denies he misled investors; Sir Philip's challenge is first time that findings by Financial Services Authority have been directly contested by executive at company that was subject of investigation; statement is released as Sir Philip's lawyers ask Financial Services and Markets Tribunal, independent appeals body in Britain, to review regulator's actions; photo (M)

headline: Adelphia Seeks $3.2 Billion From Rigases
abstract: Adelphia Communications Corp, which is trying to raise money to repay creditors, asks bankruptcy judge to order founder John J Rigas and his sons to repay $3.2 billion to company; Rigas and his son Timothy were convicted last month of conspiracy, bank fraud and securities fraud for looting company; son Michael was acquitted; court will consider company's request for repayment in October (M)

headline: With So Many Gasoline Choices, What's a Driver to Do?
abstract: Matt Richtel article on various types of gasoline available for an automobile and whether all choices are necessary; drawing (M)

headline: Lowe weighs bringing in another outsider to help it regain its financial and creative footing.
abstract: Makeover of Lowe & Partners could accelerate as agency considers hiring Tony Wright, well-known senior executive from Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, for new high-level post (M)

headline: ST.JUDE MEDICAL TO STOP MAKING HEART DEVICE
abstract: St J

headline: Back to the good days for U.S.-to-Europe mail
abstract: PARIS:  CORRECTION PUBLISHED IN THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE DATED

headline: Coors Merger Is Announced Amid Some Molson Dissent
abstract: Coors

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Symantec Cuts Profit On Accounting Error
abstract: Symantec Corp cuts its previously reported first-quarter profit and sales to reflect accounting errors; revised figures noted (S)

headline: If Failure Is Normal, How Do Workers Fare?
abstract: Advice for workers at small companies on protecting selves in light of high small business failure rate; need to be aware of any brewing problems and to take appropriate action before things go awry cited; state laws may offer protections to workers at businesses too small to be covered by certain federal laws; drawing (special section, Small Business) (M)a

headline: IRAQ UPDATE
abstract: Recap of latest events in Iraq; map (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Microsoft Chief Predicts Bright Future, Plus Cuts  In his annual message to Microsoft employees, Steven A. Ballmer, left, the chief executive, predicted that the number of personal computers in use worldwide would increase 60 percent, to 1 billion, by 2010.     But he also left no doubt that Microsoft must cut costs, like its recently announced moves to reduce coverage for employees on branded prescription drugs and to reduce the discount that employees receive on purchases of Microsoft stock. [Page C7.]

headline: Report Says Banks Helped Parmalat Hide Fraud
abstract: Report ordered by Milan prosecutors finds that main banks of Parmalat Finanziaria, bankrupt Italian dairy company, allowed it to hide true state of its finances for more than decade (S)

headline: Could That Rally Be Partisan?
abstract: Market Week column on trying to filter stock performances for party leanings as Democrats prepare to begin their national convention, with Republicans following with theirs at end of Aug; graph (M)

headline: Knock 3 Times on the Ceiling (to Turn on the DVD Player)
abstract: What's Next column examines new technology that allows user to communicate with electronic devices by rapping on tabletop or other rigid surface; technology uses small sensors that pick up vibrations, which are sent to audio input for analysis and interpretation; drawing (M)

headline: Prime minister of Luxembourg is cast as first 'Mr. Euro'
Frequent Fliers Wonder if Their Miles Have a Future
abstract: Many frequent fliers, especially business travelers, are concerned about their frequent flier miles in light of so many bankruptcies in airline industry; e-Rewards Market Research survey finds active frequent fliers hold average of 70 percent more unredeemed miles than they did during bankruptcies of 1990's; InsideFlyer magazine estimated in 1992 that travelers had amassed total of 1.4 trillion miles; photo (M)

headline: British Worry That Drinking Has Gotten Out of Hand
abstract: Britain has one of highest levels of binge drinking in Europe; Prime Min Tony Blair worries that binge drinking, defined as five or more drinks in one sitting, will become new British disease; some fear it already has; cite as contributing factors cheaper and more readily available alcohol, changing drinking patterns, steep increase in drinking among young women and decline in old standards of civility; problem is already costing society $35 billion a year, according to government estimates; photo; graph (M)

headline: As Egyptian Diplomat Is Freed, 2 Jordanians Are Kidnapped
abstract: Captors release Muhammad Mamdouh Qutb, Egyption diplomat who had been kidnapped in broad daylight outside mosque in Baghdad on July 23; Qutb says he was told his abduction was to protest Egypt's willingness to meet with interim Iraqi Prime Min Iyad Allowi last week; says no deals were made to obtain his release; spate of kidnappings continues, with two Jordanian truck drivers taken by group demanding that their employer stop doing business in Iraq; gunmen kill Interior Ministry official Col Musab al-Awadi and two of his bodyguards in drive-by attack; total of five other Iraqis are killed in car bombing in Mosul and drive-by shooting in Basra; terrifying and relentless campaign continues to challenge interim government and allied soldiers who support it; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Bank Posts Profit
abstract: The largest private bank, Banco Bradesco, said its profit rose 24 percent in the second quarter from the period a year earlier, citing an increase in demand for credit. The bank said it earned 641.3 million reais ($211 million) in the quarter, compared with 519 million reais a year earlier. The bank's credit portfolio expanded 6.4 percent from the first quarter to 58.4 billion reais at the end of June, showing growth from corporate and individual clients. That left the bank's credit portfolio 10.1 percent larger than it was at the end of June 2003.   Todd Benson (NYT)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Oil Company Plans A Charge
abstract: Royal Dutch/Shell Group plans to take $330 million charge in second quarter because some of its assets in North Sea did not yield oil as expected; charge does not affect Shell's proven reserves; Shell also says it will sell some pipelines in US and its retail, commercial and marine assets in Peru (S)

headline: Israel to Reroute Path of Barrier in West Bank
abstract: Defense Ministry says Israel revises planned path of sections of West Bank separation barrier not yet built in effort to comply with Israeli court ruling that called for barrier to be less burdensome on Palestinians; says it is not reconsidering sections already built; Palestinians say they will continue to oppose all sections of barrier built inside West Bank; Israel is insistent that all changes be based on Israeli court ruling, not International Court of Justice ruling; Israel's opposition Labor Party agrees to take part in talks on joining Prime Min Ariel Sharon's coalition government; Sharon discusses barrier with senior American envoys Stephen Hadley and Elliott Abrams; Israel reports its troops shot to death local Islamic Jihad commander, Jenin; Palestinians identify man as Numan Tahaynah (M)

headline: In Indonesia, Businesses Hopeful After Election
abstract: Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono, former general experienced at countering terrorists, has apparently defeated Indonesia's Pres Megawati Sukarnoputri; many business leaders believe Susilo will uproot corruption and revive investment; photo (M)

headline: A Day After Alert, Markets Are Stable
abstract: The stock market managed to end in positive territory as investors seemed to take the specific threats in stride.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Internet Provider Slips
abstract: South Korea's KT Corp says second-quarter net income unexpectedly fell 22 percent from year ago to 223 billion won ($192 million), while sales rose 2.9 percent to 3 trillion won; graph (S)
