headline: Air Canada Files Plan to Exit Bankruptcy
abstract: Air Canada files plan to emerge from bankruptcy protection that projects long-term debt of 2.87 billion Canadian dollars ($2.15 billion), or less than one-quarter amount it had when it filed for protection from creditors 15 months ago (S)

headline: People
abstract: Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide names Brian Fetherstonhaugh chief executive at its OgilvyOne division, succeeding Reimer Thedens, who will remain chairman until he retires next year; names John Seifert to succeed Fetherstonhaugh as global brands chairman (S)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Fatal Protests
abstract: One demonstrator is killed and six others are wounded in clash with Kisumu (Kenya) police; demonstrators are protesting against government's inability to adopt new constitution, which was promised by President Mwai Kibaki by end of June (S)

headline: Witness in Stewart's Trial Fined $2,000
abstract: Douglas Faneuil was spared from serving a prison sentence or probation for his role in Martha Stewart's stock trade.

headline: Kerry Generates Hits
abstract: Nielsen/NetRatings reports that visitors to John Kerry's campaign Web site more than doubled in third week in August, as charges and countercharges over his service in Vietnam made headlines; opposition sites also enjoyed increases during debate; photo; graph (S)

headline: Oil Nears $50 as Gulf Storms Curtail Output
abstract: Oil futures prices rise to new record; remain just below $50-a-barrel mark during trading session, but rise above $50 in electronic trading after hours; rises reflect concern that recent hurricanes have hurt United States output at time when commercial supplies are low and possibility of new clashes between army and regional group of militants in Nigeria that would threaten output (M)

headline: Washington Post's Managing Editor to Quit So He Can Write
abstract: Washington Post's managing editor Steve Coll to step down at end of year to divide his time between writing books and writing articles for Post; Coll comments; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Sentencing In 1991 Attack On Jews
abstract: Andrea Klump, Red Army Faction terrorist currently serving nine-year sentence for 1998 failed attack on Spanish disco, is convicted by German court and sentenced to 12 additional years in prison for 1991 car bomb attack on Soviet Jewish emigres in Budapest (S)

headline: Explosive Suggests Terrorists Downed Plane, Russia Says
abstract: Russia's security service says investigators have found traces of explosive in wreckage of one of two passenger airliners that crashed simultaneously on Aug 24, and declares its downing terrorist act; Islambouli Brigades of Al Qaeda says its fighters hijacked two planes to avenge deaths of Muslims in Chechnya and elsewhere; evidence of explosive aboard plane is strongest indication yet that deliberate acts, not human or mechanical errors as Russian officials initially suggested, were involved in crashes, which killed 89 people; twin disasters would be Russia's worst act of terrorism in skies (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: SAP Income Rises 14%
abstract: World Business Briefing: German

headline: De Beers Agrees to Guilty Plea To Re-enter the U.S. Market
abstract: De Beers, world's largest diamond producer, agrees to settle criminal charges that it conspired with General Electric in 1991 and 1992 to fix world industrial diamond prices; move paves way for company to return to United States after long absence; Justice Department has been unable to prosecute company because its operations are overseas; judge threw out case against GE after trial; graph of company's market share; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Suspended Sentence For Anti-Semitic Lie
abstract: French court gives Marie-Leonie Leblanc four-month suspended sentence for lying about being victim of anti-Semitic attack; also orders psychiatric treatment and two years of probation; photo (S)

headline: Putin Backs Gazprom Bid to Buy Big Oil Company
abstract: Russia's natural g

headline: EU Commission hearings offer a test for Barroso
Israel Launches Airstrike in Gaza City
abstract: An Israeli airstrike in Gaza City, the second in as many days, killed two Hamas militants and wounded at least six bystanders, Palestinians said.

headline: Stepped-Up Police Activity Irks an Arab Area in Greece
abstract: Greek, American and British intelligence agencies increase their activities in predominantly Muslim district of Athens, Greece, before opening of Olympic Games, angering residents there; Greek officials say they asked for, and received, assistance from counterterrorism teams and intelligence operatives from Jordan and Egypt; says Israelis are keeping eye on Arab embassies; say 100,000 people of Arab or Muslim background who live in Athens have generally not been militant, but fear is that Al Qaeda or affiliated terrorist group has planted sleeper cell in their neighborhood; Col Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya sends word to Libyan population in Athens not to engage in acts of violence during Games, and Palestinians make similar appeals to their residents in city; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Parcel Bomb Suspects Arrested
abstract: Italian police arrest four people suspected of involvement in series of letter bombs mailed to European Union officials last year; no one was injured during spate of bombings (S)

headline: Ex-Official Challenged on Madrid Bomb Inquiry
abstract: Former Interior Min Angel Acebes of Spain comes under fierce questioning in Congress about why he had continued to say domestic Basque terrorists were primary suspects in Mar 11 train bombings, even after police said they were not; claims that when he gave news conference on Mar 13 citing ETA as main suspect, police had not yet determined that evidence pointed decisively to Islamic terrorists; Acebes's party was defeated in elections three days after attacks; photo (M)

headline: Sharon Rebuffed by Party, as Arafat Admits Making Mistakes
abstract: Leaders of Israel and the Palestinians face deep dissension in their constituencies; Prime Min Ariel Sharon loses nonbinding vote in his Likud Party regarding his intention to expand his coalition to include Labor Party, to carry out unilateral withdrawal from Gaza Strip and dismantle some Israeli settlements; aides say Sharon will move forward without his party's clear support; he has lost his parliamentary majority, and might be forced to call new elections; in Ramallah, Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat admits in rare, televised speech that he and Palestinian Authority made serious mistakes; younger generation of Palestinians have denounced chaos, lack of security, overlapping institutions, administrative corruption and long-postponed elections over which Arafat has presided; Arafat deflects calls from audience for specific commitments to specific measures; photo (M)

headline: Italy's hostage response reflects shift in tactics
World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Marks & Spencer Bidder Gives Up
abstract: World Business Briefing: Britain: Mark & Spencer

headline: Iraqis Postpone Conference As Kidnappings Increase
abstract: Iraq postpones major national conference billed as one of its first steps toward democracy and national reconciliation, as epidemic of kidnappings widens; insurgents announce they kidnapped five more foreign hostages; roughly 20 people have been taken hostage since Philippine government withdrew its troops to save life of abducted Filipino truck driver; kidnappings add another dimension of tension and fear to conflict, emerging as major challenge to Prime Min Ayad Allawi and American forces in Iraq; it has also confounded assumptions about what lines insurgents might not cross since many hostages are Muslim, like their abductors; photo (M)

headline: Oil, Venezuela's Lifeblood, Is Now Its Social Currency, Too
abstract: Petroleos de Venezuela is once against one of world's greatest producers of oil seventeen months after antigovernment strike crippled production; its giant refining arm is talking of adding two refineries to three already operating in US; company says it is embarking on strategy, heavily dependent on foreign oil companies, to nearly double production by 2009; Petroleos de Venezuela's new earnings have been siphoned from exploration and production and being used to finance social revolution long promised by Pres Hugo Chavez's 5 1/2-year-old government to extricate country from its malaise and ease life for poor; spending spree is increasingly important as Aug 15 recall referendum nears, and successful, tool for solidifying support for Chavez; recent polls show Chavez could squeak to victory; oil company's new role has raised eyebrows among oil executives and in Washington, which has long counted on Venezuela as one of four big exporters of oil to US and which has been hoping company will help curtail reliance on Middle Eastern crude; charts; photos (M)

headline: Jury Finds Ex-Tyco Lawyer Not Guilty of All Charges
abstract: Tyco International's former general counsel Mark A Belnick is acquitted of charges he stole millions of dollars from company in form of unauthorized bonuses and loans and that he failed to disclose payments; decision is setback for prosecutors, whose efforts to convict former Tyco executives L Dennis Kozlowski and Mark H Swartz ended in mistrial in April; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Court Grants Same-Sex Divorce
abstract: Ontario, Canada, court grants first same-sex divorce after ruling current Divorce Act, which considers marriage to be exclusively between man and woman, violates Charter of Rights and Freedoms; same-sex marriage is legal in Ontario, Quebec, British Columbia and Yukon (S)

headline: At U.N., a Missourian Who Wears Faith Boldly
abstract: John C Danforth, Episcopal minister and former United States senator, will be sworn in as American ambassador to United Nations on July 1; attributes most ascribed to him by friends and associates are eagerness to hear both sides, dedication to bridging differences with well-mannered diplomacy and belief that religious leaders have role in publc life; photo (M)

headline: California Dealers Win Ally on Car Bill
abstract: Schwarzenneger administration opposes bill before California Legislature that would limit ability of car dealers to bump up interest rates on loans they offer consumers on behalf of banks or financial companies; bill would limit so-called dealer markups to two percentage points on loans up to 60 months and one point on longer loans; dealers, who keep markups as profit, charge them on some customers' loans and not others; all major automakers, as well as some bank, have been sued by minority customers who claim that dealers discriminate against them in way they selectively apply markups; consumer groups criticize markups more generally, saying they are often invisible to all but most knowledgeable car shoppers and make loans much more expensive than those customer could get directly from bank; photo (M)

headline: ENRON SEEKS TO BLOCK FEDERAL PENSION FUND TAKEOVER
abstract: Enron Corp asks court overseeing its bankruptcy case to block efforts by Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp to take over four of company's retirement plans; John Forney, former trading executive, pleads guilty to charges he manipulated energy markets during California's power crisis in 2001 (S)

headline: MediaTalk; Treading on the Thin Line Between TV News and Show Business
abstract: Will Ferrell crashes set of CNBC show Power Lunch with John McEnroe and camera crew from McEnroe's new CNBC talk show to promote his movie Anchorman and his appearance on first installment of McEnroe's show; repeatedly kisses anchorwoman Sue Herera, who later stresses in interview that she is happily married; CNBC shows clip of event through rest of day, and McEnroe uses it to open his show, McEnroe, which attracts bigger-than-usual audience in that time slot; CNBC defends moment of lightheartedness in many hours of business programming; photo (M)

headline: SOARING OIL PRICES PUSH EXXON'S NET INCOME UP 39%
abstract: Exxon Mobil Corp's second-quarter net income climbs 39 percent, to $5.79 billion; sales increase 24 percent, to $70.69 billion (S)

headline: Manila Signals Troop Pullout
abstract: Philippine government appears to accede to demand by Iraqi insurgents to pull its small contingent of troops from Iraq in exchange for life of Filipino hostage, Angelo dela Cruz (S)

headline: Schrder's Opponents Get 2nd Setback in 2 Weeks
abstract: Chancellor Gerhard Schrder's Social Democrats were celebrating today after voters in North Rhine-Westphalia backed them convincingly.

headline: Talk to the Tiara
abstract: Gymboree children's clothing company chairwoman and chief ex

headline: U.S. HOLDS BACK FROM ATTACKING REBELS IN NAJAF
abstract: American forces hold back from attacking insurgents loyal to Moktada al-Sadr in Najaf; officers decline to say what caused them to change their plans after spending days preparing for major assault; Sadr's control of Iman Ali Mosque, one of holiest sites in Shiite Islam, is frustrating American efforts to crush his movement; any damage to mosque would cause outrage among Shiites, who constitute majority of Iraqis; tensions in Najaf are first major test of relationship between American military and interim Prime Min Ayad Allawi, whose approval is needed for any attack on Sadr; although Allawi has said he would not negotiate with Sadr forces, his assent to all-out assault is another matter; spokesman for Sadr vows that cleric will continue his fight in Najaf; photos; map (M)

headline: DaimlerChrysler Profit Jumps Fivefold
abstract: Stronger sales of new Chrysler models like the Dodge Durango, 300C and new minivans boosted the division's sales revenue by 12 percent.

headline: Europe, easing budget rules, bows to the inevitable
Taliban Fighters Increase Attacks, With Troubling Toll Among G.I.'s and Afghans
abstract: Taliban has increased attacks on American and Afghan security forces in eastern Afghanistan; rate of American combat deaths is much higher this year than in 2003 while Afghan deaths seem to be up by 50 percent; central government has weak hold in south and east, where popular support for Taliban is greatest; Taliban campaign aims to disrupt scheduled elections, but roughly 8 of 10 million eligible voters have defied Taliban by registering to vote; photos; map; graph (L)

headline: Russians Cite Porous Security in Terror Bombings of 2 Planes
abstract: Russian Prosecutor Gen Vladimir V Ustinov reports that two Chechen women who killed themselves and 88 others in bombings of two Russian passenger jets last month were able to pass uninspected through layers of airport security and checks even after being identified as possible terrorists; says police bungling and petty bribe eased their passage; fresh details about worst terrorist acts to strike Russia's aviation industry provide chilling view of nation's weaknesses as it tries to defend itself from escalating terror strikes (M)

headline: Ex-Officer's Wife Begins Prison Term In Enron Case
abstract: Lea Fastow, wife of Enron Corp's former chief financial officer Andrew S Fastow, begins one-year prison term at Federal Criminal Detention Center, Houston, for her role in accounting fraud that forced company to seek bankruptcy protection in 2001; photo (M)

headline: Computer on Board, And It's Not a Laptop
abstract: CarBot is fully functional personal computer for automobiles intended to centralize navigation, music, DVD movies, Internet and e-mail access into one unit; photos (M)

headline: Lingering Sex Scandal in Chile Still Roils and Divides the Political Heirs of Pinochet
abstract: So-called Caso Claudio Spiniak sex scandal continues to roil Chilean politics; Maria Pia Guzman, conservative member of Congress, accused Spiniak in 2003 of running prostitution and child pornography ring with participation of politicians and bishop; accusations were mainly directed against Independent Democratic Union, which is linked to elements of Pinochet dictatorship, splitting political right; Socialist-led coalition government is enjoying distraction from its own corruption scandal; photo (M)

headline: Deal Gives Banco Santander a Foothold in Britain
abstract: Banco Santander Central Hispano of Spain will acquire British mortgage banker Abbey National for 8.5 billion pounds ($15.6 billion), largest cross-border banking deal ever attempted in Europe; Abbey National will bring Santander stable foothold in Britain if deal goes through; Banco Santander chairman Emilio Botin and Abbey National's chief executive Luqman Arnold comment; photo (M)

headline: Perilous Conditions Led Up to Abuses At Baghdad Prison
abstract: Army investigation of abuses at Abu Ghraib jail describes what happened after prisoner from Syria tried to shoot American soldiers with handgun that had been smuggled in by Iraqi police officer; says prisoner was quickly shot, after which 11 Iraqi police officers were rounded up, strip-searched, and interrogated for hours with military dogs harassing them; report states that 'tone and environment' that night, presided over by Lt Col Steven L Jordan, was causative factor that set stage for abuses that followed for days afterward; report offers most detailed look yet at series of systemic failures that plagued prison; it provides harsh indictment of Jordan, who ran Joint Interrogation and Debriefing Center at prison, and of Col Thomas M Pappas of 205th Military Intelligence Brigade, to whom Jordan reported; photo; excerpts from specific charges against Pappas, Jordan, Maj David M Price, Maj Michael D Thompson and Capt Carolyn A Wood (M)

headline: NATO Ready To Help Train Iraqi Forces
abstract: NATO overcame French opposition and agreed Friday to dispatch ''as soon as possible'' a small group of officers to Iraq to train the country's military.     The agreement was an important political milestone for the alliance but in military terms represented only a modest contribution to the efforts to stabilize Iraq. NATO is to send fewer than 40 officers, the secretary general, Jaap de Hoop Scheffer, said at a news conference, but he called the mission a ''nucleus'' of future operations.

headline: In a New Twist, the Family of a Marine Says Iraqi Captors Have Released Him
abstract: Relatives of Cpl Wassef Ali Hassoun, marine reported beheaded by captors in Iraq, now say they have received signal that he has been released, but have not talked with him directly; violence continues as suicide bomber drives into funeral service near Baquba for earlier terrorist victims, killing perhaps 13 people; photos of damage and of Marines at school in Falluja; sign of Iraqi anger at such attacks emerges in video in which militant group threatens to kill Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, Jordanian terrorist leader; US bombs Zarqawi safe house in Falluja, killing 12-15 people; three US marines are killed by roadside bomb near city (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Communications: Leucadia Sells Stake In MCI
abstract: Leucadia National Corp sells its entire stake in MCI; held 15,738,100 MCI shares in August; says it has not ruled out acquiring MCI in future (S)

headline: New York gains ground in bid for 2012 Games
World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Profit For Telecom Company
abstract: Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp says first-quarter net profit was on target at 186 billion yen ($1.66 billion); revenes fell to 2.65 trillion yen ($23.7 billion) from 2.67 trillion yen (S)

headline: New Qaeda Activity Is Said To Be Major Factor in Alert
abstract: Senior government officials say new intelligence pointing to current threat of attack on financial targets in New York and possibly Washington, not only old information on Al Qaeda surveillance, was major factor in raising terrorism alert level; say separate intelligence stream reached White House late last week, even as Bush administration acknowledges that much of surveillance activity cited by Sec Tom Ridge was at least three years old; White House vigorously defends alert; Ridge, in New York, says 'we don't do politics' in Homeland Security Department, and that government should let public know of such situations; photos; senior intelligence official says 'very current' activity leaves little doubt that Al Qaeda 'is moving toward the execution stage of attacks'; shifting tone offers little guidance to public trying to assess gravity of threat; White House officials give The New York Times detailed accounting of decision-making (M)

headline: A Seasoned U.S. Defendant Scolds Afghan Judge on Law
abstract: Jonathan K Idema, former Special Forces soldier, convict, author and media hound, is facing 15 to 20 years in Afghan prison, charged with running private jail in Kabul and torturing its Afghan inmates on no authority but his own; standing trial, he appears to be reveling in being star of drama; he claims to have broken up terrorist plot that would have left two Afghan ministers and hundreds of American soldiers dead; much of trial hinges on whether American and Afghan officials approved his detentions and interrogations, and on whether he stopped multiple terrorist plots, or invented them; he is acting as his own lawyer (M)

headline: People
abstract: Phil Smith is named to new post of president at Boone/Oakley; Jack Rooney is named president at Campbell Mithun, succeeding Les Mouser, who continues as chief executive; Matt Seiler is named PHD ad agency president for US, new post; Zain Raj is named executive vice president and chief marketing officer, new post, at Chicago office of Euro RSCG Worldwide; Peter Himler is named executive vice president and chief media officer, new post, at Edelman, New York, part of Daniel J Edelman Inc (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Qatar: Court Upholds Sentences Of 2 Russians
abstract: Qatar court rejects appeal by two Russians convicted of killing former Chechen president Zelimkhan Yandarbiyev, who was living in exile in Qatar; Russians are serving life sentences (S)

headline: Nightmare at Sea Shatters Dreams in a Dominican Town
abstract: About 80 Dominicans paid about full year's wages to pack into boat to go to Puerto Rico; about 50 of them died en route; survivors tell harrowing tale of their journey; contradictory accounts of struggles on boat have raised suspicions among families of those who died; photos; map (M)

headline: Some Abu Ghraib Abuses Are Traced to Afghanistan
abstract: Both Pentagon investigations of prisoner abuse at Abu Ghraib in Iraq find that some aggressive tactics used by American military interrogators had their origins in interrogation techniques developed by Special Operations forces and Central Intelligence Agencies for use in Afghanistan in campaign against terrorism; suggestion that CIA's practices are in part to blame for Abu Ghraib abuses reinforces clash of cultures between by-the-book Army and CIA, which operates by its own rules; Fay report says Lt Col Steven L Jordan, head of militaryinterrogation center at Abu Ghraib, had waived rule that required military officers to monitor CIA interrogations; intelligence officials say CIA's inspector general is carrying out series of investigations of agency's involvement in alleged abuses in Iraq, including handling of 'ghost detainees,' those never listed as being held (M)

headline: U.S. voters overseas being left out in cold
Mexico's Leader to Pursue Genocide Case
abstract: Pres Vicente Fox says that if Mexico's Supreme Court will not hear genocide charges his government has filed against former Pres Luis Echeverria he will propose truth commission to investigate abuses by Institutional Revolutionary Party, which used fraud and corruption to rule for more than seven decades; court threw out special prosecutor's case charging Echeverria, two former aides and three generals in deaths of student protesters in 1971; photos (M)

headline: ViewPoints:NO CHEERS
China Will Use Ping-Pong to Influence Hong Kong Elections
abstract: Chinese and Hong Kong men's doubles table tennis teams will stage rematch in Hong Kong of their gold medal face-off in Athens Olympics four days before Hong Kong legislative elections; match is part of Chinese drive to induce Hong Kong voters to support its candidates over pro-democracy opposition; pro-Beijing business leaders are becoming much more involved in campaign, stepping up their spending; photo (M)

headline: Despite U.S. Penalties, Burmese Junta Refuses to Budge
abstract: United States has renewed sanctions against Myanmar, banning all imports in effort to force ruling junta to share power with opposition leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, but government is proud of its long record of survival under international isolation and has not been influenced by American sanctions; European countries have applied less stringent sanctions, while China trades freely with Myanmar; photos; map (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Fitch Raises a Rating
abstract: Fitch Ratings raises Brazil's sovereign debt rating, citing nation's decreased dependence on external financing (S)

headline: Car Bombing Kills Official of Hamas in Damascus
abstract: Hamas official Izzideen al-Sheik Khali is killed when his car explodes in Damascus, Syria, area heavily populated by Palestinian refugees; Syria and Hamas officials quickly blame Israel for killing, calling car bombing new phase in Israeli government's assassinations of Hamas leaders; Israeli government officials decline to confirm or deny charge, but Israeli authorities have stepped up threats against Hamas since group carried out double suicide bombing on Aug 31 that killed 16 people in two buses in Beersheba; photo (M)

headline: Yonaguni Island Journal; The Old Man Has Begun to Fear His Old Friend the Sea
abstract: Yonaguni Island Journal article on 74-year-old Hiroshi Fukumine and other Japanese commercial fishermen who have spent their lives chasing prized marlin in East China Sea; map; photo (M)

headline: OPPORTUNITY KNOCKS DEPT.
abstract: System Planning

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Austria: A New President
abstract: Heinz Fischer is sworn in as Austrian president two days after death of predecessor Thomas Klestil (S)

headline: Basic Training Doesn't Guard Against Insurance Pitch to G.I.'s
abstract: Captive Clientele, first of two articles, says several financial services companies or their agents are using questionable tactics on military bases to sell insurance and investments that may not fit needs of people in uniform; finds that during basic training, compulsory classroom briefings on personal finance are life insurance and investment pitches in disguise; finds insurance agents making misleading pitches to 'captive' audiences, posing as counselors on veteran benefits and independent financial advisers; says some have solicited soldiers in their barracks or while they were on duty, violating Defense Dept regulations; military market includes hundreds of thousands of men and women, many of them young and financially unsophisticated; to reach them, many companies are using their military connections to lend credibilty to their sales efforts; Pentagon is aware of such practices but has taken almost no action to sanction those responsible, because of industry lobbying, Congressional pressure, weak enforcement and Pentagon's own ineffective oversight; some cases cited; photos; graphs (L)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; S.E.C. Inquiry To Encompass 401(k) Plans
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission asks two dozen mutual fund companies to provide details about payments they may make to ensure that their funds are included in corpoorate 401(k) plans; wants to assess prevalence of so-called pay-to-play arrangements among funds and what effect these deals may have on performance fo retirement plans; pension experts say many companies that offer 401(k) plans are unaware of hidden compensation arrangements that influence which funds are included on 401(k) menu and which are not; arrangements between fund companies and intermediaries may increase investors' costs, diminish returns and result in poorly performing funds being offered on 401(k) menu while better funds are left off; Fidelity Investments, Putnam Investments, Dreyfus Corp and T Rowe Price say they are complying with document requests (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Invent Your Own Superhero, or Enlist a Star
abstract: Charles Herold Game Theory column reviews City of Heroes, Onimusha 3: Demon Siege and The Chronicles of Riddick: Escape from Butcher Bay; photos (M)

headline: Clear Channel to Experiment With Digital Radio Signals
abstract: Clear Channel Communications, nation's largest owner of radio stations, plans to spend more than $100 million over next decade to experiment with transmission of digital radio signals; stations that will have capability to transit digital signals will continue to broadcast analog signals because almost no one now owns receiver capable of retrieving digital signal (M)

headline: That High-Tech Balloon Is Going Ssssssssss
abstract: Investors are concerned about recent warnings from computer hardware and software companies that financial results in second quarter may not be as good as in 2003; investors want to know whether it is a blip, or is second-quarter slowdown beginning of long-term malaise in technology; biggest trouble spots on horizon are ballooning inventories on tech companies' balance sheets; chart (M)

headline: To the analysts who are watching its turnaround, the Interpublic Group says: We're working on it.
abstract: Turnaround at struggling Interpublic Group of Companies is still work in progress, as evidenced by mixed results reported for second quarter and first half; company reports net loss of $5.4 million, compared with loss of $13.5 million year earlier; revenue rose to $1.54 billion from $1.5 billion; net loss was $22.3 million for first half, compared with net loss of $34.2 million year ago; revenue rose to $2.94 billion from $2.82 billion (M)

headline: Chvez Is Declared the Winner in Venezuela Referendum
abstract: Former President Jimmy Carter, who helped monitor the vote, endorsed returns showing that President Hugo Chavez had won.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Central Bank Raises Inflation Target
abstract: Brazil's central bank raises its inflation target for 2005 to 5.1 percent from 4.5 percent, move that should remove some pressure on bank to increase interest rates in coming months to curb rising consumer prices (S)

headline: MARATHON AND HESS FACE INQUIRY INTO AFRICAN DEALINGS
abstract: Marathon Oil Corp and Amerada Hess Corp says Securities and Exchange Commission is probing their payments to government of Equatorial Guinea; Marathon, which produces natural gas off coast of Equatorial Guinea and owns part of methanol plant there, has paid or agreed to pay Equatorial Guinea Pres Teodoro Obiang more than $2 million to buy land to expand operations; Hess allegedly paid Equatorial Guinea officials almost $1 million for building leases (S)

headline: France Vows to Enforce Scarf Ban Despite Threat
abstract: Officials vowed today that they will not allow the fate of two French hostages in Iraq to interfere with a new law.

headline: Brazil Is Leading a Largely South American Mission to Haiti
abstract: Brazil takes lead in United Nations peacekeeping mission to Haiti; 5,000 mostly South American troops will be under command of Gen Augusto Heleno Ribeiro Pereira; Brazil hopes mission will boost its credibility as mediator and enhance ability of Mercosur trade bloc to act on world stage; Bush administration fully supports Brazil's efforts; US, France and other rich countries have pledged $1.3 billion in aid to Haiti, which Brazil says is essential to success of mission; photo (M)

headline: Nepal Is Considering Negotiations As Blockade by Rebels Continues
abstract: Katmandu remains cut off from rest of Nepal for third consecutive day because of blockade ordered by Maoist insurgents on two main highways in Katmandu Valley; government indicates that it might be willing to negotiate with rebels, who have been waging war against country's constitutional monarchy since 1996 (M)

headline: U.S. Soldiers Kill 3 Afghans at Checkpoint
abstract: KABUL, Afghanistan, Aug. 22  Soldiers from the American-led coalition killed three people after a pickup truck carrying them failed to stop at a checkpoint on Saturday night, officials said today. A statement issued by the American ambassador here expressed condolences for the loss of

headline: North Korea allows foreign law firm to set up shop
KFC Supplier Accused of Animal Cruelty
abstract: People for Ethical Treatment of Animals, which has been involved in long legal dispute with Kentucky Fried Chicken about treatment of chickens it buys for its restaurant chain, is set to release videotape showing slaughterhouse workers for one supplier, Pilgrim's Pride Corp, jumping up and down on live chickens and otherwise abusing them, apparently for fun; KFC officials, after viewing tape, say they will seek dismissal of workers, inspect slaughterhouse more often and end their ties if cruelty is repeated; Pilgrim's Pride says it is 'appalled' by tape and will reopen probe into poultry mistreatment at Moorefield, W Va, plant (M)

abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago       Prime rate   4.50   4.50   4.00       Federal Funds   1.56   1.40   0.97       3-month Libor   1.89   1.88   1.14       3-month T-bills   1.66   1.65   0.94       6-month T-bills   1.87   1.88   1.01       10-yr. headline: Safety Precautions Transform Appearance of Capitol Hill
abstract: Capitol Hill resembles walled fortress, encircled with concrete barriers that have now expanded outward to include adjacent House and Senate buildings; map; tourists and lawmakers say they feel safe from terrorist attack, but lament time when citizens could walk into Capitol and visit their congressmen (S)

headline: Luang Prabang Journal; Where Pagodas Draw Tourists, Concrete Is Unwelcome
abstract: Luang Prabang, former royal capital of Laos, was named world heritage site by Unesco in 1995, making it eligible for United Naitons preservation funds; its residents, preferring concrete to wood, are resisting Unesco efforts to maintain houses there in style of long ago; photos; map (M)

headline: Powell's 'Solid' C.I.A. Tips Were Soft, Committee Says
abstract: Senate Intelligence Committee report cites Defense Dept's concerns about credibility of Iraqi defector code-named Curveball, whom Sec of State Colin L Powell cited in his report to United Nations Security Council on mobile bioweapons labs in Iraq; CIA downplayed concerns, and Powell did not hear of them; all four sources cited in Powell's report have now been discredited; report concludes CIA does not readily accept information from other agencies and does not always share information with those who might contradict it (M)

headline: Union Asks Judge to Appoint Trustee to Run United Airlines
abstract: Machinists' union asks federal bankruptcy judge to appoint trustee to run United Airlines after carrier decides to stop contributing to employee pension plans; appointment of trustee effectively removes chief executive's power and often prompts departure of other senior managers; union also files motion against United's request that it be given four more months to draft restructuring plan; United's flight attendants begin no-confidence vote, through their Web site, of United's chief executive Glenn F Tilton and airline's management; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Breakaway Communists Lose
abstract: Russian Justice Ministry announces that breakaway Communist Party faction's election of new Communist Party leader is invalid; Gennadi A Zyuganov remains party leader (S)

headline: A New Legal Chapter for a 90's Flameout
abstract: Suit by J P Morgan Chase and other leading banks charging Global Crossing founder and former chairman Gary Winnick and other executives inflated company's performance to win loans refocuses attention on what Winnick knew about company's finances when it was borrowing heavily and he was selling hundreds of millions of dollars in stock; his rise from humble circumstances to upper tiers of American business and wealth discussed; his detractors say Global's downfall involved arcance accounting gimmicks that eluded federal prosecutors, allowing Winnick to escape punishment; his supporters cite his extensive philanthropy; photos (M)

headline: Schering Case Demonstrates Manipulation Of Drug Prices
abstract: $345.5 million settlement by Schering-Plough to resolve government Medicaid probe provides detailed glimpse into how drug companies can manipulate prices to overcharge state and federal programs; case centers around Schering-Plough offering insurers Cigna and PacifiCare Health Systems lower price for its allergy drug Claritin to prevent them from buying drug Allegra, and insurers wound up paying less than drug maker demanded from Medicaid; Federal law requires drug makers to offer their lowest prices to Medicaid; government's inquiry began six years ago after Schering-Plough employees Charles Alcorn, Beatrice Manning and Raymond Pironti Jr filed suit under private whistle-blower provision of federal False Claims Act; photo (M)

headline: Sony's Profit Up Sharply For Quarter
abstract: Sony Corp reports net income of 23.3 billion yen ($210 million) for its first quarter ended in June, compared to 1.1 billion yen in quarter year earlier; sales rose 0.5 percent, to 1.612 trillion yen from 1.604 trillion yen year ago; operating income fell 41 percent,t o 9.8 billion yen for quarter; photo (M)

headline: MediaTalk; This Magazine Even Carries the Bags
abstract: Vitals, new high-end men's shopping magazine from Fairchild Publications, allows readers to select from 25 items in first issue that it will actually help them buy; photo (S)

headline: PROPERTIES : HOME PAGES
Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago       Prime rate   4.25   4.25   4.25       Federal Funds   1.25   1.25   0.95       3-month Libor   1.71   1.70   1.14       3-month T-bills   1.47   1.48   0.92       6-month T-bills   1.74   1.75   1.01       10-yr.
