headline: With Boxing Show, Fox Makes Quick Move, but Judge Reacts
abstract: Fox network moves up premiere of its boxing reality show The Next Great Champ to day before Judge Lisa Hart was planning to hear suit by DreamWorks SKG and Mark Burnett Productions, creators of competing series, to block broadcast; Hart responds by moving up hearing; suit holds Fox and production companies Endemol USA and Lock and Key Productions staged matches without properly following rules set by California State Athletic Commission (M)

headline: Unilever and Colgate Issue Profit Warnings for Rest of the Year
abstract: Unilever and Colgate-Palmolive issue profit warnings, underscoring increasingly tough competitive landscape for makers of some of world's best-known brands; Colgate's chairman-chief executive Reuben Mark and Unilever's co-chairmen Niall FitzGerald and Antony Burgmans comment; graph; photos (Market Place column) (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Payment Wanted For U.S. Space Trips
abstract: Russian space agency director Anatoly N Perminov announces that US will have to begin paying cost of transporting American astronauts to International Space Station, beginning next year; Russia has taken over all transport flights to station since grounding of US space shuttle program in February 2003 (S)

headline: Oil Explorers Searching Ever More Remote Areas
abstract: Western oil companies are running out of likely place to look, and significant finds are becoming rarer; exploration teams are having to push into harsher, more remote and less promising territory, where costs and risks are high; oil trading in range of $40 to $45 per barrel may make such projects seem attractive, but there is widespread concern in industry that prices cannot remain that high; companies direct much of their effort toward wringing more production from known fields rather than hunting for new ones; Norway's Statoil and others are spending more in Norway, up to $9 billion in 2003, but are drilling fewer exploratory wells; production in Norway has leveled off around three million barrels per day. Stavanger has become center for oil and gas exploration off Norway; world still has lot of underground oil left to develop; Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia and United Arab Emirates are situated atop 700 billion barrels of oil, or 61 percent of of world's proven oil reserves; enough oil has already been found to last 41 years at today's pace; map; photos (M)

headline: This article has been temporarily removed from our Web site.
abstract: As the jury in the trial of the Connecticut state pension fund's lawsuit against Theodore J. Forstmann's buyout firm deliberates, there may already be a loser: the pension fund.

headline: Politicus : Polarized and divided?Not Americans on Iraq
No, the Conquistadors Are Not Back. It's Just Wal-Mart.
abstract: Large cinderblock building rising in San Juan de Teothihuacan, Mex, near ruins of giant Mayan pyramids, will house supermarket that is subsidiary of Wal-Mart of Mexico; how Wal-Mart got permission to build superstore on farmland supposedly protected under Mexican law as archaeological site vexes local merchants, who accuse town, state and federal Institute of Anthropolgy and History of corruption; photos; map (M)

headline: Jobs are it in Eastern Germany
Before You Buy Into That I.P.O., Search 'Lemmings'
abstract: Article on whether Google Inc's upcoming initial public offering is good investment; company is expected to be worth $29 bilion to $36 billion when it goes public; chart; photo (M)

headline: US Airways Asks to Skip Pension Payment
abstract: US Airways starts out on its second bankruptcy by asking Federal Judge Steven Mitchell for permission to skip $110 million contribution to its employee pension plans that is due Sept 15; Air Transportation Stabilization Board and other US Airways lenders will be receiving counsel from investment banker Lazard; Lazard is retained fro them by Phoenix American Financial Services, which administers loans in $900 million package of guarantees that board awarded US Airways when it emerged from its first bankruptcy in 2003; US Airways chief Bruce R Lakefield says industry's problems were hard to have foreseen; photo (M)

headline: What's on Your IPod? A List Keeps Track
abstract: Q. Is there a way to print a list of all the songs in my iTunes library?    A. Most versions of the iTunes music-management program for Macintosh and Windows have an Export Song List command under the File menu. You can use this command to export a list of songs into several formats, including plain text, Unicode and XML.

headline: Retrial of Suspect in 9/11 Attacks Begins in Germany
abstract: Mounir el-Motassadeq, whose earlier conviction was oveturned because German and American authorities withheld key evidence, goes on trial again in Germany on charges he provided support for some of suicide hijackers in Sept 11, 2001, attacks in United States; US says it will share evidence about plot for first time in form of unclassified summaries of relevant intelligence data; his lawyers threaten to make trial as much about American conduct since Sept 11 as about events leading up to attacks; photo (M)

headline: IRAQ UPDATE
abstract: Update of events in Iraq; map (S)

headline: North Korea recalls ambassador to protest handling of defections
Nonunion Builders' Group Accused of Misusing Funds
abstract: Report released by Building and Construction Trade Department of AFL-CIO suggests money from apprenticeship programs was steered, in violation of federal law, to local chapters of Associated Builders and Contractors, trade association that promotes nonunion labor in construction industry; apprenticeship programs and trade association's chapters are tax-exempt, but they are governed by different sections of tax code; union group asks that federal and state regulators investigate movement of money between chapters and apprenticeship programs; union group's president Edward C Sullivan says it is time to find out if law applies to allies of Bush administration; Associated Builders and Contractors, which has said it number 1 goal this year is re-electing Bush, dismisses report as effort to divert attention from scandal that involves union-owned insurance company and from what it calls declining union membership (M)

headline: Let a Thousand Ideas Flower: China Is a New Hotbed of Research
abstract: Hundreds of multinational companies have set up research and development laboratories in China in recent years; labs vary in size and ambition, but may help China grow as they multiply and expand from mostly user and copier of advanced technologies developed elsewhere into powerful incubator of its own; shift may eventually reshape applied research, jobs and policies in United States and other developed nations; concerns about protecting patents, retaining and training researchers and managing physical and cultural distances between China and headquarters threaten trend; graph of China's spending on applied research; photos (M)

headline: WHEN SOUND BITES ARE NOT ENOUGH
abstract: Comcast official David Cohen has invited Pres

headline: Vatican to Investigate Pornography Accusations
abstract: Pope John Paul II to name Austrian Bishop Klaus Kung to investigate charges of homosexual behavior and downloading of child pornography at St Polten Roman Catholic seminary in Austria; Kung photo; St Polten Bishop Kurt Krenn, conservative who is intensely disliked by reformist Catholics, refuses to resign in scandal (S)

headline: S.E.C. Opens Investigation of Fannie Mae
abstract: Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight report accusing Fannie Mae of improper accounting has led to informal probe by Securities and Exchange Commission; company's shares fall $4.96, to $70.69; report finds improper 'cookie jar' accounting--setting aside artifically large cash reserves to reduce revenues in some years so they can be drawn on in other years when company needs higher revenue and earnings; SEC says practice gives investors inaccurate picture of company's financial performance; Fannie Mae director Ann McLaughlin Korologos is working with oversight office to resolve issues; board has hired former Sen Warren B Rudman, partner in Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, as independent counsel (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Services: Electronic Data Cuts Dividend 67%
abstract: Electronic Data Systems Corp cuts its dividend by 67 percent to preserve cash and defend credit rating, which has been lowered to junk (S)

headline: G.E. to Put Insurance Units Under One Name
abstract: General Electric will unify more than dozen reinsurance and commercial insurance businesses under brand name GE Insurance Solutions; move brings to end four years of restructuring (M)

headline: Neo-Nazis in Paris Vandalize and Burn a Jewish Community Center
abstract: In the latest in a wave of neo-Nazi acts sweeping the country, arsonists broke into the building and scrawled swastikas and anti-Semitic slogans inside.

headline: Army's Report Faults General In Prison Abuse
abstract: Classified parts of report by three Army generals on abuses at Abu Ghraib prison say procedures approved by Lt Gen Ricardo S Sanchez, former top commander in Iraq, and revisions made when Central Command found fault with initial policy, exceeded Geneva Convention guidelines as well as standard Army doctrines; say that Sanchez and his legal staff revised rules for interrogations in Iraq three times in 30 days, sowing great confusion among interrogators, who understood Geneva guidelines poorly anyway; say military police and military intelligence soldiers who used abusive techniques believed they had been authorized by senior commanders; report shows in much clearer detail than ever before how interrogation practices from Afghanistan and Guantanamo, where detainees were not afforded protection of Geneva Conventions, were brought to Abu Ghraib, and how poorly nuances of what was acceptable in Iraq were understood by military intelligence officials there; classified sections of so-called Fay report reinforce criticisms made in report by independent panel headed by James R Schlesinger; photo; timeline (M)

headline: PNC Financial to Buy Embattled Riggs Bank for $779 Million
abstract: The Washington area Riggs has been under scrutiny for possible violations of federal money laundering laws.

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Strike Halts Air And Sea Traffic
abstract: General strike in Israel is called in support of municipal workers who have not been paid in months; is led by main labor federation Histadrut; 400,000 public workers take part in job action (S)

headline: For Hackers, Shop Talk, A Warning And Advice
abstract: Stephen Wozniak, Apple Computer co-founder, recalls era when word 'hackers' referred to technological wizards, not rogue computer users, Manhattan conference sponsored by hacker magazine 2600 News; recalls many pranks he pulled; deplores harsh penalties set by computer fraud laws, interview; much of conference focuses on arguments for less government monitoring and control of computer networks; photo (M)

headline: Doctors question effects of British warning on drugs
World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Alstom Raises Funds
abstract: Alstom raised 1.75 billion euros ($2.14 billion) in government-led bailout to avoid bankruptcy; government will own 21.4 percent of Alstom after investing 415 million euros in sale (S)

headline: Pakistani Chief Might Retain His Dual Role
abstract: Pakistan's information minister, Sheik Rashid Ahmed, announces that Pres Pervez Musharraf will renege on public promise to take off his military uniform and serve as Pakistan's civilian president; Ahmed later appears to say it is his 'own hope and appeal' that Musharraf break his promise; his comments are latest in series by government officials apparently laying groundwork for announcement by Musharraf that he will remain both top military commander and president (M)

headline: Absolut to Try Television Ads
abstract: Absolut Spirits Co will introduce raspberry-flavored version of its flagship vodka brand, launching it with television commercials for first time; ads will run on some cable networks; campaign was developed by TBWA/Chiat/Day; television spots are one element of multifaceted campaign for new flavor, with total budget estimated at $9 million to $10 million; photos (M)

headline: NEWS CORP. EXTENDS CONTRACT OF PRESIDENT FOR 5 YEARS
abstract: News Corp's president and chief operating officer, Peter Chernin, signs agreement to remain with company for additional five years (S)

headline: World Briefings
abstract: ASIA.

headline: Protests Powered by Cellphone
abstract: TXTMob allows people to quickly and easily send text messages from one cellphone to group of other cellphones; technology was developed by Institute for Applied Autonomy, which says their mission is to develop technologies that serve social and human need for self-determination; TXTMob was used by protesters during national conventions to convey latest information on route changes, street closings and police actions; photo (M)

headline: E-Mail in Your Hand, No Matter Where You Go
abstract: Basics column compares palmtop computers from Hewlett-Packard, Dell and Palm; photos (M)

headline: Looking Back and Looking Ahead, Panel Assesses the Opportunities for Prevention
abstract: Report from 9/11 commission says nation's investment in improving transportation security has been too focused on passenger airlines, while opportunites to 'do harm' are as great, or greater, in maritime or surface transportation, or cargo aviation (M)

headline: Merrill Analyst Cuts Estimate of Spending
abstract: Merrill Analyst Cuts.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Allure magazine, New York, published by the Cond Nast Publications division of Advance Publications, promoted two employees and hired another. Susan Bornstein , executive director for creative services and business development, was promoted to associate publisher for marketing. Wendi Cassuto , advertising manager, was promoted to advertising director. And Diane DePaul was named associate publisher for advertising; she had been associate publisher at Star magazine, New York, part of American Media Inc.

headline: It's Monday in Germany. Time for Social Protest.
abstract: Demonstrations across Germany over last four Mondays protesting Chancellor Gerhard Schroder government's plan to cut back generous unemployment benefits have injected volatile new element into German politics; mounting public anger underscores perils of attacking Germany's once-sacrosanct welfare state; government has held line against demands that it dilute or delay measures; but political analysts predict that this will end Schroder's reform drive, at least for now; protests could dull whatever conservative opposition has to press for more radical changes and cuts in social benefits; measures, scheduled to take effect in January 2005, would affect Germans out of work for more than 12 months; rather than drawing long-term unemployment compensation, which can be up to 60 percent of recipient's original salary, they would receive only basic welfare, amounting to 345 euros ($417) each month, plus extra money to help for rent and utilities; photo (M)

headline: METLIFE REPORTS RISE IN 2ND-QUARTER PROFIT AFTER AUDIT
abstract: MetLife says tax audit of its accounts

headline: FOOD FIGHT
abstract: AFL-CIO is threatening to seek antitrust charges against Penford Corp, which has been struck by AFL affiliate, charging company shares director with rival food additives maker in violation of Clayton Antitrust Act ban on interlocking directorates (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Interest Rate Raised
abstract: Mexico's central bank raises interest rates to stem accelerating inflation; raises amount commercial banks must borrow at higher rates to 45 million pesos ($3.5 million) a day from 41 million pesos (S)

headline: Treasury Bills Set For This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.    At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 1.56 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 1.80 percent, and the rate on the four-week issue was 1.41 percent.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PENN TRAFFIC CO., Syracuse, an operator of 109 supermarkets, said it filed a plan to exit its second bankruptcy by giving unsecured creditors as much as 100 percent of its common stock. Penn Traffic will convert about $277 million in debt to equity under the plan, according to documents filed with the Federal Bankruptcy Court in White Plains.    ADVANCED NEUROMODULATION SYSTEMS INC., Plano, Tex., said it took a 14.9 percent equity stake in Cyberonics Inc., Houston, and expressed interest in a merger, but Cyberonics said it was not interested in a deal. Advanced Neuromodulation, which makes implantable systems to treat disorders of the central nervous system, said it bought 3.5 million Cyberonics shares.

headline: Unilever and Colgate Warn of Slowdowns in Their Earnings
abstract: The two companies do not operate in all the same markets, but Monday's warnings seemed to suggest that both were suffering from tougher competition in some areas.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Chatter Over The Head Of State
abstract: Italian newspapers suggest Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, who has been seen at his Sardinia villa wearing pirate-style bandana while hosting British Prime Minister Tony Blair, has had hair transplant; photo (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | People: New Technology Chief At Cisco
abstract: Cisco Systems Inc names Charles H Giancarlo chief technology officer; Giancarlo will continue as president of Linksys, Cisco subsidiary (S)

headline: Accused American Deserter Arrives in Japan
abstract: American officials say they intend to prosecute Charles Robert Jenkins, 64, who is accused of deserting the army four decades ago and fleeing to North Korea

headline: Stocks Off as Intel's Weak Forecast Overshadows Jobs Data
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average finishes week down 30.08 points, to 10.260; Nasdaq composite index falls 1.6 percent, or 28.95 points, to 1,844; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index drops 4.68 points; ten-year treasury note jumps 4.29 percent while price falls 21/32, to 99 20/32; graphs; charts (M)

headline: W.T.O. Rules for Brazil in Sugar Dispute
abstract: Brazilian officials say World Trade Organization has ruled that European Union's sugar subsidies give its farmers unfair advantage on global export markets; sugar is one of European Union's most heavily subsidized crops, and government supports have helped European sugar producers become second-largest exporters in world, behind Brazil, which is also largest sugar producer; photo (M)

headline: Staying in Touch
abstract: To the Editor:    Re ''RUOK? A Tutorial for Parents'' (Aug. 19): As a pediatrician I found it fascinating and informative. By reading this, and, of course saving it for future, frequent reference (when my memory reflects my age), I can now relate even more effectively to my patients, both pediatric and adolescent. I can actually be ''cool'' and start or continue conversations with those who are wiser and smarter than their doctor.

headline: Download Music and Movies
abstract: Basics column explores subscription services for streaming specialized audio and video programming over broadband Internet connections; photo (M)

headline: Be Prepared for Anything From Pyramids to Onions
abstract: Veronica Scheubel, senior manager of community relations at Nokia, in Frequent Flier column, discusses some of her airline travel experiences; photo (M)

headline: Cleric Keeps Grip on Najaf Shrine, Even While Saying He'll Yield It
abstract: Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr remains in control of Najaf shrine of Imam Ali; aides say he will surrender keys to Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani and his militiamen will leave shrine to go to neighboring buildings; some militiamen appear to be leaving shrine as American forces push forward in pincer movement to keep pressure on al-Sadr; photo (M)

headline: Psst. This Is Your Sensor. Your Grapes Are Thirsty.
abstract: Wireless networks of sensors, machinery and computers are reaching new frontiers: telling precisely when to irrigate and harvest grapes to produce premium wine, monitoring stresses on aging bridges to help states decide maintenance priorities and warning when oil tanker equipment is in danger of failing; Intel researcher says such wireless communication will be pervasive in 20 years; trend captures interest of venture capitalists, whose investments are supporting start-up sensor networking companies; photo (M)

headline: Senate Iraq Report Said to Skirt White House Use of Intelligence
abstract: Bipartisan Senate report that is highly critical of prewar intelligence on Iraq is expected to sidestep question of how Bush administration used that information to make case for war; under deal reached between Republicans and Democrats, administration's role will not be addressed until Senate Intelligence Comm completes further stage of its inquiry, probably not until after Nov elections; as result, initial, unanimous report will focus solely on misjudgments by intelligence agencies, not White House, in assessments about Iraq, illicit weapons and Al Qaeda that administration used as rationale for war; this may provide opening for Pres Bush and his allies to deflect responsibility for what now appear to be exaggerated prewar assessments about threat posed by Iraq; Democrats will try to focus attention on issue by releasing 'additional views' to supplement bipartisan report (M)

headline: A Radio Giant Moves to Limit Commercials
abstract: Clear Channel Radio plans to begin limiting number of commercials played on its more than 1,200 stations; revenue growth in radio industry has slowed despite long-term run-up in number of minutes in each hour devoted to commercial, by one estimate, up to 20 minutes today from 10 to 12 a decade ago; expanding volume of commercial has bred frustration among advertisers and radio audiences; proportion of people who turn on radio at least once a week remains high, but average time they actually listen each week has slid downward during last 10 years; Clear Channel's new limits on commercials is expected to create pressure for other station owners to do something similar; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Job Growth Slowed in July; Jobless Rate Fell to 5.5%  Employers added 32,000 jobs in July, a fraction of what forecasters had expected and far below the robust gains in employment earlier this year. In a further sign that the economy has weakened, the Labor Department also announced that job growth in May and June was less than initially estimated.    The unemployment rate, however, fell slightly last month, to 5.5 percent from 5.6 percent in June. The unemployment rate is based on a smaller survey than the job growth numbers, which are widely considered the more reliable gauge of employment. [Page A1.]

headline: 4 Die in Accident at Japan Nuclear Power Plant
abstract: Blasts of non-radioactive steam also burned seven workers today in the first fatal accident at a Japanese nuclear power plant.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    Today  Personal Income: July    Tomorrow  Consumer Confidence: August

headline: Tribe, Claiming Whites' Land, Confronts Kenya's Government
abstract: Kenyan authorities rebuff efforts of angry Masai tribesmen to claim sprawling ranches held by white settlers in lush Rift Valley; police in riot gear are forcibly ousting men, whom government calls invaders, as well as their cattle; at least one Masai has died in recent days, shot during confrontation with police; heavily armed police fire tear gas at and chase for blocks Masai demonstrators marching, Nairobi, to protest 100-year-old accord that stripped them of their land; government has adopted cautious approach to land reform, proposing cutting to 99 years leases granted some wealthy ranchers; map; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Airport Gains Reprieve
abstract: Berlin city court suspends order to close Tempelhof, historic downtown airport, pending hearing (S)

headline: TXU SPENDS $797 MILLION TO REPURCHASE SHARES
abstract: TXU Corp, largest power producer in Texas, buys back 20 million shares at price of $39.86 each in step toward reducing its debt by $4 billion this year (S)

headline: A hunter is hunted down in 800
abstract: ATHENS:  Kelly Holmes has spent more than a decade chasing Maria Mutola. On Monday, when it mattered, she finally caught her.

headline: Draft Your N.F.L. Dream Team, Then Plot Out the Season
abstract: EA Sports will kick off Fantasy Football, which allows users to assemble teams and earn points based on real players' performance in specific categories; photo (S)

headline: Iraqi Urges Allies Not to Be Deterred by Kidnappings; Executive Is Seized
abstract: Iraqi Prime Min Iyad Allawi urges Egypt not to give in to demands of kidnappers of Egyptian diplomat Muhammad Mamdouh Qutb; captors say kidnapping was response to Egypt's pledge to help train Iraqi security forces; separately, Raad Adnan, general director of state-owned Al Mansour Contracting Co, is kidnapped in Baghdad; photo (M)

headline: Miller tones down its low-carb focus, emphasizing taste tests to go after Anheuser-Busch loyalists.
abstract: SABMiller is toning down its focus on low carbohydrates in ad campaign and is emphasizing beer taste tests to go after Anheuser-Busch customers; Miller says it has already conducted blind taste tests involving more than 400,000 people and is planning to test additional patrons in bars and restaurants in more than 50 cities by September; photo (M)

headline: Self-Propelled, With a Mission: Clean House
abstract: Roomba Discovery is second-generation robotic floor vacuum from iRobot; device tested and compared with original Roomba; photo (M)

headline: Of Hubs, Spokes And the Airlines' Future
abstract: To the Editor:    Re ''Get Out the Glue for a New Business Model'' (July 11), which described fundamental changes affecting the airline industry:    Though I was quoted about problems facing the major hub-and-spoke airlines in the industry, I do not support the view that this system is irretrievably broken. In fact, I believe the opposite. As long as travelers will pay some premium to travel between cities like Portland, Me., and Portland, Ore., in a convenient time channel, the cheapest and best way to serve them will be to combine their journeys with those of others going at least part of the way.

headline: Bias Suit Delayed Against Wal-Mart
abstract: Judge Martin Jenkins halts discrimination suit against Wal-Mart Stores pending appeals court review of his ruling that lets 1.6 million female workers sue as group; suit charges Wal-Mart pays women less than men and offers them fewer promotions (S)

headline: Palestinian Mortar Kills Israeli-U.S. Woman in Gaza Home
abstract: Palestinian mortar round kills Tiferet Tratner, Israeli-American woman, in her home in Neve Dekalim, Jewish settlement in Gaza Strip, on eve of Yom Kippur; Israeli forces fire at nearby Khan Yunis refugee camp, suspected source of mortar fire; witnesses say Israeli helicopter later fired missile into camp, killing elderly man (M)

headline: Poultry Processor Fires Workers for Abuse
abstract: Pilgrim's Pride Corp fires 11 employees in connection with violations of animal abuse policies at poultry plant in Moorefield, W Va; halts production at 25 plans so that animal handling practices can be reviewed (S)

headline: World Briefings
abstract: MIDDLE EAST.

headline: S.E.C. Proposes New Oversight on Hedge Funds
abstract: If adopted, the rules would subject the growing industry to some of the same regulations that govern the more tightly-regulated mutual funds.

headline: Head of Applied Biosystems Retires as Business Shifts
abstract: Dr Michael W Hunkapiller is stepping down as president of Applied Biosystems; will be succeeded by Catherine M Burzik, company's executive vice president and chief operating officer (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Utility Sells Auto Unit
abstract: British gas company Centrica says it will sell Automobile Association, its operation that provides roadside assistance to motorists, to private equity investors CVC Capital and Permira Advisers for 1.75 billion pounds ($3.2 billion); graph (S)

headline: ROCHE SAYS DRUG FOR PANCREATIC CANCER IS PROMISING
abstract: Study shows experimental drug Tarceva being developed by Roche Holding and OSI Phamaceuticals helped patients with pancreatic cancer live longer when combined with chemotherapy (S)

headline: IN REORGANIZATION, MANUGISTICS DISMISSES PRESIDENT
abstract: Manugistics Group, maker of business software whose shares have fallen 63 percent this year, dismisses president Jeremy Coote because new chief executive Joe Cowan decides job is not necessary (S)

headline: Coalition Seeks Action on Shared Data on Arab-Americans
abstract: Coalition of ethnic advocacy groups, privacy watchdogs and civil rights and civil liberties organizations is demanding that Census Bureau announce 'plan of action' to address public concerns about bureau providing demographic data on Arab-Americans to Homeland Security Dept; letter of complaint drafted by Arab American Institute Foundation and signed by 50 organizations and people questions bureau's 'judgment and discretion' in cooperating with domestic security officials; representatives from group plan to meet with Homeland Security Dept official Daniel W Sutherland and Robert Bonner, commissioner of Bureau of Customs and Border protection (M)

headline: U.S. Fights Cleric's Militia for a Sixth Straight Day
abstract: The U.S. used loudspeakers to appeal to entrenched guerrillas to put down their weapons and to residents to stay away from the areas of fighting.

headline: Take flexible stance, Polish leader urges : A plea from a close friend of U.S.
Casino Owner Posts Profit
abstract: Alliance Gaming Corp reports income of $45.9 million in its fiscal fourth quarter ended June 30 compared with loss of $11.4 million year earlier; revenue rose 41 percent, to $163 million (S)

headline: Iraq Airstrike Killed Civilians, U.S. Military Acknowledges
abstract: U.S. forces said they had killed 57 enemy fighters near Mosul with great precision, and without a single U.S. casualty. But a local hospital said it received scores of civilian dead.

headline: Marine Who Had Been Missing in Iraq Denies He Deserted
abstract: Cpl. Wassef Ali Hassoun said today that he had been "captured and held against my will" for nearly three weeks.

headline: Italians Unite, for a Time, in Joy at Release of 'the 2 Simonas'
abstract: Italy rejoices at safe release of Simona Pari and Simona Torretta, aid workers whose three weeks of captivity in Iraq wrenched nation and brought unusual displays of political unity; photo; Prime Min Silvio Berlusconi declines to say if ransom was paid, although release is not likely to ease pressure on him for supporting widely unpopular war (M)

headline: Putting out the message that registering and voting should have a place in the youth culture.
abstract: Declare Yourself, non-partisan voter-registration group stgarted by television producer Norman Lear, will raise two giant billboards in Times Square featuring Christina Aguilera and Andre 3000 aimed at potential young voters; ad agency is Benenson Janson; photo (M)

headline: Proponent of Democratic Change Takes Office as Serbian Leader
abstract: Boris Tadic, leader of Democratic Party of Serbia and supporter of democratic changes, is sworn in as president, heralding hopes of new era; he defeated Tomislav Nikolic, far-right nationalist and onetime ally of Slobodan Milosevic; Tadic's victory gives new hope to those supporting change, even though powers of president are limited and his ability to initiate change depends largely on Parliament dominated by nationalists; photo (M)

headline: EasyJet shares tumble on warning of fare wars
Young Men Are Back Watching TV. But Did They Ever Leave?
abstract: New evidence indicates men ages 18-34 are back watching television in pretty much same numbers they were in 2002 despite falloff Nielsen Media Research first detected in July 2003; Nielsen stands by its ratings, which showed Sept viewing by young men fell over 10 percent, drop questioned by critics as inconsistent with viewing patterns established over years of measurements; reported drop cost networks millions of dollars in advertising sales last fall and winter; graph; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: ASML And Zeiss To Pay Nikon $145 Million To Settle Suit
abstract: Nikon Corp, maker of equipment used to etch computer chip circuits, will receive $87 million from ASML Holding and $58 million from Carl Zeiss SMT to settle patent suit (S)

headline: Trying to Bring Big-Media Ideas Into the World Of Art Theaters
abstract: Todd Wagner and Mark Cuban are bringing high-definition digital projection to 204 movie screens in 57 theaters owned by Landmark Theaters, nation's largest art house chain, as part of plan for vertical integration with other properties they own; envision producing low-budget digital movies through Wagner's HDNet Films, releasing them through his Magnolia Pictures, projecting them in Landmark theaters and broadcasting them on HDNet Movies, one of two high-definition television networks run by Cuban; some in independent film community fear Cuban and Wagner will ultimately veer toward more commercial fare, hurting independent films; photo (M)

headline: Dell's Forecast Of Solid Profit Lifts PC Sector
abstract: Dell Computer, world's leading maker of personal computers, says second-quarter earnings should be 31 cents a share, or 2 cents above its previous estimate and consensus of analysts; outlook is based on second-quarter revenue of $11.7 billion; announcement comes day after IBM reports quarterly profits that surpass Wall Street estimates; research firm IDC reports that personal computer shipments were more robust in April, May and June than expected; photo of Michael Dell with Kevin Rollins, who succeeds him as chief executive of Dell (M)

headline: Ex-Broker Guilty of Banking and Wire Fraud
abstract: Consuelo Marquez, former investment manager at Lehman Brothers, pleads guilty to banking and wire fraud, involving use of fraudulent loans to invest in stock market; Marquez was accused of conspiring with Sylvia Aubuchon, investment adviser at Bank One subsidiary in Arizona, to take advantage of elite loan program between two companies for their own profit (M)

headline: Sudanese Suffer as Militias Hide in Plain Sight
abstract: Government of Sudan, under threat of United Nations sanctions, promises to contain Janjaweed militias, but whether it can is not clear; 50 prisoners lined up by government and offered as evidence to world that it is cracking down on Janjaweed are in fact mostly petty criminals; aid workers and human rights workers say Janjaweed is fluid identity; say Janjanweed militiaman can spend day burning and killing, then return to his village, hide his gun and blend into community; say many policemen are Janjaweed at night; in many cases, government has provided Janjaweed with uniforms, identification cards and commissions in police, army or popular defense force; as far as government is concerned, they are no longer Janjaweed; but not all such fighters in Darfur are following government's script; some are loyal only to themselves, roaming countryside as criminals, taking advantage of chaos; photos; map (M)

headline: G.E. Settles S.E.C. Case on Welch Retirement Perks
abstract: General Electric and Securities and Exchange Commission settle accusations that company failed to describe fully substantial compensation that its former chairman-chief executive John F Welch Jr received after he retired; GE agrees to describe all such perks in future; does not admit or deny SEC's accusations; (M)

headline: Symbol Technologies Buys Matrics, Accelerating Its Move Into Radio Tags
abstract: Symbol Technologies acquires Matrics, pioneer in promising field of radio-frequency identification, for $230 million, but warns that deal will cut 5 to 6 cents a share from earnings this year and lesser amount next year; Symbol's share price falls 15 percent in heavy trading (S)

headline: Making Wheels of Justice Turn in a Chaotic Iraq
abstract: Fuaad Ahmed al-Jawary has emerged as leading lawyer defending captured insurgents in Iraq as American officials increasingly turn to Iraqi courts to prosecute suspects; hundreds of detainees are being shuffled from American custody into one of three tiers of Iraqi criminal justice system: special tribunal for top officials, new national criminal court for terrorism suspects and local courts for ordinary crimes; al-Jawary complains system remains rife with corruption; photos (M)

headline: PROPERTIES : Trophy address?Nothing beats Belgravia
World Briefing | Europe: Germany: President Sworn In
abstract: Parliament swears in Horst Kohler as Germany's ninth postwar president; post is largely ceremonial (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Phone Company Posts Profit
abstract: Telephone and Data Systems, parent of wireless carrier United States Cellular, reports second-quarter profit of $41.4 million as it added customers and bolstered revenue from existing clients (S)

headline: WESTAR RAISES OFFER TO BUY MAKER OF BANKING SYSTEMS
abstract: Westar Capital increases its offer to buy Troy Group, which makes systems used to transfer funds between bank accounts, by 50 cents, to $4.50 per share; offer is 47 percent higher than competing offer of $3.06 per share by Dirk Inc, company controlled by Troy founder-chairman Patrick Dirk (S)

headline: Israel Could Safely Withdraw From Golan, Army Chief Says
abstract: Lt Gen Moshe Yaalon says Israel could safely withdraw from Golan Heights in future peace settlement with Syria, without retaining any occupied territory as buffer (M)

headline: Coors and Molson Announce They Are in Merger Talks
abstract: United States brewer Adolph Coors Co and Canadian brewer Molson say they are in merger talks; analysts comment (M)

headline: Federal Reserve Raises Short-Term Rates a Quarter Point
abstract: The Fed said rising oil prices had slowed growth but expressed confidence that the economy growth would soon pick up.

headline: More Errors in Circulation Found in Newsday and Hoy
abstract: Tribune Co finds additional errors in circulation figures for its Newsday and Hoy newspapers and sets aside $35 million to compensate advertisers who may have overpaid; Tribune reports second-quarter net income fell 58 percent, to $96.4 million; Dow Jones & Co says second-quarter profit rose 10 percent, to $34 million; sales rose 11 percent, to $437.8 million (M)

headline: Gates and Jobs, Together at Last
abstract: Bill Gates and Steve Jobs have been celebrated in books, magazines, newspapers, even a television movie. Now comes musical theater.

headline: Ex-General Leads Indonesia Poll 5 Days Before Presidential Vote
abstract: Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono holds a commanding lead five days before the first round of Indonesia's presidential election on July 5.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Haiti: Spain and Morocco To Send Joint Mission
abstract: Morocco and Spain agree to send peacekeeping mission to Haiti; it is first time two nations have combined efforts and formed single military unit (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Jobless Rate Rises
abstract: Brazil's unemployment rate rose in August to 11.4 percent from 11.2 percent in July; number of umemployed people searching for jobs in six metropolitan areas surveyed rose to 2.5 million, from 2.4 million; number of employed people increased, to 19.2 million from 19.1 million (S)

headline: Trends in Costs And in Carbs Nag at Kraft
abstract: Article on financial problems plaguing Kraft Foods; says surging prices for commodities and drop in number of consumer eating carbohydrates are main factors in 25.5 percent drop in second-quarter earnings; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Brussels: Phone Rates Challenged
abstract: European Commission issues objections to way British cellphone operators Vodafone and mm02 have charged foreign rivals for allowing their subscribers to use their networks in Britain; competition commissioner Mario Monti says high international roaming charges levied by mobile phone operators have made traveling abroad very expensive for mobile phone users; Vodafone says it has added 5.8 million customers in three months ended June 30, more than expected, bringing its total customer base to 139.2 million (S)

headline: Freed U.S. Journalist Found Solace in Philosophy During 'Moments of Terror'
abstract: Micah Garen, American journalist freed by Islamic militia group that seized him in Nasiriya, Iraq, and held him captive for 10 days, describes ordeal, interview, Baghdad, after brief news conference; is still under FBI protection; photo (M)

headline: The Midas Touch, With Spin on It
abstract: Donald J Trump's billionaire persona, as projected in The Apprentice television show, belies troubles with his business enterprises, including expected bankruptcy filing for Trump casinos; photos (M)

headline: Zimbabwe Sentences Briton to 7 Years in Jail on Arms Charge
abstract: Zimbabwean magistrate sentences British soldier of fortune Simon Mann to seven years in prison for illegally trying to buy weapons in Zimbabwe for botched coup attempt against Pres Teodoro Obiang Nguema Mbasogo of Equatorial Guinea; court also seizes $170,000 down payment on weapons and Boeing 727 jet Mann and others flew into Zimbabwe; judge sentences 67 others to terms ranging from one year to 16 months for violations of immigration law; additional 19 accused plotters are on trial in Equatorial Guinea (M)

headline: Auto Industry Debates Virtues of Diesels vs. Hybrids
abstract: Automakers remain divided on whether diesel or hybrid cars are best way to improve fuel efficiency, and split is often drawn along cultural lines; all major manufacturers are developing cleaner diesel engines, hybrids and hydrogen fuel cells; companies are pushing harder on different technologies to get leg up in meeting regulations that are becoming tougher around world; Toyota and Honda first developed hybrid-electric vehicles, in part because they save gasoline in sort of stop-and-start driving that is common in clogged traffic of densely populated Japan; European automakers are skeptical about how profitable hybrids can be and prefer diesel-powered vehicles because they offer car owners alternative to high taxes on gasoline; environmental advocates remain cautious about diesels; photos (M)

headline: Israeli Airstrike Kills 3 Palestinian Militants
abstract: An Israeli airstrike killed three Palestinian militants in the West Bank town of Jenin as they traveled in a car.

abstract: Fidelity National Financial acquires InterCept Inc, provider of technology services to banks, for $408 million (S)

headline: World-Class Trains? Not Even Close
abstract: Article on lack of first-class rail system in US focuses on one bright spot, Amtrak's Acela line in Northeast; drawing (M)

headline: Indexes Bounce Off Early Lows, But Tech Stocks Don't Rebound
abstract: Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declines 3.25 points, to 1,075.79, while Dow Jones industrial average falls 6.35 points, to 9,938.32; Nasdaq composite index drops 26.28 points, to 1,782.42; US Treasury bonds rise; 10-year note ggains 5/32, to 103 25/32; yield slips to 4.27 percent from 4.29 percent; graph; charts (M)

headline: Cellphones in Flight Face Technical and Social Hurdles
abstract: What's Next column on new systems being developed to allow use of cellphones on airplanes; Federal Communications Commission forbids use of cellphones in flight out of concern that passengers calling from air could overwhelm nation's system of cell towers; drawing (M)

headline: Globalist : Bush's momentary shift on war against terror
Americans seem not to focus on the war
Bank of America to Pay $69 Million to Settle Enron Suit
abstract: Bank of America Corp agrees to pay $69 million to settle suit by Enron investors over bank's role as underwriter of some debt offerings; denies breaking laws; is first financial institution to resolve such suits and only bank not accused in suits of fraud that contributed to Enron's collapse (M)

headline: ConocoPhillips Buys $2 Billion Stake in Lukoil
abstract: The purchase, which ConocoPhillips, the American energy conern, made at an auction today for the Russian government's stake in Lukoil, sets the stage for projects in Iraq.

headline: Mitsubishi to refocus its LCD output
U.S. Investigates Payments To Equatorial Guinea
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission begins inquiry into payments made by Exxon Mobil Corp, Marathon Oil Corp, Amerada Hess Corp and ChevronTexaco Corp to government and senior officials of Equatorial Guinea; Equatorial Guinean government had about $700 million in cash and investment accounts at Riggs Bank, until banking regulators forced accounts closed earlier this year; accounts, as well as accounts held by former Chilean dictator Gen Augusto Pinochet and by Saudi Arabian Embassy, are part of wide-ranging federal probe of possible money laundering and terrorist financing at Riggs; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar rises on expectations that Federal Reserve will lift its interest rate on overnight loans between banks; euro settles at $1.2165, down from $1.2178, in New York trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: SanDisk Shares Soar On Sales Forecast
abstract: SanDisk Corp's shares rise as much as 29 percent after it forecasts sales this quarter may exceed analysts' estimates; graph (S)

headline: A Bush Aide (and a Mother) Emerges as a Major Player in the Antiterror Campaign
abstract: Frances Fragos Townsend, White House domestic security adviser, has moved to center stage role as advocate of raising terrorist threat level with urgent warnings of possible attack; she is one of few officials from Clinton administration to retain senior job; before being named to her current post in May, she worked as Condoleezza Rice's counterterrorism deputy, and still performs those duties; photo (M)

headline: Rewound: A Lesson In Hot Properties
abstract: THE truth is, I did not get one of the hot gadgets of my first year of college until well into the second semester.     That is probably just as well, because if I had bought it earlier, it might have affected my level of engagement with classes and classmates. I would have been tuned out.

headline: Dominican Retires Rich
abstract: Former Pres Hipolito Mejia of Dominican Republic, who lost his bid for re-election, left office a millionaire even as most of his countrymen saw deepening poverty (S)

headline: Feast for marketers:It's all about soccer
abstract: MILAN  With their chiseled cheeks, tattooed arms and cross-bearing chests, the Italian soccer stars Christian Vieri and Paolo Maldini look more like Harley riders than fashion icons. Throw a diamond-laden David Beckham into the mix and one wouldn't be faulted for mistaking Europe's soccer royalty with the in-your-face flash of America's rap stars.

headline: Colombia's Paramilitary Factions Offered Safe Haven
abstract: The offer stands as long as the groups declare an immediate cease-fire and begin disarming.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Growth In Exports
abstract: Hong Kong reports its Aug exports rose 21 percent from 2003 level to 182.7 billion Hong Kong dollars ($23.4 billion); goods made in China and shipped through Hong Kong account for over 90 percent of city's overseas sales (S)

abstract: Analysts and critics in Philippines say Pres Gloria Macapagal Arroyo had no choice but to accede to demands of Iraqi insurgents who abducted Philippine truck driver last week and threaten to kill him unless country withdraws its troops by July 20; say risk of disappointing Washington, her most important ally, is easily outweighed by potential political retaliation that could have imperiled her political and economic agenda for next six years; photo (M)

headline: For Internet Subscribers, A Bonus: A Cut-Rate PC
abstract: America Online offers AOL Optimized PC for $300 to people who sign up for dial-up service for at least one year; photo (S)

headline: Love of Leisure, and Europe's Reasons
abstract: Europe has shortest workweeks and longest holidays in world; its citizens are on average almost 30 percent poorer than their counterparts on other side of Atlantic, and potential growth in next decade risks being stuck at 2 percent; some economists and European officials argue that, rather than reflecting failure to catch up with more industrious competitors because of faltering productivity growth, Europe's more modest income level mainly reflects policy choices that have tended to put premium on leisure and equality at expense of greater wealth; photo; graph (M)

headline: Fierce Gunbattles Rage for a Second Day in Iraq
abstract: American commanders in charge of the Najaf operation said that 2 marines had been killed and 12 wounded in the fighting.

headline: U.S. Trade Gap Reached Record $166.2 Billion in 2nd Quarter
abstract: The record trade deficit, a sign of the growing imbalance of the U.S. dollar against other currencies, raised new concerns about the country's indebtedness.

headline: No Tears for Trump in Atlantic City's Casinos
abstract: News that Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts intends to seek bankruptcy protection elicits little sympathy from gamblers, as they go about normal routines at three Trump casino resorts in Atlantic City; some gamblers comment; photo (M)

headline: China Holds Candidate From Hong Kong on Prostitution Charge
abstract: Hong Kong's already heated election campaign for legislature takes new twist with arrest of Democratic Party candidate Alex Ho on charges of soliciting prostitute in Dongguan, on mainland; Ho is sentenced without trial to six months in detention (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Sale Of Apartments Is Approved
abstract: World Business Briefing: Germany: Sale of Apartmen

headline: Taesung Village Journal; In a DMZ That Bristles Less, the Villagers Are at Home
abstract: Demilitarized zone dividing Korean peninsula remains enclosed in barbed wire fences, surrounded by hundreds of thousands of soldiers; in 1955, North and South agreed to build model villages in DMZ to extol each side's superior way of life; in South Korea's Taesung Village, lavish propaganda spending is evident in village's school, which receives special budget allowing it to buy equipment and facilities found in no other school; photos; map (M)

headline: Pyongyang critics face dissuasion, intimidation and threats : South cool to anti-Kim activists
Japan's Economy Continues to Grow, but at a Slower Rate
abstract: Japan's gross domestic product grew at annual rate of 1.7 percent for second quarter ended June 30, less than 4.2 percent predicted by economists; growth rate is sharp slowdown from 6.6 percent in first quarter; consumption among Japanese households declined 2.6 percent in June, compared with figures year earlier; current account surplus rose 15.7 percent in June from year ago; unemployment rate was at its lowest level in more than three and half years in June, at 4.6 percent; photo (M)

headline: Proposals on How to Handle Options
abstract: Accounting for stock options has become internatinal battleground, but those conflicts may be nearing end as major industrial countries move toward rules that force companies to deduct value of options from their earnings; new battles may be brewing in different but related area: taxation of profits deprived from exercising options; Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development recommends that workers should be taxed by countries in which they performed labor for which option was rewarded (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Paris Airport To Reopen Partly
abstract: Charles de Gaulle International Airport (Paris) Air France terminal, which experienced structural collapse in May, is scheduled to reopen non-damaged section in mid-August to help ease airport congestion; four people were killed in collapse (S)

headline: Time on a Chip: The Incredible Shrinking Atomic Clock
abstract: What's Next column explores development of atomic clocks using standard semiconductor process; device would replace quartz oscillators used in watches and electronic devices; drawing (M)

headline: Mixed on Missiles
abstract: Senate Intelligence Committe report finds that intelligence agencies' assessments of Iraqi efforts to build medium-range missiles were 'reasonable,' but says agencies 'overstated' Iraqi efforts to develop pilotless drone aircraft or their potential use in dropping biological weapons on US (M)

headline: Magazine Advertising Continues Recovery
abstract: Magazine Advertising.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Bank Executives Suspended
abstract: BOC

headline: Voting With Your Mutual Fund Pocketbook
abstract: John Schwarz humorous article on creating separate mutual funds for investors who support Republican and Democratic candidates; suggests stocks for each fund; drawing (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: HARRIS INTERACTIVE INC., Rochester, a market-research consulting firm, said it had bought WirthlinWorldwide, Reston, Va., an opinion-research and consulting company, for $41.8 million.    BANK OF NEW YORK CO., New York, and Standard Bank Group Ltd., a South African banking company, said they had started talks with Old Mutual Asset Managers South Africa Ltd. to form an investment administration company in South Africa.

headline: Militant Group in Iraq Claims It Beheaded 3 Men
abstract: The militants posted a gruesome video of the beheading of three men said to be members of a Kurdish political party in Iraq.

headline: Nortel Expects Restatement to Halve '03 Net
abstract: Nortel Networks, under investigation by US and Canadian regulators, says restatement of its results will probably cut 2003 net income in half, in line with previous forecasts (M)

headline: Two Dentsu Agencies Merge in New York
abstract: Dentsu Holdings USA MERGERS its New York-based agency Oasis Advertising into another, DCA Advertising (S)

headline: Opposition Offers Compromise in Venezuela
abstract: Venezuela's largest and most influential business association Fedecamaras, in break with other government opponents, says it is prepared to embark on talks over economy's future with Pres Hugo Chavez, but offer is rebuffed by administration; Interior Min Jesse Chacon says government rejected offer because association receives orders from Democratic Coordinator, opposition group intent on removing Chavez, and does not reflect general position of most businessmen; group's president Albis Munoz comments; photo (M)

headline: Finding Holes in Corporate Excuses
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission may be cracking down on some creative excuses for disappointing company results; cites Krispy Kreme chief executive Scott A Livengood's claim that company has been hurt by low-carbohydrate diet craze while Dunkin' Donuts has not reported slowdown; notes Donald J Trump cited higher gasoline prices as reason for recent profit slump at Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts; photo (M)

headline: Cisco Reports Strong Revenue In 4th Quarter
abstract: Cisco Systems reports net income of $1.38 billion in fiscal fourth quarter ended July 31, up 41 percent from $982 million year earlier; revenue was $5.9 billion, compared with $4.7 billion year ago and $5.62 billion in previous quarter; chief executive John T Chambers comments; photo (M)

headline: Behind the Curve; Access on Metro-North or Amtrak Cars? Not So Fast
abstract: Roundup of transportation services in New York area that offer wireless Internet access (S)

headline: Videotapes Were Souvenirs Of Trip, Man's Brother Says
abstract: Irfan Akhtar, whose Pakistani-American brother Kamran Shaikh was arrested in North Carolina after videotaping buildings and transit systems in several states, denies that Shaikh has any connections to terrorism; describes Shaikh, who lies in Elmhurst, Queeens, as family man who loves United States; Shaikh has been charged with immigration violations, and authorities say terrorism investigation is continuing (M)

headline: Lessons in Reality for Apprentices
abstract: German government's plan is forcing millions of companies to hire extra apprentices or pay 50,000 euro annual fine; Social Democat-Green Party ruling coalition is poised to levy fee that businesses say will worsen prolonged economic stagnation; Germany's economic growth is averaging just 0.3 percent a year since 2001, and unemployment in May was 10.5 percent; most companies with 11 or more workers that do not employ 7 percent of their work force as apprentices will be forced to pay 3,500 euros a year for each missing apprentice; business groups and opposition conservative lawmakers are threatening lawsuits if Chancellor Gerhard Schroder imposes fine; photos (M)

headline: CARNIVAL TO MOVE CUNARD LINE'S OPERATIONS TO CALIFORNIA
abstract: Carnival Corp, cruise operator, will move North American operations of its Cunard Line to Santa Clarita, Calif, from Miami, eliminating as many as 300 positions and saving about $20 million annually (S)
