headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Aug 29 article: Jeffrey K Skilling got his MBA from Harvardm

headline: Brazilians forsaking big cities for work
Will a Short Sentence Prove Sweet for a Stock?
abstract: Article on whether short sentence for Martha Stewart in ImClone Systems stock case will help or hurt stock of Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia; photo (M)

headline: Electronics Recycling Plan
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co will offer free electronics recycling through program with Office Depot Inc; customers can drop off any brand of electronics at any Office Depot's 850 stores from July 18 through Sept 6; Hewlett-Packard will recycle products at its California and Tennessee plants (S)

headline: Ernst & Young Faces Inquiry in Britain
abstract: British arm of accounting firm Ernst & Young faces investigation into its auditing of Equitable Life Assurance Society, insurer that almost collapsed; Ernst & Young says complaints are unfounded and misguided and plans vigorous defense (S)p

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: 6 Injured In Blasts At Voting Office
abstract: United Nations officials confirm news reports of six bombs detonated oustide Farah Province election office; Taliban, who have vowed to disrupt Oct 9 elections, claim responsibility for blasts, which injured seven policmen (S)

headline: Discrimination on Wall St.? The Numbers Tell the Story
abstract: Morgan Stanley as well as Merrill Lynch and Smith Barney decided not to go public with their track records of hiring, paying and promoting women in discrimination lawsuits because their figures would have been hard to defend; figures show Wall Street is still dominated by white men who fill bulk of most of powerful and highest-paying jobs in industry; Equal Employment Opportunity Commission data show men made up more than two-thirds of officials and manages in securities industry in 2002, even higher than ratio in other industries; Securities Industry Association says more than half of all employees in securities industry are white men but white men fill about four out of five executive management positions and make up more than 70 percent of investment bankers, traders and brokers; chart; photo (Market Place column) (M)

headline: A Trail to Rumsfeld
abstract: Analysis of report by panel headed by James R Schlesinger, which traces responsibility for Abu Ghraib prison abuses up to management failures by Sec Donald H Rumsfeld's office, but says it would be mistake for him to resign over issue; report rarely mentions him by name; sharply criticizes failure of his office to anticipate and respond swiftly to post-invasion insurgency; photo (M)

headline: A Princess's Distress Pierces Japan's Veil of Secrecy
abstract: Japan's Imperial Household Agency announces that Princess Masako, who has stayed out of public view for months, is receiving therapy for depression and anxiety; photos (M)

headline: Most unions agree to split Alitalia in 2
COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Birds Eye Foods Inc., Rochester, the processor of frozen vegetables, said that it had acquired California and Washington Co., San Francisco, a frozen vegetable marketer. Terms were not disclosed.    Home Products International Inc., Chicago, a maker of house wares, received an offer from Equity Group Investments, Chicago, to buy the company for $1.75 a share in cash, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Home Products had previously agreed to be bought by JRT Acquisition Inc. for $1.50 a share.    Brookfield Properties Corp., New York, an owner of commercial properties, said it had bought the Potomac Tower, a 19-story office building in Rosslyn, Va., from Deutsche Immobilien Fonds, a German real estate company, for $106 million.    Celestica Inc., Toronto, which makes electronics for other companies, said it would sell its power systems unit to C&D Technologies, Blue Bell, Pa., a maker of electrical systems. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Industrial Output Rises
abstract: India reports 7.6 percent rise in manufacturing and 15.1 percent rise in consumer durables in July (S)

headline: AMERICAN GREETINGS TO SELL UNIT THAT MAKES EYEWEAR
abstract: American Greetings Corp sells its Magnivision division, which makes nonprescription reading glasses, to AAi.FosterGrant; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: France Announces Renewal of Diplomatic Ties With Iraq
abstract: Analysts said that given France's opposition to the U.S.-led invasion, it was unlikely to win access to reconstruction contracts.

headline: U.S. Warns China It May Impose Limits on Apparel Imports
abstract: The U.S. warned it would limit apparel imports from China if U.S. manufacturers provided evidence that such limits were needed.

headline: Arrests and Plots Give South Africans a New Problem
abstract: String of international arrests of South African citizens, followed by sensational reports of terrorist plots against tourism and financial sites, raises new questions about depth of Islamic extremism in country; two Pretoria-area men were arrested during raid on suspected Al Qaeda hide-out in Gujrat, Pakistan, and Gujrat's police commissioner says they had 'terror plans for South Africa' and maps of several South African cities; in Mexico, third South African Muslim is arrested after authorities find irregularities in his travel documents; national police service contended last May, to some skepticism, that it thwarted Qaeda plot to disrupt South Africa's national elections; photos (M)

headline: Wal-Mart and Productivity
abstract: Jeff Madrick's Economic Scene column on Wal-Mart as new model of American productivity but company that pays low wages; says new study by Arindrajit Dube and Ken Jacobs of University of California, Berkeley, has produced evidence of Wal-Mart's comparatively low wages; researchers calculate that in San Francisco Bay Area, company's average wage, about $11 per hour, is about 30 percent below what unionized workers get in local grocery chains; also find that average Wal-Mart wage for all of California is 20 to 30 percent below average wage paid by retailers with 1,000 ormore workers; photo (M)

headline: Putin Dismisses 4 Senior Military Officers
abstract: Moving to both quell a feud for control of the Russian military, President Vladimir V. Putin dismissed four officers today.

headline: United Provides an Idea of Worker Pension Losses
abstract: United Airlines in bankruptcy court describes how possible pension termination would affect its tens of thousands of employees and retirees, in filing that seems intended to both prepare and reassure them about impending default; says consequences may not be as dire for most plan participants as they might fear; adds various workers' benefits might be reduced as result of termination; reductions are result of limits on government's pension-insurance coverage; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Chemical Spinoff
abstract: German drug and chemical company Bayer will spin its Lanxess chemical division off rather than hold initial public offering of shares in unit (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Adobe Profit Rises 62% As Sales Increase
abstract: Adobe Systems says third-quarter profit rose 62 percent; net income rose to $104.5 million from $64.5 million year ago; sales rose 27 percent, to $403.7 million (S)

headline: World Bank Challenged: Are the Poor Really Helped?
abstract: Development economists question effectiveness of huge sums spent in third world each year by wealthy nations and international organizations like World Bank, saying there is scant evidence that myriad projects have made any real difference in lives of world's 2.7 billion poor people; MIT's Poverty Action Lab, in randomized evaluations that are considered gold standard of policy research, finds good results from simple tactics, such as hiring remedial tutors in Bombay slum or giving Kenyan students free uniforms and breakfast, and even better results from deworming drugs that make children healthy enough to go to school; photos (M)

headline: The Sleep of Forgetfulness (and the Bed Remembers)
abstract: Article on buying memory foam mattress, based on technology developed by NASA; H Thomas Bryant, president of North American operations at Tempur-Pedic, manufacturer of foam mattresses, says foam provides support that conventional mattresses cannot match; photo (M)

headline: Fed Study Regards Its Strategy a Success
abstract: Study led by Federal Reserve governor Ben S Bernanke shows unusual strategy adopted by Federal Reserve in summer of 2003 for stoking nation's economy without cutting interest rates was success; says central bank exerted powerful effects on longer-term interest rates by promising to keep key short-term federal funds rate low for 'considerable period'; study's conclusions support confidence that many Fed policy makers showed late in 2002 and early 2003 asd Wall Street fretted that central bank was running out of ammunition to stimulate economy (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Deals: LeCroy To Acquire Computer Access
abstract: LeCroy Corp will acquire Computer Access Technology Corp for about $85 million in cash and stock options; graph (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Jet Purchase
abstract: Air Canada to buy 30 regional aircraft from Bombardier Aerospace for $821 million; jets will be used by Air Canada Jazz, airline's wholly owned regional operating unit; airline, set to emerge from bankruptcy, could expand order to 90 planes (S)

headline: As Deadline Nears, Yukos Faces a $3.4 Billion Tax Bill
abstract: Russian prosecutors harden their tone against oil company Yukos as crucial July 7 deadline nears, when government could begin seizing its assets; Yukos has until July 7 to pay $3.4 billion tax bill that it says would force it into insolvency; general prosecutor Vladimir Ustinov hints further tax claims could be filed against Yukos, in addition to $3.4 billion judgment confirmed by courts for 2000 and similar claim by tax agency for 2001 (M)

headline: As a Business Gets Bigger, Its Radios Get Smaller
abstract: Sirius and XM, whose satellite radio receivers are being purchased by growing number of car buyers as factory-installed option, seek to expand market for their fee-based service by selling smaller after-market receivers, for use in car and at home, with range of new capabilities (M)

headline: People
abstract: Kevin Moehlenkamp is named executive vice president and executive creative director at Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopolos, succeeding Marty Donohue, who became group creative director in May; Craig Cooper is named executive creative director at Dallas office of DDB Worldwide, succeeding Steve Schweitzer (S)

headline: IHS ENERGY ACQUIRES CAMBRIDGE ENERGY RESEARCH
abstract: IHS Energy, which provides maps and technical databases to oil and natural gas producers, acquires Cambridge Energy Research Associates, consulting company founded by author Daniel Yergin; financial terms undisclosed; IHS Energy is owned by Thyssen-Bornemisza Group; Cambridge is owned by Clayton, Dubilier & Rice Inc (S)

headline: Stocks Dip on Fresh Economic Concerns
abstract: Bond prices shot higher and interest rates fell after the government reported that job growth in June was much weaker than expected.

headline: Advanced Micro Narrows Gap in Race for New Chip
abstract: Advanced Micro Devices has begun to ship computer chips based on advanced manufacturing process that is being used to build next generation of processors; Advanced Micro is trailing rivals Intel and IBM in making shift to new 90-nanometer manufacturing process, which makes it possible to put more transistors on single chip or shrink size of existing chips, effectively increasing performance while lowering prices (M)

headline: Mutual Fund and Top Officer Fined Over Valuation of Securities
abstract: Garrett Van Wagoner, who oversaw some of America's top-performing mutual funds in late 1990's, and his firm Van Wagoner Capital Management agree to pay $800,000 to settle accusations by Securities and Exchange Commission that they misstated value of 'illiquid securities' in their funds; Van Wagoner will resign as president of company and will be barred from serving as fund director or officer for seven years (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stewart Seeks to Begin Her Prison Term Soon  Saying she wished to ''put this nightmare behind me,'' Martha Stewart said she wanted to enter a federal prison as soon as possible to begin serving her five-month sentence without waiting to see whether an appeals court would overturn her conviction on conspiracy and other charges earlier this year.     ''I am very sad knowing I will miss the holiday season,'' Ms. Stewart said at a news conference, ticking off Halloween, Thanksgiving and Christmas as celebrations she will have to observe behind bars. [Page A1.]

headline: World Briefings
abstract: ASIA.

headline: Technology Briefing | Deals: WebMD To Buy ViPS For $160 Million
abstract: WebMD Corp acquires information-technology company ViPS Inc for $160 million to gain business from government's Medicare program; graph (S)

headline: A Growing Force Of Nonworkers
abstract: Edmund L Andrews Economic View column questions why Pres Bush says economy is strong and getting stronger when so many people are not only out of work but also not looking for jobs; holds shortfall of jobs that has built up over last years is not one million as Sen John Kerry assets but four million, and possibly higher; says if shortage has been forme4d by millions of additional discouraged job seeks, Bush will have much harder time persuading voters that economy is heading in right direction; holds if US has huge reserve pool of workers, Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan may be correct in asserting that economy has room to expand without big wage increases; that would reduce inflationary pressure and allow Fed to raise interest rates slowly; graph (M)

headline: IRAQ UPDATE
abstract: Latest events in Iraq briefly noted; map (S)

headline: Time Warner and Comcast Discuss Bid for Adelphia
abstract: Cable operator Comcast Corp says it is in talks with Time Warner Inc to make joint bid for Adelphia Communications, bankrupt cable company; deal would make it possible for Comcast to exchange its 21 percent stake in Time Warner Cable for parts of Adelphia's networks in tax-efficient manner; chart of seven parcels Adelphia seeks to sell piecemeal or as single company; map (M)

headline: Afghan Forces Retake Air Base
abstract: Forces of newly trained Afghan National Army take control of air base in western Herat Province, where 21 people were killed after local commander attacked base; in southern Afghanistan, fighting against suspected Taliban members continues (S)

headline: People
abstract: Steve Diamond is named executive vice president and executive creative director at Sloan Group; assumes some duties that had been handled by president-chief creative officer Cliff Sloan, who is planning to leave after undetermined transition period; Joseph Lagani is named vice president and publisher at House and Garden magazine, succeeding Lori Burgess, who is leaving (S)

headline: Nokia Falters, and the Finns Take Stock
abstract: Finns, reflecting on decline of Nokia as world's leader in mobile phone industry, seem to be lowering their expectations for technology sector; Nokia stock, bellwether for technology industry, peaked in early 2000 and has lost more than 80 percent of its value since then; while Nokia remains by far biggest mobile phone maker in world, it's share of market has slipped below 30 percent this year from over 35 percent last year; company, in response, has warned investors of lower earnings forecasts and cut its prices in effort to win back market share lost to Samsung, Motorola and other rivals; graph; photos (M)

headline: CENDANT STILL SEEKING BUYER FOR MORTGAGE UNIT
abstract: Cendant Corp ends talks with potential buyer for its mortgage business; will talk with other possible buyers of unit as well as consider what it calls strategic alternatives (S)

headline: U.P.S. Insurance Settlement Approved
abstract: By Bloomberg News.

headline: Parmalat Files Lawsuit Against UBS
abstract: Parmalat sues Swiss bank UBS for 290 million euros ($350 million), second move in week by Parmalat against banks that helped in finance more than decade of losses and financial fraud (S)

headline: Olympia Journal; Olympics' Old Home to Play Host Again (Zeus Willing)
abstract: Organizers of 2004 Olympic Games, hoping to recapture bit of long-ago flavor, will stage one sporting event in Olympia, site of original Olympics; men's and women's shot-put competition wil be held on packed dirt field where audiences were wowed in first century BC; not much remains from those days but ruins; photos; map (M)

headline: Outlook is bleaker for some companies : Japanese carmakers adding to gains in Europe
Euro RSCG Worldwide Adds New York Chief
abstract: Euro RSCG Worldwide names David Jones, executive vice president and managing director for global business, to new post of chief executive for New York (S)

headline: Vatican Shuts Austria Seminary Under Cloud
abstract: Vatican shuts down seminary in St Polten, Austria, that has been accused of harboring widespread sexual misconduct, including distribution of child pornography; Austrian church still bears scars of scandal in 1998, when Cardinal Hans Hermann Groer gave up church duties after being accused of molesting boys decades earier; in present case, those from St Polten seminary who want to continue path toward priesthood must undergo fresh screening process; Bishop Kurt Krenn of St Polten has resisted calls for seminary to be closed, prompting calls by church liberals for him to resign; map (M)

headline: Pan-European banking gets push from the Dutch
Oil Up to Nearly $41 a Barrel On Sharp Fall in Inventories
abstract: Crude oil prices rise to six-week high in New York after Energy Department reports largest drop in oil inventories in three months amid surging demand; US inventories fell by 2.1 million barrels last week; oil for August delivery rises $1.53, or 3.9 percent, to $40.97 per barrel in New York trading; September contract rises $1.66, or 4.2 percent, to $41.20 per barrel; graph; chart (M)

headline: E-Commerce Report; Photo-sharing Web sites have a place for your pictures in their digital albums, alongside messages from advertisers.
abstract: Growing popularity of digital photography helps create profitable business for Web sites that allow people share their digital photos with friends and family; strength is reflected in CNET Networks' acquisition of Webshots, longtime market leader, and Google's acquisition of Picasa, relative newcomer; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank Ruling Upheld
abstract: Tokyo court upholds order that UFJ Holdings cease part of its takeover talks with Mitsubishi Tokyo Financial Group, move that seems likely to complicate talks aimed at creating world's largest bank (S)

headline: PASSION FOR PORSCHE
abstract: New

headline: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Milosevic's Lawyers Ask For Trial Suspension
abstract: Newly court-appointed British defense lawyers representing Slobodan Milosevic ask court to suspend trial while Milosevic appeals appointment of council by United Nations judges (S)

headline: DISNEY'S DIRECTOR TO RECEIVE RETAINER OF $500,000 IN STOCK
abstract: Walt Disney Co says it will pay presiding director George Mitchell retainer of $500,000 in stock in quarterly increments of $125,000; raises fees paid to other board members to $65,000, from $45,000 (S)

headline: Even Near Home, a New Front Is Opening in the Terror Battle
abstract: Federal investigators are examining Web sites they suspect of having links to terrorist groups; Al Qaeda is thought to be recruiting online, reaching broad audience with relatively little chance of detection; investigators warn that site creators and administrators could be held responsible for what they post; civil libertarians and others are alarmed as federal government, attempting to apply broad new powers established by Patriot Act, wants to punish those who it claims provide 'expert advice or assistance' and therefore play integral part of global terror campaign that increasingly relies on Internet; federal investigators have help of small army of private contractors who monitor sites around clock and across world; in Clifton, NJ, Internet company called Fortress ITX unwittingly played host to Arabic-language Web site where postings in recent weeks urged attacks against American and Israeli targets; site has been taken down; photos of three sites that have come under scrutiny; photos (L)

headline: Polish President Appeals for a More 'Open and Gracious' U.S.
abstract: Polish Pres Alexander Kwasniewski makes plea for United States to be 'flexible, open and gracious' and to avoid 'divide and rule policy'; stands by his decision to send troops to Iraq, despite polls showing about 70 percent of Poles calling for bringing troops home; contends role of troops will change from occupation to peacekeeping after new Iraqi government is installed; says he is 'hurt' by American decision to impose visas on Poles (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Land Prices Fall
abstract: Japanese land prices fell for 13th consecutive year; average price of commercial properties fell 6.5 percent for year ended July 1, compared with 7.4 percent decline year earlier; residential land prices fell 4.6 percent for year, compared with 4.8 percent decline year ago (S)d

headline: Bombing in Tel Aviv Kills a Soldier and Wounds 20 Israelis
abstract: Bomb explodes next to Tel Aviv bus stop, killing Israeli soldier and injuring 20 other Israelis; Prime Min Ariel Sharon calls for Israel to respond by pressing ahead with West Bank barrier to separate Palestinians and Israelis, which international court has ruled illegal; attack is first deadly bombing inside Israel in nearly four months; Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades claims responsibility for bombing, calling it revenge for recent Israeli raids in West Bank and Gaza Strip; Yasir Arafat denounces attack, then hints that Israelis might have been behind bombing; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Angry Words By Rebels
abstract: Sri Lankan Tamil Tigers, rebel group, accuses President Chandrika Kumaratunga of inciting unrest with group and destroying relationship developed during two-year cease-fire; threatens to return to armed conflict; photo (S)

headline: Software Services Firm Is Latest In India to Plan Initial Offering
abstract: Initial public offering of Tata Consultancy Services, Tata Group unit that is India's premier software services firm, is expected to raise $935 million to $1.25 billion on sale of 55.4 million shares, or about 13.33 percent of its equity; road show to promote offering in Mumbai drew around 700 brokers and analysts, twice number company expected; Tata Group has been criticized for not taking TCS public during technology boom in 1990's, but Tata says making offering in overheated market goes against its principle of being fair to shareholders; Tata says it will use cash from TCS offering to retire debt and expand other businesses; photo (M)

headline: Equity Investors Buy Stake in a Big Hollywood Agency
abstract: Firm, leading Hollywood talent management company, sells minority stake to private equity investors Thomas H Lee Partners and Bain Capital; will use funds for day-to-day operations and possible acquisitions; Thomas H Lee will join board (M)

headline: Correction
At 5 Buildings, A Day of Pluck And Patienc
abstract: Five financial institutions cited by Bush administration as possible election-year terrorist targets, and thousands of workers in New York, New Jersey and Washington, appear to take alert and precautions in stride; workers mindful of alarming new intelligence reports still troop to work at New York Stock Exchange and Citigroup tower in New York, to International Monetary Fund and World Bank in Washington, and to Prudential Financial headquarters in Newark; political leaders are encouraged by public's response; description of some heightened security measures taken; photos (M)

headline: Parmalat Files Suit Against First Boston
abstract: Enrico Bondi, chairman of Parmalat Finanziaria, sues Credit Suisse First Boston, seeking to recover 248 million euros from transaction done before Parmalat collapsed in December (S)

headline: On the Trail of a Persistent Pest
abstract: Researchers at East Carolina University, Greenville, NC, are investigating whether they can speed up tracking of mosquitoes carrying West Nile Virus by sharing their expertise with general public through wireless computers; testing of mosquito identification system begins this fall; photo (M)

headline: the end user / A voice for the consumer : Bluetooth now lives up to hype
Miller Escalates Ad War With Anheuser-Busch
abstract: Miller Brewing division of SABMiller is escalating dispute against principal rival Anheuser-Busch Companies, with commercials that reintroduce taste test claims to beer wars (S)

headline: Nonprofit Hospital Agrees To Limits on Patient Fees
abstract: North Mississippi Health Systems agrees to provide almost free care to low-income people who lack medical insurance in Mississippi, Alabama and Tennessee; enters deal to avoid being sued by Richard Scruggs, who says deal could serve as pattern for settlements with nonprofit hospitals in 21 states that he and coalition of lawyers have accused of not providing enough free or low-cost care to justify their tax-exempt status; lawsuit is filed, nevertheless, so that federal judge can approve settlement and determine fees for Scruggs and other lawyers; American Hospital Association assails deal, saying volley of lawsuits filed against nonprofit hospitals are baseless (M)

headline: Semiconductors Offer a New Way to Cut the Cord
abstract: What's Next column on ultrawideband radio technology, which is being adapted for consumer electronics to facilitate rapid, cable-free transfer of large digital files; drawing (M)

headline: South Koreans Repeat: We Have No Atom Bomb Program
abstract: South Korean officials continue to assure world that nation has no nuclear arms program; fear of more intrusive, short-notice visits to nuclear sites by International Atomic Energy Agency inspectors seems to have caused South Koreans to volunteer information on tests by what it calls group of rogue scientists; scientists brought uranium close to weapons grade by using lasers, apparently in violation of North Korea-South Korea mutual pledge not to process fuel or enrich uranium; so far North Korea has not commented on revelations; Japan wants tighter control by IAEA; China calls for more international safeguards (M)

headline: As Sales Dip, Nokia Issues A Warning On Earnings
abstract: Nokia reports second-quarter decline in sales and slashes its earnings forecast for current quarter, as it continues to cut prices to try to win back customers; total sales fell 5 percent from year ago, to 6.64 billion euros ($8.19 billion), while operating profit from cellphones fell 39 percent, to 797 million euros; net income was 712 million euros, up 14 percent from last year; photo (M)

headline: Arab Reactions Vary as Ex-Dictator Has a Day in Court
abstract: As Saddam Hussein faced charges in Baghdad, governments across the Middle East largely kept silent about the extraordinary appearance of an Arab leader in the docket.

headline: Spain Considers Financing for Major Religions
abstract: Spanish Justice Ministry proposal would expand government financing to religious institutions; security officials say one intention is to subsidize mosques to make them less dependent on money from militant groups abroad; there is widespread belief amoung counterterrorism officials in Spain that country's mosques are vulnerable to influences of militant groups because they feel need to turn to militants for money; legal scholars say proposal would test limits of Spain's separation of church and state; Spain has six formally established mosques and up to 230 small, informal ones; proposal to finance them has stoked opposition from conservatives, but has support of counterterrorism specialists (M)

headline: 9/11 Panel's Report to Offer New Evidence of Iran-Qaeda Ties
abstract: Final report of commission examining Sept 11, 2001, terrorist attacks will cite evidence of cooperation between Iran and Al Qaeda; finds no evidence Iran knew about Sept 11 plot, but contends Iranian officials were directed not to stamp passports of Al Qaeda members moving through country from training camps in Afghanistan; as many as 10 of hijackers passed through Iran; evidence raises new questions about Bush administration's focus on Iraq (M)

headline: PICTURE WINDOW : California dreaming
World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Terror Suspect's Case
abstract: Milan (Italy) court denies defense motion to supress monitored conversations in case of Egyptian Rabei Osman Sayed Ahmed, who is accused of masterminding March 11 Madrid train bombings (S)

headline: DataBank; Microsoft Creates a Stir, but Markets Retreat
abstract: Market declines in week despite Federal Reserve Chmn Alan Greenspan's soothing words and Microsoft announcement of one-time special dividend to shareholders; graphs (M)

headline: Sell in Bulk, Lose Farm. Sell Locally, and Watch Revenues Grow.
abstract: Some family farms, unable to survive by serving bulk commodity market, are taking more entrepreneurial approach, selling fresh food directly to local markets; state governments are beginning to see such farms as asset capable of generating jobs and slowing suburban sprawl; photos (special section, Small Business) (M)

headline: Oh, No! I Did What At the Company Picnic?
abstract: Q. You quaffed more Pabst Blue Ribbon than was wise at the annual company picnic. That led to some embarrassing behavior on your part, including pegging your boss with a wild pitch in the softball game and splitting eardrums with your karaoke rendition of ''Stairway to Heaven.'' How can you make amends on Monday?    A. Most gaffes at company outings can be smoothed over with an apology and a little self-effacing humor, says Lisa Johnson, a senior vice president at Lee Hecht Harrison, a career and leadership development company based in Woodcliff Lake, N.J.     (An apology doesn't do the job for gaffes involving sexual or drunken behaviors that raise legal implications for the company, but that's another column.)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Aid Workers Killed In Ambush
abstract: United Nations reports that two Afghans working for Malteser, German aid group, have been ambushed and killed near Gardez (Afghanistan) (S)

headline: 3 Iraqi Guardsmen and 6 Americans Killed
abstract: Car bomb in Baquba kills at least three Iraqi national guardsmen; photos; US military reports deaths of six American troops in several incidents, including two in roadside bombing in Baghdad; Pres Ayad Allawi returns from Mideast tour, asking neighboring countries like Syria and Iran to share information on terrorists; police chief is killed in bomb in Mansour neighborhood of Baghdad (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Trade Surplus Grows
abstract: Brazil posts trade surplus in July of $3.48 billion, up 69 percent from year earlier; accumulated surplus for first seven months of 2004 is $18.53 billion, up from surplus of $12.45 billion in year-earlier period; exports totaled $8.99 billion in July, while imports reached $5.51 billion (S)

headline: London Journal; Is Anything Sacred Here? Well, That's Worth a Wager
abstract: Wagering is very popular in Britain and Internet makes gambling easier than ever; bookies are offering novelty betting, like how many sips of water government official will take during speech; it is mostly low-stakes venture, but it has soared in Britain and Ireland in past five years, attracting swath of new, casual gamblers, some of them women, who hope to make money by guessing when some celebrity will divorce; photos (M)

headline: Fannie Mae Crisis Raises Concerns on Leadership
abstract: Charges of accounting irregularities at Fannie Mae leave chairman Franklin D Raines struggling to maintain control over nation's largest backer of home mortgages, and maneuver it through thicket of regulatory and political shoals; he and predecessor, James A Johnson, both prominent Democratic fixtures in highest ranks of Washington society, were at helm of company when it allegedly engaged in sloppy and misleading accounting practices that enabled top executives to earn fatter bonuses; Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight report is explicitly critical of their subordinates, but is silent on precise role played by Raines and Johnson in accounting issue; photo (M)

headline: ON ADVERTISING : Grey sale marks end of an era
Economic Calendar
abstract: Today.

headline: Reporter Freed As Rebel Cleric Brokers a Deal
abstract: Kidnapped American journalist Micah Garen is released after intervention of cleric Moktada al-Sadr, whose Shiite militia is engaged in heavy fighting, trying to fend off renewed American assault near holiest shrine in Najaf; American tanks and planes bombard guerrilla positions around shrine after talks with Sadr's forces appear to break down; Garen and his Iraqi interpreter Amir Doushi had been investigating looting of ancient archaeological sites in Nasiriya when they were kidnapped by group calling itself Martyrs Brigade and threatened with death unless Americans left Najaf; senior aide to Sadr says kidnappers brought Garen to his office after repeated pleas by Sadr and his aides to free them; Garen and Doushi are turned over to Americans by Sadr's representatives in Nasiriya; Garen, speaking to Al Jazeera television moments after his release, thanks Sadr's representatives and others who worked to free him; Americans close to negotiations to free two men confirms that Sadr worked hard to get men released; photos (M)

headline: The Oil Market Refuses to Heed Positive News
abstract: World energy markets are so concerned about strong demand and possible disruptions of supplies that oil prices finish higher, even though Saudi Arabia announces it has capacity to pump 1.3 million more barrels each day immediately if needed; low-sulfur crude oil for September delivery settles at $44.80 per barrel in New York trading, up 28 cents; International Energy Agency says world's use of oil will be even greater in rest of 2004 and in 2005 than it previously forecast, increasing pressure on producers to step up output at time when rising oil prices could slow world economic recovery; graph; photos (M)

headline: Google's Offering Proves Stock Auctions Can Really Work
abstract: Google's success at going public at very attractive valuation while denying underwriters ostensibly unrelated profits they derive from ability to allocate shares in hot offerings shows stock auctions can work; underwriters apparently priced Google's Dutch auction low enough to insure that price would rise above offering price; unorthodox approach resulted in less flipping of shares in first day than was typical for technology shares in 1990's; table of hot technology offerings (M)

headline: Profit Surges at LG Electronics on Strong Cellphone Sales
abstract: LG Electronics Inc, giant South Korean electronics maker, posts second-quarter net income of 494 billion won ($427 million), up 85 percent from 2003 period (M)

headline: Europe Warms to Idea of Unified Military Agency
abstract: Hopes are high in Europe for newly created European Defense Agency, which would consolidate military research and spending across 25 countries; executives from European military companies attending air show in Farnborough, England, say unified front is probably best way for Europe to provide security and resist what they say are heavy-handed sales tactics used by United States aerospace companies and American government; they fear, however, that agency will be hobbled by bureaucracy, stifled by shrinking military budgets and ultimately rendered impotent by inability of its members to agree on anything; photo (M)

headline: Spinning a high-tech web of innovation
Comcast and Time Warner Mulling Bid for Adelphia
abstract: The Comcast Corporation confirmed today that it was in talks with Time Warner Inc. to make a joint bid for Adelphia Communications.

headline: Indians Go Home, but Don't Leave U.S. Behind
abstract: Many Indians who migrated to America's Silicon Valley and its suburban good life are returning to India; are drawn back by booming economy, in which outsourcing is playing crucial role, and money to buy lifestyle they had in America; there are estimated 35,000 'returned nonresident Indians' in high-tech hub of Bangalore; liberalization of India's state-run economy over last 13 years has spawned suburban culture that is enabling India to compete for its Americanized best and brightest; map; photos (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: International Traveler / Update:PARIS : Eiffel Tower is closed by employees' strike
STELLICAN BUYS INDIAN MOTORCYCLE; WILL REVIVE PRODUCTION
abstract: Stellican Ltd, British buyout firm, buys Indian Motorcycle Corp, and will resume motorcycle production that was halted in 2003 (S)

headline: Russian Faults NATO Opening To Baltic States
abstract: Russian Defense Min Sergei B Ivanov, during visit from US Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld, criticizes NATO expansion to include Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia; says original NATO members should worry about weakening their defense and wasting their tax dollars; Rumsfeld tries to assure Ivanov that NATO is no threat to Russian security; acknowledges that Russia does not have agreements with Baltic states, as it does with many other neighbors, aimed at avoiding military clashes (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Premier Hopes To Reassure Europeans
abstract: Turkey's Prime Min Recep Tayyip Erdogan plans meeting in Brussels with European Union Enlargement Commissioner Gunter Verheugen; support of proposed legislation that would criminalize adultery has jeopardized European Union membership as Turkey must institute penal code reforms before date for membership negotiation will be set by union (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    Today  New Home Sales: August    Tomorrow  Consumer Confidence: September    Wednesday  None    Thursday  Personal Income: August  Weekly Jobless Claims    Friday  Construction Spending: August

headline: U.S. Switches Tactic in Najaf, Trying Isolation
abstract: American commanders in Najaf throw wide cordon of troops and armor around city's heart and announce plans to 'further isolate' militia loyal to Moktada al-Sadr; Shiite cleric has bunkered his heavily-armed militia force in holiest shrine; only days ago, Iraqi Prime Min Ayad Allawi flew into Najaf on American military helicopter and announced there would be 'no negotiations or truce' with Sadr; he and American officials now appear to be backing away from showdown, instead pursuing combination of negotiations and tightening blockade around mosque; loyalists of cleric have spread their insurrection across central and southern Iraq, raising morale of militiamen in Najaf; attacks have been made in Sadr City, Baghdad slum, as well as in Diwaniya, Kut, Al-Hayy, Nasiriya, Amara and Basra, all towns with heavy Shiite populations; in Najaf, situation is similar to events in Apr, when American commanders, confronted by uprising stirred by Sadr, built up powerful strike force around Najaf with vow to uproot cleric and his fighters from mosque, then decided that political costs of attacking or damaging shrine compelled an accommodation; American officials say that this time aim will be to constrict Sadr's fighters much more tightly, halting flow of men, arms and food, with Iraqi police and national guardsmen moving farther forward; photos; map (L)

headline: 9/11 Panel Leader Has Praise for Plan to Split C.I.A.
abstract: Thomas H Kean, Sept 11 commission chairman, says far-reaching proposal by Sen Pat Roberts and some other Senate Republicans to break up CIA and move other intelligence agencies outside Pentagon seems to be 'constructive alternative' to panel's proposals and reflects growing view that present situation is unacceptable, House committee; does not endorse proposal, noting he has not seen details; his comments and those of panel deputy chairman, Lee H Hamilton, suggest they are willing to work with Roberts and his Congressional allies on bill for intelligence overhaul far more sweeping than Bush administration wants; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon Wireless To Buy Qwest Spectrum
abstract: Verizon Wireless will pay $418 million for spectrum held by Qwest Communications International as it tries to expand into fast-growing urban areas like Denver and Phoenix; will receive spectrum in 1,900 megahertz range in 62 markets in 14 Western states; will also receive switching centers, cell sites and other network equipment from Qwest (S)

headline: Japanese Bank Makes Hostile Bid in Takeover Battle
abstract: The biggest-ever takeover battle in Japan got even bigger today as Sumitomo Mitsui sought to disrupt a rival's expansion plans with a $29 billion hostile bid for UFJ.

headline: Euro Disney avoids collapse with debt deal
Creative Director Joins Bartle Bogle New York
abstract: Kevin Roddy is named executive creative director of New York office of London agency Bartle Bogle Hegarty, succeeding Kevin McKeon (S)

headline: Warning to Executives: Honesty Is the Best Policy
abstract: Government, in its almost three-year battle against corporate corruption, seen signaling to executives that there have been far-reaching changes in expectations for truthfulness when they communicate with shareholders; demands for frank honest communications are significant shift from late 1990's practices, when unpleasant news was excluded from relentlessly upbeat statements; government officials are now clearly telling corporate executives that deceitful public comments damage capital markets and will be taken seriously; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Gazprom Posts Higher Profit
abstract: World Business Briefing:

headline: Afghan Refugees Forced to Flee in Push by Pakistani Army
abstract: The Pakistani Army has intensified its operations against supporters of Al Qaeda, displacing thousands of Afghan refugees.

headline: COMCAST PROMOTES PRESIDENT OF CABLE UNIT
abstract: Comcast Corp promotes cable unit president Stephen B Burke to chief operating officer, expanding his responsibilities to include running company's TV networks (S)

headline: EQUIFAX CHAIRMAN AND CHIEF TO RETIRE NEXT YEAR
abstract: Equifax Inc, credit-reporting service, says its chairman and chief executive, Thomas F Chapman, will retire in 2005 (S)

headline: IRAQ UPDATE
abstract: HOSTAGES -- Philippine officials held an emergency meeting after a senior official visiting the Middle East said the country's troops would leave Iraq ''as soon as possible'' to save a Filipino hostage threatened with death by militants. [Page A9]

headline: F.D.A. Approves Cholesterol Drug
abstract: Schering-Plough Corp and Merck & Co wins Food and Drug Administration approval of Vytorin combination cholesterol pill, giving them another medicine to compete with Lipitor from Pfizer; Vytorin combines Zocor from Merck and Zetia from Schering-Plough (S)

headline: In dispute on airplane subsidies, hard lines
Tony Blair to Undergo Heart Procedure
abstract: Prime Minister Tony Blair said that he would enter the hospital on Friday for a "routine" medical procedure to correct an irregular heartbeat.

headline: Vonage Starts Review For Marketing Services
abstract: Vonage Holdings, broadband telephone company, begins review for its advertising services account, with billings estimated at $50 million to $70 million (S)

headline: Get Out the Glue for a New Business Model
abstract: Beleaguered airlines are facing market that may have changed more fundamentally than at any time since industry was deregulated in 1978; even biggest companies may have to remake themselves radically, quickly and permanently, or face extinction; predominant business model since deregulation is being buried by low-fare airlines that pick and choose their destinations and continually pare costs and ticket prices; some executives say that if airlines simply trim costs, they can withstand onslaught as they did in previous slumps; others say that industry cannot just shrink this time, and that it must reshape itself, abandoning assumptions about consumers and labor contracts; graph; photos (M)

headline: Did Comcast Fold Its Hand Too Soon?
abstract: Steven M Cohen letter on Aug 8 article hol

headline: Annan Urges Security Council to Act Quickly on Sudan
abstract: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 16  Intervening personally in an ongoing Security Council debate, Secretary General Kofi Annan urged the panel today to act quickly on a resolution to curb the violence in Sudan's Darfur region and said he was eager to set up a commission called for in the measure to investigate whether genocide had occurred.

headline: Put Your Stamp on Mail Call With Personalized Postage
abstract: Photostamps, United States Postal Service Web site, allows people to create unique, official postage stamps; program is in evaluation period; photo (S)

abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.25   4.25   4.25       Federal Funds   1.50   1.50   1.22       3-month Libor   1.71   1.71   1.13       3-month T-bills   1.44   1.43   0.95       6-month T-bills   1.73   1.72   1.05       10-yr. headline: GENERAL ELECTRIC WILL ACQUIRE BANK IN MOSCOW
abstract: General Electric Co acquires Moscow-based DeltaBank; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: For Publisher of 9/11 Report, a Royalty-Free Windfall
abstract: The 9/11 Commission Report prepared by National Commission on Terrorist Attack Upon the United States remains best seller for publisher, W W Norton & Co, which has already recovered its costs on book and begun to record profit; requirement that book be printed and bound and delivered to retailers in just four days meant higher-than-average production costs for Norton, but that is offset by fact that Norton has no royalties to pay and only minimal advertising and promotion costs for a book in great demand; photo (M)

headline: I.B.M. Profit, Up by 17%, Bucks Trend In Industry
abstract: IBM reports quarterly profits that surpass Wall Street estimates at time when much of recent news from computer hardware and software companies has been of surprisingly bad earnings, rising inventories and uncertain prospects; says profit was nearly $1.99 billion, up 17 percent from year earlier; revenue in quarter rose 7 percent, to $23.2 billion; chief financial officer Mark Loughridge comments (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Andrew Stock Falls As Results Lag Estimates
abstract: Shares of Andrew Corp, maker of equipment for wireless-telephone networks, fall about 27 percent after company says results this quarter will lag analysts' estimates in part because of pending sale of AT&T Wireless Services; graph (S)

headline: Delta Air Lines Starts Review
abstract: Delta Air Lines begins review for agency or agencies to handle creative and media duties on its ad account (S)

headline: Low Numbers, New Problem
abstract: Analysis: Republicans had hoped indications that economy was turning corner would have allowed them to neutralize, or even turn to their advantage, issue that John Kerry had once considered central to his White House bid; but paltry new numbers on job growth, coming just three weeks before Republican convention, leave little doubt that economy could still be potent issue for Democrats; Pres Bush, rather than address his vulnerability head-on, delivered upbeat assessment of economy, saying it was getting stronger and lauding American entrepreneurial spirit (M)

headline: Happy as a Clam But Willing to Jump Ship; Owner of Jeffrey Ponders Selling the Store
abstract: Jeffrey Kalinsky, commenting on success of his very expensive and chic Jeffrey speciality stores in Manhattan and Atlanta, says he would sell stores for right price; photos (M)

headline: Entrepreneurial Success via the Internet
abstract: Home Front profiles Josh Mohrer, who runs Rational Fashion, online operation that sells men's designer clothing; Mohrer comments on ways he is thinking about expanding business; photo (M)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: Zoom Media, part of Telemedia, forms partnership with New York City Department of Parks and Recreation to place poster-sized billboards in park restrooms; part of advertising revenue will go toward maintaining and renovating restrooms (S)

headline: World Briefings
abstract: AMERICAS.

headline: FOREST LABS BUYS RIGHTS TO DRUG BASED ON VAMPIRE BATS
abstract: Forest Laboratories Inc licenses from Paion of Germany the rights to experimental blood-clot-breaking drug based on saliva from vampire bats; will pay for rest of studies on drug, submit application to Food and Drug Administration and market product in US and Canada if it is approved; product, called desmoteplase, is under development for treatment of stroke (S)

headline: New Governor Takes Charge in Afghan City Hit by Violence
abstract: Sayed Muhammad Khairkhwa spent today ensconced in Herat's finest guest house, surrounded by U.S. troops and Afghan soldiers.

headline: Ex-Chief of Computer Associates Is Indicted on Fraud Charges
abstract: Federal grand jury indicts Sanjay Kumar, former chairman and chief executive of Computer Associates International, on charges of securities fraud and obstruction of justice; former executive vice president Stephen Richards is indicted on similar charges; indictment depicts wide-ranging conspiracy at company to break accounting rules and mislead government and corporate investigators; says company backdated billions of dollars in contracts in effort to meet Wall Street's forecasts for its quarterly profits; says Kumar and Richards encourged employees to mislead prosecutors and Securities and Exchange Commission lawyers; lawyers for both men say they deny charges; five other former executives have already pleaded guilty to charges of securities fraud or obstruction of justice, including company's former general counsel Steven Woghin; Judge I Leo Glasser approves deal between company and government investigators that would let company avoid prosecution; company has agreed to pay $225 million in restitution to shareholders; photos (M)

headline: HEALTHCARE REALTY TO BUY BUILDINGS FOR $133 MILLION
abstract: Healthcare Realty Trust acquires 20 medical buildings from Baylor Health Care System and its affiliates for about $133 million; properties are on or near hospital campuses in Dallas-Fort Worth area (S)

headline: Co-Founder Leaving Firm As Its Hedge Funds Struggle
abstract: Andor Capital Management says chief investment officer Christopher James is leaving company he founded after months of weak performance in its hedge funds; Daniel C Benton, chief executive and co-founder, will stay (M)

headline: Eisner to Step Down as Disney Chief in 2006
abstract: Michael D. Eisner told the board of directors Thursday that he plans to step down in two years.

headline: UNITED AIRLINES PLANS $625 MILLION IN ADDITIONAL CUTS
abstract: United Airlines, which is trying to develop restructuring plan to leave bankruptcy protection, identifies $625 million in additional annual savings; executive vice president Peter D McDonald says biggest savings, $200 million annually, will come from maintenance department (S)

headline: U.S. Regulators Release Vehicle Rollover Data
abstract: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration releases figures for first time that show how prone individual models of new cars and light-duty trucks are to roll over in accident, exposing occupants to high risk of death or serious injury; Ford Explorer Sport Trac is found to have highest rollover risk of 68 models agency tested for 2004 model year; four-door Mazda RX-8 sedan was best performer is tests; chart; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Profit At Airline
abstract: World Business Bri

headline: Built for America, Sold (Cheaply) to the World
abstract: Billions of dollars of global telecommunications networks bought or built by US investors belong to Chinese, Indian and other non-American companies that bought them for fraction of their cost; shift in ownership of networks comes less than four years after telecommunications bubble burst; Asian companies in particular have taken advantage of troubles at American companies, at time when government monopolies on telecommunications in their countries are waning, access to capital is greater and consumer appetite for bandwidth is growing; analysts say American investors overpaid to set up global networks and have ended up inadvertently financing them for foreign owners who bought at fire-sale prices when companies fell on hard times; photo (M)

headline: Iraqis Condemn Attacks on Christian Churches
abstract: Top Muslim clerics and political leaders united behind Iraq's Christians after Sunday's bombings, but some Christians are frightened about their future in the country.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Euronext Offices Raided
abstract: European antitrust re

headline: A PC That Packs Real Power, and All Just for Me
abstract: Orion Multisystems, startup company in Santa Clara, Calif, is set to introduce new desktop workstation computer intended for engineers and scientists, one that is size of pizza box, has 12 processors and delivers about 10 times performance of standard desktop PC, while using about same amount of power; idea is throwback to early days of workstation computers, before shift away from specialized workstations and toward desktop PC's and cluster computers, which run software that needs lots of computing power; Orion believes sheer electrical power needs of today's high-performance computers are in its favor; photo (M)

headline: Whose DVD? A Debate Over Copies
abstract: Legality and ethical implications of copying DVD's by individual consumers discussed; software for copying DVD's is availble online and is often free, even though Digital Millennium Copyright Act of 1998 forbids distribution or use of any program that cracks digital copyright-protection systems, regardless of purpose; critics argue that DVD owners should be entitled to back up DVD's that they buy; photo (M)

headline: Stock Offerings This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:      BioMed Property Trust, an initial public offering of 27 million shares. Raymond James; Friedman, Billings, Ramsey; KeyBanc; Legg Mason Wood Walker;.    Blount, 10 million shares. Lehman Brothers, J.P. Morgan.

headline: Two Ad Forecasts, One Revised, One New
abstract: Harris Nesbitt cuts its estimate for increased United States advertising spending in 2005 to 3.7 percent from 7.2 percent; continues to forecast rise of 4.9 percent for 2004; MG Strategic Research president Miles E Groves predicts rise of 5.2 percent in 2005 (S)

headline: KRISPY KREME SAYS CHIEF OPERATING OFFICER HAS LEFT
abstract: Krispy Kreme Doughnuts, which is being investigated by Securities and Exchange Commission over its accounting practices, says chief operating officer John W Tate has left company; chief executive Scott A Livengood has assumed Tate's duties (S)

headline: A Palmtop As Wireless Omnivore
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column reviews palmtop computer from Hewlett-Packard; device includes standard palmtop suite of applications, but also communicates wirelessly using infrared, Bluetooth, WiFi and cellular phone technologies; photo; drawing (M)

headline: Subsidy battle heats up
Head of Kidnapped American Is Discovered in a Saudi Raid
abstract: Saudi police discover frozen head of Paul M Johnson Jr, American hostage decapitated last month, during raid of suspected hide-out of Saleh al-Awfi in Riyadh; he is reputed leader of main franchise in Saudi Arabia of Osama bin Laden's Al Qaeda; raid leads to gun battle with militants, including Sawt al-Jihad, who was on list of kingdom's 26 most wanted militants; Awfi, who escaped, is believed to have been wounded; Johnson was kidnapped on June 12 and threatened with beheading unless Al Qaeda prisoners were released; pictures of his beheading were posted on Internet on June 18; just four militants have accepted monthlong amnesty offered to militants by royal family (M)

headline: Software Program
abstract: Advice for small businesses on choosing software program;computer; sampling of products noted; drawing (special section, Small Business) (M)

headline: NOT ON SALE AT KMART
abstract: Thesmokinggun.com has printed part of Government Exhibit 123-C document from Martha Stewart trial on dish towel; reproduced message taken by Ann E Armstrong, Stewart's personal assistant at time: 'Peter Bacanovic thinks ImClone is going to start trading downward'; William Bastone, Thesmokinggun.com co-founder, says his wife Barbara Glauber dreamed up idea (S)

headline: Voters seen turning to ex-communists : East German discontent
COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: MARSH & MCLENNAN COS., New York, the insurance brokerage, had its credit rating cut to A+ from AA- by Standard & Poor's because it is taking on debt to buy Kroll Inc., a security firm.    BANK OF NOVA SCOTIA, Toronto, said it planned to cut 100 jobs at its Montreal call center, while adding 50 positions at call centers in Toronto and Halifax, Nova Scotia.

headline: Judge Orders U.S. to Release Data on Detainees It Holds Overseas
abstract: Federal Judge Alvin K Hellerstein of Manhattan orders government to release information on treatment of detainees held at military bases or other facilities overseas, including official policies and records requested months ago by American Civil Liberties Union under Freedom of Information Act; ACLU and various other civil liberties groups filed lawsuit against Defense Dept, Central Intelligence Agency, Federal Bureau of Investigation and other US agencies, demanding release of information; judge also orders government to produce log with explanations for documents it claims are exempt from release, that cannot be located or that will be produced after deadline, which he sets at Aug 23; appears unmoved by suggestion from government lawyer that delays are caused by tedious work involved in producing information (M)

headline: As Bull Market Nears a Birthday, Few Seem Ready to Celebrate
abstract: Floyd Norris comment on upcoming second anniversary of stock markets' bull market, which began on Oct 9, 2002; says tepid stock market this year illustrates how little enthusiasm this economic recovery is producing as election nears; graph (M)

headline: Parliamentary Vote Delayed in Afghanistan
abstract: Afghanistan's Election Commission says parliamentary elections will be delayed for six months, until April 2005, in effort to ensure more democratic process, but presidential election will go ahead in fall

headline: July Factory Orders Exceeded Forecasts; Productivity Pace Slows
abstract: Factory orders rose 1.3 percent in July, to $369.6 billion, after revised 1.2 percent increase in June; first-time applications for unemployment benefits rose last week by 19,000, to 362,000; number of people continuing to collect state jobless benefits fell to 2.882 million in week ended Aug 21, from 2.887 milion prior week (M)

headline: Canada's Prophets of Pessimism (Is It the Weather?)
abstract: Number of Canadian historians, foreign policy thinkers and columnists put forth view that Canada is in decline, adrift at home and wilting as player on world stage, for which they blame uninspired leaders, lack of national purpose, stunted imagination and befuddled priorities; photos; historians David Bercuson, Michael Bliss and Desmond Morton discuss gloom (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Retail Sales Increase
abstract: Hong Kong's retail sales rose 20 percent in May from year earlier after rising 23 percent in April (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Ford To Build Third China Plant
abstract: Ford Motor will build third factory in China to make cars with its Mazda Motor affiliate, part of $1.5 billion investment to catch rivals who have expanded quicker in world's third-biggest car market (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nextel Says F.C.C. Is Overcharging For Airwaves
abstract: Nextel Communications says Federal Communications Commission is asking it to pay $452 million more than it should for airwaves that wireless carrier will receive in $4.86 billion transaction with government; FCC underestimated value of radio frequencies company plans to trade; Nextel says frequencies, used by cellphones, are worth $2.06 billion; FCC set value at $1.61 billion (S)

headline: Palestinian Turmoil Threatens to Erode Arafat's Power
abstract: Yasir Arafat's policies have become fair game for criticism yet he remains a symbol of Palestinian aspirations to full nationhood.

headline: Twist the Screen, and a Notebook Has Something to Grow On
abstract: New computer from Averatec converts from tablet to standard laptop; photo (S)

abstract: Human Rights Watch charges that Pakistani paramilitary forces have killed at least four Pakistani farmers, tortured dozens of others and arrested hundreds more in violent dispute with tenant farmers over ownership of fertile land controlled by army in Punjab (S)

abstract: E*Trade Financial and Martin/Williams Advertising, which has handled E*Trade account since September, have parted ways; billings estimated at $90 million (S)

headline: At Disney, Mending Fences or Moving On?
abstract: Michael D Eisner's plan to leave as Walt Disney Co chief executive when his contract expires in two years may not be enough to salvage company's testy ties with Harvey Weinstein of Miramax and Steven P Jobs of Pixar Animation Studios; Pixar has been responsible for big part of Disney's film profits, but Jobs has heatedly scored Eisner and Disney; Disney has been negotiating accord in which Dimension Films head Bob Weinstein would stay at Disney while his brother, Harvey, would produce movies on his own to be distributed by Disney; photos (M)

headline: Alitalia board backs recovery plan
No Decline In Service, Company Says
abstract: AT&T Corp will continue to provide local and long-distance services to its existing companies and will connect new consumers who ask for service despite its decision to stop marketing retail phone services (M)

abstract: Egyptian Ministry of Investment announces plans to sell government's shares in 10 companies in number of industries; no timetable for sale is released (S)

headline: Fetch Photos Wirelessly With a Dynamic 19-Inch Frame
abstract: PhotoVu digital picture frame displays pictures stored on PC via wired or wireless network; photo (S)

headline: China in Africa: All Trade, With No Political Baggage
abstract: China's trade with Africa reached $18.5 billion in 2003, up 50 percent since 2000; China's growing interest in trade with Africa comes at time when Africa has otherwise been on sidelines of global trade; China's interest in Africa is driven by need for natural resources, particularly oil; China lacks West's legacy of colonialism in Africa, and its policy of non-interference in internal affairs of other countries wins it acceptance with African governments; Pres Hu Jintao visited three African countries in February; graph (M)

abstract: World Business Briefing: Ireland: Bank Executiv

headline: Google's Slow Search for a Good Share Price
abstract: Google Inc is search for price at which it will sell stock to public for first time; company begins taking bids on Internet for 25.7 million of its shares after nearly three months of intense government scrutiny, few modest legal setbacks and rising investor skepticism; is hoping to sell about $3 billion worth of stock using form of Dutch auction; expects to close auction next week; chart; photo of Google's co-founders Sergey Brin and Larry Page (M)

headline: DEFINITELY NOT WOBEGON
abstract: Richard H Anderson of Northwest Airlines comments on being only major airline CEO to keep his job since Sept 11, 2001; credits Northwest's location in Minneapolis (S)

abstract: MSS Group, consultant firm that helps companies manage their telecommunications spending, will merge with Telwares, which negotiates with carriers on behalf of corporations (S)

headline: Author Says New Film Is Similar to Her Novel
abstract: Margaret Peterson Haddix says she recognizes numerous similarities between her 1995 book Running Out of Time and The Village, new film by M Night Shyamalan; Dennis Rice, senior vice president for publicity at Buena Vista Pictures, unit of Walt Disney Co, says whatever claims are being made of similarities between book and movie have no merit; neither Haddix nor Simon & Schuster, publisher of Haddix's book, has yet to contact Shyamalan or Disney (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Justice Department Inquiry Examines Medical Supplies  The Justice Department has opened a broad criminal investigation of the medical supply industry, apparently to determine whether Medicare and other federal and state health programs are being overcharged for goods like rubber gloves, drugs and X-ray machines.     More than a dozen medical supply companies have recently received federal subpoenas in what appears to be a wide-ranging investigation into the way suppliers market their products to clinics, hospitals and nursing homes that serve Medicare and Medicaid patients and whether those institutions properly account for the purchases. [Page A1.]

headline: Jordan's King Says 'Chaos' in Iraq Rules Out January Vote
abstract: King Abdullah said he was concerned that this would leave the Sunni Arab minority, which controls a number of cities in Iraq, out of the voting.

headline: Fed Cites Inflation and Wages for June Increase
abstract: Minutes of Federal Open Market Committee meeting shows higher inflation, business confidence and compensation costs prompted committee to raise benchmark interest rate for first itme in four years on June 30 (M)

headline: Coca-Cola Says That Earnings Rose 16% in the 2nd Quarter
abstract: Coca-Cola Co says second-quarter earnings rose 16 percent; net income rose to $1.58 billion from $1.36 million year ago; sales rose 4.7 percent, to $5.97 billion (M)

headline: Sudanese Workers Are Stranded in Iraq
abstract: Many Sudanese workers who came to Iraq years ago for menial jobs have returned home since outset of war; Sudanese who remain are those who cannot afford to flee; no one knows their numbers for sure, but Sudanese Assn of Iraq estimates about 3,000; their plight described; photos (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Wyeth, Madison, N.J., the drug maker, said it planned to close a factory in West Chester, Pa., in December, eliminating about 200 jobs.    ITT Industries, White Plains, which makes military electronics and fluid-control products, said it had won a $359 million contract from NASA to design and make instruments to gather weather images from space.

headline: Rome Journal; Sure, It's Syrupy and Old-Fashioned, but That's Amore
abstract: Ettore Spina is among small troupe of professional serenaders that Romans are hiring to do their courting for them; accompanied by future grooms, he travels to homes of brides-to-be on eve of their weddings, luring them out on their balconies by belting out love songs that can be heard over city's noisy traffic; he can make $300 a night and up; typical night's work described; photos (M)

headline: A Quicker Paper Swapper
abstract: Simplehuman, kitchenware

headline: S.E.C. Accuses 4 in Golden State Deal
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission charges Auto One Finance chief financial officer Mark Kelly and three others with insider trading violations related to Citigroup's 2002 purchase of Golden State Bancorp, which owned Auto One; charges that Kelly told friends Martin Angel and Chad Latvaaho about merger plan and that Angel told John Buck; says Angel, Latvaaho and Buck made almost $250,000 in illegal trading profits; Latvaaho agrees to pay $30,857 to settle charges (M)

headline: Coke European Accord Seen
abstract: European Commission is set to announce settlement of three-year antitrust investigation of Coca-Cola; Coca-Cola has offered to drop its requirement that retailers stock wide array of Coke and Fanta drinks, which take up large amount of shelf space; currently, retailers must take whole range of drinks to qualify for rebate from company; European Commission was concerned that program was stifling competition in soft drinks (M)

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Staying in Touch.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: TENET HEALTHCARE CORP., Santa Barbara, Calif., the second-largest hospital chain in the United States, reached a two-year contract with Humana Inc., Louisville, Ky., that allows the insurer's members to use Tenet's 15 hospitals and diagnostic centers in South Florida. Terms were not disclosed.    ARCHER DANIELS MIDLAND CO., Decatur, Ill., the world's largest grain processor, said it has formed a joint venture called Skyland Grain with Johnson Cooperative Grain Company, Johnson, Kan., to handle some of the two companies' business operations in Kansas and Colorado.

headline: MIDAMERICAN ENERGY ENDS ZINC EXTRACTION PROJECT
abstract: MidAmerican Energy Holdings, which is 81 percent owned by Berkshire Hathaway Inc, will record $340 million expense after taxes to shut down money-losing zinc extraction project in California's Imperial Valley (S)

headline: Nielsen Critics Seize on New Ratings Data
abstract: Critics of Nielsen Media Research's new method for measuring local television audiences say latest data suggest system continues to undercount number of black and Hispanic viewers despitge company's efforts to fine-tune technology; Nielsen has been target of coordinated and well-financed campaign by News Corp and black and Hispanic groups against its plans to measure ratings in big cities with electronic devices known as people meters (M)

headline: Zimbabwe Sentences 68 Accused Mercenaries to Prison
abstract: A British soldier-of-fortune was sentenced to seven years in prison today for illegally trying to buy weapons in Zimbabwe.

headline: PFIZER APPEALS REVOCATION OF VIAGRA PATENT BY CHINA
abstract: Pfizer goes to Chinese court to appeal China's revocation of its patent on Viagra, impotence treatment; wins appoval from China to expand sales of drug from hospitals to pharmacies (S)

headline: Delays in Athens Raise Concern On Olympic Security Readiness
abstract: Intelligence officials who fear terrorism at Athens Olympics say delays in completing security apparatus and athletic facilities have left too little time to fully test systems meant to detect or respond to attack; say security command center will not be operating completely until mid-July; say Science Applications International Corp, US-led consortium building system, has provided defective software and failed to complete work on command center by May 28 deadline; map; photos (M)

headline: Bobby Fischer's Fiance Is Fine With Being a Pawn
abstract: TOKYO Aug. 19  In a high-stakes chess game with Japanese immigration authorities, Miyoko Watai, the freshly minted fiance of Bobby Fischer, acknowledged today that the imprisoned American chess master might be using her as a

headline: Competing Bid Made in Japan to Create Big Bank
abstract: Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group, Japan's third-largest bank, plans to propose merger with UFJ Holding, fourth largest, which is already in merger talks with Mitsubishi Tokyo Financial Group, second largest (S)

EU nominee defends business record, promising to be impartial

abstract: Cap Gemini reports first-half net loss of 135 million euros ($164 million), compared with loss of 90 million euros year earlier; chief financial officer William Bitan will leave and be succeeded by Nicolas Dufourcq; Standard & Poor's cuts company's credit rating; stock price falls 13 percent; graph (S)

abstract: Defense Department confirms deaths of three service members in Iraq

abstract: Excerpts from interview with Iraqi Prime Min Iyad Allawi on new national safety law; photo (S)
