headline: Toyota Plans to Assemble Prius Hybrid in China
abstract: Toyota Motor Corp wil assemble and sell its fuel-efficient Prius hybrid sedan in China beginning in 2005 with its local partner, China FAW Group; move seems intended to appeal as much to Chinese government as to car buyers in China; photo (M)

headline: New President for Cond Nast Media Group
abstract: Advance Publications Inc names Richard D Beckman president of Conde Mast Media Group, newly established division of Advance Magazine Group; Beckman is also named executive vice president of Advance Media Group (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Former Wall Street Banker Is Sentenced to 18 Months  Frank P. Quattrone, the Wall Street banker whose pay and deals made him a vivid symbol of the 1990's technology boom, was sentenced to 18 months in prison for obstructing a government investigation into the allocation of hot stock offerings.      Mr. Quattrone, who led the initial offerings of companies like Amazon.com and Cisco Systems as a banker at Credit Suisse First Boston, is the most prominent Wall Street figure to face prison since Michael R. Milken pleaded guilty to securities charges in 1990. [Page A1.]

headline: Lleida Journal; Catalonia Yearns to Root for a Home Team of Its Own
abstract: Catalonia, like Spain's other regions, has substantial autonomy from Spanish government, but many Catalans want even more; nationalism flows thick, but it is wrapped in Catalan flag, not in Spain's; some Catalans support full independence from Spain; photos; map (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft To Sell Cheaper Windows In India
abstract: Microsoft says it will sell cheaper version of Windows software in India to make it more affordabe there (S)

headline: HIGH COURT TELLS ISRAELIS TO SHIFT PART OF BARRIER
abstract: Israel's Supreme Court, in unanimous decision, orders army to remove small portion of barrier it is building along West Bank and to reroute other sections to reduce harm imposed on Palestinians cut off from lands they need; three-judge panel asserts that while Israel has genuine security reason for building barrier and can expropriate land in West Bank for it, 20.5-mile section of barrier could not be justified because of suffering it would cause Palestinians, even if this reduces security for Israelis; decision affects eight Palestinian villages with 35,000 residents northwest of Jerusalem; it sets precedent for how Israel can complete fence, which is one quarter built; ruling does not address whether fence can extend deep into Palestinian territory to Israeli settlements; legal experts say court would closely scrutinize any challenged sections to make sure they conform to principles set in its ruling; photo; maps showing routes of original and redrawn barriers (M)

headline: Entr'acte : For Olympics, Greeks already lose one contest
abstract: LONDON  All being well, everything  at least almost everything  should be ready for the opening of the Olympic Games in Athens late next week. Yet one crucial Greek dream for 2004 will not be fulfilled. Greece had hoped to recover the magnificent 2,500-year-old sculptures known as the Elgin marbles, which were ripped from the Parthenon early in the 19th century. Instead, they remain in the British Museum. And for the foreseeable future, that is where they will stay.

headline: Mattel Earnings Increase 12%
abstract: Mattel Inc, world's largest toy maker, reports its second-quarter net income rose 12 percent, to $23.5 million (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: China: Bid For Hungarian Airline
abstract: China's Hainan Airlines Co, whose biggest shareholder is financier George Soros, plans to bid for Malev, Hungary's unprofitable airline; photo (S)

headline: Big nations 'examine' Russian's proposals; others are critical : EU divided in reaction to Putin's power play
Earnings Double at Fedex, but Wall St. Punishes Stock
abstract: FedEx says profit more than doubled in fiscal first quarter ended Aug 31; net income rose 158 percent to $330 million from $128 million year earlier; revenue increased 23 perent, to $6.98 billion; company's shares fall $3.48, to $85.21, on concern that it will not be able to sustain its growth rate; photo (M)

headline: Merrill Analyst Cuts Estimate of Spending
abstract: Lauren Rich Fine of Merrill Lynch & Co reduces some estimates for ad spending in 2004 and 2005, partly because of reduced expectations of growth in ad revenue for newspapers and radio (S)

headline: A Long Deadly Day in Gaza as Israel Fights Way Into Camp
abstract: Twenty-eight Palestinians and 3 Israelis were killed as the Israeli army battled militants darting among cinderblock houses.

headline: A Sweet Spot For Every Listener
abstract: What's Next column on Iosono surround-sound system, which creates illusion of sound enveloping each individual in audience; system, which was developed at Fraunhofer Institute for Digital Media Technology, Germany, can create illusion that sound is emanating from another place or right next to listeners; application noted; photos (M)

headline: Despite a Jolt, Japan's Mood Remains Upbeat
abstract: Japan's economy grew at annual rate of 1.7 percent in second quarter, surprisingly sharp deceleration from heady rate of 6.6 percent in first quarter and 7.4 percent in last quarter of 2003; growth slowed, in part, because of disappointingly weak consumption at home; Japan is counting on rebound in spending to take up slack when, as anticipated, slower global economy takes toll on Japanese exports later in year; economists and policy makers are confident that Japan's recovery remains on track, though at slower pace, and that consumer spending will again help drive growth; photos (M)

headline: Sales of Clinton's Memoirs Top a Million
abstract: Alfred A Knopf Publishing Group says former Pres Clinton's book My Life sold more than one million copies in first eight days after its publication on June 22 (S)

headline: Trade Group to Cut Farm Subsidies for Rich Nations
abstract: World Trade Organization agrees to phase out $300 billion in annual farm subsidies in rich nations under new framework for revising global trade rules that aims to help farmers in poor countries; many ideas behind compromise come from small group headed by US trade representative Robert B Zoellick, European Union's top trade representative Pascal Lamy and Foreign Min Celso Amorim of Brazil; group also includes Australia and India; compromise is widely praised as move toward fairness; photo (M)

headline: Pope's Visit Shines Light on the Practical Side of Lourdes
abstract: Several hundred thousand Catholic pilgrims, many of them sick or injured, gathered on green fields under the Pyrenees mountains here to celebrate Sunday mass with Pope John Paul II.

headline: When E-Mail Points the Way Down the Rabbit Hole
abstract: Kirk Johnson Essay on spam e-mail, marketing of anti-spam software and philosophical questions raised by use of autonomous technology; drawing (M)

headline: The New Trend in Spending
abstract: Virginia Postrel's Economic Scene column on New Age economics in US that stresses consumers' experience instead of just owning stuff; cites study by Profs Leaf Van Boven and Thomas D Gilovich in Journal of Personality and Social Psychology that shows most people surveyed preferred experiences to goods; research found that less people already had, more benefits they reported from additional goods as opposed to experiences; photo (M)

headline: Afghanistan Elections to Be Postponed Until October
abstract: The vote, already postponed for three months, was postponed again for both logistical and political reasons.

headline: J. Irwin Miller, 95, Patron of Modern Architecture, Dies
abstract: J Irwin Miller, chairman of Cummins Engine Co for 26 years, whose patronage turned Columbus, Ind, into a showcase for modern architecture, dies at 95; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Sabre Profit Rises
abstract: Sabre Holdings Corp says net income rose to $58.9 million in second quarter from $6.8 million gain year earlier; sales rose 8.6 percent, to $550.9 million from $507.2 million (S)

headline: Bored With EBay? Try Google's Unusual Auction
abstract: Article on risks involved in Google's online auction of its shares in initial public offering (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Schrder's Bond With Russia: A Little Girl, Now His Own
abstract: German Chancellor Gerhard Schroder and his wife have adopted 3-year-old Russian girl named Viktoria from orphanage in St Petersburg; Shroder has worked to heal wartime wounds in Europe and Doris Schroder-Kopf is former journalist active in charities for children in St Petersburg; photo; separately, Defense Sec Peter Struck reveals that he suffered mild stroke in June; line drawn by German public and media on personal stories noted (M)

headline: Treasury Bill Auctions Set for This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.    According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was at 1.70 percent, the rate on the six-month issue at 1.90 percent and on the four-week issue 1.56 percent.

headline: 2 Tribune Papers Revise Circulation Again
abstract: Tribune Co reports that Newsday overstated average circulation by as much as 122,000 copies and Spanish-language newspaper Hoy by between 22,000 and 32,000, even more than initially disclosed in early June; says average daily circulation figure for Newsday for 12 months ended September 2003 should have been 480,000 to 490,000; says that, as result of scandal, it plans to take pretax charge of $45 million to $60 million in third quarter to compensate advertisers in addition to $35 million charge in second quarter (M)

headline: The Return of the Venture Capitalists
abstract: Venture-capital industry is coming back to life four years after Internet bubble burst; investments by venture firms rose 22 percent in second quarter, to $5.8 billion, from $4.7 billion year earlier; analysts project 11 percent rise in investments for all of 2004, to $20 billion, from $18 billion in 2003; photo (M)

headline: Capture of Hussein Aides Spurred U.S. Interrogators
abstract: US military jailers at Abu Ghraib prison received important batch of prisoners within days after Saddam Hussein's capture in Dec 2003; they were bodyguards and other loyalists who tended to Hussein in his final weeks on run; military intelligence soldiers at prison say capture of bodyguards led to all-out push for information about Hussein's close supporters who were suspected of plotting against US occupation; say interrogators were given greater latitude to use tactics on new prisoners that had previously required signed approval of senior officers; say tactics included sleep and food deprivation, extended isolation and use of menacing dogs; worst known abuses at Abu Ghraib occurred before Hussein's capture, and involved members of military police who have said their actions were encouraged by prison officials (M)

headline: Musicland tries to embrace the Internet and emulate the atmosphere of retail chains like Starbucks.
abstract: Musicland Group and its ad agency Zimmerman Partners are planning makeovers for 900 stores that Musicland runs under Sam Goody, Media Play and Suncoast Motion Picture brands; strategy envisions stores that embrace Internet's role in music sales and emulate loungelike atmosphere of chains like Barnes & Noble and Starbucks; Musicland's ad billings estimated at $50 million (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Portugal: Fires Rage
abstract: Portugese government asks European Union for aid in fighting string of forest fires stretching length of country (S)

headline: Latest MyDoom Worm Plagues Search Sites
abstract: Latest version of computer worm known as MyDoom disrupts Google search site; Google, AltaVista, Lycos and Yahoo search engines are temporarily affected by searches for e-mail addresses generated by MyDoom worm (M)

headline: 2 Canadian AgenciesMake Acquisitions
abstract: 2 Canadian Agencies.

headline: People
abstract: Michael Wall, managin

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Bank To Focus On Customers
abstract: World Business Briefing: Ireland: Bank To Focus on Cust

headline: Federated Profit Falls in Quarter, But Company Lifts Year Forecast
abstract: Federated Department Stores says fiscal second-quarter earnings fell 35 percent; net income in quarter ended July 31 fell to $78 million from $120 million year ago; revenue rose 3.3 percent, to $3.55 billion (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Today.

headline: 'Everything Will Work Out for the Best'
abstract: The mayor of Athens talks about the Olympic Games in an unsafe world, the prognosis of the Oracle of Delphi and a surplus of tickets.

headline: In a Galaxy of Hotel Ratings, Are 5 Stars Enough?
abstract: Advice on rating systems for top hotels; some luxury hotels, citing expansion and improvement in five-star category, are claiming added star; others resist ratings inflation; use of stars can be so indiscriminate in some areas as to be nearly meaningless; table of ratings criteria; photos (M)

headline: New Chairman of Fiat Takes Added Challenge
abstract: Interview with Luca Cordero di Montezemolo on his new posts as head of Confindustria, Italy's manufacturers' association, and as Fiat chairman; he makes no effort to cloak his role at Fiat as not so much hands-on manager as mentor and protector of John Elkann, vice chairman, and other members of Agnelli family's newest generation, who have yet to gain experience to lead Fiat; photo (M)

headline: Privacy and Amusements Meant to Go a Long Way
abstract: Business travelers who take super-long-haul nonstop flights say they are attracted by time saved, not amenities lavished on them; rundown of ammenities offered by Singapore Airlines, Emirates and Cathay Pacific, which have introduced super-long-haul flights from United States to Asia and Mideast; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Court To Let In Cameras As A Test
abstract: British Lord Chancellor Lord Falconer announces limited use of television cameras to broadcast court proceedings; originally only judges and lawyers will be able to view footage taken (S)

headline: Spain Looks to Sell More Than Its Sand and Sun
abstract: Spain's Ministry of Industry, Tourism and Commerce will begin exploring ways to promote Spain's cultural, historical and architectural sites, as well as its food and restaurants; Spain's hotels have reported hig vacancy rates for second year, even in hotels that line Spain's fabled beaches; photo (M)

headline: At Deutsche, a new focus on Germany
U.S. Loses Trade Cases and Faces Penalties
abstract: World Trade Organization authorizes European Union and seven other leading American trading partners to impose more than $150 million in retaliatory sanctions on exports from US; ruling comes after Congress refuses for two years to repeal subsidy for American companies that WTO found to be in violation global trade laws; WTO rules against US and in favor of Canada in cases involving Canadian wheat and lumber; measure found to be illegal under global trade rules allows American companies rather than government to receive duties that US government imposes on foreign companies deemed to be unfairly dumping products in US; ruling gives European Union, Canada, Japan, Brazil, Chile, India, South Korea and Mexico right to impose higher tariffs on their choice of products; tariffs could be worth slightly more than 70 percent of value of money received by American companies; photos (M)

headline: the end user / A voice for the consumer : Patent fight is pending
Israel Adds to Plans for More Housing Units in Settlements
abstract: Israeli officials announce plan to rezone land within existing West Bank settlements to allow for construction of 533 more housing units, most of them close to Jerusalem; announcement comes week after government issues tenders for construction of 1,001 new housing units on West Bank and says it plans to issue tenders for another 633 units; taken together, this would amount to 2,167 permits to build dwellings beyond Israel's 1967 boundaries; this is far greater amount of new units than have been offered in previous 3 years; announcements come after United States signals that it would accept housing growth within boundaries of existing settlements; Palestinian Authority and Arab League say such expansion would be direct violation of Israel's 2001 agreement to freeze all settlement activity, including 'natural growth'; photo; map (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Growth Outlook Reduced
abstract: European Commission lowers its third-quarter growth forecast to 0.3 percent to 0.7 percent for dozen euro nations, compared with 0.4 percent to 0.8 percent it predicted on June 1 (S)

headline: Trade Talks in Geneva Offer More Hope This Time
abstract: Consultations between rich and poor nations ahead of trade talks set to begin in Geneva inspire some hope for compromise under which Europeans and US would reduce their subsidies and artificial supports for their own farmers and third world would open new markets to goods and services produced in industrial nations; failure would put entire round of trade talks in doubt and raise larger questions about value of World Trade Organization, especially among members of Congress unhappy over WTO's rulings that American trade laws have violated global rules on protectionism; photos (M)

headline: Overwhelming Militiamen, Troops Push Closer to Shrine
abstract: American forces in Najaf attack rebels loyal to Moktada al-Sadr from three sides and press into inner ring of Najaf's Old City for first time; Sadr's poorly armed loyalists inside Old City appear to be on verge of collapse, overwhelmed by American attack helicopters and gunships; many members of militia have fled Najaf since American forces began intensifying their assault; after offering to negotiate, interim Iraqi government appears to have lost patience with Sadr; American attacks in Najaf have been approved by Prime Min Ayad Allawi; Sadr may be hoping to gain support from Muslim anger at fact that American troops are fighting so near one of Shiite Islam's holiest sites; American attack does not appear to have damaged dome of mosque, but deep hole is punched in wall of shrine; photos; map (M)

headline: SOUTHWEST PRESIDENT LOSES CHIEF OPERATING OFFICER TITLE
abstract: Southwest Airlines' president Colleen C Barrett will give up chief operating officer title, as new chief executive Gary C Kelly reorganizes management responsibilities; chief operating duties will be split between executive vice presidents Jim Wimberly and Donna Conover (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Fewer Job Cuts At Bayer
abstract: Bayer AG will limit projected 4,000 job cuts to 3,000 at its German operations, reducing worldwide number of cuts to 14,000 by end of 2005; graph (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Advertising account changes noted (S)

headline: Google Hopes to Raise $2 Billion in Initial Public Offering
abstract: Giving a bullish assessment of its own worth today, Google said it expected its shares to sell for $108 to $135 each.

headline: Acting C.I.A. Chief Opposes Push for New Intelligence Post
abstract: John E. McLaughlin reiterated his concern today that a proposed cabinet-level intelligence post would needlessly add to bureaucracy.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Bombs Injure 8 In Area Near Chechnya
abstract: Russian Itar-Tass news agency reports that two bombs exploded near Dagestan police station (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of June 27 article by Daniel Akst about possible ways to paint rosy pictures of business decisions, which misstated role of Mercer Human Resource Consulting in pay package of former New York Stock Exchange chairman Richard A Grasso; it was one of several consultants to exchange about package, not the only one (S)0

headline: MCKESSON LOWERS EARNINGS FORECAST, CITING PRICES
abstract: Drug wholesaler McKesson Corp says net income in second quarter will fall because of fewer price increases, setting off 15 percent drop in its share price (S)

headline: Halliburton Says Joint Venture Considered Paying Bribes
abstract: Halliburton Co says officers from Nigerian joint venture related to production of liquefied natural gas considered paying bribes to win contracts; says venture, called TSKJ, may sue to recover payments made to agent named Tri-Star Investments; says TSKJ had series of agency agreement in connection with work on $5 billion gas plant; Halliburton, whose chief executive from 1995 to 2000 was Vice Pres Dick Cheney, says it does not have evidence confirming that bribes were paid; Halliburton surrenders new information to Justice Department, Securities and Exchange Commission and French magistrate who is probing payments by TSKJ (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cox Profit Plummets
abstract: Cox Communications reports second-quarter earnings of $62.7 million, down 46.7 percent; revenue rises 12 percent, to $1.6 billion (S)

headline: AT&T Uses Its Long Past To Promote Its Near Future
abstract: AT&T is aggressively pushing its Internet phone plan even as it is getting out of business of providing traditional phone service to consumers; has expanded service, which connects calls over broadband lines, to 170 metropolitan areas; hopes lower price will help draw customers who would have abandoned it for Baby Bells, which now offer full range of phone services; it is far from certain whether company can win control of Internet phone market; AT&T official Cathy Martine cites cost advantage of Internet over traditional service; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Returned Exile Attacked
abstract: Novelist Ngugi wa Thiong'o, who is visiting native Kenya for first time in 22 years, is robbed and assaulted in Nairobi (Kenya) apartment; Thiong'o and his wife are hospitalized as result of attack; photo (S)

headline: NAJAF FIGHTING PAUSES TO ALLOW TALKS ON TRUCE
abstract: US troops and Moktada al-Sadr's rebel militiamen pause after eight days of fighting to allow negotiations on truce that would end siege of rebel bastion in Imam Ali Mosque in Najaf, one of greatest pilgrimage sites in Islam; Sadr's stand against US forces has stirred widespread insurrection across southern Iraq, starting in Najaf and spreading to at least eight other predominantly Shiite cities; Iraqi government officials and Sadr's emissaries appear far apart in truce talks; photo (M)

headline: Disney Gives Details of Plan to Aid European Parks
abstract: Walt Disney Co, facing reality that Euro Disney theme parks east of Paris have not earned money needed to pay their bills, agrees to restructuring that will cost American parent hundreds of millions of euros while also reducing its chances of getting cash out of parks for years to come; photo (M)

headline: Familiar Face vs. Anonymous Judge: The Words That They Sparred With
abstract: Following are excerpts from Saddam Hussein's arraignment yesterday, as transcribed by Federal Document Clearing House Inc. from a translation of the Arabic-language proceedings broadcast by CNN. The judge was not identified, for security reasons. Longer excerpts are online at www.nytimes.com /international.

headline: THOMAS H. LEE BUYS NORTEK FOR $1.75 BILLION
abstract: Thomas H Lee Partners acquires Nortek Holdings, maker of range hoods and fans, in transaction worth $1.75 billion (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Hoaxer Freed Pending Trial
abstract: Marie Leblanc, who confessed to lying about being victimized in recent anti-semitic attack by young men on train, is released from police custody but must appear in court on July 26 to answer charges of filing false crime report (S)

headline: World Briefings
abstract: ASIA.

headline: September Trial Is Rejected for Enron's Lay
abstract: Federal Judge Sim Lake says he will not rule until end of September or October on Enron Corp former chairman Kenneth L Lay's request to sever his fraud trial from those of other former company officers (S)

headline: Fallon Wins Emmy For Citibank Spot
abstract: Emmy for best television spot commercial is awarded to Fallon Worldwide for Citibank ad highlighting bank's program to fight identity theft (S)

headline: U.S. Army Accepted Afghan Prisoner From Vigilante Suspect
abstract: American military officials in Afghanistan say they accepted but later released Afghan prisoner handed over to them in May by Jonathan K Idema, American now accused of running his own freelance antiterrorism campaign; United States military had previously denied ever working with him or encouraging his activities; Idema, former Green Beret, claims he was working in Afghanistan with approval of senior Pentagon officials; international security forces stationed in Kabul disclose that they were duped into assisting in three of Idema's raids; say his uniform led them to believe he was member of American military (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Applied Materials Reports Profit
abstract: Applied Materials Inc reports its largest quarterly profit in almost four years; net income was $440.6 millin compared to loss of $36.8 million year earlier; sales in quarter ended Aug 1 rose to $2.24 billion (S)

headline: Oil Price Comes Close to $47; Continued High Demand Seen
abstract: Crude oil prices rise to intraday record of $46.95 per barrel in New York trading as strengthening US economic figures raise concern that production capacity might not be adequate to meet global demand; oil is up 51 percent from year ago; October futures contract for Brent crude oil rises 30 cents, or 0.7 percent, to $42.99 per barrel in London; September Brent futures contract reaches $44.11 on last day of trading; graph; chart (M)

headline: Devastated by AIDS, Africa Sees Life Expectancy Plunge
abstract: Life expectancy in Africa continues its steep decline in seven countries hardest hit by AIDS pandemic; United Nations report says infants born now in Zimbabwe, Swaziland, Lesotho, Zambia, Malawi, Central African Republic or Mozambique can expect to live less than 40 years; Africa's setbacks are break from recent decades of progress; from 1960 to 2000, life expectancy in developing countries worldwide rose to 63 years from 46; Africa was part of that progress until mid-1990's, when AIDS began seriously eroding its gains; even South Africa, region's economic powerhouse, has falling life expectancy, 48.8 years, because of AIDS; spokesman for South African government calls UN estimate 'nonsensical' and claims South Africa has continent's biggest prevention program; South African Pres Thabo Mbeki has been criticized at home and abroad for being slow to aggressively tackle AIDS; graph (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia-Pacific: Indonesia: Afghans Fast For Asylum
abstract: Thirty-nine Afghans seeking asylum begin hunger strike in Bogor (Indonesia); group was trying to get to Australia when they were detained (S)

headline: Transcript of Palestine Lost
abstract: INTRO

headline: Looking to Africa to Polish Its Diamonds
abstract: Eurost

headline: So Many Hedge Funds, So Few Strategies
abstract: Some hedge fund specialists say pro

headline: S.E.C. PLANS TO SUE AMERICAN INTERNATIONAL GROUP
abstract: American International Group says Securities and Exchange Commission plans to sue company for helping PNC Financial Services Group remove bad loans from its books; AIG Financial Products sold partnerships that regulators say PNC improperly used for loans; PNC agreed last year to pay $115 million to settle Justice Department allegations that it used entities to inflate 2001 earnings by 52 percent by removing $762 million in bad loans from financial statements (S)

headline: Forstmann Said to Make Deal for Talent Agency
abstract: Theodore J Forstmann and his buyout firm reportedly agree to acquire IMG talent agency for $750 million in cash; move will give IMG capital and access to expand its reach in sports, entertainment and television; may be last major deal for Forstmann, 64, who reportedly does not plan to raise another investment fund; he is expected to become IMG chairman and hands-on partner; top IMG executives, Robert D Kain and Alastair J Johnston, will remain as day-to-day managers and buy equity stakes; photos (M)

headline: Trend Still a Friend, The Bush Camp Says
abstract: Pres Bush and army of top administration officials try to make best of weaker-than-expected June job growth, holding nation has added 1.5 million jobs since last Aug; advisers to Sen John Kerry, presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, hold nation is still over million jobs short of where it was when Bush took office; both sides are keenly aware that how voters perceive job market's broader direction is key election issue; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Nun Is Refused ID Card Over Head Covering
abstract: Italian newspapers report that nun in L'Aquila was refused identification card because photograph submitted showed her in nun's habit; Muslim woman wearing headscarf had been refused earlier; local officials, criticized for position, are seeking clarification of national ID card regulations (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Machinery Orders Rise
abstract: Japanese machinery orders rose 3.9 percent in June from May, seasonally adjusted; orders in April-June quarter increased record 10.3 percent from previous three months (S)

headline: Enron Criminal TrialBegins in Houston Court
abstract: First criminal trial involving Enron financial transaction begins, with prosecution arguing that six defendants helped company illegally increase its income through bogus asset sale; defense lawyers argue their clients, former Merrill Lynch executives Robert S Furst, Daniel Bayly, James A Brown and David Spears and former Enron executives Dan Boyle and Sheila Kahanek, were bit players who knew of no illegalities in transaction, which entailed sale to Merrill Lynch of indirect stake in some electricity barges in Nigeria; Nigerian barge deal in 1999 played no role in Enron's collapse, and brought in only $12 million in profit; Merrill Lynch put up $7 million for its stake in barge deal, but only after receiving oral commitment from Enron that Merrill would be able to sell its stake at profit in six months (M)

headline: Putin Dismisses A Top General Among Moves To Quell Feud
abstract: Pres Vladimir V Putin dismisses four senior military and security officers in effort to quell feud for control of Russian military and simultaneously react to stinging military setback last month during rebel raids in Ingushetia, adjacent to Chechnya; those dismissed include Gen Anatoly Kvashnin, who held post equivalent to Pentagon's chairman of Joint Chiefs of Staff; he had been mired in bureaucratic quarrel with Defense Min Sergei Ivanov, one of Putin's confidants; Putin also removes deputy leader of Federal Security Service, successor of KBG; analysts call public firing of senior officer from that service an atypical gesture for president who is former spy himself and has remained closely identified with nation's intelligence services; photo (M)

headline: Wal-Mart Is Said to Be in Talks to Settle Illegal-Immigrant Case
abstract: Wal-Mart Stores, seeking to forestall indictment, is in settlement talks with federal prosecutors who are investigating whether company officials knew its janitorial contracts were using illegal immigrants to clean its stores; settlement talks come nine months after federal prosecutors in Pennsylvania sent Wal-Mart letter informing it that it was target of grand jury probe into use of illegal immigrants at its stores; federal officials rounded up 250 illegal immigrants at 60 Wal-Mart stores in 21 states on Oct 23 (M)

headline: BJ's Names Six in Account Review
abstract: BJ's Wholesale Club narrows review of its advertising account, which had been handled on project basis, to six agencies

headline: When Buffers Replace 'Replacement'
abstract: Most home insurance policies provide for payment of amount stated on policy plus additional 20 percent to 25 percent known as extended replacement coverage; owners should review coverage with agent each year and specifically consider rise in costs of building materials, not just general rate of inflation; coverage should be increased whenever house is remodeled (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Deals: Viacom Offers $42 Million For The Rest Of Sportsline
abstract: Viacom offered $42 million in cash for rest of sports Web site operator SportsLine.com; graph (S)

headline: Blair Says Iraqi Arms May Never Be Found
abstract: It was the closest the prime minister has come to acknowledging that his central argument for the invasion may never be proven.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Fischer Moved
abstract: Former world chess champion Bobby Fischer, who is appealing his extradition to United States for defying international embargo on travel to former Yugoslavia in 1992 to play re-match against Boris Spassky, is moved from Narita Airport (Tokyo, Japan) to detention center in Ushiku; lawyer Masako Suzuki holds Fischer wants to renounce US citizenship (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Veritas Software Corp., Mountain View, Calif., a leading maker of data storage software, agreed to buy closely held Invio Software Inc., Los Altos, Calif., for $35 million to gain some automation technology.    Penn Virginia Resource Partners, Radnor, Pa., manager of coal properties, acquired a 50 percent interest in a joint venture from an affiliate of Massey Energy Co., Richmond, Va., for $28.5 million.

headline: World Briefings
abstract: AMERICAS.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: EarthLink Rebounds To Profit
abstract: EarthLink reports re

headline: TEACH YOUR C.E.O.'S WELL
abstract: David Crosby says his song about corporate greed is about Enron; is annoyed by how long it took to indict Enron chairman Kenneth L Lay; photo (S)

headline: In Address at U.N., Bush Defends Decision to Invade Iraq
abstract: President Bush told skeptical foreign leaders and envoys today that Iraq was on its way to stability and democracy.

headline: Drowned, Not Downed, Trees in the Amazon Get Nasty
abstract: Brazilian government built $8 billion dam in Tucurui, but did not clear trees and other growth in area that would be flooded; now, 20 years later, it has become problem; decomposing vegetation has resulted in emission of millions of tons of greenhouse gases; submerged tree trunks hinder navigation, and scientists worry that increasing acidity of water in reservoir could corrode hydroelectric dam's turbines; photo; map (M)

headline: Britain Offering to Pay Off 10% of Third World Debt
abstract: British chancellor of Exchequer Gordon Brown announces that Britain is planning to help poor countries reduce their huge debts by offering to pay off 10 percent of total owed to international agencies; challenges other nations to follow suit; issue is rising again on international agenda because previous mechanism for debt relief, set up by World Bank and International Monetary Fund in 1996, is to be renewed for two years; Brown's proposal is significant because it comes days before annual meetings of World Bank and IMF; photo (M)

headline: Bacteria That Strike Elderly Spread in Canadian Hospitals
abstract: Canadian medical authorities say type of bacteria that causes virulent diarrhea in elderly is spreading through hospitals in Quebec and Alberta and may have contributed to deaths of 100 patients in one institution alone in past 18 months; bacteria commonly found in hospitals does not pose health threat to healthy people but can be deadly to already weakened people; Quebec public health officials are urging hospitals to reinvigorate their hygiene programs (M)

headline: Cellphones, Say Hello to iTunes
abstract: Users of Apple Computer's itunes music service will be able to play songs on some Motorola cellphones beginning next year; agreement is first for cellular phone industry (S)

headline: KANSAS CITY SOUTHERN PLAN TO BUY RAILROAD IS REJECTED
abstract: Kansas City Southern's plan to take control of TFM, Mexico's biggest railroad, from Grupo TMM is rejected by Mexico's foreign investment regulator (S)

headline: The Boot Camp For Corporate Directors
abstract: Michael G Brautigam letter on July 4 article on seminar for corporate board members

headline: Now, an Advance Look at Those Big Paychecks
abstract: Public companies, which traditionally reported past pay of top managers in following fiscal year, are beginning to provide more timely disclosure under new Securities and Exchange Commission rules requiring separate filings for variety of events; accelerated disclosures give shareholders chance to react by submitting proposals for inclusion on proxy statements; photos (M)

headline: Italian schools expand horizons
Disney to Hire Search Firm to Find New Chief by June
abstract: Walt Disney Co board says it will immediately hire executive search firm and will name successor to chief executive Michael D Eisner by June 2005; calls Disney's president Robert A Iger highly qualified candidate and says it will consider him for job, but also says it will look for outside candidates; chairman George Mitchell says board might determine that Eisner should leave earlier than September 2006, when his contract ends, if it finds qualified candidate ready to take job; also says he will not seek to continue as chairman past 2006; some contenders for Eisner's job discussed; photo (M)

headline: North Korea Is Reaching Out, And World Is Reaching Back
abstract: Experts say Bush administration's efforts to isolate North Korea to get it to drop nuclear program may end up isolating United States instead; note that Asian and European governments are actively engaging North Korea on diplomatic, cultural and economic levels; North Korea now has embassies in 41 countries and diplomatic ties with 155; it recently held first-ever military talks with South Korea, and is moving toward normalizing diplomatic relations with Japan; Democrats and other participants in talks on North Korea's nuclear program--South Korea, China, Russia and Japan--are pressuring Bush administration to come up with offer; in June, Pres Bush made first significant offer to North Koreans since coming into office; Asian and European diplomats and businessmen who have long dealt with North Korean officials describe their eagerness to adopt new ideas and policies; say North Korea of today is less isolated and more economically stable than it was just two years ago; North Korea began opening up immediately after its first summit meeting with South Korea in 2000; photos; map (M)

headline: A Professor's Long Rsum
abstract: Warren Batts, adjunct p

headline: At Deutsche, a new focus on Germany
World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Business Investment Grows
abstract: Investment by Japanese corporations rose 10.7 percent in second quarter from same quarter year earlier (S)

headline: Cameras in Chicagokeep a sharper watch
10 IN BAGHDAD DIE AS SUICIDE BLAST SHATTERS A CALM
abstract: Suicide car bomb kills at least 10 people at gates of American-occupied Green Zone in Baghdad, and governor of Nineveh, one of Iraq's largest provinces, is assassinated; events shatter tentative calm that has prevailed since Iraq regained formal sovereignty two weeks ago; Prime Min Iyad Allawi says suicide bombing could be retaliation for crackdown on insurgents by newly minted Iraqi security forces, who have fanned out across country, sweeping up hundreds of suspected terrorists and criminals; many Iraqi officials blame bombing on Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, Jordanian militant who has taken credit for relentless terrorism campaign that has killed hundreds, mostly civilians; assassination of Gov Osama Kashmoula of Nineveh Province is carried out by gunmen in four cars who swarm his convoy; Philippines beginswithdrawing its small contingent of troops in response to demand by Iraqi insurgents who kidnapped Filipino truck driver and threatened to kill him; Al Jazeera reports that group connected to Zarqawi beheaded one of two Bulgarian hostages after demands were not met to free Iraqi prisoners; photo (M)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: Pepsi-Cola North America reaches agreement for its Mountain Dew soft drink to become title sponsor of TV series Dew Action Sports Tour produced by NBC Sports and Motor Sports division of Clear Channel Entertainment; series is scheduled to begin in May 2005 and will be supported by promotions like sports and entertainment festivals (S)

headline: Mondavi Family to Loosen Control Over Winery
abstract: Robert Mondavi Corp, parent company of Robert Mondavi Winery, proposes share reorganization that would, for first time, leae Mondavi family without controlling interest in business; takes first step in separating luxury and everyday wine lines, which company calls 'lifestyle' wines, strengthening speculation that one or both parts of company might soon be up for sale; recapitalization plan calls for family's share of company to increase from about 36 percent to about 39 percent, but voting control would drop from just under 85 percent to just under 40 percent; president-chief operating officer Greg Evans comments; executive vice president Dennis Joyce is named chief operating officer for everyday-wine business; search is under way for executive to lead luxury division; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Strike Kills at Least 5 Afghan Civilians
abstract: The deaths came after insurgents attacked a base used by the American-led coalition.

headline: School Siege in Russia Sparks Self-Criticism in Arab World
abstract: The brutal school siege in Russia has sparked an unusual round of self-criticism and introspection in the Muslim and Arab world.

headline: The Many Delicate Issues Of Spirituality in the Office
abstract: Many Americans try to bring their spiritual life into their workday, sometimes raising questions about fine line between religious self-expression and proselytizing; photo (M)

headline: Northwest Cancels a Travel Agency Fee
abstract: By Reuters.

headline: Amazon Reports a Profit But Misses Expectations
abstract: Amazon Reports

headline: Indonesian Police Say Van in Attack Carried 2 or 3 Bombers
abstract: Indonesian police say security-camera photo shows at least two or three suicide bombers were in van that exploded outside Australian Embassy in Jakarta; describe how they followed suspects over last several months but then lost their trail; say men had written letters expressing willingness to commit suicide in terror attack; police blame Jemaah Islamiyah for mounting attack after receiving message before blast demanding release of group leader Abu Bakar Bashir from jail; photo (M)

headline: Spanish Judge Says Clues in Attacks Pointed to Islamic Radicals
abstract: Spanish Judge Baltasar Garzon, who is investigating Al Qaeda's activities in Spain, says he suspected almost immediately that Mar 11 terrorist attacks in Madrid were work of Islamic radicals; says nature of attacks suggested from outset that they were not carried out by ETA, Basque separatist organization blamed initially by Spanish government (M)

headline: Entr'acte : 'Seraglio' is scandalizing, revolting  and sold out
abstract: BERLIN  Usually played for laughs, Mozart's "Abduction from the Seraglio" is a light opera set around a Turkish palace and harem in which everyone except the pantomimic bad guy ends up happy. Not so in Calixto Bieito's new production at the Komische Oper in Berlin. Here, after scenes of copulation, fellatio, rape, torture and mutilation, almost everyone ends up a corpse. "Titus Andronicus" could hardly be bloodier.

headline: Outsourcing Corner Offices
abstract: Institute for Public Policy Studies and United for a Fair Economy, identifying United Technologies chief George A David as highest-paid chief of any of 15 companies deemed 'leading outsourcers,' suggests outsourcing his job to India, where highest-paid executive made $1.1 million to his $70 million last year; suggests United States executives should consider outsourcing themselves to save on labor costs (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: New Premier Is Approved
abstract: Pakistan Parliament elects former Finance Minister Shaukat Aziz as new Pakistani Prime Minister; Aziz was President Pervez Musharraf's choice for post (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Putin Backs Gazprom Bid To Acquire Oil Company  The Russian natural gas giant Gazprom said that it would buy one of the country's top oil companies, a move that would create a state-owned energy juggernaut.     President Vladimir V. Putin said he personally backed a proposal that Gazprom, the country's No.1 gas concern, swap some of its shares for Rosneft, the country's No.5 oil company. [World Business, Section W.]

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Federal Reserve Increases Benchmark Interest Rate  The Federal Reserve raised its benchmark interest rate for the first time in four years, officially signaling that a remarkable period of historically low rates is drawing to a close.    But even as the central bank increased the cost of borrowing for financial institutions on overnight loans to 1.25 percent from 1 percent, it sought to soothe investors by saying that inflationary pressures remain low and that further interest rate increases should come at a ''measured'' pace. [Page A1.]

headline: APPLIED EXTRUSION TO SEEK BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
abstract: Applied Extrusion To Seek

headline: Aid to plane makers pits Boeing vs. Airbus : EU and U.S. can't solve jet dispute
Book About Peasants Causes Stir in China
abstract: A muckraking best seller about abuses against Chinese peasants told the stories of farmers who fought the system and lost.      Now, the husband-and-wife authors say, it is their turn to be silenced.

headline: Watch Sales Rise for Fossil
abstract: Watch Sa

headline: Where Do the Jobs Come From?
abstract: Small businesses, even fast-growing small companies, remain extremely cautious in how they add workers, calling into question belief that small companies are responsible for bulk of new jobs created in United States; both small companies and big corporations shed jobs from 2001 through 2003 and both are still wary about hiring; percentage of people who work at small companies has remained roughly constant over last decade; photos (special section, Small Business) (M)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: Defense Dept confirms deaths of two service members in Iraq (S)

headline: BRIEFLY:EUROPE:BERLIN : Local vote gives hope to Schrder's party
Schrder is bloodied but hopeful
BRINKER SAYS INCOME WILL NOT MEET ANALYSTS' FORECASTS
abstract: Brinker International Inc says income in its fiscal first quarter ended Sept 29 will be 45 cents to 47 cents, less than analysts' estimates; says uincome rose 60 percent in its fourth quarter from year earlier, to $64.5 million; sales rose 16 percent, to $1 billion (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Auto Exports Rise
abstract: Auto exports from Mexico rose 15.3 percent in August; production rose 11.3 percent, and domestic sales grew 8.8 percent (S)

headline: U.N. and Congress in Dispute Over Iraq Oil-for-Food Inquiries
abstract: Congressional committees investigating allegations of corruption and mismanagement in UN oil-for-food program in Iraq are at odds with UN's own inquiry, led by Paul Volcker, over access to records and personnel (S)

headline: Security Briefings for the Other Guy
abstract: Intelligence officials brief John Kerry on latest terror threats in 40-minute call on secure telephone line; call is part of tradition that started during 1952 presidential campaign, when Pres Harry S Truman ordered that Gen Dwight D Eisenhower and Gov Adlai E Stevenson be briefed on urgent matters of that time (M)

headline: First Lady Of Mexico Rules Out Run For President
abstract: Marta Sahagun, wife of Pres Vicente Fox of Mexico, says she will not run for president in 2006; announcement is meant to end months of scorching commentary in press and political circles about Sahagun's flirtation with idea of succeeding her husband (M)

headline: Diet Pill Was a Driving Force in French Drug Merger
abstract: French drug company Sanofi-Synthelabo's acquisition of French-German rival Aventis linked to Sanofi's new drug rimonabant, which will be marketed as Acomplia, that fights obesity and smoking; drug was in Sanofi's pipeline long before merger of company, now called Sanofi-Aventis; analysts and doctors say drug could become one of industry's once-in-a-decade blockbusters; Sanofi plans to file for regulatory approval early next year in US and Europe; hopes to put drug on market in 2006; Sanofi needed Aventis's powerful sales force to market drug; photo (M)

headline: ON THE RECORD
U.S. Supermarkets Are Cited As Ahold Misses Profit Goal
abstract: Royal Ahold says its slumping American supermarkets unit contributed to lower-than-expected profit of 32 million euros, or $38.7 million, in second quarter; sales fell 5 percent, to 12.3 billion euros, from year earlier; chairman Karel Vuusteen resigns; photo (M)

headline: Virgin Atlantic to Purchase 26 Airbus Planes for $5.5 Billion
abstract: The announcement by Virgina Atlantic today would double the company's fleet as it continues its efforts to best rival British Airways.

headline: Karzai Trying to Regain Political Backing
abstract: Preparations are under way for Afghanistan's first presidential election; nine million eligible Afghans have registered to vote, several million more than expected, despite efforts by Taliban to disrupt process; NATO has agreed to provide extra forces to help 18,000 American troops maintaining security; incumbent Pres Hamid Karzai and 22 opponents have registered for race; despite trappings of democracy, real decision about who will be elected will be made by men who command thousands in their own private armies, some of them veterans from past wars; whichever way they choose, their soldiers, or mujahedeem, and their local communities are likely to follow their instructions at polls; Karzai has vowed, with American and international backing, to disarm them and build unified national defense corps; he is expected to gain bulk of vote of his own Pashtuns, largest ethnic group in country, but he may not be shoo-in he was thought to be; photos (M)

headline: Curtiss to Acquire Synergy
abstract: Curtiss-Wright Corp, maker of electronic controls and sensors for aircraft, agrees to buy Synergy Microsystems Inc for $49 million (S)

headline: Australia's Wines Expanding Their Global Shelf Space
abstract: Australia's McWilliam's Wines plans to increase sales to America substantially; Australia is second-largest source of imported wine in US, having shipped $600 million worth last year, surpassed only by Italy; McWilliam's Wines has new distribution agreement with E & J Gallo Winery; photos (M)

headline: U.S. Military Families Leaving Bahrain Over Terror Threat
abstract: The pullout has raised the possibility that the terrorist threat has begun seeping through the entire Gulf region.

headline: Euro RCSG Worldwide Wins Glaxo Campaign
abstract: GlaxoSmithKline expands its relationship with Euro RCSG Worldwide by awarding agency assignment to create campaigns aimed at consumers for asthma medication ; spending, which was handled by Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, is estimated at more than $100 million (S)

headline: MAJOR PORTION OF ISRAELI FENCE IS RULED ILLEGAL
abstract: International Court of Justice, in nonbinding decision, rules that major portion of barrier Israel is building violates international law because it is rising on Palestinian land on West Bank; calls on Israeli officials to tear down illegal sections and to compensate Palestinians whose land it cuts across; opinion is endorsed by all 15 justices with exception of sole American, Thomas Buergenthal; Israel says it will press ahead with planned 437-mile barrier, which it credits with helping to curb number of suicide bombings; about 120 miles have been completed since construction started about two years ago; photos (M)

headline: Pharmacy Sales Bolster Walgreen Profits
abstract: Walgreen Co reports net income for fiscal fourth quarter ended Aug 31 rose 18 percent, to $327.2 million, from year-earlier (S)

headline: Loans and Income Rise; Jobless Claims Fall
abstract: Federal Reserve says nonmortgage debt rose in May by $8.2 billion, or 4.9 percent at annual pace; borrowing rose by revised $5.3 billion, or 3.1 percent annually, in April; total consumer debt was $2.03 trillion in May; Labor Department says number of workers filing initial claims for jobless benefits fell for week to 310,000, lowest level since October 2000 (M)

headline: For Rabbits, Only the Best
abstract: To the Editor:    Re ''For the Diligent, a Soft, Furry Reward'' (Online Shopper, July 8), on acquiring and caring for a pet rabbit: Getting a rabbit from a shelter or rescue organization has several advantages over getting one from a pet store.

headline: From Dismal Chechnya, Women Turn to Bombs
abstract: Participation of women in Chechen suicide terror attacks--despite culture's deeply patriarchal society--reflects radicalization of war that began as separatist struggle but has turned increasingly nihilistic; it also exposes deep schisms that are tearing apart Chechnya, where few people speak warmly of Russia or Kremlin, but where all express horror at recent attacks carried out for sake of Chechnya's independence, including bombing of two planes and siege at school; Chechens have not embraced cult of religious martyrdom, and their religious leaders do not preach fiery sermons revering them; those who knew four women involved in recent attacks say they cannot believe they were involved and speculate about some other fate that has befallen them; female suicide bombers have taken part in at least 15 attacks since war erupted again in 1999; some say decade of war and destruction, including atrocities by Russian forces, have driven women to desperate acts; photos; brief descriptions of some suicide bombings by Chechen women (L)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Fetal Rights A National Issue
abstract: European Court of Human Rights, hearing case of involuntary abortion caused by doctor's error, rules that fetal rights must be determined on national level; French courts originally convicted doctor of involuntary homicide, but mother brought case before European Court after decision had been overturned (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Retail Sales Surge
abstract: Brazil's retail sales rose 10 percent in May from year earlier and 4.2 percent from April (S)

headline: Forstmann Little to Pay $15 Million in Lawsuit
abstract: Forstmann Little & Co, buyout firm led by Theodore J Forstmann, settles lawsuit with Connecticut state employees' pension fund for $15 million; state pension fund sued Forstmann Little, seeking return of $120 million lost from retirement funds in investments in McLeodUSA Inc and XO Communications Inc (M)

headline: Team Player? Problem Solver? There's the Door
abstract: Resume D

headline: Economic Scene; Gasoline prices are easing -- but not in California. Should the state step in?
abstract: Hal R Varian Economic Scene column on report from three analysts at University of California Energy Institute on steps California state government could take to reduce gasoline prices, which have not eased in recent weeks as they have elsewhere in country and are highest in country; they note that California's problem arises partly because it uses special low-pollution blend of gasoline called CaRFG; suggest that state could allow importation of non-CaRFG gasoline when CaRFG is in short supply, as long as importer pays tax equal to difference in cost between two kinds of gasoline; photo (M)

headline: China Ex-President May Be Set to Yield Last Powerful Post
abstract: Jiang Zemin reportedly tells Communist Party officials that he plans to resign as China's military chief and senior leader, prompting intense and so far inconclusive struggle for control of armed forces; it is unclear whether he genuinely intends to step aside, or if he would do so on terms acceptable to Hu Jintao, who succeeded him as head of Communist Party and president of China in 2002 and is now vice chairman of military commission; one official says Jiang, 78, may be calculating that he will be called on to remain military chief; if Hu were to gain control of armed forces, he could potentially carry out agenda that some analysts say is more open to change at home and possibly less truculent in managing local hot spots like Hong Kong and Taiwan; Hu and Jiang have not publicly sparred over domestic or foreign policy but are widely thought to represent different schools of thinking on some major issues; their struggle for influence is widely believed to have tipped China toward harder line on issues such as relations with Taiwan and political change in Hong Kong; photo (M)

headline: Weight Loss Surgery MaySoon Be Paid by Medicare
abstract: Medicare advisers will assess safety, efficacy and cost of increasingly popular method of weight loss--surgery--as first step in new policy that could lead to use of federal money to cover range of other obesity treatments; coverage by Medicare and other insurers may increase at time when evidence suggests that few obese people can lose significant amounts of weight in long term, and some obesity researchers question fundamental idea that losing weight improves health; reason for dearth of information on long-term effects of weight loss is that very few people keep weight off; currently, Medicare will pay for weight-loss surgery when patients suffer other problems associated with condition, like diabetes; new talks will discuss covering treatment for those who are simply obese; agency wants to determine if obesity treatments help people lose weight and improve their health; bariatric surgery costs $30,000 to $40,000; cost to Medicare for such coverage has not been determined; 61 million Americans are termed obese, including 9 million of Medicare age, 65 and older; photo (M)

headline: Ex-Employee Held in Arson First Linked To Neo-Nazis
abstract: Police arrest Jewish former employee in connection with recent arson attack on Jewish community center in Paris, suggesting that attack was not neo-Nazi act as originally assumed; if man is found guilty, it would be third case in under two months in which apparently anti-Semitic acts turned out to be work of disturbed individuals seeking attention, rather than neo-Nazis or others pursuing anti-Semitic agenda; hoaxes threaten to overshadow hundreds of real acts of anti-Semitism that have occurred this year in France (M)

headline: A New Sight In a District Of Najaf: Iraqi Troops
abstract: Small unit of new Iraqi Army soldiers begins working with American forces for control of Najaf shrine occupied by Shiite militia for three weeks; their patrol of area has at times air of public relations stunt; most residents of area, parts of which have been caught in heavy fighting, welcome Iraqi troops (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CITIGROUP INC., New York, the financial services company, said it had named Frits Seegers chief executive of its consumer business in Europe, the Middle East and Africa, succeeding Jean-Paul Votron, who left last month.    CITIZENS COMMUNICATIONS CO., Stamford, Conn., a telephone company, said it had hired Maggie Wilderotter, who was a senior vice president for Microsoft Corp., as president and chief executive, effective Nov. 1.

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: Defense Dept confirms deaths of three service members in Iraq (S)

headline: Reliance Posts Record Profit in Quarter
abstract: By Bloomberg News.

headline: STEEL DYNAMICS REPORTS SURGE IN EARNINGS
abstract: Steel Dynamics Inc, which makes steel from recycled metal, reports second-quarter net income surged to $67.3 million from $5.43 million in 2003 period (S)

headline: For some, French settlement is $3,000 : For Nazi victims, a low payout rate from banks
abstract: NEW YORK:  When Simon Jeruchim was 12, the French police raided and sealed his family's apartment in Montreuil, on the outskirts of Paris.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: New PBS Cooking Show Will Build a Brand Without Martha Stewart
abstract: New cooking series Everyday Food to air on PBS beginning in January is first for Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, which has long prclaimed that its corporate strategy is to build brands that do not necessarily revolve around Stewart; Sharon L Patrick, who replaced Stewart as chief executive of company after Stewart's indictment in June 2003, says series based on Everyday Food magazine, was long in series and it was not intended to be with Stewart; featured chefs will include Allie Lewis, John Barricelli, Lucinda Scala Quinn, Margot Olshan and Sarah Carey; photo (M)

headline: THE WORKPLACE : Bully them to make them leave
Technology Briefing | Hardware: I.B.M. To Supply Computers To Circuit City
abstract: IBM wins contract to supply computers and consulting services to Circuit City Stores; financial terms undisclosed; graph (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Sprint Plans Coffeehouse Venture
abstract: Sprint and National Federation of Coffee Growers of Colombia reach accord for Sprint to provide Internet and phone service to chain of Juan Valdez coffeehouses that federation plans for United States (S)

headline: 99 Cents or a Dollar?
abstract: My son, who just turned seven, was looking through an electronics catalog the other day. (The apple doesn't fall far from the tree, does it?)

headline: Landlocked Mongolia's Seafaring Tradition
abstract: Landlocked Mongolia is latest country to enter business of flags of convenience, international service that offers quite competitive fees and no restrictions on ownership of any ship; some 260 ships at sea fly Mongolia's red, yellow and blue colors; Bazarragchaa Altan-Od, Mongolia's maritime administrator, says 20 to 30 ships register monthly; photo (M)

headline: Amid a Price War, Revenues Fall at AT&T and MCI
abstract: Quarterly results from MCI Inc and AT&T Corp do little to reassure investors that long-distance industry is stabilizing, and reinforce speculation that companies have become potential takeover targets; MCI says sales fell 15 percent in second quarter from same period year ago, to $5.2 billion; lost $71 million after earning $8 million year ago; AT&T reported two weeks ago that revenue in second quarter dropped 13.2 percent, to $7.6 billion, and net profits plunged 80 percent, to $108 milion, from same period year earlier; MCI chief executive Michael D Capellas comments; photo (M)

headline: Chirac Condemns Desecration of Jewish Graves, Latest in a Wave
abstract: Pres Jacques Chirac scores desecration of 60 Jewish graves in Lyon, latest in wave of attacks on Jewish and Muslim cemeteries in France, letter to Jewish community leader Marcel Dreyfus; vows to find and prosecute vandals; many people suggest incidents are linked to young neo-Nazis entering France from Germany; map (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Brewer Expands With Purchase
abstract: SABMiller's China Resources Breweries acquires three unprofitable breweries in China from Lion Nathan for $71 million (S)

headline: Adultery a Crime? The Turks Think Again and Say No
abstract: Turkey's governing party abandons proposal to criminalize adultery, following wave of criticism from European Union, women's groups, columunists and its own members; photo; map; may still have forfeited good will after two years of reassurances that it does not have fundamentalist Islamic agenda; Prime Min Recep Tayyip Erdogan repeatedly endorsed proposal as way to preserve families (M)

headline: 3 Indicted on Charges of Insider Trading
abstract: Former Standard & Poor's analyst Rick A Marano, his brother William and friend-former business partner Carl Loizzi are indicted on charges of trading on confidential information about coming mergers, reaping hundreds of thousands of dollars (S)

headline: CALPINE TO SELL CANADIAN ASSETS TO PRIMEWEST ENERGY
abstract: Calpine Corp sells its Canadian natural-gas reserves and petroleum assets to PrimeWest Energy Trust for 825 million Canadian dollars ($631 million) (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Regulator Finds Problems At Big 4 Accounting Firms  The Public Company Accounting Oversight Board, which was established by Congress in 2002 as the regulatory body for the audit industry, said that its inspections of the Big Four accounting firms had found ''significant audit and accounting issues'' in work done by all four firms. The board reviewed the details of 16 audits in 2003 at each firm.      It added that it had found problems in the quality control systems at each firm, but that it retained confidence in them. [Page C2.]

headline: United Airlines Likely to Terminate Pension Plans
abstract: The cash-strapped airline said in a bankruptcy court filing today that it "likely" will be necessary to terminate and replace its employee pension plans.

headline: Manager at McCann Is Leaving for TBWA
abstract: Brett Gosper is named president of TBWA New York Group (S)

headline: Safety Gap Grows Wider Between S.U.V.'s and Cars
abstract: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration figures show gap in safety between sport utility vehicles and passenger cars last year was widest yet recorded; find people driving or riding in sport utility vehicle in 2003 were nearly 11 percent more likely to die in accident the people in cars; says crash fatalities declined across board in 2003 to lowest levels in six years, with 42,643 people killed in traffic accidents in US; Ward's AutoInfoBank says SUV's accounted for 27.2 percent of all light-duty vehicles in first seven months of 2004, up from 26 percent in period year earlier; graph; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Airline Plan Advances
abstract: Alitalia says eight of its nine biggest unions agreed to plan to split airline in two, enabling carrier to get loan to stay in business; Italian government will reduce its 62 percent stake in carrier, keeping at least 30 percent; plan will allow carrier to reduce work force by 20 percent; union that represents 1,200 flight attendants does not sign accord (S)2

headline: China Sets Its First Fuel-Economy Rules
abstract: Chinese government sets fuel-economy standards on new cars, sport utility vehicles and vans for first time; regulations represent broad effort by government to address its soaring dependence on imported oil; new rules coinicide with growing difficulties in last few months in China for multinational and domestic automakers, which find themselves stuck with large and growing inventories of unsold cars; Volkswagen, which dominates Chinese auto market, welcomes new regulations; photo (M)

headline: $220 for Two Hours? Clocking Mr. Fix-It
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column on finding repair contractor online; drawing (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Oil Prices Hurt Airlines
abstract: Standard & Poor's says European airlines may have trouble meeting earnings because of high oil prices; adds airlines and manufacturers of airline parts could suffer weakening credit quality (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Moves For Commercial Whaling
abstract: Japanese officials attending annual International Whaling Commission meeting in Sorrento, Italy, threaten to quit organization unless Japan is given concessions to reinstitute commercial whaling (S)

headline: Marine Said to Be Beheaded
abstract: A militant Iraqi group posted an unconfirmed statement on the Internet that it had beheaded an American marine who had been abducted from near the city of Falluja. Page 9.

headline: Spanish Romance Novel Comes to Prime Time
abstract: Telenovela, staple of Spanish-language television since 1950's, adheres to traditional form; usually involves central romantic couple separated for 120 episodes and reunited for happy ending; form can accommodate wide range of storytelling styles; photo (M)

headline: ON THE RECORD
In a Lavish Layette, the Illusion of Control
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column discusses Web sites that carry supplies and gifts for babies; drawing (M)

headline: People
abstract: Sharon Love, president at Promotion Network, is promoted to chief executive, succeeding Roger Winter, who becomes chairman; executive vice president Richard Feitler is promoted to president, succeeding Love; Penry Price is named Eastern sales director at New York office of Google, new post (S)

headline: Iraqi Reports on Capture of Hussein's Deputy Remain Unconfirmed
abstract: The last member of Saddam Hussein's inner circle still believed to have been at large was captured, Iraqi officials said, but doubts remain.

headline: Sharon Issues Bids for New Housing Units for Settlers
abstract: Prime Min Ariel Sharon, facing sharp debate at Likud Party convention, moves to pacify Israeli critics by issuing tenders for 1,001 new subsidized apartments in Beitar Elite settlement on West Bank, near Jerusalem; move will irk US, since Bush administration's peace plan calls for freeze on all settlement activity; Palestinian medics report 9-year-old boy was shot and killed by Israeli troops searching for weapons and enforcing curfew in Nablus; photos; map (M)

headline: Pilot Says Private Rocket 'Flew Like a Dream'
abstract: A test pilot returned successfully to earth today after a foray into space that was marked by a white-knuckle ascent.

headline: TiVo, Cable or Satellite? Choose That Smart TV Wisely
abstract: Advice on choosing digital video recorder, which records television programs onto hard drive, market that has taken off as prices have fallen and more cable and satellite companies offer them to customers for monthly fee; table of factors to consider; graph of DVR use; photo (M)0

headline: Computer Associates to Make Cuts
abstract: Computer Associates International will dismiss 800 workers, about 5 percent of work force, and cut number of software products it sells to save $70 million a year; Agere Systems, chip maker, says it will dismiss about 1,100 workers worldwide, about 17 percent of its work force, close Orlando, Fla, wafer plant that employs 600 people and close several offices (M)

headline: New Figures Hint at a Slowing of Chinese Economy
abstract: Growth in industrial output edged down slightly while economists and China's central bank prepare for likely evidence soon of higher inflation.

headline: Wiring a Convention, Version 2004
abstract: Modern journalism is increasingly reliant on advances in wireless and fiber optic technology; use of wireless frequencies for audio and video feeds at Democratic National Convention is strictly controlled to avoid communication problems and security breaches; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Payment To Oil Executive
abstract: Royal Dutch/Shell Group will give Walter van de Vijver, former head of exploration and production, one-time payment of 3.8 million euros ($4.6 million) in connection with his departure in March; van de Vijver remains on payroll until Sept 1; van de Vijver and former chairman Sir Philip Watts were ousted from Shell after company unexpectedly lowered its reserve estimates by 20 percent in January (S)

headline: India Sets A Fast Pace, Expanding 8.2% in Year
abstract: India's economy rose 8.2 percent in year ended in March, country's most rapid pace of growth in decade and half; manufacturing output rose 7.6 percent in quarter, while services grew 7.9 percent; farm output rose 10.5 percent, compared with year ago; photo (M)

headline: I.B.M. Supercomputer Sets World Record for Speed
abstract: International Business Machines supercomputer overtakes NEC Corp machine as world's fastest supercomputer; is based on technology that takes radically different approach from that used in Japanese computer; is one-hundredth size of NEC rival and uses far less power; will have wide commercial applications (M)

headline: Russians Find Explosives On 2nd Plane
abstract: Russian investigators find traces of explosive hexogen on second of two passenger airplanes that crashed simultaneously, first near Tula and second near Rostov-on-Don, confirming suspicion that twin air disasters were terrorist acts; investigators are focusing on two Chechen female passengers, although Islamouli Brigades of Al Qaeda have claimed responsibility for attack (M)

headline: Once a Corporate Hunter, Enron Is Now Just Leftovers
abstract: Enron, once pinnacle of international energy industry, is now little more than shadow of its former self; gone are some iconic properties, including company's ambitious energy trading operations, which it transferred to investment bank UBS in 2002; its share of controversial Dabhol power project in India, sold to General Electric and Bechtel in April 2004, and Wessex Water, British utility that it sold to YTL Power of Malaysia in May 2002; Enron's payroll is down to 10,300 employees, compared with 32,000 before company collapsed; charts; photos (M)

headline: Shares Decline, Pulled Down by Reduced Profit Forecasts
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average drops 86.80 points, to 10,231.36; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index loses 7.96 points, to 1,120.37; Nasdaq composite index declines 18.88 points, to 1,896.52; Russell 2000 index loses 2.44 points, to 568.52; US Treasury prices fall; price of benchmark 10-year note declines 10/32, to 100 22/32; yield rises to 4.16 percent, from 4.13 percent; graph; chart (M)

headline: Panel Hearing On Soldiers And Insurers
abstract: House Financial Services Committee chairman Michael G Oxley decides to hold hearing this fall on sale of mutual funds and life insurance on military bases, affirming growing bipartisan concern in Congress over marketing practices that have exposed young recruits to high-pressure or misleading sales pitches for products that may be ill suited to their financial needs; Oxley was asked by Rep Rahm Emanuel to consider holding hearings on issue; photo (M)

headline: Bomb Is Defused Near a Villa Where Berlusconi Met With Blair
abstract: Police defuse bomb in Porto Rotondo, Sardinia, town where hours earlier Prime Min Silvio Berlusconi entertained British Prime Min Tony Blair; bomb is found half mile from Berlusconi's villa after warning call is made to local newspaper from person claiming to be from local extremist group Proletarian Nuclei for Communism; map (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: RCN Plans To Exit Bankruptcy
abstract: RCN Corp files plan to exit bankruptcy that will exchange $1.2 billion in unsecured debt for all of equity in company by end of year (S)

abstract: Alimentation Couche-Tard reaches $33 million agreement to buy 22 gas stations and convenience stores in Phoenix area from Shell Oil Products US; stores will be converted to Couche-Tard's Circle K brand and gas pumps will be switched from Texaco to Shell brand (S)

headline: LOUISIANA-PACIFIC CHOOSES CHIEF EXECUTIVE
abstract: Richard Frost will become chief executive of Louisiana-Pacific after retirement of chairman-chief executive Mark Suwyn on Oct 31 (S)

headline: Falluja Pullout Left Haven Of Insurgents, Officials Say
abstract: American and Iraqi officials say decision in April to pull back American forces from Falluja inadvertently created safe haven for terrorists and insurgents there; say sending American troops back into city might touch off another uprising; say they would prefer to re-enter city with sizable force of Iraqi soldiers, backed up by Americans, but concede that Iraqi force capable of mounting assault on city of 250,000 people is months, even years away; result is that Americans and Iraqi government are faced with growing danger that they are nearly powerless to confront; American and Iraqi intelligence reports suggest that Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, Jordanian believed responsible for scores of attacks, is in Falluja, working with dozens of hard-core Islamist fighters, some from outside country and some former members of Saddam Hussein's Baath Party; Americans say they could regain control of Falluja by military means, but it would cost hundreds of Iraqi lives and risk sparking same sort of backlash as in April; photo (M)

headline: Earnings Increase 7.8% at News Corp.
abstract: News Corp says fiscal fourth-quarter profit rose 7.8 percent; net income rose to $399 million from $370 million year earlier; sales rose to $5.52 billion (M)

headline: Santa Cruz Journal; In Bolivia's Elitist Corner, There's Talk of Cutting Loose
abstract: Santa Cruz, Bolivia, considers itself better than rest of country, as evidenced by remarks made by country's Miss Universe contestant Gabriela Oviedo, who is from Santa Cruz; rift between city and highlands is emblematic of country riven by regionalism and centuries-old resentments between highland Indians and country's traditional ruling classes; photo (M)

headline: Pakistan Arrests Suspect in Bombings of U.S. Embassies
abstract: The Al Qaeda operative, who is on the F.B.I.'s most-wanted terrorist list, was arrested on Sunday.

headline: 9 Questioned in Attempt to Kill Pakistani Official
abstract: Pakistani law enforcement authorities are questioning as many as nine Pakistani suspects in connection with suicide bomber's assassination attempt last week on Prime Min-designate Shaukat Aziz; group calling itself Islambuli Brigades of Al Qaeda says it was behind assassination attempt, which it made in response to Pres Pervez Musharraf's willingness to turn over captured militants to Americans; Aziz escaped unhurt but eight others were killed (M)

abstract: Manitoba judge rules that marriage law is unconstitutional and must be changed to include same-sex marriage; Manitoba becomes fourth Canadian province to legalize gay marriage following Ontario, Quebec and British Columbia (S)

abstract: French Foreign Min Michel Barnier, addressing annual conference of French ambassadors, is far cry from man he succeeded, Dominique de Villepin, who was Europe's most vocal critic of Bush administration's march to war against Iraq; Barnier does not even mention United States, and says almost nothing about Iraq; some ambassadors note that when Barnier took office five months ago, part of his mandate was to repair France's tattered relationship with US, not to ignore it; photos (M)
