An Elite Squad of Iraqi Soldiers Tests Its Newfound Autonomy
abstract: Members of Second Battalion of Iraqi Intervention Forces are only Iraqi soldiers allowed to patrol streets without American troops beside them; battalion's 700 men still work closely with Americans, who are now more advisers than supervisors; unit gets curious and even supportive reception on streets; unit's biggest role is collecting intelligence on weapons and potential attacks (M)

headline: Former Boeing Executive Said To Be Close to a Guilty Plea
abstract: Michael M Sears, former chief financial officer for Boeing Co, is expected to plead guilty in early August on charge stemming from job offer to Darleen A Druyan, Pentagon official who negotiated on behalf of government in multibillion-dollar contract for fighter jets, cargo planes and other equipment; is expected to serve little or no jail time on single count of aiding and abetting (S)

abstract: Kommersant, Russian newspaper, reports that lower house of Parliament has approved several measures to ban beer drinking in public locations; holds that most beer in Russia is purchased for immediate consumption and predicts ban will have impact on product sales (S)

abstract: Judge Miriam Goldman Cedarbaum rejects Martha Stewart's request for new trial on charge of lying to investigators looking into her late 2001 sale of ImClone Systems shares; declares testimony of Larry F Stewart, government ink expert accused of perjury, could not have affected jury's verdict in trial (M)

headline: A Religious Tangle Over the Hair of Pious Hindus
abstract: Majority of India's Hindu population have their heads shaved at least once in lifetime as prescribed by Hindu scriptures, many unaware that temples sell traditional hair offerings to India's lucrative wig export industry; most of those who buy wigs abroad were equally unaware of religious aspect involved in collecting hair, at least until group of Orthodox Jewish rabbis in Israel barred wigs made with ritually tonsured hair as idolatrous; controversy seems to have made no dent in temples' earnings from hair; photo (M)

abstract: Food and Drug Administration says AstraZeneca may need to provide more data to prove its experimental blood thinner Exanta is safe and effective (S)

abstract: Bar code is joining forced march of globalization, with American retailers being forced by Uniform Code Council, North American arbiter of bar codes, to change their computer systems and software programs by Jan 1 to read 13-digit code now used in European Union and most other countries in addition to 12 digit code used in United States and Canada; bar code's 30-year history noted as example of how new technologies become adopted; drawing (M)

abstract: Audio Xtract software enables computer to record up to eight Internet radio broadcasts simultaneously as MP3 files; photo (S)

headline: Journalist From Italy Killed in Iraq By Captors
abstract: Al Jazeera reports that it received videotape from group calling itself Islamic Army in Iraq, showing killing of Italian journalist Enzo Baldoni; he disappeared last week while traveling to Najaf, after which group issued statement saying it could not guarantee his safety unless Italy withdraws its 2,000-member military contingent from Iraq within 48 hours; Italian government rejected demand; Prime Min Silvio Berlusconi, learning of Baldoni's murder, condemns act of 'barbarity'; photo (M)

abstract: Saddam Hussein may face execution, but the judge who will try him may himself be a marked man.

abstract: William J Holstein interview with Organization Resources Counselors chief executive Robert J Freedman on growing percentage of non-American executives working abroad for United States companies; drawing (M)

headline: Serbia parties called 'mafia'-riddled
When Funds Have to Show Their Hand
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson column on new Securities and Exchange Commission rule requiring mutual funds to disclose how they vote their shares on key matters that come up in proxy materials each year; holds change will show which fund companies have shareholders' best interests in mind; notes large majority of fund companies oppose antitakeover measures executives put in place to keep their cushy jobs (M)

headline: GIVE A GUY A BREAK
abstract: Andrew A Wiederhorn, chairman, chief executive, treasurer and secretary of Fox Cutter Capital Group Inc, who checks into federal prison Aug 2 to start 18-month sentence for filing false tax return and giving illegal gratuity to business associate, will be paid his regular salary and bonus (total of $2.3 million last year) and additional 'leave of absence payments' of $2 million, same amount he was ordered to pay in restitution as part of his plea deal; investor Jeff Allan McCoon has sued over pay package, alleging company's board has conflicts; Fog Cutter says its board agreed to deal because it worried that oen of company's investments would be at risk if Wiederman was fired and because he threatened to sue if let go (M)

headline: Verizon Wireless Expands High-Speed Data Network
abstract: Verizon Wireless will expand its wireless high-speed data network into 14 additional cities, including New York and Los Angeles, starting Sept 27; move is part of acceleration by wireless companies to expand reach of their broadband Internet services; company expects to spend $1 billion through 2005 to upgrade its cellular network to carry data at faster speeds; service will cost $79.95 per month for unlimited access, but laptop computer users must also purchase access card for their computer for $250, but company is offering rebates of $150 (M)

headline: ELIZABETH ARDEN FORECASTS SIZABLE PROFIT GROWTH
abstract: Elizabeth Arden Forecasts Sizable Profit G

headline: Powell Travels to Baghdad In Effort to Improve Morale
abstract: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell used an unannounced visit to Baghdad on Friday to tell anxious and embittered Iraqis that the United States will stand by its pledge to bring ''peace, freedom and democracy'' to their country, and to issue a rallying cry against kidnappers, bombers and others who, he said, wanted to return the country to a ''Saddam Hussein-like'' past.    Mr. Powell's visit, his third in the 16 months since Baghdad fell to American troops, appeared to be aimed in part at improving the uncertain morale of the Iraqi interim government. In its first month, the government has seen its hopes of drawing support from Iraq's 25 million people blighted by a wave of kidnappings of at least 25 foreigners, four of which have ended in grisly, videotaped beheadings, and by bombing attacks like the huge blast on Wednesday in the city of Baquba, 40 miles north of Baghdad, which left about 70 dead. Bombings have killed many more Iraqis than American troops.

headline: The new budget attempts to stem the flow of jobs abroad : France taking care of businesses
Alexander Lerner, Cybernetics Expert, Is Dead at 90
abstract: Dr Alexander Yakob Lerner, star of Soviet Russian cybernetics and patriarch of Jewish 'refusenik' colony in Moscow, dies at age 90; photo (M)

headline: A Transfusion of Fresh Power for an IPod on Its Last Legs
abstract: Newer Technology and Other World Computing introduce high-capacity lithium-ion cell that can last longer than iPod's original battery; photo (S)

headline: DELTA AND PINE LAND CUTS EARNINGS FORECAST
abstract: Delta and Pine Land Co reports net income in third fiscal quarter ended May 31 rose 10 percent to $31.4 million, up from $28.5 million a year earlier; cuts full-year earnings forecast (S)

headline: Asian Nations To Cooperate On Avian Flu
abstract: Ten Southeast Asian countries agreed here on Friday to form a new veterinary network to create and share the expertise needed to detect and control the spread of a highly contagious influenza virus that is deadly to birds and other animals and a threat to human health.     The network will provide basic training for veterinary workers, create ways to speed up exchanges of epidemiologic and laboratory information and better link veterinary and human health services.

headline: Even Under a Cloud, Yukos Continues to Thrive
abstract: Russia's Yukos Oil continues to thrive even though company owes government $3.4 billion in taxes and its founder, Mikhail B Khodorkovsky, is in jail for giving financial support to opposition political parties and by differing publicly with government over pipeline and export policies; Yukos still pumps nearly 1.7 million barrels of oil a day, or 2 percent of world's supply; photo (M)

headline: The Color of Mayhem
abstract: Marc Sylvestre letter says gangs in video game Grand Theft Auto are made up of many ethnic types, not just blacks (Aug 12 article)

headline: GENERAL MEDIA'S PLAN TO LEAVE BANKRUPTCY IS APPROVED
abstract: US Bankruptcy Judge Stuart M Bernstein approves plan by General Media, publisher of Penthouse magazine, to leave bankruptcy by transferring ownership of company to its bondholders from its parent Penthouse International; Penthouse International, which owns 100 percent of General Media's common stock, will not receive anything; Penthouse opposes plan and may seek to have it overturned (S)

headline: DataBank; Good News From G.E. Doesn't Rescue the Week
abstract: Down performance of key stock mB

headline: Google Is Said to Delay I.P.O. Because of Snag in Signing Up Big Investors
abstract: Google delays public stock offering by at least few days because of snags in preparing institutional investors for unusual auction company plans for its shares (M)

headline: Correction
Tokyo Court Allows Bank To Resume Merger Talks
abstract: Tokyo court grants appeal by UFJ Holdings that clears way for struggling Japanese bank to resume merger talks with larger rival Mitsubishi Tokyo Financial Group; reverses injunction by lower court that had banned UFJ from including its money-management unit in merger talks because of previous agreement to sell that business to Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group; Mitsubishi Tokyo says it is prepared to put as much as 700 billion yen ($6.3 billion) into UFJ, exceeding 500 billion yen ($4.5 billion) offered by Sumitomo Mitsui this week (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Retail Sales Rise
abstract: Canada's retail sales rose 0.2 percent, to 28.7 billion Canadian dollars ($22.1 billion) in June; retailers increased sales 1.3 percent in second quarter; graph (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Car Production Slows Again
abstract: China's passenger car production rose to 216,100 cars in June as output growth slowed to 20 percent from 32 percent in May and nearly 44 percent in April; government has clamped down on investment in industry, which it views as overheated (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Deals: Qualcomm To Acquire Iridigm
abstract: Qualcomm will buy 86 percent of Iridigm Display Corp it does not own for $170 million to acquire Iridigm's patented technology for cellphone screens (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Contract For Iron Sale
abstract: Australian mining company BHP Billiton says JFE Steel of Japan has acquired about $3.7 billion worth of its iron ore over next 11 years and take equity stake in one of BHP Billiton's mines (S)

headline: Governor of Iraqi Province Dies in Ambush
abstract: Gov Osama Kashmoula of Nineveh, sprawling and ethnically diverse northern province of Iraq, is ambushed and killed on his way to Baghdad, dealing new setback to American-led rebuilding of country and providing stark illustration of how freely terrorists are choosing their targets; two of Kashmoula's bodyguards are also killed in attack; before becoming governor, he had been professor of agriculture at Mosul Univ; photo; map (M)

headline: Hollinger Inc. Says S.E.C. May Bring a Civil Lawsuit Against It
abstract: Hollinger Inc says Securities and Exchange Commission might bring civil lawsuit against company because of violations of securities laws; plans to make so-called Wells submission to SEC stating why action should not be initiated (M)

headline: ALTRIA GROUP'S PROFIT RISES 7.8% IN SECOND QUARTER
abstract: Altria Group, parent of Philip Morris and Kraft Foods, reports second-quarter net income rose to $2.63 billion, up 7.8 percent from 2003 period (S)

headline: Seminary Sex Scandal Divides Austrian Church
abstract: Austrian news magazine publishes photographs of rector and deputy rector of Roman Catholic seminary in St Polten apparently kissing and fondling seminary students; publication of photographs comes after thousands of images downloaded from child pornography Web sites appeared on seminary computers, prompting police investigation; disclosures have taken on added importance because person in charge of St Polten Seminary is Bishop Kurt Krenn, prominent conservative; Krenn photo (M)

headline: Phelps's dreams meet not-so-bad realities
abstract: ATHENS:  Imagine, just for the length of a breezy, sun-kissed summer evening in Athens, that you had not heard a word about Michael Phelps before these Olympics began. That you knew nothing about his childhood in Baltimore; the failed Olympic dreams of his older sister, which pushed him to make the most of his obvious talent; the serial breaking of world records; the real or imagined link with Mark Spitz and his seven Olympic gold medals.

headline: Skittles overhauls a familiar theme to encourage experiencing the candy, not just tasting it
abstract: Masterfoods USA is overhauling its 10-year-old 'taste the rainbow' ad campaign for Skittles candy; campaign, developed by TBWA/Chiat/Day, encourages experiencing the candy, not just tasting it; photo (M)

headline: 'No Blood on Our Headscarf'
abstract: France' Muslims declare their solidarity with the secular state.

headline: Home Price Rises Hard to Track, Fed Chief Says
abstract: Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan, in letter to Sen Richard C Shelby, says Federal Reserve policy makers cannot accurately tell whether home values are overheating; says global economic recovery 'has become both stronger and more sustainable' in last year; adds economic recovery in Latin America and Canada 'appear to be on track'; says Japan's economy 'may finally be on its way to a self-sustaining recovery'; also says 'case has not been made' for need to specifically monitor hedge funds (M)

headline: Budget Fares Change Face of Air Travel for Indians
abstract: Air Deccan, India's first no-frills airline, is beginning to make flights between major cities affordable for many middle-class Indians; discount carrier flew its first glight on Aug 25; some tickets are 700 rupees ($15); photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Solid Profit Reports Lead To Rebound in S.&P. 500  Stocks climbed, helping the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rebound from a 2004 low, after companies reported better-than-expected profit.      The S.&P. 500 added 10.76 points, or 1 percent, to 1,094.83, and the Dow Jones industrial average advanced 123.22 points, or 1.2 percent, to 10,085.14. Both benchmarks had their biggest gains since June 7. The Nasdaq composite index climbed 30.08 points, or 1.6 percent, to 1,869.10. [Page C6.]

headline: Deutsche executives retreat to ready a new strategy
Feeling a Pinch on Payday; Putting the Business First
abstract: Many small business owners pay themselves only modestly in order to put money back into their business; experts warn that letting a business gorge on cash that could have ended up in owner's paycheck has its own problems; contend underpayment tactic can be risky, in that such owners are shouldering all the risk; experts say that owners are the ones paying bills and guaranteeing loans and have right to be compensated well; owners of United Agricultural Services, Mark Pecsenka and his brother Lajos, refuse to give themselves raises, even though their business is doing well; photo (M)

headline: What a Difference a Day Makes: The Sting of Late Fees
abstract: Advice on avoiding and fighting high fees for paying bills late; businesses of all sorts seem to have discovered that such punitive fees are lucrative; proliferation of such fees has caught eye of both regulators and class-action lawyers, opening some new options for consumers; table of key points; photo (M)

headline: Thailand Investigates Possible Bird Flu
abstract: HONG KONG, Sept. 27 - Officials in Thailand announced today that a 32-year-old woman had been hospitalized with avian influenza and that two of her family members had already died of a flu-like illness, raising the possibility that these might be among the first case of human-to-human transmission.

headline: Chairman Leaves Amid Pay Dispute At Sainsbury
abstract: Sir Peter Davis, chairman of Britain's oldest supermarket chain J Sainsbury, resigns after criticism of his $4.55 million bonus, which was awarded despite company's poor results in 2003; Sir Peter will be succeeded by Philip Hampton, who was chief financial officer of Lloyds TSB; photos (M)

headline: After Cutting Its Phone Prices, Nokia Raises Its Outlook
abstract: Nokia raises outlook for third-quarter sales and earnings after decision to cut handset prices (M)

headline: Iraq Is Soliciting Bids To Help Determine How Much Oil It Has
abstract: Iraq's oil ministry is undertaking first comprehensive evaluation in decades of two biggest oil fields in production, at Rumaila in south and Kirkuk in north; has invited dozens of foreign energy companies to compete for job of evaluating them; bids are due on Aug 15 and contracts are expected to be awarded in October; map; photo (M)

headline: Tech Company Settled Tax Case Without an Audit
abstract: IRS agent Remy Welling reveals how she was saked to sign off on secret deal work out by other IRS officials that allowed Micrel Inc and its executives escape paying at least %51 million in additional taxes that she is convinced they should have paid; agreement required IRS to cooperate with company in keeping its shareholders uninformed of some basic terms of its stock-option plan; revealing information about audit by IRS agent can open agent to criminal prosecution; Welling has decided to reveal information about case because she believes it represents particularly striking example of how outside influence and internal obsequiousness is corrupting integrity of tax system; Welling says she is about to be fired for going outside agency by taking her complaint to FBI and Securities and Exchange Commission; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: JDS Uniphase Narrows Loss
abstract: JDS Uniphase Corp says net loss narrowed to $24.3 million in its fourth quarter ended June 30 after sales rose for first time in 12 quarters; net loss was $61.6 million year earlier; sales rose 8.7 percent to $174.5 million, from $160.6 million (M)

headline: California Backs Plan for Big Cut in Car Emissions
abstract: California regulators approve plan aimed at drastically reducing over next 11 years vehicle emissions of gases that scientists link to global warming; California and seven Eastern states following its lead potentially represent 30 percent of automobile market; new standards challenge automakers to choose between building different vehicles for different markets or developing unified national strategy to meet standards; industry has fended off previous state efforts to regulate air quality, but states believe they will prevail this time; latest plan still faces expected legal challenge on multiple fronts from automakers and could be blocked by Bush administration; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Profit At Phone Concern Falls
abstract: NTT DoCoMo reports net income fell 13 percent, to 170.4 billion yen ($1.5 billion) for quarter ended June 30 from 196.8 billion yen year earlier; revenue dropped 2.5 percent, to 1.22 trillion yen for quarter (S)

headline: EU countries split over plan for refugee camps
PNC Financial To Acquire Riggs National
abstract: PNC Financial Services, Pittsburgh bank, will acquire Riggs National Corp for $779 million in stock and cash; deal ends Riggs's independence, but does not fully put to rest investigation of possible money laundering and terrorist financing through Saudi Arabian and Equatorial Guinean accounts at bank (M)

headline: Looking for More Than a Few Good Directors
abstract: Prof Joseph A Grundfest, former Securities and Exchange Commission member, runs program at Stanford University for corporate directors to learn best practices in corporate governance; demand for annual 3-day program is strong, spurred by rules changes that followed corporate scandals; lecturers and attendees comment; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Insurer Reacts To Rating Cut
abstract: World Business Briefing: Switzerland: Insurer Reacts To Rating

headline: G.I.'s in Battle of Wits With Rebels Over Bomb Technology
abstract: Iraqi insurgents, in deadly game of technological one-upmanship, have been adapting their most effective weapon, concealed and remotely detonated bomb, to increasingly sophisticated US attempts to detect devices before they explode; US soldiers say modifications suggest that there is technical elite among insurgents who are guiding changing designs; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Cases Of Missing On The Rise
abstract: Amnesty International reports that Nepal, where Maoist insurgency has been responsible for 10,000 deaths, has reported 378 disappearances in past year (S)

headline: The Cellphone's Next Makeover: Affordable Jukebox on the Move
abstract: Wireless industry is preparing to make affordable new cellphones that can store and play full-length downloaded music tracks; Apple Computer and Motorola, which have announced joint plan, and industry analysts say new feature will not alter market for portable music players anytime soon; photo (M)

headline: WORTHINGTON TO BUY ASSETS FROM WESTERN INDUSTRIES
abstract: Worthington Industries acquires propane and specialty-gas cylinder assets of Western Industries for $64.5 million (S)

abstract: List of Americans newly confirmed dead in Iraq (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Middle East: Switzerland: Swatch Investigation Dropped
abstract: Swatch says US Labor Department has dismissed complaints brought by two former employees, who claimed company used its Asian unit to evade taxes and customs duties (S)

headline: A Top Yukos Shareholder Is Charged With Murder
abstract: Moscow court issues arrest warrant for Leonid B Nevzlin, one of top shareholders in Russian oil company Yukos, charging him with murder and attempted murder; former Yukos security officer has been in jail since June 2003 on charges that he carried out Nevzlin's order to kill married couple; Nevzlin fled to Israel after arrest of Yukos founder Mikhail B Khodorkovsky, who is on trial on fraud and tax evasion charges, in case that analysts agree is politically motivated; Nevzlin has not returned to Russia (M)

headline: The Collections / LONDON : Urban versus country:The hunt is on
Europe Clears Merger Plan Of 2 Giants In Recordings
abstract: European Commission approves merger of recorded-music units of Sony Corp and Bertelsmann to form Sony BMG; deal, which has been opposed by rival music corporations and coalition of smaller independent record labels, would shrink number of global competitors to four and create company with second-largest market share; decision reflects sharp reversal by Europe's antitrust unit and its competition chief, Mario Monti, who took dim view of music industry consolidation in recent years; two companies hail decision (M)

headline: The Call to the Torah, Now Heeded Online
abstract: Web site developed by Rabbi Celso Cukierkorn offers online conversion course to anyone wants to become Jewish; photo (M)

headline: Mitsubishi Tokyo Provides $6.4 Billion to UFJ
abstract: Mitsubishi Tokyo Financial Group agrees to provide 700 billion yen ($6.4 billion) in emergency financing to UFJ Holdings in exchange for shares it could use to block bid from rival Sumimoto Mitsui Financial Group; agreement moves Mitsubishi Tokyo step closer to taking over UFJ by October 2005; Sumitomo Mitsui pledges to continue pursuit of UFJ (M)

headline: U.S. Airstrikes Said to Kill at Least 44 in Iraq
abstract: Iraqi health officials said U.S. airstrikes south of Falluja killed at least 44 people and wounded 27, including women and children.

abstract: World Business Briefing: China: Pipeline Deal Canceled*

headline: Joy in Italy as 2 aid workers go free in Iraq
Balance Sheet : A matter of survival
A Nike Veteran Adds Some Swoosh to Disney's Tired Mouse
abstract: Andrew P Mooney discusses his efforts to reinvigorate Walt Disney Co's consumer products division, turning Disney name into lifestyle brand, much as he did for Nike before joining Disney in 1999; division provides only about 9 precent of Disney's overall revenue, but toys, costumes and backpacks have life far beyond movie theater; Mooney hopes to turn Mickey Mouse and company into Martha Stewart of bed, books and apparel for children, trading as much on Disney's reputation for quality, which appeals to parents, as on its characters' appeal to children; photos; graph (M)

headline: Seeking Peace in a Once and Future Kingdom
abstract: China and South Korea, close economic partners, try to patch over sharp crisis by agreeing to discuss calmly boundaries of ancient Koguryo, whose tribes ruled much of modern-day North Korea and northeastern China from 37 BC to AD 668, when it was conquered by China's Tang dynasty; Koreans see kingdom as forerunner of their nation and source of name Korea; China, apparently concerned that two million ethnic Koreans in northeastern China will one day support 'greater Korea,' has begun portraying kingdom as merely Chinese vassal, stirring growing anti-Chinese sentiment in South Korea; map; photos (M)

headline: Pentagon lifts block on voter site
Miscellany
abstract: Kupper Parker Communications plans to acquire EPS Communications; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: A Vigorous, Improvised Response in a City That Remains a Prime Target
abstract: Final report of 9/11 commission finds that New York City's emergency response was plagued by many of same failures of imagination and preparedness that it cited in nation's anti-terrorism policies; finds that cascade of systemic failures and institutional weaknesses was overcome in part by vigorous, improvised response in city, where thousands of people escaped from World Trade Center; warns that New York and Washington remain prime targets of even bigger terrorist attacks that not only are possible, but probable; says these cities should receive bulk of federal homeland security money, and Congress should drop current system of spreading funds across country based on population rather than threat; says New York's current emergency system 'falls short'; spokesman for Mayor Michael Bloomberg says city's plan is still being refined (M)

headline: S.&P. Hits Lowest Point in '04 as Profit Forecasts Fall
abstract: Standard & Poor's 500-stock index loses 2.13 points, or 0.2 percent, to 1,084.07; Dow Jones industrial average drops 0.30 point, to 9,961.92; Nasdaq composite index drops 10.07 points, or 0.5 percent, to 1,839.02; Russell 2000 Index loses 5.74, or 1.1 percent, to 533.49; US Treasury notes decline; price of benchmark 10-year-note falls 15/32, to 102 1/32; yield rises to 4.49 percent, from 4.43 percent; graph; chart (M)

headline: US Airways Asks Court for Pay Cuts
abstract: US Airways asks federal bankruptcy court to approve emergency pay cuts of about 23 percent plus other moves, aimed at raising $38 million in cash per month; chief executive Bruce R Lakefield says airline will implement spending cuts and other cost-saving moves aimed at generating additional $5 million per months; cuts would apply to five unions; about 150 flight dispatches, who are members of transport workers, are exempt from motion; they reached tentative agreement with carrier earlier in week on $4.5 million in cuts (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: BskyB Reports Lower Profit
abstract: British broadcaster BskyB says profit margins will be lower than expected through 2007 as it increases spending, sending stock dropping more than 19 percent; graph (S)

headline: HANGER ORTHOPEDIC SHARES FALL AFTER PROFIT WARNING
abstract: Shares of Hanger Orthopedic Group drop 41 percent, one day after company says that its second-quarter profit will decline sharply and will not meet estimates (S)

headline: Wholesale Inventories Rise as Sales Slow
abstract: Commerce Department reports inventories at wholesalers rose 1.1 percent in June, more than expected, amid stagnant sales; says increase, which brought value of goods at distributors, warehouses and terminals to $309.5 billion, followed gain of 1.4 percent in May; sales were unchanged after rising for 12 consecutive months, including 0.3 percent increase in May (M)

headline: Arrested Qaeda Operative: Life of Degrees and Aliases
abstract: Muhammad Naeem Noor Khan, Pakistani computer engineer now being described as Al Qaeda facilitator or operative, appears to have background similar to 9/11 hijackers, many of whom were children of opportunity and well educated, who abandoned career for mission; according to Khan, he has been Al Qaeda sympathizer at least since he was 19; he seems to have traded his birth family for ideological one, living in Lahore rather than at his parents' home; he says Al Qaeda helped pay his rent and even chose his wife; at time of his capture on July 13 he was portrayed as facilitator of communications for Al Qaeda; since then, news reports have upgraded him to mastermind who possibly helped plan attacks abroad; it was his computer that yielded information including graphics of designs of important buildings and calculations of impact of explosions (M)

headline: Bank
abstract: Advice for small businesses on choosing bank; sampling of bank offerings; drawing (special section, Small Business) (M)

headline: Restrained Start for Football Marketing
abstract: National Football League will kick off season on ABC with back-to-basic, wholesome programming; there will be 10-second delay for concert portion of Kickoff Celebration featuring various artists; advertisers and agencies say they feel assured that NFL is doing all it can to deter repeat of problems unleased when Janet Jackson-Justin Timberlake incident during Super Bowl halftime show; photos (M)

headline: U.S. Military Arrests A Senior Iraqi Officer
abstract: The American military has arrested a senior commander of the Iraqi National Guard, raising concerns about the loyalty and reliability of the new security forces.

abstract: Leucadia National Corp says in Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it owns 5 percent of common stock of long-distance carrier MCI (S)

headline: Muslim-West divide is on Anwar's mind : Return of a Malaysian
Storm Chasing on Wall Street
abstract: Catastrophe bonds, little-known securities through which investors bet on natural and even terrorist disasters, described; insurance companies issue bonds to help them pay excess claims from such events; bonds usually pay high interest rates and are sold to hedge funds and other institutional investors; holders could lose their investments if insured losses from catastrophe exceed certain threshold; bonds trade over the counter and through private deals; Standard & Poor's has yet to downgrade bonds, despite unusually high number of hurricanes hitting Florida this season, because insured damage is not expected to exceed threshold; most of bonds have four-year maturities and have triggers tied to one event; market graph; photo (M)

headline: AFGHAN PRESIDENT DESCRIBES MILITIAS AS THE TOP THREAT
abstract: Pres Hamid Karzai says private militias have become Afghanistan's greatest danger--greater than Taliban insurgency--and that new action is required to disram them, int; says persuasion has not worked, and now 'stick has to be used, definitely'; makes remarks two days after postponing parliamentary elections by six months because of threat of disruption; does not specify what action he would undertake against militias; his leadership over two and half years, with heavy American backing, has rested largely on accommodation with various forces; his current frustration, and that of his ministers, seems acute; he says corruption remains rampant and that failure of disarmament program is source of keen anxiety among people; asked to rate his government on how well it has achieved its goals, Karzai offers grade of D; out of 60,000 armed militiamen, only 10,000 have been disarmed and demobilized; Karzai expects struggle with warlords to be decisive, suggesting that his government and society are at turning point; photo (M)

headline: Consumer Lending Helps Bank of America in Quarter
abstract: Bank of America Corp says second-quarter profit rose 41 percent, lifted by purchase of FleetBoston Financial Corp and increase in consumer lending; net income rose to $3.85 billion compared with $2.74 billion year earlier; revenue increased 35 percent, to $13.2 billion; chief executive Kenneth D Lewis comments (M)

headline: Investors Show Faith in Economy, Pushing Markets Higher
abstract: Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 14.54 points, or 1.4 percent, to 1,079,34; Nasdaq composite index rises 25.62 points, or 1.5 percent, to 1,782.84; Dow Jones industrial average gains 129.20 points, or 1.3 percent, to 9,954.55; US Treasury securities fall; price of benchmark 10-year note declines 10/32, to 99 28/32; yield rises to 4.26 percent, from 4.23 percent; graphs; charts (M)

headline: Want More Stuff? Lend a Few Rooms To the Nearest Bank
abstract: Homeowners are cashing out rising value of their homes by refinancing or taking out home equity loans; rising interest rates may end refinancings, leaving equity loans as only option and risky one should home prices fall; home equity lending graphs (S)

headline: Apple Attacks RealNetworks Plan to Sell Songs for iPod
abstract: Apple Computer sharply criticized RealNetworks for giving away software that lets people download songs from its online music store and play them on Apple's iPod portable music player, as well as on any of 70 other music players on market; says it is weighing legal implications of move and warns that RealNetworks' software, called Harmony, might not work with future versions of iPod software; Networks replies that consumers, and not Apple, should be ones choosing what music goes on their iPod; RealNetworks is first company besides Apple to sell songs in protected iPod format, but others companies sell them in MP3 format, which player can also use; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Pressures Rebels in Najaf as Talks to End Fighting Stall
abstract: The U.S. is again preparing for an assault on Najaf's Old City, which surrounds the rebel base at the shrine of Imam Ali.

headline: Europe Approves Genetically Modified Corn as Animal Feed
abstract: European Union approves importation of genetically modified corn from United States for animal feed, breaking six-year moratorium on biotechnology crops; decision will allow importation and sale of corn, but not its cultivation; Monsanto, corn's developer, hails decision; Bush administration says it will still press its case against European Union at World Trade Organization; holds Europe must have predictable, timely, science-based regulatory system for biotech products (M)

abstract: Allied Waste Industries cuts profit forecast for second time in two months because of higher costs for truck maintenance (S)9

Copenhagen Journal; Wedding Vows Can Lock Danes Out of Their Homeland
abstract: Denmark's laws on immigration are thought to be toughest in entire 25-member European Union and have produced strange and unwanted result; they have barred about 1,000 mixed Danish-foreign couples from setting up households; they live across strait and commute across bridge from Malmo, Sweden, to Copenhagen every day, or take ferry, to work or study; some of immigration legislation's sponsors say law is not intended to throw out Danes, but it is unavoidable result of effort to reduce influx of foreigners who, they argue, burden social welfare system and often defy efforts to integrate; photos; map (M)

headline: Don't Run From That Portfolio. Tweak It.
abstract: Fundamentally column by Paul J Lim notes money managers move in and out of assets when they sense too much risk, but individuals are often advised against making such moves; says individual investors, unlike professional money managers, must tend to longterm goals; says short-term fluctuations should not affect financial plans intended to meet targets 20 or more years out; says investors must be willing to expose themselves to some degree of risk if they expect much in way of returns; cites ways to reduce risk while tweaking portfolio; graph (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Vivendi's Loss Grows
abstract: Vivendi Universal reports net loss of 1.85 billion euros in second quarter compared with loss of 313 million euros year earlier; chief executive Jean-Rene Fourtou comments; photo (S)

abstract: The former president of South Africa lent his prestige to the battles against two deadly diseases that are intricately linked.

abstract: Officials said that 527 people suspected of crimes from kidnapping to murder were arrested today in a major sweep.

headline: Schwab Ousts Chief and Founder Steps In
abstract: Charles Schwab Corp ousts chief executive David S Pottruck; chairman and founder Charles R Schwab will return as chief; second-quarter earnings fall 10 percent from year earlier, to $113 million; photo (M)

headline: A Win-Win Merger (For the Bosses, That Is)
abstract: Patrick McGeehan column on efforts of pension managers and California regulators to reduce total of $200 million or more dozen executives will get if Anthem Inc acquires rival health insurer WellPoint Health Networks for $16.4 billion; critics of deal have tried to tap into investors' anger over excessive executive pay, citing $82 million WellPoint chairman and chief executive Leonard D Schaeffer will get; deal provides immediate benefits for all senior executives of both companies, but little of synergy that justifies most mergers; graph of Schaeffer's pay; photo (M)

headline: Stent Maker Says Sales Lost After Recall Have Returned
abstract: Boston Scientific says it has regained virtually all of business it lost after recall this summer of some of its heart stents; characterizes recall as $100 million 'blip' in year when revenue will end up growing about $2 billion, to as much as $5.58 billion (M)

World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Trade Surplus Grows
abstract: Canada's second-quarter current account surplus rose to 10.4 billion Canadian dollars ($7.9 billion), up from 8.8 billion Canadian dollars in first quarter; trade surplus reached 20 billion dollars, up from 3.6 billion dollars during previous three-month period; services trade deficit shrank slightly, to 2.9 billion dollars; graph (S)

headline: A Wide Lens Helps In Emerging Markets
abstract: Manager Christopher D Alderson comments on his strategy for T Rowe Price Emerging Europe and Mediterranean fund, interview; photo (M)

headline: March Gives Impetus to Hong Kong Democracy Movement
abstract: Unexpected size of march in Hong Kong on July 1 has put renewed pressure on local government and Beijing to allow greater democracy, but little change is likely until after Sept 12 legislative elections; crowd, estimated at 200,000 to 530,000 protesters, is evidence that Chinese government's efforts to dampen democratic sentiment in Hong Kong have not succeeded (M)

headline: Around the World, Markets Are the Dullest in Years. Is That Good News?
abstract: Floyd Norris column on boring stock markets around world; says in most cases, doubts shown by dull markets have been resolved with good news and could be harbinger of good times; graph (M)

headline: Infineon to Pay a Fine in the Fixing of Chip Prices
abstract: Justice Department says that it has cracked global cartel that illegally fixed prices of memory chips in personal computers and servers for three years and that one of companies involved, Infineon Technologies, has agreed to plead guilty to one criminal count and pay fine of $160 million; complaints by computer makers of possible collusion in memory equipment market led to probe; computer makers that were hurt by alleged collusion included Dell, Compaq, Hewlett-Packard, Apple, IBM and Gateway (M)

headline: Chalabi Files Suit in U.S. Challenging Conviction in Jordan
abstract: Ahmed Chalabi returned to Iraq to face criminal charges made by the Iraqi government as his lawyers took steps to salvage his crumbling reputation.

headline: Microsoft May Sell Slate, a Pioneer in Web Magazines
abstract: Microsoft is exploring sale of Slate, pioneer in digital publishing; MSN Network Experience general manager Scott Moore says Slate executives have been assured that if suitable buyer does not step forward with attractive offer, Microsoft would continue to own and operate site; Slate's editor Jacob Weisberg says new owner may help magazine's future; photo (M)

abstract: Qualcomm and Microsoft reach agreement that will let customers play digital audio and video files created with Microsoft Windows Media software on wireless devices that use Qualcomm's chips; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Putin Visits Chechnya After Rebel Attacks
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin's trip, along with the fighting, came a week before Chechnya is to hold an election to replace Akhmad Kadyrov.

headline: Barred by Israel as Security Risk, Pro-Palestinian American Refuses to Go
abstract: Ann Petter, New Yorker who flew to Israel to take part in pro-Palestinian marches, is denied entry and ordered expelled; she is free to return to US, but has spent past week in Israeli custody at airport while fighting deportation order; Israelis declare her security threat because of her involvement with International Solidarity Movement, pro-Palestinian group made up mostly of Americans and Europeans (M)

headline: Music Official At Warner To Step Down
abstract: Roger Ames, who ran Time Warner's global music division and remained as consultant after its sale to investment team headed by Edgar Bronfman Jr, is leaving Warner Music Group; photo (S)

headline: Annuity Sales Help MetLife Increase Profit 45% in Period
abstract: MetLife Inc says profit rose 45 percent in second quarter; net income rose to $842 million from $580 million year ago; total revenue rose 9.3 percent, to $9.69 billion (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Woman With Ties To Militant Held
abstract: Palestinian woman Tali Fahima has been detained by Israeli police on suspicion of terror-related crimes; is believed to have served as human shield for wanted West Bank leader Zacaria Zubeidah, who heads Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades; photo (S)

headline: US Air to Seek 5-Year Extension for Pension Fund Payments
abstract: US Airways, facing cash shortage as it tries to avoid another bankruptcy filing, says it will seek Internal Revenue Service permission to stretch out $67.5 million contributions it owes to pensions, due for 2004, of up to five years of its mechanics and flight attendants (M)

headline: The 3 R's and Beyond, With a Software Boost
abstract: Basics column roundup of educational software for primary and secondary school students; Web sites noted; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Telecom Dispute Ends
abstract: BCE Inc to sell its 22 percent stake in Manitoba Telecom Services Inc after companies settle suit and sever commercial ties, heralding increased competition between them; Manitoba Telecom agrees to pay BCE 75 million Canadian dollars ($56 million) as part of deal (S)/

headline: Port-au-Prince Journal; Soccer's Odd Bonding: When Brazil Scores, Haiti Roars
abstract: Haiti's 40-year love affair with Brazilian soccer has grown to obsessive proportions over past decade, and extends to all things Brazilian; United Nations peacekeeping force in Haiti is anchored by 1,200 Brazilians in capital of Port-au-Prince; Brazil's national soccer team, accompanied by Pres Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, will arrive there to play exhibition against Haiti on Aug 18; Haitians cannot conceive of notion that Haitian team could win against Brazil; photos; map (M)

headline: SCHWAB CUTS 186 WORKERS AND WILL CLOSE OFFICES
abstract: Charles Schwab Corp lays off 186 employees and will close 53 branch offices as it moves to cut as much as $200 million in costs to deal with decline in trading (S)

headline: Rumsfeld Errs on Reports
abstract: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld mischaracterized the findings of two reports on prison abuse, saying there was no evidence of abuse during interrogations. Page A6.

headline: REED ELSEVIER TO ACQUIRE SEISINT FOR $775 MILLION
abstract: Reed Elsevier Group acquires Seisint Inc for $775 million in cash to expand in market for risk management in US; Seisint's Accurint product provides online access and analysis of public records to help governments and law firms with tasks including due diligence, debt recovery and pre-employment screening (S)

headline: Good Stock Advice or Online Noise?
abstract: Hal R Varian Economic Scene column on study by University of British Columbia economists Werner Antweiler and Murray Z Frank on legitimacy and worth of stock message boards on Internet; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Blacks Buy Bank Stake
abstract: South Africa's Standard Bank Group and its Liberty Group life insurance unit agree to sell 5.6 billion rand ($925 million) in shares to black investors in biggest attempt yet to raise black participation in South Africa's economy; investors will be Millennium Consolidated Investments Ltd, led by Cyril Ramaphosa, Safika Holdings Ltd, led by Saki Macozoma, employees and community trust; photo (S)

headline: Selling Caution Or Hedonism In a World Of No Smoking
abstract: Reynolds American Inc, company that will be formed by merger of R J Reynolds Holdings and Brown & Williamson, will be promoting Advance cigarettes to health-conscious consumers and Camels to those who might be moved to rebel against repressive orthodoxies for the sake of a little glamour; campaigns go different ways to make brands stand out, but they both reflect tobacco industry's struggle to broaden appeal of cigarettes in world where smoking is increasingly scorned, forbidden or hidden; photos (M)

headline: Court Allows Hollinger to Sell Paper Without Investor Vote
abstract: Delaware court rules that Hollinger International can sell Telegraph Group, which includes London's Daily Telegraph, Sunday Telegraph and Spectator, to David and Frederick Barclay without first holding shareholder vote; Lord Black, Hollinger International's controlling shareholder, will appeal ruling (S)

abstract: Andrew Ross

headline: CORNING REPORTS NET INCOME GAIN OF $130 MILLION
abstract: Corning Inc, fiber optic cable maker, reports second-quarter net income of $108 million, compared with year-earlier loss of $22 million (S)

headline: Thais Suspect Human Spread of Bird Flu
abstract: Two members of Thai family fall ill with avian influenza, and third probably died of it, prompting Thai health ministry to announce that human-to-human transmission of deadly illness has probably occurred for first time this year; biggest worry of public health officials has been that virus would evolve into form readily transmissible among people that would allow it to spread around globe within weeks; Thai health officials say there is no evidence that virus mutated; photos (M)

headline: The Poker Player
abstract: Interview with chairman and chief executive Brian L Roberts on Comcast Corp's plans to grow in wake of of its failed bid for Walt Disney Co; scars from failed bid run deep at Comcast, largely because company has long had its way in merger talks and has been one to walk away from high-profile deals; graphs of Comcast holdings and of largest cable operators; photos (M)

abstract: Defense Dept confirms deaths of nine service members in Iraq (S)

headline: Back From the Drawing Board, A Game Console That Rings
abstract: Nokia redesigns N-Gage, combination hand-held game console and cellphone; first generation was badly designed, too multifunctional and drew complaints from users; photo (S)

abstract: The return of the summer jacket, especially the blazer

abstract: Roundup of new ad account assignments (S)

abstract: What's Next column on research and developments for reducing noise created by jet engines; newest research focuses on altering exhaust turbulence; drawing (M)

headline: All Over the Living Room, An Acoustic Sweet Spot
abstract: Denon audio-video receiver uses new technology to adjust speaker response to fit room characteristics; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Petroleum Taxes Cut
abstract: India cuts taxes on petroleum products to curb effect of high energy prices on growth and on inflation (S)

headline: New Face of Farming in Russia's Far East
abstract: Russia's farmland in Far East is drawing reverse migration as Russian youths abandon farm villages for city; there are five South Korean commercial farms on leased land and 2,390 Chinese farm workers and sharecroppers in Primorye, or Maritime province; Russia is still net food importer from China, but trend is shifting fast; Russian land tenure law that went into effect last year allows foreigners to sign 49-year leases for farmland; map; photos (M)

headline: True Hospitality: At Your Service and Then Invisible
abstract: Article on proper hotel etiquette, which can make all difference to guest; photo (M)

headline: United Airlines to Quit Paying Into Pension Plans
abstract: United Airlines will not contribute to its employee pension plans while it remains under bankruptcy protection; that move could save it more than billion dollars over coming year, but pension experts say it signals likelihood that United will terminate some or all of plans; full-blown default by United on its pension plans would send tens of thousands of current and future retirees, and billions of dollars in unfunded obligations, to Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp, government's pension insurance program, dealing program its biggest blow since government began insuring pensions in 1974 (M)

headline: Who's Knocking at the Door? Check Your E-Mail First
abstract: New Web site called E-Neighbors hopes to break down barriers of communication within neighborhoods; site allows people to post profiles to encourage interaction with others with similar interests; photo (M)

headline: KANSAS CITY SOUTHERN TO BUY STAKE IN TEXAS RAILROAD
abstract: Kansas City Southern acquires 51 percent of Mexrail from Grupo TMM for $32.7 million as part of plan to gain control of Mexico's biggest rail network; must buy rest of Mexrail for $31.4 million by Oct 31, 2005 (S)

headline: KINDER MORGAN ENERGY BUYS OIL PIPELINE IN TEXAS
abstract: Kinder Morgan Energy, pipeline partnership, acquires Kaston Pipeline Co from Western Refining for about $100 million in cash; pipeline can carry as much as 115,000 barrels of oil daily from fields in West Texas (S)

headline: British Hospitals Struggle to Limit 'Superbug' Infections
abstract: Britain has one of worst rates of hospital-acquired MRSA (methicillin-resistant staphylococcus aureus) bloodstream infections in Europe, second only to Greece, and problem is getting worse; National Audit Office says there has been 8 percent increase in number of staph infections in bloodstream, to 19,311 in 2004 from 17,933 in 2001; says 40 percent were resistant to antibiotic methicillin; says infections result in at least 5,000 deaths a year; photo (M)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: American Vantage Media, New York and Santa Monica, Calif., part of the American Vantage Companies, formed a branded-content division by consolidating some assets of three subsidiary production companies: Hypnotic Media, a co-producer of the Fox Broadcasting series The O.C.; Wellspring Media; and YaYa Media. The division will be overseen by David Schulte , vice chairman. Separately, MasterCard International, Purchase, N.Y., named American Vantage Media to handle development, production and marketing duties in support of its 2004 Priceless Experience Music Internship promotion, which offers the 16 college students who win the contest a monthlong course in music video production.

headline: Serra Pelada Journal; Brazilian Miners Wait for Payday After Diet of Bitterness
abstract: Prospectors for gold still linger in Serra Pelada, in corner of Amazon jungle, refusing to give up their dreams of another lucky strike nearly quarter century after discovery of some of biggest nuggets on record anywhere started gold rush there; Serra Pelada is now home to about 8,000 people, mostly prospectors who have no other place to go or who cannot afford to leave; photo; map (M)

headline: Looking Back and Looking Ahead, Panel Assesses the Opportunities for Prevention
abstract: Report from 9/11 commission says it found no evidence that Iraq, Iran or Saudi Arabia knowingly provided operational or financial support to Al Qaeda in advance of attacks, but it calls for further investigation of relationship between Iran and Al Qaeda (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Inflation Rises
abstract: Brazil reports consumer prices rose more-than-expected 0.71 percent in June (S)4

headline: U.S. Army Charges 4 Soldiers in the Drowning Death of an Iraqi Man
abstract: US Army charges Lt Jack M Saville, Sgt First Class Tracy E Perkins, Sgt Reggie Martinez and Specialist Terry Bowman in drowning death of Iraqi detainee who was pushed off bridge north of Baghdad along with another Iraqi man in January (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Talks On Broker End
abstract: Talks b

headline: Global Oil Demand Expected to Exceed Forecasts, Report Says
abstract: Oil producers are under pressure to boost their output at a time when rising oil prices may hurt a recovering world economy.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: Mattson Jack Group acquires DaVinci Healthcare Partners (S)

headline: Looking for a Chance by Looking for Trouble
abstract: Advice for would-be entre

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Fischer Appeals Deportation
abstract: Former world chess champion Bobby Fischer, who is being held at Narita Airport (Japan) for traveling on revoked American passport, is appealing Japanese court's decision to extradite him to US; is wanted in US for playing match in 1992 against Boris Spassky in defiance of international sanctions (S)

headline: Despite risk and a government ban, Filipinos line up for Iraq jobs
Corrections
abstract: The Armchair M.B.A. column last Sunday, about a return to corporate growth after years of cutbacks, misstated the surname of the Marakon Associates consultant in charge of the firm's organic growth practice. He is Mike Baxter, not Brewster.

headline: Spotlight
Drift of altered grass sharpens gene debate
IRAQ UPDATE
abstract: Update of events in Iraq on July 3; map (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Deals: Paramount Buys Film Rights To Area 51 Game
abstract: Paramount Pictures, unit of Viacom, agrees to buy film rights to Midway Games' Area 51 video game, in collaboration between film company controlled by Sumner M Redstone and electronic-game company in which he is majority owner; Christine Peters will produce movie; photo (M)

headline: Undeterred, Insurgents Keep Up Deadly Attacks Across Iraq
abstract: New swell of insurgent violence in Baghdad includes car bomb explosion and rocket attack on hotel used by foreigners; deadly attacks also hit in Mosul and Falluja, showing that insurgency is still robust and its anger still raging despite formal transfer of sovereignty to interim Iraqi government and formal beginning of Iraqi legal proceedings against Saddam Hussein; in Najaf, militiamen loyal to Moktada al-Sadr agree to trade 16 policemen they captured this week for two insurgents jailed by government; 9 other policemen remain in hands of militia; photo (M)

headline: Adelphia to Begin Accepting Bids for Company After Labor Day
abstract: Adelphia which has operated under bankruptcy protection for the last two years, hopes to make the results final by the end of the year.

headline: AGSTAR OFFERS $650 MILLION FOR FARM CREDIT SERVICES
abstract: AgStar Financial Services makes unsolicited offer to buy rural cooperative Farm Credit Services of America for $650 million in cash (S)

headline: Doubts on Informant Deleted in Senate Text
abstract: Among passages deleted from public version of Senate Intelligence Committee's report on Iraq is said to be detailed assessment that casts doubt on credibility of Iraqi defector whose claims about Iraq's mobile biological weapons laboratories were cited by Sec of State Colin L Powell in speech to UN in 2003 and have since been discredited; source, known to CIA as Red River, is reportedly still working for British intelligence; about one-fifth of 511-page report still has not been made public, reportedly including details of covert actions undertaken by American intelligence agencies to gather information about Iraq and to disrupt suspicious shipments to it, including aluminum tubes (M)

headline: Arby's Begins a Review; Doner Won't Take Part
abstract: Arby's, sandwich shop chain owned by the Triarc Companies, begins review for creative part of its national branding account (S)

headline: Former Executive Testifies, Offering Insider's Look at Enron's Deal Making
abstract: Former Enron executive Michael Kopper testifies against four former Merrill Lynch & Co executives and two former Enron executives charged with conspiring with former Enron chief financial officer Andrew S Fastow to rig bogus deal in Dec 1999 that made it appear Merrill bought interest in some Nigerian barges owned by Enron to let Enron report some $12 million in profit; offers glimpse through eyes of participant of deals Fastow orchestrated; says Fastow told colleagues of oral agreement to take Merrill out of investment within six months; alleged accord between Fastow and defendant Daniel Bayly, former head of investment banking at Merrill, is at heart of case; Kopper says Fastow arranged for LJM2, investment fund Fastow managed, to buy investment at profit for Merrill and said unnamed Enron executives would buy out LJM2's interest in barges if buyer could not be found by early 2001; photo (M)

headline: Gabelli Profit to Be Lower
abstract: By Bloomberg News.

headline: Armani stays 70 years young
abstract: MILAN  'Night and Day," crooned the music as Giorgio Armani ended the final collection of his 69th year by paying homage to his workers. They were lined up, all in white, behind a gauze backcloth as Armani, who turns 70 this month, bounded out to take his bow.

headline: Jordanian Firm Pulls Workers to Comply With Iraq Militants
abstract: Secretary of State Colin Powell urged American allies not to hand the hostage takers victory by giving into their demands.

headline: In Climate War, It's Sweater or Sweating
abstract: Lisa Belkin Life's Work column describes common problem in offices: disputes among co-workers about temperature; drawing (M)

headline: Dallas Publisher to Cut 3% of Its Workers
abstract: Belo Corp says it will pare its work force by 3 percent before year's end, eliminating 250 jobs, mostly at Dallas Morning News; weighs canceling up to $2.1 million in future bonuses for senior executives, including those ultimately responsible for circulation; releases results of its probe of practices that resulted in previously disclosed circulation overstatements at paper; chairman Robert W Decherd says problem probably began as result of 1999 policy change that effectively discouraged reporting unsold papers; Belo reports reimbursing overcharged advertisers (M)

headline: U.N. Report Shows Concern Over Rise of H.I.V. in Asia
abstract: UN reports that proportion of world's new HIV infections occurring in Asia has risen sharply in past two years; nearly 1.2 million of estimated 4.8 new infections in 2003 occurred in Asia; photo; graph; rate of new infection worldwide was highest ever (M)

headline: Claiming a Threat to Innovation, Group Seeks to Overturn 10 Patents
abstract: claiming a th

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: General Electric Reports Higher Income and Sales  Second-quarter profit at General Electric rose 3.4 percent, beating Wall Street expectations by a penny a share. Revenue climbed 11 percent, and nine of the conglomerate's 11 business units posted double-digit growth.      General Electric raised the low end of its 2004 profit forecast by 1 cent, to $1.55 to $1.60 a share. It had 2003 income of $1.49. [Page C2.]

headline: Frenchwoman Fabricated Tale of Attack, Police Report
abstract: French police say Marie Leblanc, who provoked national wellspring of outrage and sympathy when she reported being accosted at knifepoint in anti-Semitic attack on commuter train, has admitted making up story; she claimed she was attacked on suburban train north of Paris by six men who mistook her for Jew (M)

headline: IRAQ UPDATE
abstract: Update on Iraq; map

headline: Twin Bus Bombings in Israel Kill at Least 15 and Wound Dozens
abstract: The Palestinian militant group Hamas reportedly took responsibility for the near-simultaneous blasts.

headline: Residents of a Shattered City Begin to Pick Up Its Pieces
abstract: Najaf is badly damaged after 23 days of fighting between American forces and Moktada al-Sadr's militia; calm following Sadr's surrender is giving residents first chance to properly bury dead and assess damage; city is littered with unexploded shells; United States sources say hundreds of militia fighters were killed; al-Sadr's office says 110 were killed and 300 wounded; photos (M)

headline: Congress Puts Insurance Sales To Military Under Scrutiny
abstract: State and federal investigators and members of Congress are broadening their efforts to address problems in sale of life insurance and mutual funds to young soldiers and other service members on military installations nationwide; Rep Max Burns has drafted legislation aimed at preventing marketing practices that have exposed young recruits to high-pressure or misleading sales pitches for products that may not fit their financial needs; Rep Michael G Oxley says House subcommittee will hold hearing on issue on Sept 9; Government Accountability Office is expanding study of military insurance sales that it began last spring; insurance regulators in Georgia and Texas have started examination of insurance sales on military bases under their jurisdiction; photo (M)

headline: Eat Your Heart Out, Lance Armstrong
abstract: Citigroup Inc managing director Leigh Allen, in Frequent Flier column, discusses some of his air travel experiences; photo (M)

headline: Ngogo Journal; Garage the Harvester, Bring on the Rhinos and Zebras
abstract: South Africa has emerged from apartheid into acceptable, even desirable stop for wealthy tourists; to accommodate them, some of finest farmland is being turned into game preserves for foreigners who thirst for African wildlife experience and do not mind paying to get it; there are at least 140 private preserves in KwaZulu/Natal, covering thousand square miles of converted farmland; one problem is that turning farms into game preserves means moving farm laborors to make way for wild animals; this exacerbates poisonous disputes between white farmers and black tenants who have staked claims to land; photos; map (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Ryanair Shares Drop On Lawsuit
abstract: World Business Briefing: Britain: Ryanair Shares Drop

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Power Plant Panel
abstract: Indian government sets up panel to look into Dabhol power plant, $2.9 billion operation--idle for three years--that is capable of producing 2,184 megawatts of power; government is eager to restart project, which was built by Enron Corp; Dabhol is mired in disputes over debt and arbitration proceedings involving its shareholders, including General Electric and Bechtel Group, which own 86 percent of project after buying Enron's stake earlier this year (S)

headline: Russia to Sell Its Holding In Lukoil At Auction
abstract: Russian government will hold auction Sept 29 to sell its 7.59 percent stake in Lukoil at starting price of $1.93 billion; Western companies will be allowed to take part, and ConocoPhillips is widely considered front-runner in bidding (M)

headline: Claritin Is Awarded to Euro RSCG
abstract: Claritin Is Awarded.

headline: Three Seats Sold on the Big Board
abstract: By Bloomberg News.

headline: Zarqawi's Journey: From Dropout to Prisoner to an Insurgent Leader in Iraq
abstract: Article profiles Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, Jordanian who has emerged as insurgent leader and biggest terrorist threat in Iraq, accused of orchestrating guerilla attacks, suicide bombings, kidappings and beheadings; his jihadist history in Jordan, where he has been sentenced to death in absentia, detailed; chronology; photos (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Economic Growth Slows As Consumers Cut Back  The pace of economic growth slowed abruptly in the second quarter as consumers, forced to pay higher energy bills, curbed their spending, the government reported.    The Commerce Department estimated that the output of the nation's gross domestic product -- the broadest measure of economic activity -- expanded at an annual rate of 3 percent in the quarter, sharply below the 4.5 percent growth in the first quarter and lower than Wall Street expectations. [Page A1.]

headline: People
abstract: John Middlebrook is named vice president for global sales, service and marketing at General Motors...Mark D'Arcy is named chief creative officer at Time Warner Global Marketing Group (S)
